name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the oral issue at the Commission on hearing on daylight saving time changes in Europe by Pavel Svoboda and Michael Cramer, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Transport and Tourism (O-000111/2015 - B8-0768/2015) (2015/2722 (RSP)).

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, the conclusions of the public hearing on the change between summer and winter time held in March this year were clear. In the field of energy today, there is no reason to save on light, that is why. The same applies to transport. But the health consequences are numerous, according to recent research by 9 European universities. Around 20% of Europeans have a change in time, while the other 80% cannot understand that it can cause problems for someone. Health problems go from fatigue, drowsiness and disorientation, to indigestion, migraines and depression, to triggering genetically conditioned diseases such as obesity and diabetes, including heart attacks. For those affected by autism, this change is causing major problems. The direct and indirect cost of health consequences in the EU has been estimated at a whopping EUR 131 billion by this research. This may mean that EU citizens spend almost as much – around €140 billion a year – on the EU as they do on remediation of health damage caused by this single directive. The Commission's response to the public hearing was a press statement saying that the Member States were not complaining and that this Commission would not deal with such a small matter. Thus, the Commission considers the health problems of one fifth of Europeans to be a small thing. If the research of nine universities is right, the Commission also considers the damage to health to be a small matter in the amount of the Union budget. I find such a statement scandalous. Indeed, Member States may not complain, because they do not suffer from depression or diabetes. But people complain. The citizens of the European Union complain to us, to their representatives in the European Parliament. This must be enough for the Commission to begin to deal with the matter in all seriousness. I am therefore pleased to be able to ask the Commission an oral question today and call on it to show that the research of nine universities is wrong, that there are rational reasons for maintaining a change in time, reasons that outweigh the harm to the health of a fifth of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to thank the JURI Committee and Chairman Pavel Svoboda for this initiative, which is shared jointly by both committees – the TRAN Committee and the JURI Committee. This, of course, also has an impact on road safety, on the transport sector, on timetables, on the working hours of employees and so on. That is why we held a joint hearing between the two committees on this subject in March this year. The expert opinions were clear: the arguments for the time change are being questioned by science and the negative effects have been clearly demonstrated there. So there is no scientific reason for daylight saving time. That is why I also share the disappointment of my colleague Pavel Svoboda at the Commission's press release, but also at the Commission's refusal to take this issue seriously. The original argument was energy saving. You can imagine that, as a Green, I am naturally in favour of energy saving, which is also the Commission's aim. But what comes out now? Many studies see no effect, and in Indiana – as has already been mentioned – it has been found that there is even a negative effect. Instead of being positive that we save energy, we are wasting energy. And that is why we need to change that. We want to examine impartially whether the current system still makes sense. We have certain problems, particularly in the transport sector. People are tired after the changeover because they sleep an hour less. This is a major threat to safety. The timetables need special rules, trains must be open for one hour at night so that the timetables that are written down are complied with; this is crazy, but reality. The working hours of employees must be adjusted and many processes in transport and logistics are interrupted. In the United States, the cost has now been calculated: EUR 1.7 billion per year costs us, and the effect is zero! Do we have so much money? I can put a thousand arguments to you about where we can make better use of the money, in the interests of the citizens. The initiatives exist in almost every Member State. I have received a great many letters, as have our fellow Members. Hence the questions to the Commission: why is the Commission not taking a serious look at the scientific results, including from the United States? When and how will it re-examine the effects of the time change? Or is it evidence of reducing energy consumption? What are the Commission's estimates of costs and benefits? What are the impact swaying advances in energy efficiency? And does that press release reflect the Commission's view? Is this the way in which it intends to deal with the concerns of citizens and Members of Parliament? I would therefore like to thank the JURI Committee and Pavel Svoboda once again. And to the Commission: look at the facts impartially! We look forward to hearing from you. (Applause)

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission is aware that at regular intervals citizens ask for the abolition of summer—time. Citizens mainly point to health problems, but also question if the reasons that led Member States to introduce summer—time have proven valid. Be assured that the Commission is taking the concerns of citizens seriously. The Commission has examined different studies on the subject matter, but these studies present mixed results and no conclusive argument was to be gained from them regarding potential impacts on health, energy savings or other impacts, for instance on road safety or productivity levels.  The Commission does not have estimates of the economic benefits and costs of changing clocks or adjusting schedules. Neither does it have estimates of the impact of energy efficiency of electric lamps and appliances under the current summer—time arrangements in Member States. The Commission believes that the reason that motivated the adoption of the Directive on summer—time arrangements in 2001, which was to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market through harmonisation of timetables, is still valid. It therefore does not see a reason for revising this directive at this stage.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I appreciate you very much, but the Commission's response is actually a naughty one, really a naughty one. There are problems with people – not everyone – and if they want to take people's concerns seriously, then it is not enough to say that it has always been nice. For more than ten years, the Commission has not given a serious and honest answer. Studies have been presented, and some of the answers are truly cabaret-ready. It is outrageous how these health problems are dealt with. On every other issue, on any other health threat, this Parliament is stirring up and making huge uprisings. Only on the subject not. And, by the way, the central question, Commissioner, I really would like to pass it on to the entire Commission. The central question is not whether there are enough reasons to take it back, but whether there is a single reason to annoy people twice a year. You have to explain why we are switching twice a year. We do not have to justify anything! I have never understood why we need to justify restoring normality. The normal state was, it is not changed twice a year – with effort, with trouble. I don't care how much and how little. There is no reason to change. Give me a reason, a proof, why we change twice a year, then I am on your side. Otherwise, I think it is possible to withdraw this directive from circulation. This Commission is taking on deregulation. We want fewer rules. So what's the point? What is the point of changing things twice a year if it makes no sense? If there was any purpose, they would have an argument. By now, the number is clear: there is no argument for switching. But there are problems. And in this respect, Simsalabim, we are simply restoring the normal state. The single market argument is the most stupid of all, because none of us wants anything else to happen in every country. We are all saying: change the internal market for all, and of course. Of course, uniform rules throughout Europe. But, ladies and gentlemen, I would ask you to take this issue seriously at long last. When I started with the question, everyone just looked and said, someone spins, someone dreams. There are tens of thousands who sign, tens of thousands of people complain. Please take this seriously! (Applause)

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As you can see, Commissioner, this is a very passionate discussion, even though we are not yet so many in this Chamber. But your response was really a very technical one and does not address people's concerns. This is not just a single market issue, it is about the issue of time touching the lives of each individual individually. And you can go out: each individual has a personal opinion on it because it interferes with life. In this context, I would also like to make an impassioned plea for the abolition of daylight saving time and winter time and all this time change, because I am speaking for the people who are particularly difficult and who do not have such a great lobby behind them, namely on the one hand for commuters and, on the other, for pupils. A great many people are confronted with the fact that school hours are not changed, for example, and then struggle in the morning to get up, are of course also forced to heat up and that we are accordingly naturally in the darkness. In other words, this is also a plea for people not to be forced to get up so terribly early in the dark.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the regulation of summer and winter time by means of a directive has come to an end. It would make sense to end up with a change in the directive, which abandons the two-time system. The clock would only be moved over time zones. Studies have revealed that people's sleep deteriorates in spring and autumn when the clocks are moved. Senior children and children in particular find it difficult to get their internal clocks right. Studies have also shown that the change of time also affects people's mood and causes severe depressive symptoms. The treatment of depression today causes a huge expense across Europe. Does the Commission really want to increase this burden on the European Member States as well? Not only humans, but also the effects on the health of farmed animals are significant. Although Russia is not on a very high course in this House, it must be said to their credit that they have been able to deregulate daylight saving time in the past, based on the welfare of citizens and animals. If Russia can do this too, will Europe be a backward state? Now it is our turn to stop playing with human and animal health. My own position is that winter time could even remain permanent and my country could also move to the central European time zone. (Applause)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, I find it absolutely incredible that the Commission is responding to us in its press release that this Commission is only engaged in big questions and therefore daylight saving time regulation is nothing for this Commission. I find it absolutely incredible that this is an arrogant attitude towards the concerns of the citizens that Parliament represents here! Every time I write about this topic on Facebook, I get a thousand likes just like that. This means that the public really thinks this is quite a big deal. I remember this very well because my own child was born on the night that my country, Finland, first moved to summer time in the spring of 1981. So it will not be forgotten. Moving clocks causes serious problems for human health. It confuses the biological clock of both humans and animals, and this in turn causes unnecessary harm, costs and risks in schools, kindergartens, workplaces and transport. The European Union has regulated the transition to daylight saving time diligently. Indeed, the current 2001 directive is already the ninth of its kind. Why should we not think that it is time to adopt the last tenth directive on this subject, which would definitively transfer the turn of the clocks' visas to history. This would benefit not only transport and communications, but also people's internal clocks. Parliament's consultation revealed that this is strongly supported by experts in the human internal clock. As my fellow Member said, if, for the sake of human and animal welfare, Russia has abandoned the movement of clocks, then we can do it too. (Applause)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. We are pleased that time has not stood still with the Commission and that this issue is now finally being discussed. The PVV raised this issue here five years ago. Is the Commission familiar with the British research showing that daylight saving time is much better for health than winter time, and does it share this conclusion? The PVV says stop winter time. It is not only better for health, but also better for tourism, for the transport sector and for saving energy. That should appeal to the Commission. In an age of energy-saving lamps, lighting doesn't cost that much anymore, while energy-consuming air conditioners are on much longer in the summer. We can also think about safety. For example, the disruption of sleep rhythm could lead to many more accidents. Mr President, can the Commission (but rather the Council) find out for us whether there is enough support in Europe to abolish winter time and, if so, is it prepared to do so?

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done As you can see, you have an indignation here, which goes beyond all the groups in this House, at the Commission's non-action and also at the Council's position. We call for an immediate review of the time change, the two-time change every year. We need a scientific, serious, well-founded review. What you are telling us is not exactly those qualities of scientific reputable reviews. The Commission is in default here! We have no advantages in the field of energy, we have high costs, and we have a myriad of expert opinions and scientific studies, including from nine European universities, from chronobiologists, doctors and experts from every profession, which show that there are enormous costs and risks to be feared here. And we do not recognise that these risks are not being reviewed. Of course, europe's causa prima also deals with other issues – we know this: migration, jobs. But people's health and money are also part of the causa. We have an increase in road accidents. An Austrian insurance company has collected up to 48% more road accidents in the past week; this must not be wiped away. I support European Commission President Juncker's announcement that EU rules will be reviewed every few years for their meaningful implementation. That has not happened here. It is high time to finally take action here! Please assume your responsibility - thank you!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Europeans have been changing hours twice a year for forty years. It is time to return to a single time system, as Russia did in 2011. The experts interviewed by the European Parliament on 24 March 2015 showed that the time change has many drawbacks: sleep disturbances, especially in children, heart attacks or disturbance of livestock, especially dairy cows. Moreover, the benefits that were hoped for were not verified: no savings, no reduction in the number of traffic accidents.  In these circumstances, the European Union must renounce the time change. To take into account the expectations expressed by 76% of the French, I ask that daylight saving time rather than daylight saving time be maintained rather than daylight saving time. I ask the Commission to listen to the citizens and stop its blocking, which no one understands.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I would particularly like to thank my colleague Svoboda for the perseverance with which he deals with the issue of daylight saving time. We inherited this administrative measure from the beginning of the last century. It is time we thought about whether the arguments that were made 100 years ago or in 2001 will continue today. I consider it doubly inappropriate for the Commission to ironise Parliament's initiative to launch a substantive debate on summer time. Firstly, because the officials are not here to jokingly gloss over members' proposals in official statements, but also because it is the Commission's direct duty to include facts, analyses and concrete proposals in the public debate. I therefore fully support the questions put by my colleagues and ask the Commission to pay due attention to this issue.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Madam President, my notes were in English, but since I have a lot of respect for you, let me speak in French. On this subject, dear friends, colleagues, know that when my children go to school in the morning, because of the time change, they leave when it is no longer dark, but already day. And I'd rather have my kids go to school by day than at night.  At the same time, I think we need to analyze these influences in depth because they are largely positive influences. Believe me, in view of the current situation in Europe, the issue of migration, the Greek debt crisis, the economic situation, unemployment, social conditions, and so on, I consider that this is not the time to address this subject again. And at the same time, I must tell you that I do not agree with the Commission's arrogance in this regard.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, Commissioner, the massive involvement of colleagues and the passion with which the debate is taking place demonstrate that there is indeed a serious issue, and I think that the way in which you have responded does not show the appropriate seriousness towards this issue. Daylight saving time has been introduced for many years and it has been thought that this is a positive thing. However, you can see that the studies show the exact opposite, because there has also been a public hearing on this matter by the European Parliament. It has now been proven that daylight saving time has a negative impact on health, transport and European industry, and does not help to reduce energy costs. So you have to look at this serious issue, you have to deal with it. When citizens are already sending such messages alarmingly, the Commission must do a serious study and give us a serious answer to this issue.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – I would like to thank my colleagues whose efforts are being discussed in Parliament. I would like to draw the Commission's attention to another very important sector for which time-changing is evident. I do not think that at least one farmer has managed to explain to cows why they should be milked one hour earlier or later. The effect of turning time on people working in the agricultural sector is very negative, because they depend on two regimes: one is the biological time of the animals, which we cannot change, the second is the public time to which farmers have to apply, transporting children to school, going to markets or managing other farm matters. I therefore call on the Commission to take the initiative to amend this Directive and to repeal this ...

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, if the European Commission were to be voted on again today, you would probably get a question from me about changing winter and daylight saving time. And if you answered as you did today, I would very much consider voting for this Commission. I just want people to fight for citizens' rights as commissioner. If half a billion citizens of the European Union here are saying unequivocally that they want to abolish a re-experience that is of no use, Then I expect you to take this seriously. Commissioner, please, let us stop ironising and let us really deal with this matter, which has a real impact on the health of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, what a debate! Across all faction boundaries. When there is talk on the left, the clapping on the right is made, and when the right is spoken, the clapping on the left is made. This has never happened before! Everyone agrees. It is a completely non-ideological issue: the citizens do not want the changeover from winter to summer time and vice versa. The Commission stands up and says: we have no arguments. You will have the floor again. Stand up and explain why the changeover needs to be. Do not tell us and the citizens that we need to prove anything! Prove and prove why the changeover has to be. But make really good arguments. What you have done so far has actually been nothing more than a naughty thing. (Applause)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank all my colleagues for sticking to a matter-of-fact cross-party debate, and I would like the Commissioner not to take this as a personal attack on her, but you represent the European Commission here today, Commissioner, and that is why our questions are directly up to you. You have heard clearly here that there are many citizens and many reasons why we are asking this question, whether it is necessary to carry out this mobilisation of citizens twice a year and to move the clock forward and then backward by an hour. I think that it is at this very moment that we could demonstrate that the Institutions of the European Union are actionable and we can deal with this technical problem quickly, because citizens are being tormented by many other, more important things that we need to address. So let's prove that you submit a study and change the directive.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, from my own observations I have become more and more against the change of time in recent years, because I see that it brings in the winter overnight and stops the onset of spring by at least a month. But coming in here this morning, I am delighted to hear cases being put forward by my colleagues and the impact it actually has on citizens and on agriculture, costs and energy. Mr Becker referred to 48% more accidents and disturbed sleep patterns for children. Surely the case is clear, and all it takes is for a directive from the Commission. It would cost nothing, and I am quite sure citizens would be delighted. Once again we would be able to show citizens that we can act in their interest. If Russia did it, why can we not do it? Or are we afraid to say maybe that Russia was right and we were too slow to follow them? In this instance, they were right and we should introduce to change as soon as possible because we do not want winter coming in overnight anymore and we want spring to come in its natural order.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members very much indeed for this very lively debate. It sends a very strong message – which was commented on before – that representatives of all parties are here discussing this issue. As stated in my introduction, the Commission is aware of the different arguments for and against. I have spoken personally with many Member States, asking them for their opinion, and I have to say that opinion is divided. It is not as coherent as Members are being here. There are indeed many studies examining potential impacts on health, but there is still no really strong argument to be gained from them at this time. I agree that the challenge is greater than we are sometimes willing to admit.  I hear what Members are saying – honestly – but let me also stress that my strong motivation is to keep the Single Market alive and to have a unanimous decision on this issue at European level.  So, at this stage, the Commission is not considering changes to the relevant directive but, should new evidence emerge and a more systemic approach be put forward, we would be willing to reconsider that position.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. – There is sufficient scientific evidence that current daylight saving time has more negative than positive effects. This was evident at an EP hearing in March this year. Any positive effect of the periodic switch from summer to winter time and vice versa to transport, tourism, energy consumption, agriculture, health and European industry has not been proven. Contrary. It is also highly uncertain whether the introduction of daylight saving time in Europe has reduced energy consumption. Nevertheless, the Commission is adamant that the scheme is favourable. In doing so, it hides behind the option of a large number of Member States, which do not seem to want to change the rules, it is unacceptable for the Commission to continue to deliberately ignore numerous research results from the EU and the rest of the world, in particular the US, which highlights the negative effects of daylight saving time. It is good that we are in the debate today in this plenary session. There is no point in maintaining measures that many citizens consider to be very annoying. The Commission continues to hold off the boat. Further political action is therefore needed.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Jacqueline Foster's report, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems (RPAS), better known as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), in the field of civil aviation (2014/2243(INI)) (A8-0261/2015).

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, small radio-controlled model aircraft have been flown by enthusiasts for many decades. The first recorded use of them in the UK was in 1935 when the British Royal Navy used the DH82 Queen Bee for target practice. During the past 15 years we have seen rapid growth in the use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS), more commonly known as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) or drones. Technology developed primarily for military purposes is now being applied for commercial use, pushing technological and legislative boundaries. In recognition of the rapid development of this market, RPAS are rightly being incorporated into existing aviation programmes such as Sesar and Horizon 2020. In addition, the potential for growth in this industry, from the manufacturer to the end user, is immense for large and small businesses alike. Therefore, it is imperative that we maintain world-class standards for manufacturing. Europe leads the world in drone development, with two and a half thousand drone operators. In the UK alone we have more than 600 RPAS operations providing services from photography to land surveillance. RPASs have become an increasingly popular alternative to manned aircraft for aerial surveillance activities, among other things. They are used to monitor railway lines, power plants and farmers’ crops, as well as at rock concerts and in football stadiums. They are being used increasingly in humanitarian circumstances, in dealing with forest fires and earthquakes, for example, and in search and rescue operations. At the same time, ‘baby drones’ designed for leisure and hobby use have become increasingly popular. All the stakeholders have recognised the potential of this market and we are all keen to stress that any policy framework must enable growth in it in order to compete globally. My role as rapporteur has been to find the right direction and framework to take this industry to the next stage, and I believe that this report, as it now stands, has answered the key questions. Earlier this year I brought together representatives from industry, Member States, civil aviation authorities, air traffic services, the European Safety Agency and the Commission. It was widely recognised by participants that any framework must be proportionate and risk-based to enable the sector to grow while, at the same time, avoiding any unnecessary burdens. In addition, any legislation must reflect global cooperation in order to stimulate R&D. I also had constructive meetings in Washington in March with representatives from the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and the US Transport Department. This all culminated in a high-level meeting under the Latvian Presidency in Riga, which produced the Riga Declaration. That key message stated that the European aviation community would commit itself to allowing businesses to provide RPAS services everywhere in Europe from 2016. To do this, I believe that we need to establish European and global rules which will address the following areas: air worthiness, certification, commercial and recreational use, drone identity, appropriate pilot training, liability and insurance, operations, protection and privacy, geo-fencing and no-fly zones. The Joint Authorities for Rulemaking on Unmanned Systems (JARUS) is a committee comprising non-EU and EU Member States and national aviation authorities. It sits under the umbrella of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO). Its purpose is to develop technical safety and operational requirements for the certification and safe integration of large and small RPAS into airspace and at aerodromes. The Chair of JARUS is a representative from European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA). In my view, JARUS is ideally placed to draft global safety regulations for the use of these systems quickly and effectively. We need to ensure that any future EU rules will be compatible with international arrangements through a process of mutual recognition. To conclude, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs on the Committee on Transport and Tourism for their very constructive input and cooperation, as well as our colleagues on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and in particular Patrick Cassidy from the ECR Group, who has been an invaluable help to me. I believe that we have acknowledged the opportunities that this nascent market can create for both investment and job creation, whilst at the same time safeguarding public interest. I would therefore ask Parliament for its support in order to send a strong political message that we are ready for this new exciting step forward for the aviation sector. (Applause)

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President and  distinguished Members of Parliament, drones are a technology which has already changed the way we do things and which creates opportunities for new services and new applications.  Unmanned aircraft are able today to perform missions that are not conceivable or economically not feasible with manned aircraft, ranging from safety inspections – as already pointed out – and monitoring activities to precision farming operations or assessment of natural disasters. The range of drone applications for civilian use is developing fast, underlining the significant economic potential of this sector to contribute to growth and jobs in Europe.  Everybody acknowledges the enormous potential of drone technologies, yet citizens are also raising concerns about drone operations: hence the challenge for us to come up with rules that strike the right balance between promoting this promising technology and adequately protecting our citizens.  It is our conviction that only common European rules would provide a solid basis for promoting investment in, and facilitating the development of, drone technologies while duly protecting all our citizens. That is why the Commission greatly welcomes the support for this approach in the Foster report. I would really like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Foster, for her great work and her efforts in bringing together the views of different political groups in her very comprehensive report. The Commission agrees with the report’s call for a clear, harmonised and proportionate EU regulatory framework, removing the current 150 kilogramme threshold separating EU and national competence. We need to go for common rules for all drones, regardless of weight. But please understand me, this does not mean that every drone operation requires heavy-handed regulation. The Commission agrees with the report that we need to evolve towards an operation-centric approach to safety rules that are proportionate to the risk associated with a particular operation. These ideas are already being developed by the European Aviation Safety Agency and the Joint Authorities for Rulemaking on Unmanned Systems (JARUS), where experts from the European Member States play an active role together with experts from the US, China, Japan, Brazil, Canada, and many more. The Commission also supports the idea that safety rules could be supplemented by internal market or international commerce rules, using leaflets, for example, to make each drone user aware of possible risks.  The Commission is aware of the need to let drones operate further away from the ground station, in other words further than the pilot can see. If drones are allowed to operate over a longer distance in one mission, the cost of the operation will decrease drastically, and wider-range operations will encourage innovative businesses. And yes, we should find sufficient R&D funding to finance the missing technologies. While we support the development of drones, public acceptance of drone operations is key, and we therefore agree that adequate enforcement of safety and other existing legislation, for instance on privacy or data protection, is crucial. However, there are a number of other aspects related to drones, such as security, environmental protection and liability, and these also need to be addressed.  Let me conclude: the Commission greatly appreciates this report on drones, which will significantly contribute to steering safety rules in the desired direction and to the Commissionʼs ongoing work to lay down an enabling framework for drones. The topic has been thoroughly addressed in the aviation package, and I hope that we will be able to proceed swiftly in the near future.

name: Soraya POST
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Drones become more and more important in our society both commercially and in performing important public services. A key use for drones is monitoring people, often without their knowledge.  Nowadays, anyone can buy a drone with a camera or other equipment. EU legislation for the protection of privacy and personal data must be respected in a civilian drone market. This is non-negotiable and cannot be set against commercial interests.  The Commission must carefully examine the risks posed by a market for civilian drones and inform the public about this. The Commission must also come up with a proposal for a regulatory framework with which everyone can be safe. We also need to look at how intelligence agencies use drones and how we can ensure that our fundamental rights are not violated.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, I would like to thank, of course, Mrs Foster for the report that has been made and presented, as well as the other political groups for the good work they have done.  At present, there is no global, Nor European or major international competition legislation, whether the United States or China. Several Member States are starting to have legislation and we Europeans are the world leaders in drones, with more than half of the world's companies in this sector. Let me remind you that this market will represent at least 80 billion turnover and 100,000 jobs in 2025. So if we want to remain leaders, we have the opportunity to write the flight rules that will then be imposed at the global level. These rules will dictate the technological standards applicable to drones and the challenge is no more or less to impose on the world our vision: we can take as an example the GSM standard for mobile phones.  It is not all to be the first to have rules, but they must be good, and European rules must give companies maximum freedom of innovation while guaranteeing absolute protection of the population.  To date, two million drones have been sold and no deaths are reported. It is clear that this report provides very clear answers, in particular to the Commission: data protection is essential, privacy must be protected. But we have to let the drone develop; indeed, blocking drones would be as if telephoto lenses were banned on cameras. So today we have a clear innovation, a simple proposal, so we are anticipating and we will not disappoint with this report.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. This pleases us, but it also shows that we are dealing with the development of technology and that drones will be a permanent and evolving phenomenon. The problem, however, is that advances in technology are not accompanied by adequate legal solutions. The Member States of the European Union regulate the use of drones in very different ways. According to my S&D Group, this is precisely the area in which the institutions of the European Union must actively participate – because it is objectively appropriate for EU regulation. After all, the civilian use of unpiloted aircraft does not restrict the borders of any country. There are two fundamental problems to solve here. The first problem is that pilots have to move safely in air traffic, and the long problem – and it has already been mentioned here today – is to ensure the protection of the privacy sphere. I think that mrs Foster's report very aptly draws attention to these two aspects – in my opinion, it is a very valuable and interesting document. As these two areas, namely security issues, but also important privacy issues, are clearly covered here, my group will continue to be very active in the work on this document.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: on the ecr group. – Madam President, Commissioner, drones are another phenomenon where technology has overtaken legislation, and we see the need for a coordinated approach at European level. In areas of critical infrastructure, drone traffic should no doubt be limited. The issue of privacy across the spectrum is also topical. I am glad that, as rapporteur, Mrs Foster has prepared a balanced contribution from the European Parliament to the debate on how to approach drones. It is clear to me that this report does not want to prejudge the details of what future European rules will look like. I think this is a very characteristic approach and I very much appreciate Mrs Foster's approach to this matter. On the other hand, I would not want there to be unnecessary administrative restrictions on drones used for individual entertainment or for the actual development of applications for the future.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Foster, for her work. In this context, I would say, "well done" becomes "well drone". The safe integration of drones into European airspace must be ensured. That is why European regulation is desperately needed. The faster, the better. Recent accidents involving drones illustrate this all too well. A very important concern is liability. Who should the damage be ified when a drone falls from the sky? In order to ensure liability, we must ensure that there is a clear link with the owner or driver of the drone and that it can be traced at any time when such a drone causes damage. Mandatory registration and the installation of a mandatory identification chip could be a solution. That is also the direction I have indicated in an amendment of mine that has been incorporated into the report. It is therefore clear that European regulation is needed and we really need to look at that. Fortunately, an aviation package with a proposal will be presented at the beginning of December. I think it is important for the Council, under the Dutch Presidency, to take a step in the right direction, together with the European Parliament, so that the drone industry can actually take off.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Madam President, Respected Commissioner Bulc, colleagues and colleagues, I first thank Rapporteur Foster for her excellent cooperation in drafting this report.  The European Union's task is to develop a legislative framework as soon as possible that will apply exclusively to the civilian use of drones. The legislative framework must ensure the investment and development of a competitive European drone sector for civilian use and clearly distinguish between the professional use of remotely piloted drones and their recreational use.  The potential for economic growth in this sector is enormous. It encourages the development of innovative technologies that have great potential for job creation, in particular green jobs, both in large companies and in thousands of SMEs.  Quality education is essential in this sector and I stress the need to organise and promote qualification and training centres for pilots and drone operators. The European Legislative Framework must enable the innovation and development of the sector under the best possible conditions, with effective protection of property and persons, as well as personal data and citizens' privacy. In the end, we must not forget the limited resources at our disposal and the protection of the environment. This new sector is an ideal opportunity to start applying the principles of the circular economy right from the beginning, and for drone propulsion we use propellant that will not impair air quality and increase greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Drones are a growing business with a lot of potential. In any case, it is my opinion that clear rules are needed for this market in order to enable further investment in technology. People are often sceptical about novelties. Just think of the childhood of aviation – most of them dismissed the men who developed airplanes, as crazy people. Today, I believe that very few of us could imagine a world without the ability of aviation to move rapidly between different continents. A trip to the United States in the past, at least from my home country, Sweden, was in a couple of weeks. The technology is thus evolving and progressing all the time. Many times, as I said, the problem is that we find it difficult to absorb it before we see the practical possibilities of it. The industry can therefore be very large in this market. It is large and can be even bigger, but it also assumes that there are very clear rules of the game in the market, because there is no company that dares to invest a lot of money in a novelty without knowing the rules of the game.  Integrity, as I said, is a very sensitive issue. Who wants a drone over your head when you're sitting in the garden drinking coffee? So that is an aspect that legislators need to look at in order to protect privacy. However, I see great social opportunities in technology.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I welcome your text, Mrs Foster. I find it very positive that it is not intended to regulate military drones. Because of their strategic stake, it was necessary to be very clear on this point.  I share your concern to give small and medium-sized businesses a flexible enough framework to remain competitive in the face of foreign competition, particularly from the United States.  I support the idea of sparking a debate among stakeholders to define balanced regulation that protects privacy and ensures the safety of individuals while promoting the development of new technologies.  Furthermore, as I said in the committee, it is essential that Member States and the relevant national authorities retain significant leeway to authorise or ban the use of drones over sensitive areas. From this point of view, I fully agree with paragraph 44 of the report, which calls for greater exchanges of views between Member States, national regulatory authorities, the European Union, the civil aviation sector and SMEs. I will therefore vote in favour of your text.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Twenty-five years ago, the Internet was a science fiction. It is now indispensable for the development of the economy and, at the same time, has many other effects in society, including negatives. Hence the need to be regulated.  RPAS is a similar example. Twenty-five years ago, a drone was a rare and expensive weapon. A few years ago, there were timid attempts in civilian clothes. Since then, there has been a technological boom and today drones are a trivial object. The areas in which we find them are very diverse, they contribute to the development of the economy, but at the same time they also cause problems, some quite serious, if we think about privacy or flight security. They are needed, but we also need to protect ourselves from them.  This phenomenon cannot be stopped and will very soon become a mass phenomenon. It is obvious that regulation is necessary. The report discussed today, I think it is very good and deals with all aspects of this phenomenon, suggests good bases for future regulations. The Commission must address these regulations in a particular way because of the special characteristics of this object; we're talking about a flying machine. So the rules must deal with the construction, certification of the apparatus and personnel, security aspects, aspects related to the economic areas where they are used, separation: civilian, military, economic or pleasure, a complex regulation that should not be elaborated superficially, but nor should it be very late.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – The use of unmanned aerial systems is undoubtedly an important step towards the aeronautical market of the future. In recent years, this technology has developed greatly for military purposes, but it has tremendous potential to be used for civilian purposes, i.e. in everyday life.  Sectors such as transport and agriculture, as well as human rescue actions, can benefit from these versatile aircraft, limiting the risk of human operation and increasing efficiency through access to areas where it is difficult to reach. This emerging market also brings with it the need for regulation, in order to ensure security, security and respect for privacy, as well as the protection of the data of European citizens.  It is clear that we need a European-wide strategy for remote unmanned air systems that is in line with THE ICAO standards. While I am convinced that the hardware and software performance of the machines will evolve in the near future, we need to agree to some minimum standards in terms of the conditions for certification of pilots and identification and operation of the aircraft. Thank.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Today I will vote in favour of my colleague Jacky Foster's report. It has struck a good balance to give a burgeoning industry a boost on the one hand and, on the other hand, to ensure the safety of citizens. All too often, this Parliament falls into the trap of over-regulation. Privacy fetishists see danger everywhere and threaten to nip the industry's growth in the bud with a plethora of rules. But the drone industry just needs realistic and stimulating measures. With this report, Mr Foster has struck a good balance between respect for privacy, the safety of the devices and for the environment, and finally the growth opportunities for a promising industry. It is now up to the European Commission to maintain this line in legislative work.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, while they have long been confined to the military field, drones are now everywhere, from agriculture to cinema to logistics and security.  I underline the quality of Mrs Foster's report, which has been able to distinguish both the potential and the specific nature of these drones and to contain a great deal of problems they pose in terms of their integration into civil society.  In the face of such a development, we say yes, of course, to harmonised EU-wide regulation. Any other approach would prevent the emergence of a European market, and this would probably be fewer opportunities for a booming industry. On the other hand, we must remain extremely vigilant on a number of aspects, which have been highlighted in the report: privacy, risk-based approach, distinction between recreational and professional use.  We must also promote European dominance in this area, by equipping the European Aviation Safety Agency with the means to defend our industry vis-à-vis the rest of the world. In short, it is a reasonable and ambitious approach that we need, and that is what Mrs Foster's report offers us.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Madam President, I am speaking against this report. In paragraph 21 it calls for clear harmonised and proportionate European and global regulatory framework, which looks like to me that the rapporteur is trying to push more powers to the EU. There is a call for the Commission to remove the 150 kilogramme limit in paragraph 22 and replace it with the EU regulatory framework that would allow national competent authorities to oversee the activities. What right does the EU have to decide what a national competent authority actually is? Then in paragraph 48 there is a call for a regular reporting mechanism at EU level that would address our past incidents. (The President instructed the speaker to slow down) I would like to know the definition of ‘incident’ as it is a very broad term. I am in agreement with the UK Government that any heavy-handed regulation could only stifle potential growth in this new emerging area of technology. The general public who fly model aircraft are going to be penalised by the lack of clarity demonstrated this report. I urge all Members to vote against this.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, I too would like to commend the work of Mrs Foster, rapporteur, and the very good collective work with the shadow rapporteurs.  By adopting this report, the European Parliament is taking the lead in laying the groundwork for a future European regulatory framework for drones. This is a major challenge for the future of our civil aviation and the competitiveness of our companies in a high-potential market. The European Union could no longer ignore this reality, I hope that the Commission will hear the recommendations of MEPs. From this perspective, security issues are paramount and require special attention, especially in terms of the use, control and monitoring of drones and users or the prohibition of flying over certain sensitive areas. The report also highlights data protection issues, which will have to be taken into account by the Commission.  In the future European framework, it will also be necessary to take into account the differences between recreational and commercial use of drones, which are by nature different. With today's vote, we are sending a message of support to the aviation sector for the development of a European drone market, as well as a political message to the Commission to propose an ambitious framework.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, the widespread use of drones in the field of civil aviation has led to the emergence of new enterprises, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises. This is indeed a sector where the Union can and must be a leader, but for this, as we discussed here, we need to find a proportionate and clear regulation. We must not block the potential of this emerging sector. However, we must respect the privacy, data protection and security of citizens. We are obviously talking about complexes where we need to legislate and for what? So that these technology companies, in this area, can bet on innovation, creation and, above all, the provision of services. In view of the legal vacuum that exists in some Member States, there are barriers to overcome in terms of contracting this type of service. There is an urgent need to create a European legal framework, without over-legislating and without creating unnecessary burdens on small and medium-sized enterprises. I will vote in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, clearly it is about time to have a harmonised and proportionate EU regulatory framework on the use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) and to set out clear guidelines to the Commission for outlining the upcoming aviation package expected by the end of 2015. In order to reach this objective we must follow a risk-based approach, in line with the Riga Declaration, ensuring safety. At the same time, we must guarantee adequate protection of citizens, which means respecting the fundamental rights of privacy and data protection. We have to ensure that investments and innovation in the industry are stimulated, and we must make efforts to create sustainable and innovative jobs. I support the compromises included in the report, such as the Commission’s removal of the 150kg threshold, and the provision on ‘detect and avoid technology’ for RPAS.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, drones in the age of technology will be very useful in relation to research and rescue, environmental protection, agricultural and industrial production, journalism, commercial and leisure activities. However, the European Commission should adopt immediate measures so that remote-controlled aircraft are used exclusively for the purpose of serving the people themselves.  At the same time, the European Commission should adopt measures, as drones are by definition a form of dual-use technology and thus require the imposition of restrictive and strict rules in order to protect privacy and personal data. At the same time, these systems can, whether intentionally or not, be used to harm people and infrastructure. I therefore draw the Commission's attention to remote-controlled aircraft and call for concrete legislative intervention.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate Mrs Foster on a work we need to speed up the regulation that drone manufacturers and operators need at European level. We have the opportunity to place the industry's civilian industry in a global leadership position. Achieving this depends on manufacturers, operators, users and citizens have a stable framework for investing safely and legal and technical guarantees for operators, users and citizens. Properly identify drones, their qualities and those of their operators, coordinate them with manned aviation, delimit professional and recreational uses and regulate the training of operators, and prevent possible abuses against fundamental rights—communications, intimacy and self-image—are some of the issues that regulate urgently, and it is up to them to turn a risk—representing all dual-use technologies—into an opportunity and foster an industry with enormous potential and a quarry quality jobs.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Unmanned aerial aircraft are in the hands of those responsible; in dangerous tasks, for example, replace people. However, in the hands of the irresponsible or unskilled, they are a threat to people's things, animals, safety and privacy, so this area needs to be well and quickly regulated, and the highest standards in the field of production must also be adopted. Security and privacy are of paramount importance here, and the report also points out.  The recent Volkswagen car scandal, however, has shown the importance of overseeing the implementation of the law. The call on the Commission and the Member States to provide sufficient resources for enforcement is therefore in place. The drone market is already very large and their scope, as we all note, is still very messy. We therefore need a single European strategy, particularly in the areas of security, privacy, accountability, qualifications and environmental protection.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, I welcome this debate on drones, and the thoughtful and consultative way in which our report under consideration today was produced. I utterly reject the unhelpful and ill-informed knee-jerk comments of the UKIP colleague opposite. There is a growing consensus among the public and experts that an extended legal framework on drones, for reasons of safety and orderly economic development, is necessary. It is clear that drone technology can be extremely useful – for example, in undertaking repairs and safety inspections in the construction and transport sectors that would be very risky for staff to conduct. However, drones are potentially dangerous aircraft, and there has been a growing incidence of serious accidents and near misses involving their use in Europe and worldwide. It is therefore disappointing that the Commission appears reluctant to regulate properly the leisure use of drones. Speaking for myself, while drones can obviously create high quality jobs, I would be reluctant to see them replacing valued customer-service roles in the delivery and retail sectors.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, let me, Madam Commissioner and Madam Rapporteur, clearly support this report because the drone market really has fantastic development opportunities, especially those that will serve to live better, in better commercial use of drones, not only more in military use.  However, what I want to warn about are two things because it is definitely clear that there is a possibility of misuse of drones, especially when they become part of, so to speak, everyday living and in everyday use in millions of pieces that will fly for us. The first problem is the identification of drones. So whose drones are the property of the drones because of course drone abuse is possible. And secondly, what I especially want to emphasize is the cross-border use of drones because we have the possibility of one drone reaching the border, recording everything that is happening in another country and that is where we are already getting into security issues.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for this very fruitful debate. The drone industry has huge potential for the EU: for growth, for fresh jobs and for development at all levels of innovation. The EU is still the leading area of the world for business drones and I want it to stay that way. All our efforts will be directed towards synchronising an EU single market in order to enable economies of scale to be made, and to be competitive. The market is evolving fast and we are ready to act swiftly and holistically. We are already fully engaged at EU level and globally. As I have mentioned, the aviation package will address various aspects of the report, as well as the activities of the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) and the Joint Authorities for Rulemaking on Unmanned Systems (JARUS). The technologists’ and industrialists’ enthusiasm for the process is also well balanced with addressing citizensʼ concerns regarding safety, security, noise and privacy issues, as well as issues in relation to the manipulators of drones. However, we need to act in a proportionate manner to allow the evolution of the market and the manifestation of its full potential.  Thank you again to Ms Foster, and all the MEPs involved, for this report. I am looking forward to our future cooperation on this topic.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and my colleagues for those very constructive and helpful comments. I would just like to clarify a couple of points on privacy. As we said, we work very closely with the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), and what we need to stress in our Member States is that there are already strong laws in place and we must make sure that our law enforcement is absolutely up to scratch. So that is the starting point. In terms of these little baby drones – one of my colleagues mentioned it – we are not looking at regulating a tiny little thing that a child would play with. The whole point of this report is about that section in the middle, which is commercial use and the slightly bigger ones, which could actually cause damage. This is what this is about. It is also not about the top—end ones, which are already covered by aviation regulation. So this is why we are looking at a case—by—case type class approach. In terms of the protection of facilities – whether it to be nuclear plants, airports, etc. – this is where technology comes in. This is where I mentioned geofencing. We have been talking very often with these technological bods to find ways to see how we can deal with this. My good colleague, Ms Arnautu, is quite right: this is not about military use. This is just about civil use. The points that she has raised are very important. My final point goes to our colleague, Ms Seymour, who very sadly lacks any real understanding of the aviation sector and does not understand that aviation per se already comes under national (UK), European and global rules. That is what the sector does in any event, and drones will be no different. But never mind, I will perhaps explain that to her privately.  On that closing point, I would just like to say that I am very much looking forward to what the Commission will produce. I think that together we can come up with a very good regulation. My final point to the Commissioner would be that I want to make sure that the manufacturers, the end-users and all the bodies that I have mentioned and spoken to are included in this debate and will be included as the legislation rolls on.  I look forward to all Members, hopefully, supporting this report in the vote at 11.30.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, October 29, at 12 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Drones are no longer something taken from a science fiction movie. Rather, they are an increasingly developed technology, which is reflected in an emerging industry in which the Union must aspire to be a leader. But these unmanned aerial vehicles are also a new reality, which poses new challenges to the protection of fundamental rights, security, police forces and public order. I therefore welcome the report under discussion today reflects precisely this approach — on the one hand, recommending a set of measures to achieve a single European market, as well as taking the lead in the creation of global standards, and, on the other hand, recognising the new challenges and following the recommendations adopted by the LIBE Commission, such as the need for traceability , from a legal framework appropriate to the enhancing effect of new technologies, such as cameras and thermal sensors, or stimulating investment in privacy and security technologies. All this is based on the assumption that any measures should involve all stakeholders and be proportionate, i.e. taking into account the associated risk and the size of the undertakings. It's time to get to work, because technology doesn't wait!

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The last 15 years have been a time of rapid use of remotely piloted aerial systems (RPAS), which we colloquially call drones. They are becoming more and more popular in Poland as well. Undoubtedly, these devices contribute to the success of the military operations to which they were originally designed. It is a major positive to use them in particular for safety checks and infrastructure monitoring, natural disaster assessment, precision-demanding agricultural activities or media production. The most worrying issue, however, is the use of drones by private individuals for commercial purposes and the lack of Community legislation in this area. I believe that clear, harmonised and proportionate regulations should be developed that do not burden companies that invest and innovate in the RPAS sector. On the other hand, they must provide adequate protection for citizens and create sustainable and innovative jobs. Account should be taken of the illegal and dangerous use of drones, e.g. their conversion from civilian devices into weapons or their interfering with navigation or communication systems, particularly at airports. The impact of the planned regulation must be balanced. I would like to stress once again that it must protect the lives of all of us, which is why European law should extend to the use of drones; however, it must not restrict the newly created market too much, as it will make it unattractive to investors and customers.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "There are currently around 5,000 drone operators registered worldwide. Half of them are based in Europe. The number of objects you have is already difficult to verify. It is therefore easy to imagine the scale of the various risks involved in the use of drones today. The urgency of regulation is therefore extraordinary. Certification of facilities with a weight of more than 150 kg is absolutely insufficient, mainly due to the technological possibilities of creating very large and yet lighter objects. I would also like to make clear the importance and possibilities of using the GNSS system created and implemented and the need to focus not only on the user, but also on the objects themselves. Their mandatory labelling should be introduced fairly quickly, also in order to reduce the risks associated with the transport of facilities across EU borders.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Isabelle De Monte's report, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe (2014/2241(INI)) (A8-0258/2015).

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is still the world's leading tourist destination. The figure is comforting today, but it is expected that in 2030 we will be surpassed by other continental destinations. This is due to globalisation, the increase in different economic conditions in the population of third countries, but also as a result of digitalisation and the lowering of air transport costs, which make places first distant or unknown destinations that are now accessible. In view of this changed situation, we must be competitive, we must take into account the fact that tourism is Europe's third largest economy, and the European institutions must therefore pay the right and well-deserved attention to it. Moreover, the sector has maintained a good level of arrivals and attendance even in years of economic crisis, with positive results for companies and an increase in the level of employment. Tourism from competence to ambition: and our ambition is to increase our potential, but in a sustainable and responsible way, assessing the difficulties related to climate change and with respect for the environment.  All Member States, without exception, will increasingly have an attractiveness as a destination, because the key to success in the tourism sector is to treasure the territorial peculiarities that reside in culture and cultural heritage, traditions, the environment and biodiversity, food and wine, sport, wellness and so on. Of course, we could discuss at length everything that can be achieved, given that more than 100 types of tourism have been established, but it is clear that in order to have effective and also communicative action we must focus on something as precise and determined as pan-European and transnational tourism products.  Tourist attractions are today a product that must be communicated quickly and widely. For this reason, I call on the Commission to pay particular attention to the issue of digitalisation. More than 95% of travelers plan their trips and itineraries online, with a growing offer of collaborative consumption services. We have a productive fabric made up of small and medium-sized enterprises that must be supported in global challenges: to know and make known, in a digital world that is evolving, from day to day, more and more quickly. The debate held since the beginning of the process in committee has revealed other important aspects, such as the need for strong joint promotion, training for quality tourism, and the need for European funds to be adequate for the growth of the sector. I would like to thank the Committee on Transport and Tourism for voting in favour by a large majority on the own-initiative report, thanks to the shadow rapporteurs, who have done a good and constructive job. I would also like to thank the members of the Committee on Culture, Education and the Internal Market because, through the debate and the opinion expressed, it has been possible to enrich the report with important content. The contribution of the parliamentary groups shows that tourism has no political colour, it is a great opportunity for everyone. For this reason, there must not be a solitary voice, but a choral voice that can give strength and impetus to effective action by the Commission and the Member States.  The hope is that there will be no divisions in today's vote too, so that consensus will allow the Commission to be given the widest possible delegation so that there can be a further quantitative and qualitative increase in tourism in the coming years. Through these concrete actions we will demonstrate together that the European Union is not bureaucracy and austerity, but our chance to succeed for the economic and working future of the younger generation.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Members of Parliament, I would like to thank you and in particular the rapporteur, Ms De Monte, for this excellent report. I fully share your views on the importance of the EU tourism sector. The travel and tourism sector makes a very substantial contribution to European economies. In 2014 its direct, indirect and induced impacts supported 33.5 million jobs. Moreover, in the same period it also contributed more than EUR 1.3 trillion to the economy, making up almost 10% of total European GDP. By 2025 the travel and tourism sector's total economic contribution is expected to grow to 38 million jobs and EUR 2.1 trillion. In addition, travel and tourism is key to the recovery of those countries that have been hit hardest by recession and the euro zone crisis. 20% of employees in the European tourism industry are aged below 25. Tourism is therefore an important entry point to the labour market. Tourism has also significant spill—over benefits for the cultural and creative industries, including fashion and high-end products – agrifoods, transport, construction, shipbuilding or retail. Therefore tourism has a huge potential to generate economic growth and create jobs. But although Europe is still the number one destination, we should not rest on our laurels. We have to address important challenges – competition from emerging destinations is increasing. In 2000 the EU had 51% of the worldʼs tourism market; today we are below 40% and forecasts indicate a further drop to 31% by 2030. To attract new investment and ensure faster growth, we must increase the number of travellers from key markets such as China, India or the US. For this to happen, we need to strengthen our promotional activities. In doing so, we should consider that 99% of the tourist sector is made up of SMEs and 90% of them have fewer than 10 employees. It is important that we improve the business environment, not least by ensuring a well—functioning single market for services. The Commission adopted the new Single Market Strategy just two days ago. We have to fully capitalise on the potential offered by this strategy, ensuring effective enforcement of single market principles and rules, extending also to tourism services. We must continue to work on the issue of over—regulation and cut down red tape where possible. At the same time we must ensure that the principles of the Small Business Act are fully implemented in the tourism sector.  We should also follow market trends and enable the development of new innovative business models and take on board the advantages of the digital revolution. Especially in this case digitalisation will be a key driver of the sector’s competitiveness. We must help tourism-related SMEs to seize the opportunities offered by the digital revolution. We wish to embrace the opportunities created by the sharing economy, including for the EU tourism industry. At the same time, we must create a level playing field for all actors and make sure that public and consumer interests are properly reflected. To compete with new emerging destinations were must invest in high-quality offerings and improve infrastructure, resource efficiency and skills. To that end it is essential to ensure better access to finance. There is a serious mismatch between the demand for and the supply of skilled labour in the sector. Erasmus+ and the European Social Fund play a key role in the upgrading of skills, including digital skills, as well as in training and workforce mobility. We have helped to define tourism qualifications and developed a skill passport to help match businesses with job-seekers. We are also promoting high-quality cross-border traineeships and the smooth entry into the labour market for young professionals through a digital platform. There is a strong added value in promotion activities carried out jointly with public and private stakeholders. American and Asian tourists want to come to Europe and visit more than one country. We should preserve, and capitalise on, our unique cultural and natural heritage and diversity. We should invest more in joint promotion in close collaboration with Member States, regions and the industry.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur from the IMCO Committee, I would like to stress that this report is very welcome for the internal market, for the European Union. Too little has been said in the European Parliament about tourism, and the European Commission has focused too little on policies to promote tourism, to promote Europe as a tourist destination.  Sustainable, accessible and responsible tourism is not only a holiday activity, it is also a way of promoting the richness of cultural diversity in Europe and a way of developing new jobs, it is a lever for the development of SMEs.  Many Member States, including the country where they come from, have untapped potential, which is why, in the opinion report, we proposed concrete measures to promote Europe as a tourist destination, a brand strategy. The European Union must be prepared to realise the potential in third countries with a large number of inhabitants. New concepts to promote tourism Europe can lead to economic development and job development in poorer, rural areas but with significant tourism potential. I would like to finally thank the shadow rapporteurs and Isabella De Monte for a full report, and I hope that this report will be voted on today.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, congratulations to the rapporteur on her excellent work. It has already been said that Europe, especially because of its very rich cultural, material and immaterial heritage, declined in all its various aspects – artistic, linguistic, religious, historical, traditional – is the main tourist destination in the world. In particular, cultural tourism accounts for as much as 40% of European tourism. It is undoubtedly the key sector for reviving growth and employment in Europe.  In order to maintain existing levels and attract new tourist flows, it is essential to promote quality, sustainable and inclusive cultural tourism, to preserve and enhance Europe's cultural and natural heritage, to strike the right balance between expanding tourism and safeguarding cultural heritage.  It is therefore right to support and strengthen all existing European initiatives and programmes, such as the European Capitals of Culture, European cultural routes, the European Cultural Heritage Label and Creative Europe. But that's not all. European cultural tourism is an important instrument for growth and personal knowledge, a means of promoting the richness of European cultural diversity and, above all, of strengthening the meaning and belonging to our common European identity.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank all the colleagues who have worked and who have drawn up this report directly. We have been able to reach a consensual document where we identify the current situation about the challenges and this important sector and the challenges facing employment itself. This is the first debate of this parliamentary term and it is the first debate we have on tourism. I cannot but regret that the Commissioner responsible for this sector is not here with us, is not with us to discuss such an important sector for job creation, which is so important for the growth of the Union economy.  Here we have listed a set of proposals. I would therefore like the Commission to present an action plan, a concrete action plan, so that together we can, Commission and Parliament, set priorities in our actions and also for these actions to know what kind of funding exists and where we can channel it.  I am available and we are all available to work together on the eight actions that the Commissioner presented this summer at the World Tourism Forum and I hope that this action plan will arrive as soon as possible so that we can work.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. You mentioned the figures, Commissioner, and 13 million people are employed in tourism. I do not need to repeat what this has an impact on the European economy.
