I am also with you when you say that we are the largest tourist region in the world. But the other regions are also catching up, of course, because they are also, in part, much cheaper and also offer better services. That is why it is important and right for the European Parliament to look at what we can do here in the future. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur, Isabella De Monte, for the extremely good work she has done.  I would like to highlight just three points: sustainability, for example, digitalisation – these are very decisive topics for the future, including in the field of tourism. I would also like to appeal once again that we must stop restricting visa policy towards third countries if we want to invite more citizens or more tourists in the field of tourism.  As far as safety standards are concerned, we must also take a close look, because there is a need to catch up, particularly in the area of fire protection and carbon monoxide, in various accommodations. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: István UJHELYI
text: Blue card question. – I received the Blue Card because Mr Ismail Ertug is the coordinator of the Social Democratic Group in the Committee on Transport and Tourism and he is a big supporter of tourism, which is why we can do so much. Still, Congressman, do you think what the committee is doing is sufficient? Do you see that the Chairman of the Committee and some of your colleagues are serious about what a major sector this is? That we should do a lot more in committee to increase the lobbying power of tourism? Can you help me with that as coordinator to hire the other factions and the chairman of the committee?

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much, sir. Of course, we in the European Parliament and, so to speak, in committee must do more. We will see in the next few years whether the Commission has done enough. Whether the Commission will ultimately leave it to this, or whether it will support us in the future – that is, those who want to introduce more legislation here, or at least more measures, from within Parliament. I am already glad that we have these proposals at all and that the Commission is open to this debate. Because in the previous period there was relatively little. In this respect, we want to look and be good-natured with the Commission.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Tourism is an extremely important and very sensitive sector of the European economy. At the moment, Europe is the world leader in terms of the number of tourists visiting it, but this position is not given to us once and for all. We must be ready for the challenges of the present and look for ways to constantly increase the tourist attractiveness of our continent. First of all, it is important to break the seasonality of this sector, which will increase employment and diversify the offer aimed at tourists from all over the world. Religious and pilgrimage tourism, among others, play an important role here. It is also important to create tools that will support the development of small and medium-sized enterprises providing tourism services, including in regions which, despite their potential, are not yet popular destinations. This is what the digital age and the emerging model of the sharing economy provide us with.  We should be ready to make effective use of these new phenomena. However, the future of the European tourism sector is also a spectre of threats, including those caused by the uncontrolled influx of illegal immigrants into the European Union. Images from the coasts of Greece, Croatia and Italy force us to ask how much damage the tourism industry suffers as a result of this crisis. I would like the Commission to examine this issue fairly and to answer this question without hiding behind political correctness.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, at the beginning I would like to thank Mrs De Monte for her good cooperation, as well as other colleagues and fellow rapporteurs and for the excellent report we have before us.  Tourism is an important branch of the economy in Europe, and Europe is an outstanding tourist destination and everything should be done to remain the best and most important tourist destination in the world in the conditions of new markets and new technologies. That is why I welcome this Report of the European Parliament, which aims to take a full look at tourism, work in a coordinated way on the development of tourism in Europe and of course achieve a common, quality European tourism product. On behalf of the ALDE group, I of course support the content of the report, but I would like to emphasize in particular the two dimensions that are interconnected. This is the use of new digital technologies and the need to develop tourism in rural, mountainous and remote areas. With better internet coverage of these rural, mountainous and remote areas, we will achieve two very important goals. We will reduce the seasonal character of European tourism as a first goal and reduce the difference in the development of these areas compared to other urban areas of our continent.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am not going to repeat how important the tourism sector is and how important it is to invest well in the tourism sector. Italy knows this well, because twenty years ago it was the world's first tourist destination and now it is the fifth, also for mistakes in investments and poor modernization. I welcome the De Monte report, which Seems to me to be an excellent piece of work. There are critical points in the enthusiasm to create a market. The market is not everything, there is the protection of the landscape, the territory and the environment, there are other values, such as the quality of the work of the workers, which is very low in the sector.  And then there's a critical point, which is when you try to promote health tourism. I would like this point to be clarified better, because I would not like it to be an encouragement to a type of tourism that we do not like at all. Health is a right that has cost great struggles and cannot be put on an equal footing or included in a tourist package along with food and wine or other pleasant aspects, of course. I do not want to encourage health dumping among our countries, where the dismantling of national public health services, which are one of the greatest achievements of our civilisation, is already under way. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Dear colleague, you have spoken of investment and I am very happy. Do you not think that we should ask the Commission, since we still have a Commissioner on Transport and Tourism, that transport investments be linked and targeted at tourist points? And, you said health, don't you understand that there is also a prevention in health? And that's what we meant. Because when you go on vacation, I think it helps to have a health prevention package. Prevention is cheaper than treatment.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Perhaps I have not been clear. We should discuss this, of course! Because if you talk, in fact, in the list there are also spa treatments. No one is going to oppose the promotion of the beautiful Slovenian, Italian or French spas. But if we put health and health care on the European market, we must be careful: there are also great differences in height, we create competition in an area where we cannot allow ourselves to be left to work the miracles of the free market.

name: Jill EVANS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, tourism is a vital industry. In my constituency of Wales alone it generates some 4.5 billion a year for the economy and supports nearly 89 000 full-time jobs. The industry, as we know, has huge potential and, developed correctly and responsibly, could provide many long-term benefits to communities right across the European Union. The Greens/European Free Alliance Group welcomes the comprehensive nature of this report and thanks the rapporteur, Isabella De Monte, for her collaborative work. The report recognises the importance of cultural heritage in that all of our different languages can themselves be a driving force for good-quality tourism. Also important is the inclusion of climate change and the urgent need to act on this, particularly for coastal, island, and mountainous areas. For us too, it was vital that the call for accessibility for people with reduced mobility was included. However, my group cannot support the language used in reference to the refugee crisis, which fails to recognise the dire circumstances of asylum seekers coming to Europe and their need for support and for solidarity.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Ladies and gentlemen, tourism is an area that I believe europe should keep its fingers very far from. Tourism is a national, a regional and, indeed, mostly a local issue in each Member State. It is each country's unique characteristics that attract tourism. In Sweden it is the beautiful nature with fresh air and great opportunities for silence and peace and quiet. In Spain it is the sun and the heat for example. I do not want to see europe's bizarre ideas also incorporated into the tourism sector. You will certainly vote in this House on the proposal – the vast majority of you. Because you have long since failed your countries and voters. You give away the sovereignty and self-determination of your home countries piece by piece on every issue without any qualms whatsoever. Let me remind you that it has tried to build great kingdoms before, but it has failed every time. It will fail again this time. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Silvia COSTA
text: "blue card" question. I have a question for my colleague. I am convinced that Europe's strength lies in its diversity also in terms of heritage, landscape and traditions. Do you not think that in the global challenge of the tourist offer, for example, a Quality European Framework, which guarantees the quality of services, products, professionalism and even European packages that enhance the territories, is necessary to meet this challenge? Just think of European cultural itineraries: they are an extraordinary transnational product that also crosses your country, from Canterbury to Rome there is the Via Francigena. Do you not think that these are positive experiences?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: answer ("blue card"). I am terribly sorry, but so far, since its birth, the EUROPEAN Union has not achieved what can be called high-quality. I am quite sure that it will not be done in this area either. It is each country's unique characteristics that make tourism come. If europe is to put its fingers in it and try to unify tourism in the EUROPEAN area, then I fear that it will have the opposite effect. It is far too bad an experience so far as we see from europe. This is definitely an area from which europe should keep its fingers away.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the European Union that has been sold to us has failed miserably and the peoples of Europe today are turning away from it. But never mind, you are now proposing to transform Europe into a vulgar marketing product. And to achieve your goals, you are not at a paradox.  You say that the administrative burden on SMEs needs to be reduced, but you are increasing it with new regulations. You say that the conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East as well as terrorism threaten tourism, but the European Union has encouraged chaos in Ukraine and has not supported Syria in its fight against Islamist terrorism. You talk about the challenges of tourism without even mentioning the rampant insecurity that is infecting this sector. You deplore the harmful effects of mass tourism while advocating even more tourists and, finally, you talk about European identity and cultural wealth, but I fear that these are essentially only destructive values of the Europe of nations to which we aspire; that is why we will vote against this report.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the new challenges and ideas for promoting tourism in Europe, the report is moving in the context of embellishing the current situation. Europe as the world's leading tourist destination, with a market share of 52%, is an important social and economic activity in the European Union.  But things for the countries of the South, such as Greece, are not so rosy. Greece relies financially heavily on revenue from tourism. But in this summer tourist season a huge economic blow was taken by the Aegean islands. The impact of the particularly increased flows of refugees and migrants is significant on the islands that are the main destinations of these flows, such as Kos, Lesvos, Chios and Samos. In Kos alone, 120,000 cancellations by touroperates and 58,000 by individual customers corresponds to a 400% increase in cancellations. This means a loss of income and jobs, especially among our young people, who in Greece reach 60%. Humanism is good in the European Union, but Europeans cancel their holidays on islands that are being sinked by illegal immigrants, because they are spoiling the peace and quiet they seek. How can we also talk about competitiveness, when the special regime of reduced VAT in the most popular destinations is abolished on the Greek islands and the third most onerous memorandum imposes the absurd VAT of 23%, when in the competitive market of the acceding Turkey it is at 6%? Is this a united Europe also on the issue of tourism development? If we do not change tactics, this Union as it evolves will begin to collapse.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Dear colleague, it is clear, you have mixed the plans: the migration problem with the issue of tourism. I ask you a clear question: did you enjoy the solidarity that was with you? Romania, for example, came with many tourists to you and other countries in Europe came with tourists precisely to help Greece. Do you like this solidarity or not?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), answer a question with a blue card. – First of all, I would like to remind you of the solidarity that Greece has shown and its humanity on the issue of migrants. Thousands of people have been rescued from the waters of the Aegean Sea. Secondly, the countries that have helped Greece financially I think have taken too much interest from Greece, which has been financially enslaved with the memorandums, which have failed.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission, with its 2010 Communication 'Europe, the world's first tourist destination: a new policy framework for European tourism' undoubtedly gave this sector a boost with a consolidated political framework and action plan. This is the time, Commissioner, to design a new strategy and new challenges. It is the right time for this strategy to contain the essential elements, in our view. The new strategy must respond both to old challenges and long-term challenges — such as seasonality, quality improvement, competitiveness of the sector, accessibility, demographic developments, climate change, competition from new third destinations or the need for more sustainable, responsible and social tourism — and others again, Commissioner— such as the emergence of the sharing economy or the unstoppable digitisation of the purchasing and interaction process. customers' tourist destination. It is clear that this is a time when the Commission must give more priority and more resources to this objective of tourism, which is a fundamental industry. Of course, in my country we live with the greatest success in our history. Without tourism, we would be something else. And it is necessary that, although harmonization is prohibited, nationalism and the lack of generosity to share cultures, resources, projects and humanity should not be imposed.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Madam President, as co-chair of the Intergroup for the Development of European Tourism, I tell you that this sector needs more strategic attention, more funds and more investment, but, above all, more courage and more involvement from all the European institutions. This report is the result of the joint efforts of many members of the European Parliament, civil society and the private environment, an effort to keep Europe the world's number one priority in the world. I would now like to insist on a few clear and priority points: 1. I call on the European Commission to support the nomination of a European year of cultural heritage and tourism in order to promote our tourism potential, especially the less visible areas of Europe, such as Bucovina, Maramures or Transylvania; 2. We encourage the Commission to develop a new European tourism strategy, a strategy tailored to the changes that have occurred in recent years; 3. We are laying the foundations for a common European tourism brand for a unified promotion of the diversity and unique experiences offered by the Member States.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The tourism industry continues to grow and the tourism industry is considered one of the largest in the world, providing more than 255 million jobs and generating 9% of GDP per year. In the European Union, tourism is the third largest socio-economic activity after trade and distribution and construction. It is also a key sector for my country, for my province, for the Podcarpathian voivodeship, which has an extremely rich tourist offer, from nature, views, to tourist attractions of Podcarpathian cities. It is also a very economically attractive region where global companies invest. 90% of the aviation industry is created in Podkarpacie. Nevertheless, in order to maintain the pace of development, the industry needs constant innovation and improvement, which I call on the European Commission to do.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, I would like to express my agreement with this report and my gratitude to the rapporteur for incorporating some of our contributions, and my support also for a European tourism brand that supports, promotes and disseminates our diversity and ensures the quality of our offer. A homogeneous training of professionals aimed at excellence and innovation, the cross-border combination of routes that promote the concept of experience that travelers increasingly demand, the ability to keep us visible in an increasingly competitive environment and the need to add in this effort to the nearest administrations and make them collaborate with each other is one of the keys to success. The other, the technology. The deployment in cyberspace of a consistent, diverse and reliable catalog of offers, online sales and auxiliary services at destination for all types of media, including mobile ones, is essential. We need to intensify the promotion and digital management of the sector and only then can we position ourselves with all our offer in the same common brand and maintain our leadership. These should be the priorities set by European policies to support the sector.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that tourism is an important factor in economic development for Europe. That is why we welcome several of the initiatives contained in this report for the empowerment of quality, cultural and sustainable European tourism, the impetus for green and rural tourism as a survival factor for many European regions affected by depopulation and aging, initiatives such as the rehabilitation of old hotel structures, aid for the rehabilitation of natural areas degraded by unsustainable mass tourism , especially in coastal areas – such as the one that promotes the Law People's Party coasts in my country. Likewise, we believe it is necessary to dignify working conditions in a sector where precariousness and temporality abound. We advocate enhancing Europe as an international tourist destination, but being aware of the environmental cost of hypermobility that the report seems to promote. We also believe that states, regions and cities have the right to protect themselves from mass tourism, as the Government has made from change in Barcelona with a moratorium on the opening of new hotels. We are committed to tourism that is not over-tified. We are committed to sustainable tourism. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support You mentioned an important element of the development of tourism, the green aspects, but I ask whether you can agree that, in addition, there are other instruments to expand the opportunities for tourism. For example, in many countries, vat rates are being lowered to stimulate tourism. I ask whether you could agree that vat on food vat or tourist services in Europe should be uniformly zero, whether in certain regions or in certain seasons.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: "blue card" response. – With regard to VAT, I think it is the most unfair tax there is, because it is the one that everyone pays equally. No matter what rent you have, VAT is paid exactly the same. I therefore believe that VAT, if reduced, should be a reduction that meets basic needs, basic necessities and, for example, culture and cultural activities. Indeed, this would also have a positive impact on tourism, but it would have a positive impact on the majority of the population and on the cultural industry and the cultural sector.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the adoption of this report on sustainable tourism, with the hope that this Europe will finally decide to pay more attention to this sector, which alone could be the driving force of our economy, as well as a way out of the economic and employment crisis that affects us. So far, too little effort has been made by the institutions, including in terms of allocating financial resources to support small and medium-sized enterprises in the sector.  I would, however, like to stress the importance of protecting the 'made-in' of our States, which was accepted in committee thanks to an amendment tabled by us of the 5-star Movement, and which, in my opinion, is far more important and significant than a European label, which does not in fact exist and which not only does not appear to be attractive, but would even penalise our many wonderful specificities. It is in the diversity of our beauties and heritage that lies the true wealth of the European Union and not in flattening on a common mark.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report – for which I thank the rapporteur, Mrs De Monte, and all the shadow rapporteurs, starting with my party's rapporteur Monteiro – is a report that deals with an objectively central issue in the economic and cultural development of our continent. And the demands are correct: more data from the Commission to give a rigorous structure to this economic and cultural awareness, new forms of relaunch through digitalization, the idea of the multimodal ticket, integrated digital services, the simplification called for by some colleagues on the issue of visas. But the central element, in my view, is the challenge of the Europa brand. What is the Europa brand? Viewed from above Europe, geographically, as a place, it looks like the periphery of Asia, the eastern periphery, but seen from within before being a continent is a content. It's a cultural content. That's the Europa brand, the heart of Western culture.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). Madam President, many interesting issues are dealt with in an excellent way by Mrs De Mote, because tourism is a large European industry, which has enormous room for growth. I will focus on two of them: one is the taxation of tourist services. The European Parliament is calling for reduced VAT, because tourism enterprises, the vast majority of them small and medium-sized enterprises, are inextricably linked to local communities and in this way help local development and the maintenance of jobs. The second is the reminder that remote areas of Europe such as the small islands have huge problems in the transport and energy sector. But we cannot have two-speed European residents. We are waiting for the Commission's answers on this. I would also like to apologise for my compatriot, Mr Fountoulis. For us the answer to the refugee issue is given by a small island of 700 inhabitants that lives off tourism and asked to accommodate 100 families of Syrian refugees. So there is the great response of solidarity, there are extreme xenophobic voices.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is at least suspicious when we ask the Member States, as a Parliament, to recognise the importance of reducing VAT rates on tourist services (paragraph 63 of the report), at the same time as the so-called institutions of the famous Quartet are forcing Greece with the Memorandum to increase VAT on the Aegean islands. Obviously, the reduced VAT was not valid either freely or selectively. It balanced the increased transport costs and the specific geographical dispersion conditions of the islands. So let the Commission answer us: This blackmailing imposition which knowingly sabotages the most productive and development sector of the Greek economy, tourism, what interests does it serve? because there is a huge contradiction, if not an irony, of course, at the same time as it is talking about development, at the same time imposing such a self-evidently existential measure.  This bilingualism is not due to error and of course it is not accidental. I look forward to the Commission's replies.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here and I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report. Tourism is extremely important, as we all know, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises in Ireland, the country I come from. I would like to address the VAT issue, which has been mentioned by many speakers. The reduction in VAT from 13.5% to 9% has been singularly successful in increasing employment and in boosting tourist numbers. It has been acknowledged by hotel federations, restaurant associations and others in the hospitality sector as directly boosting employment, and it is one of the success stories. Like my Greek colleague, we came to an agreement with the Troika: the government addressed this question with them, and they were allowed to reduce VAT provided they demonstrated that the funding could be provided from elsewhere. It resulted in a tax on pensions, which was not very popular at the time. However, three to four years later, the very successful outcome in terms of employment opportunities in the sector has more than outweighed the negative impact at the time. So I would say to the Commissioner, yes, reduction of VAT rates can be very successful in this extremely important sector, particularly for rural areas and islands, where tourism is so important.

name: István UJHELYI
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I have been involved in tourism policy at home in Hungary for 10 years, and now here in Parliament as head and coordinator of the Tourism Task Force. This is a perfect material, but I have learned that such a material is worth what we can do together here in the European institutions. And my problem is that the European Commission does not see the specific gravity of the issue. Is it true that more than 12 million people in Europe are now out of work? Yes! Is it true that among young people we have 7 million compatriots, european partners, who are out of work? Yes! And is it true that tourism is one of the best labour-creating, job-creating sectors? Yes! Well, there are over 13 million people in this sector right now. Then why is the Commission not finally moving and listening to the views of members? Please devote much more energy to the development of European tourism.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tourism is a strategic sector of our economy, generating more than 10% of GDP and employing more than twenty million people, most of them young people. Despite the economic crisis that erupted in 2008, Europe remains the world's first tourist destination.  But all this must not make us sleep on our laurels: we must face the new challenges with determination, starting with the digital one, if it is true, as is true, as happens punctually in Italy, that more than 20% of travelers plan their online itineraries, with an increasing percentage year after year. In Europe, this percentage is even more significant.  However, tour operators have to compete with new emerging destinations, with significantly lower prices charged. We must focus on quality and deseasonalisation, not only in view of the changing demographic changes in the population. The European Union must give its full support to this absolutely strategic area, and in this respect I fully support the De Monte report.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Madam President, I want to focus on one aspect which is extremely important in this report, and that is safety in tourism accommodation. Nine years ago this week, two children from my constituency, Christi and Bobby Shepherd, died in a hotel in Corfu. They died from carbon monoxide poisoning from a faulty boiler in their room. A simple carbon monoxide device, like the one I have here, could have saved their lives. The parents of the children asked me at the time: ‘Are there no safety standards in European tourist accommodation?’ The answer today is still no. For the past nine years, I have been working with the Commission, with your predecessors, Commissioner, and this year the Commission published the outcome of a Green Paper on tourism safety. Now, Commissioner, it is time to act on that report. The coroner who investigated the deaths of the children has called for action at European level. Public opinion wants action: firefighters, consumer associations and travel agencies. So we now need the Commission to bring forward proposals. We need the support of this Parliament and of all our governments. This is something on which Europe could make a real difference, and we need your support.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the rapporteur, Mrs De Monte. We know that cultural tourism accounts for more than 40% of the total in Europe, and is therefore linked to the preservation and enhancement of the landscape and cultural heritage, to the professional qualifications of workers, by strengthening the alliances of knowledge, which you mentioned, Commissioner, and to the quality and safety of services and products.  That is why we need a real Integrated European Action Plan and dedicated investments in all programmes – Erasmus+, Social Fund, Creative Europe, but also Horizon 2020 – for the digitisation of cultural heritage. However, there is a contradiction: the budget dedicated for 2016 in the COSME programme to tourism has not only halved.  However, global demand is changing and supply must therefore be diversified, making it sustainable, more consistent with Europe's widespread heritage: not bites and escapes, but experiential, slow, seasonally adjusted tourism, including sporting tourism, including religious tourism, which enhances small towns and often walks along European cultural routes.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to take this opportunity to ask Mrs Costa that, if I have understood this correctly – you have talked about cultural heritage and so on – there has been a very substantial reduction on the part of the European Commission in the various funding pots, such as COSME. Is that really the case? If so, I would like to know why the cuts are being made in this area of all places.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I believe that the question is addressed to me, but also to the Commissioner, about cutting. That is quite true: there are only two COSME budget lines dedicated to tourism and in particular to itineraries, products and services and both have been cut in an absolutely significant way. Among other things, one was the result of a pilot project, which later became a budget line, proposed by myself and the Culture Committee. So I am also asking the Commissioner this question, because I believe that this answer must be given, otherwise there is a contradiction between this important report and the practical translation of these initiatives.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, it is welcome that the De Monte report focuses on the importance of European cultural tourism as well and asks the European Commission to continue to support so-called 'European cultural routes' economically. These routes are very important, first of all, for the development of thematic, selective, more demanding tourism, and offer a very wide range of offers to satisfy this option of cultural or thematic tourism. I will highlight, for example, the roads of Santiago, Europe's first cultural route, which every year breaks tourism records from all over the world. But there are thirty-two other cultural routes also very relevant. These routes are also useful for understanding the history of Europe, European art and the peoples of Europe, and contribute to the preservation of the great historical heritage we have in Europe. Moreover, these routes help to highlight — and I conclude already - the existence of a common European identity. Through it, citizens can see that European construction has a solid foundation and that is why I am in favour of bringing young people closer to these European cultural routes.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, regarding the annual European forum on tourism I believe that it is absolutely necessary to promote Europe as the worldʼs number one tourist destination. In order to take steps forward in that direction we have to act in the fields of the sharing economy, digitisation, and sustainable and responsible tourism. We must promote and preserve Europeʼs cultural heritage. This is very important, especially in these times when Europe is facing so many challenges. It has to be our priority, considering that many cultural sites lack funds and are not properly protected by national or local authorities and are therefore in danger of collapsing. We must support vocational training and education, especially in those countries most affected by the crisis, where young graduates with arts and culture degrees, and experts and researchers, face serious problems of long-term unemployment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, tourism is the heavy industry for the countries of southern Europe and in particular the impoverished Greece. And yet studies show that the new system imposed on tourist packages with the so-called "all-inclusive" ultimately not only does not help the development of tourism but instead dissolves local small and medium-sized tourism enterprises, marginalises local agricultural products and reduces employment. At the same time as the sale of the fourteen regional Greek airports in Fraport, Lufthansa, TUI and their tour operators are gaining monopoly power and turning Greek tourism into a tsifliki. Finally, the troika imposed 23% VAT on the Aegean islands in the Aegean islands, reducing the competitiveness of tourism in the region. So let the Commission tell us how, on the one hand, in its report it calls for a reduction in VAT and, on the other hand, as a troika, it is increasing VAT excessively in the Aegean islands, by dismantling Greek tourism.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, why is Tourism Europe losing out on the world market, why are we losing world competition? Because tourism is not a topic in this Parliament either, it is not a Topic of the Commission, it is not a topic at the level of Europe. Everything is left to the member states, as the first problem, the second problem - there is no real public-private partnership at the level of Europe. We have different standards, we have different financing situations, we have different VAT, we have one complete chaos when we talk about tourism in Europe.  What I want to emphasize is the success that Croatia has in tourism. Because there is a good system of tourist boards, because there is an excellent system of public-private partnership and then of course we have success in tourism. I'm peddling to form a common coordinating body, let's call it the European National Tourist Board, not with new employees, but the common coordinating body for tourism in Europe.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, today we are discussing ways to upgrade tourism in Europe but in reality there is no single European tourism market and no equal conditions are guaranteed for the Member States. The most typical example is Greece, which since the summer this year has been forced by the European Commission and the European Central Bank, as members of the troika of the country's lenders, to increase the value added tax in focus to 23% and hotel rates to 13%. In contrast to the main competing Mediterranean countries, Italy, France and Spain, VAT in these two tourism-defining sectors is only 10%. And as if that were not enough, the troika forced Greece to increase VAT on the islands in breach of Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, abolishing the reduced rate, at a time when the islands are the most attractive tourist destinations in the country. This hypocrisy must stop.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Madam Vice President, I'm glad there's a commissioner here today who I believe will understand this problem of mine. I believe that the biggest problem of tourism, specifically in Croatia from which I come, and from these other countries, is seasonality. Thus, there is huge potential in tourism, therefore for the growth of new jobs and for complete growth. In particular, Croatia has 17% of its gross state product from tourism. I am sure that this can double, but the problem is seasonality, and therefore it is necessary to maximize the potential of investments that are definitely needed, but of course investments that will be sustainable, not investments at all costs at the expense of the environment, etc., climate change that we are talking about these days. But we can also be competitive with the Far Eastern countries that are growing today, and along the way we can still get tourists from their countries.  This is what I think Europe needs to do, and that is why maybe we should really make a unified European tourism policy in some way. Although I agree with my colleagues who said that we are different and that we certainly cannot provide a level playing field, but we can create the same VAT, and a level playing field, so that as Europe we can maintain and remain the most competitive in tourism.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe – the world's leading tourist destination – is only vaguely aware of the potential that tourism can generate, traditionally relegating it to a spontaneous, if not secondary, resource. This lack of awareness is evident when we highlight the delay in building a European consciousness and when we consider that, while responding to many of Europe's priorities – I am thinking of sustainable growth, employment, the digital and fair single market – tourism does not have a dedicated line in the European Union budget, but an inconsistent distribution into funds, pilot projects and preparatory actions.  Well, this resolution , and I congratulate Mrs De Monte on her excellent work, aims precisely to satisfy this strategic need with both material (preservation and preservation of historical and monumental beauties) and immaterial (strengthening the European identity, multicultural understanding and sustainability). The desired benefit is to stimulate precisely the many regions of our continent in the development and implementation of tourism policies, in order to generate solid employment, GDP and benefits for SMEs.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Madam President, while everyone has been heard to support the position that tourism really is and adds value to the economy, growth, new jobs and, more generally, the prosperity of countries, while tourism all admits that it offers the gross national product of the European Union 5%, my own country, Cyprus, which is predominantly touristic – it offers more than 10%– , while it offers so much and rich in the European Union, in growth and in the economy, it actually gets back little, it is the poor relative of the European Union. I believe that it is not just the words and declarations from the Commission that are enough. I agree with her position that tourism must be a new challenge for a new perspective, but at the same time tourism must be able to be supported through funds and projects, because tourism serves exclusively and by definition the European Union's position for growth, for new jobs, for prosperity and further for the promotion of all those objectives and objectives that we have set from time to time but never achieved. So works and not just words from the Commission! We really expect the Commission to respond and to achieve these objectives.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I would ask colleagues to take action to keep the faculty a little quieter because they are disturbing the contributors.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – I am pleased that the report includes things that I have repeatedly pointed out in my work to the previous day. Firstly, tourism must not adversely affect the daily lives of the population. In tourism, there is also no place for the arrogance of the tourism industry towards the inhabitants in terms of "be happy to be here and give you work". There is also no place for arrogance and irresponsibility of tourists in terms of "be glad to come to you at all." Secondly, social tourism is a great opportunity to combine the pleasant with the beneficial and reduce the seasonal nature of tourism. It is therefore important to continue with projects such as Calypso, because they also get the opportunity to holiday socially weaker.  And thirdly, the action plan and the tourism strategy must have objectives and a roadmap, especially when they are financed from public funds. Without objectives and a roadmap, it is very difficult to assess the effectiveness and effectiveness of programmes and the use of public funds.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members for this rich and stimulating debate. We all agree that tourism is an important economic sector and we need to explore its potential. The Commission, Member States and the industry should join forces and work together to keep Europe as the world’s number one tourist destination. Let me be more specific now and respond to a couple of the points made. First, on the new action plan, the 2010 communication is very comprehensive and a lot of work can be done within its framework. However, new challenges have arisen. The Commission will address them through targeted measures in close cooperation with Parliament, Member States, regions and the industry. Second, on funds and investment, the Commission will continue to promote the visibility of funds that can be used in tourism. We will organise a high—level event on this topic in April 2016. I would point out, at the same time, that in 2016 the budget for tourism is EUR 4.5 million. This allows projects from 2015 to be continued and to be evaluated in order to build on their results. Third, on taxes, the Commission will analyse the impact of taxes – both national and regional – on tourism. It is important to point out that taxation is primarily a national competence.  Fourth, on branding and promoting Europe, this is an important priority for the Commission. We consider that it must be done via joint promotional efforts in cooperation with Member States, regions and the industry. Last, but not least, on safety, aspects related to the safety of services will be looked at in the context of the Consumer Protection Regulation. In conclusion, I would like to express my thanks for the very comprehensive report. I look forward to our future fruitful cooperation.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the Commissioner, because I am very pleased that she has welcomed the content of this report, which, as I said, is certainly not the result of the work of one person or a few, but it has been really useful to have everyone's contribution.  The debate certainly does not end today, because we have a task force and an intergroup on Culture and Tourism which operate very actively, and so I think that this is simply a starting point for a very intensive work between now and the future. I shared the speeches made by my fellow Members who spoke on the subject of culture and said that we must promote European cultural diversity and identities, because we really must not only talk about tourism, but we must also talk about rich territorial promotion. Instead, when we talk about immigration, we really confuse two issues that should not be put on an equal footing. Of course, I know that immigration and asylum applications are a matter of concern to the European Union. But we must not give the wrong messages either, namely that Europe is not an attractive destination and a safe destination today. And then at a time when we are coming up with the sovereignty and Europe of nations, ladies and gentlemen, then we should not be sitting here. If we are sitting here, it is because we have to believe in Europe and its potential, including the fact that we have a new fiscal policy. With regard to my Maltese colleague, I wanted to reassure him that the intention of the report is undoubtedly to take account of environmental aspects and also of the quality of work, not least in order to improve, why not, the level of pay, indeed it must certainly be, and to ensure that health does not give rise to social dumping, but is an increase in quality in all Member States. Finally, a point: I believe that Europe must not be a summation of 28 states and 28 tourism policies, but a unique, attractive destination that is the dream of many tourists worldwide. Thank you all for your cooperation and help.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I would now like to announce that, at the commissioner's request, I am ordering a two-minute technical pause before the next report and suspending the sitting until then. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. – Tourism is a key activity for Europe and, especially for some countries and regions, so sufficient funds and a strengthening of tourism policy are needed to boost this activity under the umbrella of the Lisbon Treaty. European tourism must undertake a transition from a model of quantitative to qualitative growth that pursues constant and sustainable development;  there is, in fact, the need to establish a European industry that allows the creation of more qualified jobs paid adequately. To this end, investment in training and education is an essential element of the provision of quality services in the sector. I would also like to highlight the fact that full accessibility and affordability in tourism are an integral part of the sustainability of the sector. The principle of "tourism for all" should not simply be a slogan, but should allow persons with special needs (e.g. persons with disabilities, people with reduced mobility, young people, the elderly, families with reduced incomes and families with children) to enjoy their rights as citizens and to train them to do so.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Tourism is a key sector of the EU economy, generating more than 10% of EU GDP and directly employing 13 million people. Europe is 1 first in the world's tourism destinations. This has a positive impact on the economy and employment in the EU. Nevertheless, this area of the economy also faces many internal problems, but also external dangers linked, in particular, to terrorist threats. This requires the adoption of flexible measures that can face these challenges, while at the same time adapting this area of the economy to new requirements and needs.  The EU supports the development of tourism through a number of funds and projects. Despite the increasing importance of tourism as an EU policy, a separate chapter has not yet been created in its budget for this sector. The financial resources for tourism thus come from other EU policies. Therefore, the Commission should explore the possibility of creating a separate section dedicated exclusively to tourism within the next multiannual financial framework. This will contribute to transparency and better control of the funds spent on this area of the economy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – Coming from an island country in the Mediterranean - Malta, I have tabled some amendments in different Committees aimed at promoting the importance of coastal and maritime tourism in Europe. Coastal and maritime tourism is not only the largest maritime activity in Europe, but also directly affects many other sectors of the EU economy, employing more than 3.2 million people. Tourism and in particular coastal and maritime tourism is a lever for growth and job creation in the Mediterranean region, therefore unlocking its potential is of utmost importance for the future economic development and growth of the countries in that region.  I have supported measures recommending to the European Commission to get more active and finally recognise the importance of coastal and island areas and to finally present an action plan with concrete goals and timetables to accompany the 14 actions in the European Strategy for more Growth and Jobs in Coastal and Maritime Tourism. Promoting the tourism industry of island countries or regions, such as Malta, depends largely on sea and air transport and on the connectivity and accessibility to the island. Therefore, the Commission needs to look and emphasise the efficiency of State aid in coastal and maritime regions.

name: Marek PLURA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I warmly congratulate Isabella de Monte on a comprehensive report which not only outlined the opportunities of the tourism sector, but also proposed some promising new solutions, such as the introduction of the European Year of Tourism or the European Quality Label in family-friendly tourism. I believe that specialised tourism and social tourism still do not fully exploit their potential, which, by allowing wider access, also support the extension of the tourist season, which is crucial for the stable growth of this sector. I agree with the rapporteur that the introduction of the 'tourism for all' principle will contribute to m.in fuller exercise of their rights by citizens, especially those with special needs, the elderly, people with disabilities, families with children, people on limited incomes, etc. In this context, I would like to emphasise the importance of introducing a European Charter for persons with disabilities. This document, which allows europeans with disabilities to have access to the facilities and incentives offered to this group by individual countries, local authorities or cultural institutions, can certainly contribute to greater mobility of people with disabilities and to the better use by this significant group of citizens of the European tourism offer. Furthermore, I would like to draw attention to the crucial importance of adequate training of staff, including young entrepreneurs planning careers in the tourism industry, in particular by equipping them with practical skills and experience through apprenticeships and high-quality traineeships.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – Despite the breadth of the proposals and the focus on external promotion, advocated in the resolution, through the creation of a tourist brand "Destiny(s) Europe", this points out paths worthy of prominence and support. This is the case with the enhancement of coastal and maritime tourism, which accounts for more than 1/3 of the maritime economy, with direct implications in other sectors of the Union economy, employing 3.2 million people, mostly young people aged 16 to 35, who have been a lever for growth and job creation, particularly in the Atlantic and Mediterranean regions. I also note the recognition of the importance of connectivity and accessibility in the outermost and island regions that depend on maritime and air transport and the consequent defence of actions aimed at reducing the impact of seasonality in these regions. For the reasons mentioned above and by the reasons, both in the reasons and in the provisions of the resolution, it makes perfect sense that tourism should henceforth deserve treatment more consistent with its true social and economic importance. In the same vein, the Union must walk the path of global affirmation of this sector by valuing its contribution to the sustainable development of Europe and its regions.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – The tourism sector contributes significantly both to the economic development of the whole Union and to the promotion of the economy and competitiveness of the Member States. Although Europe remains the world's leading tourist destination, its tourism industry faces increasing competition as emerging, more economic countries attract tourists from around the world. In order for the EU to cope with this competition, I am of the opinion that the EU should highlight its comparative advantages, in particular the diversity of its landscapes and regions, its exceptional cultural wealth, and, respectively, member states should promote policies that strengthen the tourism sector and, by extension, their economy, making the most of the EU's new financial potential. However, in countries such as Greece, where tourism is a heavy industry with a far-reaching economic impact on employment and social and cultural development, fiscal adjustment measures, such as increasing VAT on some islands, are affecting the competitiveness of these regions, which are directly affected by low-cost tourism developing in neighbouring third countries. Furthermore, I believe that the EU should ensure financial support for the sector in coastal areas, which are strongly affected by the refugee crisis.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question referred to the Commission by Michael Cramer on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism on the development of satellite technology for systems enabling global monitoring of flights (O-000118/2015 - B8-1101/2015) (2015/2857(RSP)).

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. On behalf of the Committee on Transport, I would like to briefly present the question on the oral answer to satellite-based positioning systems for air traffic: numerous tragedies in air transport have shown the weaknesses of the current system and have highlighted the need for accurate and constant positioning of aircraft. We remember the tragic history of Malaysian Airlines 370 flight and air france 447 and many others. Only 30% of the world's airspace is covered by today's tracking systems. This hinders rescue and recovery. So there is a need for action. And one of the most promising options is to locate with satellites, that is, the automatic dependence surveillance broadcast. This technology enables better control and management of air traffic, above all more safety, but also more efficiency and control and less infrastructure costs. So: a win-win-win-win situation. Our committee is convinced that the rules need to be reconsidered in order to save lives. The International Organisation for Civil Aviation (ICAO) also shares our concerns. The Committee and ICAO are therefore both asking the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) to allocate a spectrum of spectrum at the World Conference in Geneva this November. We have clear questions from our committee: what does the Commission think about satellite-based positioning systems? And what does the Commission think of the call for the necessary frequency bands to be allocated at the World Conference in November to enable such systems? We look forward to hearing your reply, Commissioner.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, allow me to address you for the fourth time today with an equally important topic. The Commission considers that satellite-based technology for global flight tracking is a positive development. In the aftermath of the June 2009 accident involving Air France flight 447, Europe launched extensive work on options both for tracking aircraft and for localising an airplane in distress. The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight 370 in March 2014 has contributed to fast-tracking of the regulatory process at EU level.  A committee opinion delivered on 9 July 2015 endorsed the Commission’s proposal to amend Commission Regulation (EU) No 965/2012 regarding requirements for flight records, underwater locating devices and aircraft tracking systems. Both in terms of legislation and research our work is performance—based. This means that it does not favour any specific commercial or technical solution as long as the technology used by operators is fit for the desired purpose. Our rules will both provide the necessary flexibility and accommodate a number of technical options – existing ones as well as future ones such as Galileo Search and Rescue and/or satellite-based ADS, type B. Such rules, supported by the Member States, would be based on the following three principles: First, the requirements must be technologically neutral and performance based. They will be defined to ensure that large public transport aircraft automatically transmit sufficient trajectory information regularly and accurately enough for search and rescue and investigation purposes. Second, provided that the relevant equipment can be operated safely, the requirement should specify that it should have a backup power supply and it should not be possible to disable the flight tracking functions. This apparently occurred during the Malaysia Airlines flight. Third, the requirements must allow air carriers and aircraft manufacturers to opt for the most cost-efficient solutions.  The text of the Commission proposal has already been submitted to the European Parliament and Council for scrutiny. On that basis, comprehensive legislation should be adopted and published before the end of the year. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) is also updating international rules accordingly. Furthermore, we are working actively to provide passengers with Internet connections, both terrestrial and satellite solutions. Such systems can support advanced data communication between air and ground. This will eventually make it possible for flights to be fully monitored in real time from the ground. To return to the subject of space—based ATSB technology, although this remains an interesting   option, the Commission would like to underline that it is one of several possible solutions. The Commission has set out various options in a technical working paper provided to ICAO. Concerning the Commission’s position at the World Radio Communication Conference, the European Union as such does not have voting rights in the ITU. On Monday, 26 October the Council adopted conclusions for the World Radio Communication Conference, but this topic is not addressed. We therefore welcome the European Parliament resolution and we will work together with Member States at the World Radio Communication Conference to ensure that it is coherently supported during the negotiations.  To sum up, the Commission supported the protection of ADS type B at the World Radio Communication Conference and consequently in the ITU radio regulation. We also know that during the preparations for the World Radio Communications Conference Member States signalled their support for allocation for satellite reception of automatic dependent surveillance broadcast ATSB emissions from aircraft limited to messages transmitted in accordance with ICAO standards. That will conclude my report.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I regret to mention the two sad events, two plane crashes, one in the Atlantic, the other in the Pacific. One of the planes was located after years of searching, the other has not been found yet. The reason is the absence of a system to ensure a global and permanent tracking of flights, the positioning of aircraft is possible only in 30% of the airspace. The oceans and part of Africa are not covered due to the lack of technical possibilities, i.e. the lack of terrestrial equipment.  A non-performing and expensive system which records a relatively accurate position of aircraft at large intervals and results in inefficient use of airspace shall be used. We have at hand a technical solution that can provide global coverage, the ADS-B, a system that is already used on the basis of terrestrial equipment and can be used in the future based on satellite systems. Changes to aircraft are minimal. There is a need for a frequency band to be allocated by the International Telecommunication organisation at the World Radio communication conference. The conference will take place in November 2015. The next one's in four years. It is obvious that this allocation must be made this year in order not to lose another four years. The use of the new system brings an important security addition to air transport, a highly effective tool for rescue actions, as well as an optimisation of flights in general and, in particular, trans-oceanic ones. The ESA and ICAO support this solution and have expressed themselves in this regard.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, regulatory bodies, industry and citizens are agreed that aircraft tracking by satellite must be improved urgently. The successful and growing European satellite industry is ready to play its part.  Lack of sufficient allocation of radio spectrum is only one of the barriers in this area, but it is a very significant one. This is not just about search and rescue operations, but it is also about increasing the ability to help aircraft avoid poor weather and to help them take less environmentally-damaging and shorter routes. The International Air Transport Association has effectively already supported reviewing and extending spectrum allocations. This is something we should do. Travellers and families need this extra reassurance and confidence in airline systems. I welcome this oral question and I would urge colleagues in plenary to support the resolution.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Madam President, I welcome the question that has been tabled by our colleague, Michael Cramer. I think it has come at a very appropriate time. Ironically, I raised this issue of radio spectrum for the aviation sector more than 13 years ago. That was when I was on the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). The reason at that time was the growth of mobile phones and it was actually before Galileo, so we have certainly moved on apace. That is exactly what technology has done. Therefore, we must be in a position where we can benefit from these advanced sophisticated systems for tracking flights. Air accident investigators worldwide are trusted by the public to investigate air accidents and incidents absolutely fully. It is therefore our responsibility to provide them with the tools to do the job. So we welcome the debate on this topic, rapporteur, and we are certainly supporting you in the ECR Group.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it goes without saying that we support the question and, indeed, we were involved in co-drafting it. What the Commissioner has said today shows that the Commission is making every effort, and that is definitely appreciated by my group. Secondly, Commissioner, you have reassured us that the aviation package that will be submitted at the beginning of December will definitely provide the necessary proposal. Looking at your three key elements: in relation to back-up supply, there can be no doubt; on technological neutrality, I would say, yes, and obviously we will be looking too at the impact assessment; but the key issue is absolute interoperability. You also spoke about cost-efficient solutions: for me this means not the cheapest but rather the most proportionate and appropriate to deliver. Finally, a remark on the question of regularity: we should be aiming at the shortest possible frequencies in this respect. In relation to the spectrum, I think I can fall into line with other colleagues.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Of course, I also support Mr Cramer's proposal. I would now like to devote my speaking time this time to General and Business Aviation. I believe that, in the end, we must extend this system to small aircraft. The French aviation authority, for example, has highlighted in its study that an average of 15 accidents occur each year. In 50% of cases, there are ultimately fatalities. I believe that there is already potential for further serious accidents, which we must, of course, prevent and avoid.  I therefore call for us to introduce this ADSB system across the board. Incidentally, in 2008 the European Parliament has already called for an own-initiative report on Sustainable Future in General and Business Aviation. To date, nothing has come out of this, or the Commission has not come in that direction. That is why We are once again calling for the European Commission to take action here.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, aviation safety is directly linked to air navigation systems, which allow us to identify and detect when aircraft are also in difficulty. Currently, these flight tracking systems only cover about 30 % of the world's airspace, obviously leaving areas devoid of surveillance, such as the oceans and forests. According to ICAO, the ADS-B satellite system will reduce the vulnerabilities of current navigation systems while increasing air traffic efficiency and management capacity. My question to the Commission is whether it has already assessed the possible safety problems of the ADS-B system itself and whether it already has a set timetable for examining the application of this ADS-B system in European airspace.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the air tragedies in Europe bring to mind bad memories and the loss of hundreds of our fellow human beings. The causes of air accidents are almost always unsolved and without anyone knowing the causes of these air accidents. Today, in the age of the digital age and technologies, it is unacceptable for only 30% of airlines to provide flight tracking systems. This technology will help governments, air navigation service providers and airlines to increase the efficiency of air traffic management, while significantly increasing aviation safety. The Commission should adopt immediate measures to make global use of the system under discussion, while ensuring that human rights are not violated and that the sovereign rights of States are respected.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission wishes to thank the European Parliament and the honourable Member Mr Cramer for this question, which reflects the specific worries and expectations of a great number of European citizens. We fully support steps in the direction of global flight tracking, such as the ADS-B (Automatic Dependent Surveillance – Broadcast) system, and we look forward to further steps being taken on the basis of the legislative work I outlined in my introductory remarks. I hope that this clarifies the efforts being made by the Commission for the definition of commonly acceptable safe and cost-efficient solutions for global flight tracking. We look forward to close collaboration with Parliament and the Council for the timely adoption of the proposed specific legislation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: A motion for a resolution was sent to me at the conclusion of the debate. The debate is over. The vote will take place on 29 October 2015. (The sitting was suspended until polling time at 11.25 a.m. and resumed at 11.35 a.m.) Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I would like to raise two questions. The first is how do you see trade security? We need to ensure that all interactions and data exchanged between pilots, aircraft and air traffic control are protected: hacking and other sabotage attempts are becoming more frequent, yet we hardly ever talk about them. The threat exists.  Secondly: the use of this new technology will most certainly generate a new demand in industrial matters. So can Europe capitalise on its know-how to promote these technologies in this new market? I believe that, but there needs to be political impetus. Big projects are born of big ideas, especially in the space and aeronautics field.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The Conference of Presidents took a decision this morning on the award of the Sakharov Prize in 2015. I would like to inform you that this year's Conference of Presidents wishes to award the Sakharov Prize to the Saudi blogger Raif Badawi. (Loud and sustained applause) Ladies and gentlemen, I thank the House for its support for this decision. Today, because of the particular case of Mr Badawi, I add an exceptionally courageous and, I think, exemplary man who has been punished with one of the cruellest sentences that exists in this country, which objectively can only be described as brutal torture. I hereby call on the King of Saudi Arabia to pardon Mr Badawi immediately and release him so that he can receive the prize. (Loud applause) Relations between the Member States of the European Union and the institutions of the Union, with our partner countries, also depend in their quality on the respect of fundamental human rights by our partners. In the case of Mr Badawi, fundamental human rights are not only not respected, they are trampled underfoot. I therefore call on the King to stop the execution of the sentence today, to release Mr Badawi, to let him return to his wife and to allow him to receive the prize at the December part-session here in this House.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, yesterday I raised the issue of ghost voting by Marine Le Pen, co-chair of the ENF Group. I would like to inform the Chamber about the results of the investigation. I would like to thank the plenary service for their professionalism and fast reaction and I would like to call on the President to make full use of Rule 166 in association with Rule 177 which clearly states that the vote is personal and that every parliamentarian is responsible for his vote. (Applause)

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, in my absence yesterday I was questioned in an absolutely abject manner by Mr Weber, accused of facts of which I am absolutely innocent, which was revealed at this morning's Conference of Presidents. Mr. Weber committed two offences: defamation against me and slanderous denunciation, in this case without any evidence. So what happened yesterday that justifies this cinema? I left with my voting card. That is what dozens of Members of Parliament are doing, and you are well aware. We put our card at the beginning of the session and remove it at the end of the session. But do you not have any arguments, seriously, than this one? My colleague, Mr De Graaff, whom I would like to say is an unfailing example of courtesy and ethics, believed that I had left for a few seconds and did vote four votes in my absence and without my permission. He committed a clumsiness there, it is true. Does that justify, again, this cinema?  And I want to say one thing, my dear colleagues: he showed, thinking I had gone for a few seconds, to the chivalrous spirit which you would do well from time to time to inspire you. So, Mr President, I reserve my action and I intend to file a complaint against Mr Weber, who has made unbearable accusations against me.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ladies and gentlemen! The subject was discussed today in the Conference of Presidents. Manfred Weber, who has just been mentioned here, now has the floor. (Unrest in the Hall)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Whether this statement by Mr Le Pen is sitting in his seat stunned. It is not in any way that we have seen here from the right. (Applause) Mrs Le Pen, I would like to thank Mrs Le Pen for her We know that you do not have a proper understanding of democracy. We all know that here in this House. But first of all, I would like to try to give you tutoring. In a democracy, the mandate we have been given by the citizens is sacred – sacred! (Interjections from Ms Le Pen and others) Mrs Le Pen, a democracy also involves listening. In democracy, the mandate is sacred, and we have been given it by our citizens. And this mandate cannot be passed on, it cannot be delegated to anyone else. In some countries of the European Union, this transfer of mandates is a criminal offence and can be enforced by the courts. Thank God that is not the case for you in Europe at the moment, thank God. We see it as a sacred thing to defend this mandate. You have put a major scandal on your shoulders here. We support our President in taking all legal action against you. (Applause)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Ladies and gentlemen! This morning, this incident was the subject of discussions at the Conference of Presidents. He will now be transferred to Parliament's body, where he will be examined, namely to Parliament's Bureau. Mrs Corazza Bildt can be sure that we will comply with all the relevant provisions of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I welcome a delegation of the Peshmerga military units of the Kurdistan Autonomous Region of Iraq, led by General Jafar Ali, to the official gallery.  General Ali is accompanied by Katoon Al Kheder, the commander of the Yazidi female units. These soldiers fight the Islamic State every day. They deserve our recognition and solidarity. (Loud applause)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: In the subsequent explanations of vote, we shall begin with those statements which could not be dealt with on Tuesday. This is followed by the explanations of vote on the items voted on yesterday and today. I must inform you that we have received a great many requests for oral statements. The sitting will last until 1.30 p.m. Further explanations of vote may then be submitted in writing.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Of course, I supported the new rule, which was necessary because of the actions of the dear leader, Mr Juncker. Everyone remembers the LuxLeaks scandal. In this context, we have voted, or the European Parliament has provided, that from now on each Member State must notify the other Member States of the tax advantages it receives from the various foreign investors it receives. This is necessary, so to speak, in order to balance competitiveness. I would also like us to vote in the following on what kind of help they provide, what tax incentives they provide to their own small businesses, for example in my own country in Hungary, where 6 million HUF is given to a foreign, global polluting, exploitative company for the creation of a job. I would like to see competitiveness balanced here and given the same to small entrepreneurs and family entrepreneurs.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur An effectively functioning national community (this is particularly true of the euro area because of its single currency) is not possible without a qualitative exchange of information. Of course, it is understandable that any country has different types of specific data, the exchange of which, even with the closest Allies, would not be quite logical, as it would endanger national security. In the case of tax information, particularly within the European Union, which is by its very nature aimed at closer cooperation and mutual integration, the situation is much more unequivocal. Member States should exchange at least cross-border tax rulings and arrangements for the setting of transfer prices. In view of the European Union's focus on the fight against active tax fraud, such an exchange of information would allow it both to increase the effectiveness of the action in this way and, in principle, to make cooperation between Member States in the financial field much better.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I was living in Brussels when the French Government introduced its 75% top rate tax, and my street very quickly filled up with French exiles, Brussels being not far by train.
