There was only one Belgian woman left, a matriarch of the street who I knew, and I remember her stopping me one day as I was leaving the house and saying, ‘You’re in politics, Monsieur le Député, explain something to me: what kind of hell are these poor souls fleeing from if they regard Belgium as a paradis fiscale?’  What the Hollande government had learned is that high punitive taxes do not redistribute wealth: they redistribute people. Behind this report, instead of a look at why we have a problem with people fleeing to friendlier tax jurisdictions, is an attempt to brand them as tax havens and to attack them. Surely it is we who have the problem, and the solution is in our hands. If we could cut tax to a more acceptable level, not only would we boost our prosperity, but the issue of tax havens would disappear.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the effects of cross-border tax evasion and the effects of unfair tax competition have increased in recent years. Now, Member States do not spontaneously communicate their own tax rulings.  This report is very good because it defines the tax decision; a confirmation or assurance that the tax authorities give to taxpayers in relation to the way their taxes are calculated, precisely so that the lack of transparency does not reduce the tax contribution. Tax revenues are considerably reduced and prevent Member States from applying fiscal policies leading to economic growth. Who loses? Obviously, we are losing, citizens, because we are taxed more on products. Transparency is a key issue in the exchange of information and, as such, all information must be made available to the Member States in order to take action against these practices, namely tax evasion.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am very much in favour of these proposals and obviously I supported them. I think we have now – moving away from the crisis – looked at some of the malpractices that went on over many years, in particular in relation to tax evasion and tax avoidance, and we are moving towards correcting the loopholes. I welcome that, and the mandatory exchange of information will make it much more difficult for businesses to avoid tax – something which happened far too frequently in the past and which was very unfair to businesses and to individuals who were paying their tax. I am glad to say that my own country, Ireland, was one of the early movers in relation to international initiatives on the automatic exchange of tax information, being the fourth country in the world to sign a Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) agreement with the United States, which it did during Ireland’s presidency of the European Council.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur While it is undeniable that more effective results can be achieved, especially given that by 2020 our Member States are planning to increase their scientific investment to at least one and a half per cent of their GDP, the European Union is already in the position of world leaders in terms of investment in technological development and science in general. In particular, the Artemis Joint Undertaking focuses on the development of high-tech embedded computer systems and the development of formats for their use. Since this type of computer system is used in the automotive industry, industrial automation, telecommunications, various types of electronic and health, medical equipment, as well as much elsewhere, the need for investment in general and the importance of the existence of this joint venture should not be underestimated. I am quite pleased that, within the framework of the 2013 budget, Artemis was found to be sufficiently successful.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the more we learn about life and the universe, the more we realise that things are unplanned, spontaneous and organic – not just evolution itself, but language, society, law and technology. Only the European Union – or, rather, only a large and remote state – would presume to have an agency that could control the development of computing, cyber—crime and all the rest of it. These things by definition cannot be run from the centre. That is why they are so successful – precisely because they are decentralised, unplanned and crowd-sourced. ARTEMIS is a rather neat metaphor for what is wrong with the entire European economy. If you try and run these things from the centre – be you the best, wisest and most disinterested people – you cannot, lacking a panoptic view of what is going on, possibly equal the invigilation of a million consumers, each making a self—interested and rational decision.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: "My heart was broken when we voted on the European Institute of Innovation. It doesn't seem like a very emotional report, but it still breaks my heart, because it is a Budapest-based organisation that deals with innovations and innovations, what could be more worthy of its place than Budapest.  Hungarians invented the ballpoint pen, Hungarians invented matches. Recently, Hungarians invented the tumor identification scalpel, which is to distinguish (rubik's cube, thank you very much, my colleague here) from the cancer cell, the tumor cell, from the healthy cell during surgery. What is very sad, however, is that our accession to the European Union has not promoted, promoted, promoted these innovations, these intellectual creations, but has set us back because of the disastrous European industrial property provisions, and we have become a country built on assembly plants, rather than implementing our wonderful inventions and making a living from Hungary.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The european Institute of Innovation and Technology has been aiming for seven years now, as we know, to promote the competitiveness of The Member States by stimulating technological innovation in the scientific, educational, business sectors of the Member States. And the main objective of the action is the pooling of excellent university research centres and companies and the motivation and coordination of their cooperation. An important aspect of this activity is that cross-border public-private partnerships are being formed. The report we voted on, incidentally, noted that the European Institute of Innovation and Technology would provide resources through the appropriate use and effective disposal of the financial contributions made to it. On the other hand, there is a problem of staff turnover, which the Institute is nevertheless gradually addressing. But overall, I very positively welcome this report and look forward to further results from the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, these discharge votes are kind of tedious. They are especially tedious for you. You are taking it in good cheer and you are being courteous and friendly, as always, but here we are, one after another, basically having the same argument about every one of these quangos and institutions. There is always some improper spending, there is always some waste – not because they are European but because they are quangos. It happens at every level. It happens at national level. The reason it happens is because they know that the oversight is limited to an occasional debate here involving people who, for the first time, have looked up what these agencies are, have no idea where they are and have never visited them. And so you have a situation where the employees, not being answerable to anyone, can concentrate on making themselves comfortable. Human nature being what it is, that is what goes on – and thus we have built this great corpus of interest of people who want to carry on with the project, not because of any great philosophical or idealistic attachment to it, but because it has become a handy way to make a living. Would we all not be better off – you and me and the interpreters who could go home – if we simply cut out a number of these agencies?

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Thank you, Mr President. The ENIAC Joint Undertaking, like the Artemis Joint Undertaking, merged and dealt with, is engaged in the preparation and subsequent implementation of a research programme aimed at fostering innovation in nanoelectronic skills with a view to its application in a wide range of practical areas. The Joint Undertaking was set up at the end of 2007, listing both the European Commission and the Association for Nanoelectronics Activities, as well as 13 Member States of the European Union. Unfortunately, my country, Latvia, was not on this list, although it is currently a member of ENIAC. Looking at the ENIAC budgets over the last few years, it can be seen that Latvia is quite inactive in the potential use of this joint venture compared to other countries. Given that in my country currently only 0.6% of GDP is invested in innovation and ... (the time allowed for the speaker expires)

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I could make the same speech for every single one of these, could I not? They have all got the same basic problem and it would be tedious for you and tedious for everyone else, so I am just going to repeat the basic point. Who would miss these agencies, these quangos, if they disappeared? If, by some terrible freak of nature they were all wiped out in asteroid strikes, would any of our constituents feel a deleterious impact on their quality of life? Rather than standing up and making this speech for every other discharge vote, I am going to call it a day at this one, and leave Members with the thought that we would all be much happier and wealthier and freer if we had fewer of these people telling us what to do.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much! I now take this as an invitation to simply skip you in the next reports where you are still on the list. I wish you a good journey home!

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The European Union has been built, reformed, developed for decades, in a structure that requires close and active cooperation between its governing bodies for the effective functioning of the union.  Firstly, it concerns specifically the European Commission, including the European Parliament, the Council of Ministers or the Council and the European Council, and it is perfectly understandable that often representatives of each institution, politicians or bureaucratic officials have their own interests, which they seek to proponiate and realise. However, they must not in any way harm the normal functioning of the Union, which also applies to the implementation of budgetary rules in the present case. As can be seen from the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control under scrutiny, the financial cooperation between the Council and the European Parliament is rather insufficient, and according to the european Union's primary legislative documents, it is the European Parliament that has to approve the Annual Budget of the Union, and that is what we did.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, and this year we refused to grant discharge to the Council and to the European Council for 2013. This is the seventh year in a row that the European Parliament has refused to discharge the Council and the European Council. And that's because the Member States that make up the Council refuse to provide Parliament with data on how they spent the money. It is claimed, pitifully, a gentlemen's agreement of 1970 which states that the Member States and Parliament will never control each other.  The world has changed, we already have an article in the treaty which states that Parliament must control how money is used by all the European institutions, therefore, including the Council. The problem is that after seven years we refuse discharge, but the Council is still functioning. So we have to do something else to stop this state of illegality, for example, not to approve their budget.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, let me explain why I voted in favour of the report on the lessons learned from the Ebola crisis. Indeed, we would not have to approve some of the initiative reports, but this report was very important because tens of thousands of people were victims of Ebola, and this report is very critical of the way in which the international community has approached the solution. On the other hand, it is clear that the European Union has been an important partner and has donated almost EUR 2 billion, and will continue to contribute to addressing and, in the future, preventing such epidemics. The important thing is that the solution must be systemic. Public health care in those countries most affected by the virus is called for. I think it's good news.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Thank you, Mr President. While the fight against the Ebola virus is still ongoing, I am pleased that Parliament voted in favour of the report prepared by the Committee on Development. It should, however, be of great regret that ebola-like epidemics are also shaken up by different regions of the world today, and this is particularly true of developing countries, firstly Africa. In this context, I am happy to share the positive attitude of the report, both with regard to the recent and already effective vaccine fight against Ebola and the 10% increase in the World Health Organisation's budget. This will help both to respond more effectively to this type of threat, to prevent the onsuer attacks themselves, and to counter epidemics that have already flared as possible. The European Union is the world's primary donor of financial and expert assistance to developing countries, and this is undoubtedly a very important achievement.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, I supported this report because I share the opinion of many experts who claim that the recent Ebola epidemic surprised us and that, both as Europe, but also within the United Nations, we could have done much more about preventing and controlling the spread of the disease, as 28,515 people were sickened and as many as 11,313 people died. Although the potential and danger of the haemorrhagic fever virus has been known for years and this epidemic has been repeated every so often in this part of Africa, I believe that since the last epidemic, that is, since 2001 in Uganda, more work has been done on education and prevention measures.  Assistance to developing countries is therefore crucial to ensure that epidemics are stopped and acted on in a swift and effective manner. Necessary and necessary training of personnel, development of systems, exchange of data, reconstruction of the infrastructure of the health system and education of the population on ways of infection and on prevention from its spread.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, one minute is not enough to do justice to the subject of the long—term lessons that we can take from the Ebola crisis. We need to be constructively critical – not just of the European Union, but also of our national governments. Firstly, the slow response to the crisis was a big problem internationally. Secondly, our westernised way of thinking quite often got in the way of finding the right solutions, which are often the quickest solutions to get something onto the ground. The charitable sector, the NGOs, actually understood this a lot better than we did in the West and in politics quite often. Thirdly, the myths that we saw in the media about Ebola – the way that people got an impression that was very different from the reality – was something which acted as a stumbling block. The media needs to be far more responsible than it was. Finally, there is an issue of money and the medical research that needed to be going into that, but sadly it was not sufficiently profitable for the drug companies. There are many, many reasons why we need to learn from that crisis.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – We do not yet know exactly what will be revealed in the context of manipulations in the automotive industry, I am thinking of emissions and air pollution data, but unfortunately it is almost certain that a large number of workers who are completely innocent of this matter, in the manipulations, will be made redithed in this context. I think that the European Union should already start thinking carefully and set up special committees for us to be the doers. For example, how do we determine and who determines responsibility? In law, the most important issue is always the settlement of responsibilities. Who will stand up for the lost jobs of these workers, the livelihoods of their families and all that? Unfortunately, in the case of my country, you have to be self-critical. Governments that have consistently at the mercy of these foreign companies since the regime change are also responsible, rather than developing domestic industry and agriculture.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The creation and existence of an effectively functioning society and its appropriate economic structure is inconceivable without citizens' trust in the providers of goods and services, which undoubtedly also applies to information on the characteristics of any product. In particular, in this case, it is rather regrettable that Volkswagen unfairly acted in diesel engine emission tests on the US market. I therefore agreed to the need to organise a thorough examination of the European Union markets, both in the case of Volkswagen and other car manufacturers and for diesel and petrol-engined vehicles. Given that it is vehicles of different types that are one of the main factors affecting public health and the climate, productive and regular cooperation between colleagues is very important, in particular cooperation between the responsible Member States and the Institutions of the European Union in terms of information exchange and the initiation of quality standards.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, I supported this Resolution because I believe that falsifying data for fraud by competent supervisory authorities and customers undermines trust and undermines the hard-earned reputation of the European automotive industry globally. Millions of employees and their family members across Europe depend on the industry and the whole sector.  Illicit and irresponsible behaviour should be severely sanctioned and test methods adapted to the needs of today. I am pleased that the European Commission is preparing a new act on emission measurement in real driving conditions. I regret that the possibility of fraud was not taken seriously enough, and fraud was detected in time, in order to preserve the clean face of European industry, but also european climate policy. In the situation we are in, we need to work together to restore trust in the European automotive industry. We will achieve this by supporting the deterrent penalties that fraudsters will have to face and by establishing appropriate investigations that will give the right state of emissions in real driving conditions.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I finally supported the joint motion for a resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive industry. The investigation into the whole case is not yet over, but it is now clear that some car concerns will pay the full cost, despite the fact that, for example, the Volkswagen Group has taken the appropriate steps from the point of view of customers. Our Political Group of the European People's Party has called for real-world emissions tests, while maintaining sufficient flexibility for the automotive industry to adapt technically. I regret that this amendment, which would have helped flexibility, was not supported. It is good that the final resolution calls for the introduction of a globally harmonised test procedure for light vehicles, so that there cannot be a situation where cars meet the standard in Europe but do not meet this standard in the US. It is therefore necessary to avoid these standards becoming the subject of trade wars and competition.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, this is a situation where, fundamentally, I voted against not because of a matter of sovereignty per se, but also because I think that we are taking the wrong approach. We need to take a carrot—not—stick approach to improving emissions. I look for example at various tax breaks and incentives which have been tried to make things cheaper for the consumer when they choose more efficient vehicles, and that is something which works very well indeed in practice. So I take the view that the carrot—not—stick approach works better.  The actions of Volkswagen were clearly appalling. The question is, was this something which was known about well in advance, and if so, why was it not brought to light much sooner? Finally, I would say that obsessing over the single measure of CO2 within the environment is something which we have done time and time again, and when we obsess about that one measure and forget – in the case of diesel, for example – the NOx and SOx emissions, we end up with a lopsided environmental policy when we need balance.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I voted against the European Union budget for 2016. How can someone vote as a politician on a budget issue when they don't know anything about mathematics, they don't know anything about numbers? After all, let's be honest, after all, the budget is a huge set of numbers. Well, by looking at the organizing principles that can be identified behind these sets of numbers. In our case, the question must be asked whether this is a money-driven and profit-driven budget that wants to push profits at all costs most to large global companies, banks and others, or whether it is a people-centred budget, which asks what is good for the people, the people that the politician represents, in this case small businesses, family entrepreneurs, smallholders. And given that this budget is clearly the budget of large multi-corporations and banks, that is why I voted against it.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is scandalous that EU budgets should be used to subsidise the rearing and keeping of bulls for bullfighting. It is important to know that every year around 30 000 of these animals die in agony in arenas. Fortunately, the vote here in Parliament has prevented the whole thing from happening. But this fact really gives us cause to think about the EU's policy and what is happening here in agriculture.  We are seeing that, step by step, the path is moving away from high-quality, and also very effective farming, to things which are being commercialised to a large extent, which, above all, also support large farms. Is this what we want? We must bear in mind that if you have several thousand animals in a stable, you can't get through without antibiotics. That chemistry must be used at these large farms. Do we want that?

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make two comments on the 2016 budget, which was fine overall. The first is that I believe that we have not prepared ourselves sufficiently for the financial challenges that could arise as a result of the asylum problem. I would have liked a budget line or a safety line.  Secondly, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Development, I have two comments to make. On the one hand, I was a little annoyed that the Committee on Budgets rejected all the suggestions made by the Committee on Agriculture. We were very responsible. Our suggestions were hardly paid for. The housekeeper would say that they were in the blurring area, and yet, unfortunately, all our suggestions have not been taken up by the Committee on Budgets. I very much regret that. But I conclude from this that we need to have a better conversation next year.  And to the previous speaker on agricultural policy, I would like to say once again that we may once again be talking separately. Not everything that the previous speaker said was right.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus dar ndóigh tá an buiséad an-tábhachtach ar fad chun obair a dhéanamh agus chun rudaí a chur chun cinn. Tá sé tábhachtach do gach uile dhuine go mbeadh buiséad acu d’fhiontair, do na stáit agus don Aontas, ach faraor táimid ag brath go huile is go hiomlán ar na stáit dár mbuiséad go léir.  Dá bhrí sin is dóigh liom gur cheart dúinn féachaint arís ar airgead a sholáthar dúinn féin, go háirithe ‘own resources’ mar a thugtar orthu. Tá tosú déanta againn leis an FTT, ach ba chóir dúinn féachaint arís ar shlí éigin chun airgead a fháil don Aontas gan a bheith ag brath ar na stáit uile. Rud eile ba mhaith liom a rá; is ábhar an-chasta é seo agus bhíos  ag éisteacht le mo chara agus comhghleacaí, an Feisire Fernandes, go háirithe sna grúpaí agus sa Pharlaimint ag caint faoi agus tá moladh mór ag dul dó agus do na daoine eile atá ag obair ar an ábhar seo.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Firstly, I would like to welcome a timely process for examining next year's draft budget. I am pleased that the European Union is not among the countries or supranational bodies that often accept their budgets with serious delays of up to half a year, if not more, when they leave the year to which the budget was concerned.  But secondly, competitiveness, job growth, regional development, sustainable growth and security - to a large extent, are the most important areas of the European Union's activities - play an important role in the new budget. At the same time, I would also like to mention the efforts of the responsible authorities, the Commission, the Council and Parliament, to rationalise expenditure, including the structure of such relevant jobs in the bureaucratic apparatus of the Union. It should be noted, however, that, as part of increasing the efficiency of this spending of financial resources, one of the necessary areas for the effective functioning of the European Union must not be tolerated.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – I voted against the budget because the budget is increased compared to last year, and I promised that I would never vote in favour of an increase in the budget. Furthermore, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I have been puzzled by this report on how to vote on the question of whether more judges should be brought before the Court of Justice of the European Union. As a lawyer, I experience how much people suffer from the slowness of the judiciary, so my first reaction was yes, of course, there should be more judges, because then the proceedings will be faster. Then I remembered my most wonderful teacher from law school, who happened to be a judge, and who, with twinkling eyes, repeatedly told us the following: remember, dear colleagues, that it is the real judge who sees a just solution in a case and, if necessary, does not sleep for three days, three nights until a legal solution is found to support a just solution. Now, in European Union law, justice as such is not an aspect, not a directing principle, and consequently it does not matter how many judges provide the right not related to justice. So I voted no.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Thank you, Mr President. It has already been noted on several occasions that the European Union is one of the most bureaucratic bodies in the world. Consequently, on the one hand, to increase the number of judges before the Court of Justice of the European Union for the only reason that each Member State has the opportunity to delegate its own judge, as if it is absurd. On the other hand, however, colleagues, let us remember that the right to justice is one of the most sacred rights in the European Union and, if the European Court of Justice works effectively, well and for the benefit of European citizens, it will benefit both all people, all citizens of the European Union, and the image of the European Union throughout the world. Consequently, I was very pleased to support the proposed reform, which was to some extent a compromise, and I was happy to vote in favour.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I voted against this proposal, even though my political faction supported this proposal. I believe that the increase in the onslaught on this judicial institution does not justify a political decision to double the number of judges. As Minister of Justice, I dealt with the burden on the courts in the Czech Republic, and when I calculated the onslaught and increase on the European Court of Justice, I believe that the number by which the number of judges was to be increased was and is much less than double. I even believe that we could have dealt with the whole thing by adding lawyers, assistants, assistants to individual judges, and that alone would lead to greater efficiency in this judicial institution. Doubling the number of judges is an unnecessary waste of money, and it is a political, not factual or even professional decision. This is also how the professional public perceives it.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – With regard to all decisions that promote the admission of GMOs, genetically modified food, I voted against, of course, which is to say yes to opting out. And then I asked myself, how do I even know how to do this? Well, that's a scientific question. It may be that my fellow citizens, who are visibly influenced by lobbying organisations and, well, large industry lobbies, are right to say that, but this is such a good thing, it is such an important thing, because it helps European farmers to be competitive. Then I realized it was a spiritual and deeply philosophical and philosophical issue. It's not just a little thing, whether it's GMO food or not. There are absolutely two worldviews colliding here. In one worldview, nothing but competitiveness and profit matters, and in the other worldview, the harmony of man, human dignity and created nature and man. That's the second one I believe in, which is why I voted this way.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I voted against the European Commission's proposal, which is why I want to explain my position. The European Commission has proposed that individual states should be able to restrict genetically modified food and feed on their territory. I am not a fan of genetically modified foods, I think that the public should approach this with a certain margin. But I think it is a problem that is to be adjusted at European level. Where appropriate, the European institutions are to tighten up the arrangements for authorising this type of food. The solution, in my opinion, is not to distort the internal market within the European Union and to allow some States to authorise GM food and others not to allow it in a situation where it is still not possible, thanks to non-existent internal borders, to examine where the food will then be exported from the countries where it will be authorised. The solution is not to give powers to individual states, but to tighten up and, where appropriate, revise the process at European level.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is usually the case that we are asking the Commission for legislative initiatives and that it sometimes takes the Commission quite a long time to deliver. Here it was the other way around. We have been presented with a directive that no one has ordered, which no one really needed and which was also unpractical. The ultimate aim was to preserve the common European internal market and make it practical. It was therefore right that a large majority of Parliament rejected this directive again. Because, of course, no matter how we view genetic engineering and how we look at the new technology, we must of course ensure that a patchwork does not arise and that the regions can then decide for themselves how they deal with genetic engineering. If we do something, if we want something, then the European level is in full demand here as a European internal market. We cannot make a case-by-case decision.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I attended the debate here in Parliament on this topic and I found it very enlightening. I must say that the rapporteur, Mr La Via, gave a good explanation of what was involved. I did not get to speak, but I am getting to speak now. I supported my group in the various votes. It is a difficult topic. It is actually not easy to be 100% certain that you are in favour of or against GMOs, but certainly one or two points occurred which I found interesting, namely that we are only producing 30% of our protein here in Europe. We have to import a lot of it to feed our livestock, and much of it comes from GMOs. If we take a decision not to have it, what is going to happen to the feedstock and what is going to happen to the competitiveness of Europe? But in the long term, citizens need reassurance, and for that we need absolutely independent, reliable research, especially in relation to health issues regarding GMOs.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Mankind has been engaged for several thousand years in transforming the characteristics of cultivated plants and pets according to their preferences – regional, climatic conditions, etc. And the use of modern, more than forty years of genetically modified organisms in agriculture is, in fact, a logical continuation of these skills developed throughout history. Of course, there are concerns in a number of countries and societies about the safety of the use of such organisms, firstly in the case of human health. But the reality is that Agriculture in the European Union is already to some extent dependent on imports of proteins affected by GMOs, so granting Member States the right to control imports and use of GMOs in their territories could harm the agricultural sector in one way or another.  Although it should also be noted that this applies, first of all, to non-organic farms where the use of GMOs is simply inconceivable.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, the European Commission has submitted a proposal that does not allow Member States to decide independently on the prohibition or restriction of the use of GENETICally modified food and feed on their territory. That is why I voted to reject this proposal and I ask the Commission to submit a new proposal to Parliament within a reasonable time. Given that there is no consensus at European Union level on this issue, I am in favour of Member States having the right to decide for themselves the use of GMO on their territory and it is imperative that this is made possible by the proposal for an act. I am satisfied, of course, that my amendment, tabled with other colleagues, was adopted, instructing the Commission to submit a new text of the proposal for a regulation.  This is important because today over 150 regions and 4 500 local government units across Europe have requested that they be given GMO-free status and can independently decide how they wish to approach this issue in their area. I also advocate that we as Members and the Commission, as well as the adopters in the Member States, listen more to the voice of the public and the voice of the peasants, and the voice of the public and the voice of the peasants is against the GMO.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, I supported the proposal to reject this Commission proposal on the use of genetically modified organisms because I believe that, in its current form, it will lead to malformations and problems in the functioning of the single market and may lead to the presence of GMOs where they are not desirable. The Commission's now formulated model will enable the use of GMO products in part of the European single market. However, in the framework of this free market, and the lack of border control mechanisms for imports and exports between individual Member States of the European Union, the proposal puts at risk Member States, including my country Bulgaria, which do not wish to use GMOs and products thereof on their territory. I support the call on the European Commission to produce a thorough analysis of the impact of the introduction of such a measure and to make a detailed proposal. It must meet the interests of the majority of Citizens of the European Union who are opposed to the use of genetically modified food and feed on the territory of their countries.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the request to reject the Commission's proposal shows that Parliament has played its role as co-legislator with dignity. We are talking about a proposal that is not accompanied by any impact assessment, which would create an excessive fragmentation of the internal market leading to distortions of competition against farmers in countries that are opposed to transgenicity. Not only that: the proposal, which, among other things, has elements that are not compatible with WTO rules, does not adequately protect European citizens and the environment from the risks arising from GMOs, as any national bans on their use would have been impossible to implement, according to the rules of the European Union's common market. I would like to remind you that last year we voted in favour of the new Commission on the basis of Mr Juncker's political programme, which promised to review the rules governing the authorisation of GMOs in Europe so that the Commission could no longer authorise GMOs in the event of a clear majority of states being against it. Although the Commission has indicated that it does not wish to withdraw the proposal, parliament has sent out a clear signal in this vote, and I hope that it will be taken into account.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I probably now have the opportunity to comment on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on in-food products. I supported this proposal for one simple reason. I believe that the new revised authorisation regime for new foods entering the European market at European level is something that strengthens the Internal Market of the European Union. And Here I support everything that leads to the completion and strengthening of the Internal Market of the European Union. It is, after all, one of the values that I, in the European Union, particularly respect and welcome. I supported this proposal, I am convinced that it will lead to a simplification, an acceleration, but also, according to food producers, the authorisation regime itself will become cheaper and there will be uniform rules for the whole European market.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, as you mention, Mr Nicholson was chosen as the rapporteur on this. He is a colleague of mine from Ireland and he is a sound, sensible guy, and when he proposes something he would not do so lightly. So, I had no problem in supporting this report. Essentially, it aims to ensure there is a proper evaluation and authorisation procedure, via a fully harmonised process, to protect the health of European citizens. We did not have many of these foods or food ingredients in the European Union prior to May 1997 but now, of course, we have many of them coming into Europe and they are innovative, they are newly developed and sometimes they are foods that are not used in Europe but are traditionally used in other countries. For these reasons it is important that we have proper regulation, and this regulation updates the categories of food which fall within the definition of novel foods and provides for the implementation of a centralised EU authorisation system to protect EU citizens.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Man is what he eats—it is a well-known expression of Ludwig Andreas von Feierbach. It is therefore perfectly logical for people to know exactly what they eat on a daily basis. Although, when a new food is introduced into the market, it has to undergo a number of different instances to make it clear that it can be allowed for citizens to consume it. Of course, any of us is a blacksmith of our own happiness and knows better than others what he eats and what not to eat. However, in the case of food to be sold in shops accessible to the public, it must undoubtedly undergo such an examination and certification procedure. And since more than 18 years have already passed since the entry into force of Regulation No 258/97, it is clear that the time has come to restore it in order to adapt it to new realities in both food production and consumer protection, and to the fact that the number of Member States has increased from 15 to 28 since 1997.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would just like to clarify that there was no final vote on this report yesterday, because Mrs Girling has taken the right to discuss this report. I'm ready to say my message, I just want to make sure it's valid. We voted yesterday on the amendments to this report, but there was no vote on the report as a whole. Then I'll give my reasoning if you give me space again. I would like to stress that I voted in favour of the amendments. I will therefore, with permission, comment on the course of the vote, because we voted on amendments that could have changed the committee's proposal. The proposal, as presented by the ENVI Committee, went further within emission limits than necessary. In contrast to the Commission's proposal, it also set targets after 2020, including the extent of the substances concerned. I was fundamentally opposed to setting emissions targets for methane and strict limits on ammonia, because these measures are superfluous and harm farmers. I am also sad that the committee has failed to adopt measures or amendments that would allow for greater flexibility for the Member States. I would just point out that in the end we did not vote on the proposal as a whole, I would not support it in any way as a whole.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am glad that we have not yet reached a final vote, because we will then have the opportunity to make corresponding improvements in the trialogue. What is it all about? I do not think anyone is against the fact that we want to improve air quality. But if we take such decisions, it is not just a question of improving statistics, but of real life. In other words, the objectives we set ourselves must be realistic. The previous speaker has just said that if we were to make the demand so recklessly to minimise methane emissions in agriculture, we would have to change the digestive conditions of ruminants, which is simply not possible and completely unrealistic. That was the good thing yesterday. We have therefore voted with great effort to reduce methane emissions in agriculture out of the motion. I am now putting it back to the trialogue to set realistic, achievable targets there. Once again, it is a question of improving the world, not statistics.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Every year, the world's atmosphere is polluted by huge quantities of different compounds. And not only with carbon dioxide, but with a negative impact on both human health and the economy. From national health costs to loss of overall productivity, reducing agricultural productivity. I warmly welcome the idea: this proposal for a directive, which aims to reform in this way the existing commitments of the Member States of the European Union to reduce emissions in the coming years and even decades, in order to take account of the relevant situation today and possible in the future with regard to sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, ammonia, methane and other emitted chemical compounds. But, given the very different situation since the beginning of the centenary, I consider it a logical and timely amendment of the emission directive, the Neg Directive.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Of course, I supported the report by my Hungarian colleague, Mr Schöpflin, in which he wanted to make it easier and more effective for citizens who want a say in the decisions of the European Union, one of the means of direct democracy. There is another such instrument, the petitions committee. I have an extremely painful and bitter experience with this, and I am a little ashamed to have proposed the use of this instrument to my compatriots in a very difficult situation, the victims of foreign currency lending, who have suffered from the fact that the banks have made them unbearable by grossly violating european Union consumer protection standards. They turned to the Committee on Petitions for my advice, they were here in Brussels, they were full of hope and the Committee on Petitions has not moved its ear for about seven months now. So much for European democracy and taking citizens seriously.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yesterday we voted on new rules for the European Citizens' Initiative. These are some good innovations, but they do not go far enough. Does not a European citizen who overcomes these huge hurdles for the citizens' initiative have the right either to deal with this and take a new legislative initiative, or to justify why this is not possible under the Treaties? But one principle of democracy is that all power comes from the people. And that is also important for the EU if we do not want to further frustrate the citizens, if we want to have a living democracy.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report on the European Citizens' Initiative. Unlike the authors, I do not think it is a great failure that, after three years, no initiative has yet succeeded, because, in my opinion, it should be an exceptional institute that should start the legislative process at European Union level. The problem is that in three cases citizens have already collected signatures, they have fulfilled the conditions and that the European Commission is not responding quickly enough and flexibly to the initiative. In my view, the problem is rather how to respond to a situation where citizens collect signatures and put a clear proposal on the table. And here I see the European Commission's mistake, and it should rather reflect on how it responds, not debate whether to change the rules at the moment – three years after the institute's effectiveness – when this initiative can be used. I hope that this too will be debated in 2016 if we have a debate on how to change the Citizens' European Initiative.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, during the campaign for the Lisbon Treaty to be passed by referendum in my country, I campaigned hard for a ‘yes’ vote. One of the planks of the campaign was that the Citizens’ Initiative would bring citizens closer to the European institutions and that they would be able to influence legislation, etc. Lo and behold, three years on, we have had 51 initiatives, but only three have been acted on! This is obviously not good enough. One of the problems – as explained to us by First Vice—President Timmermans – is that the Treaty does not allow the institutions to act in certain ways. But that is not good enough: it is time that we really looked at this and ensured that, if we have a Citizens’ Initiative system, then before people engage in getting a million signatures they should be told whether their initiative is actually admissible or not. The same point has been made by my colleague Ms Morvai in relation to the Committee on Petitions – because people build up their hopes, and then they are not able to follow through.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The governance structure of the European Union is closely interlinked and generally based on democratic principles, since it is the rightful citizens of the Union that are providers of its legitimacy, both in the case of the authorities of the Member States and in the transnational structures of the European Union, above all in the European Parliament. Consequently, in principle, the creation of a European citizens' initiative, the roots of which can be found earlier than 1 April 2012 (its date of entry into force), is one of the most important expressions of direct democracy in our community. The idea behind the Treaty of Lisbon that has already been mentioned is that one million citizens from at least a quarter of the EU Member States have the right to submit legislative proposals to the European Commission within one year in areas within its competence. Unfortunately, however, it must be acknowledged that the level of awareness among European citizens is very low, but, of course, the European Citizens' Initiative can be very positively assessed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that regional strategies can bring tangible benefits to the regions concerned, and the future of the Adriatic and Ionian region is crucial for the European Union. The European Union's strategy in this region must therefore be a great step forward for the development of these territories, and it must be able to add value to the interventions of community, national and regional authorities, as well as those of the private sector, in this area.  We cannot hide one issue: the strategy has particularly interesting prospects for the candidate countries and potential candidates. Although the Commission has repeatedly stated that there will be no further enlargement in the near future, the strategy will enable these countries to move closer to the Union, aligning their policies and working closely with the Member States. As the events of recent months have shown us, and in particular the refugee crisis, the Balkan area is of priority interest to Europe. Well, this strategy must equip this region with the tools it needs to become more stable.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur As part of the Mediterranean basin, the Adriatic and Ionian Islands, as part of the Mediterranean basin, continue to be one of the most important regions of Europe and its neighbours in trade, politics, cultural life and several other areas for some years now – from Phoenics, Greeks, Iwrians, Romans and many other peoples and their predecessors to the present day. I warmly welcome and support the establishment of a macro-regional strategy already initiated within the framework of the Third European Union. That is good. Given that the Adriatic and Ionian Seas also have the Western Balkans, a region that has experienced a national collapse, civil war, mass emigration, and economic devastation and other sorrows, the European Union's strategy could certainly contribute to the creation of a strong positive momentum in the region. But it is perfectly understandable that wounds are not so easy to heal and especially - to overcome. However, there is another instrument that could help on this difficult road, and that would be very useful.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to protest against the decision you have taken just now, understanding that there is time to end the October session. Nevertheless, I would like you to point out to me that the Vice-Presidents should take very responsible decisions. If they decide to resign on Tuesday and Wednesday, they close the possibility of using this procedure to all those who wish to use it, because it is clear that if we accumulate this procedure from these two or three days, we will not be able to serve all Members. This is very unfair to all those who, after today's vote, wanted to explain their decision as to why they voted in this way. All the more so because all the Members from Tuesday and Wednesday have been accepted, and unfortunately not on Thursday.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: You are absolutely right. Thank you for your remark.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I want to agree with my colleague. Particularly in an exceptional week like this, where we had no explanations of vote yesterday and we had to cram three days’ explanation of votes into less than an hour, it is not good enough. It is not your fault, Mr President. It is a decision taken by the Bureau, but it has to be reflected on. When MEPs are willing to stay here they should be given the opportunity to do so, especially as, normally, we would be here until 17.00 on a Thursday and it was decided we should finish at 13.30, even though MEPs wanted to stay and give their explanation of the votes. I know one can do it in writing, but if we were all going to do it in writing we could go home when the votes are over. It is not satisfactory, it is not democratic and it is certainly not fair to MEPs that this is the decision which has been taken. It has nothing to do with you, Mr President – you are only implementing what has been decided – but we would appreciate it if you would take this back to the Bureau. Certainly, in exceptional circumstances, it should be changed. We have a position today where we had votes on seven or eight issues and there is not even an opportunity for one person to give an explanation on today’s votes.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I entirely agree with you and I will inform the Bureau and personally inform President Schulz of your suggestion.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This report has a dual objective: on the one hand, to change the headquarters of CEPOL (European Police School) to Budapest following the UK's decision not to maintain facilities on its territory; and, on the other hand, give CEPOL the mandate set out in the Commission Communication on the training of agents. We have maintained that this is a decision focused on washing the image of the Hungarian Government, which, in an interested way, grants the facilities to house CEPOL for free for the first four years. We cannot support the more belligerent attitude towards migrants or minorities in their own country, by mobilizing their security forces to gas attack refugees, to host the training of security agents. In addition, we understand that the CEPOL Training Communication does not include sufficient content relating to fundamental and procedural rights, especially given how they have been systematically violated, particularly at our borders, and that is why we have been against it. For both reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This file sought to enhance the remit of CEPOL with a focus on strategic objectives, not exclusively training. The file also sought to enhance the autonomous nature of CEPOL and increase its funding. I, therefore, voted against this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The rapporteur takes note that effective and harmonious cross-border cooperation to combat organised and transnational crime is needed. According to him, the current situation justifies modernising the legal basis of CEPOL (European Police College), which is an EU agency responsible for the training of law enforcement services at European level. This reform aims to adapt CEPOL to the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty and to entrust the agency with the implementation of the new European programme on the training of law enforcement services (services that concern police, border guards, customs officers and prosecutors).  Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we believe that voting for this reform would be tantamount to endorsing the Schengen system. One does not go without the other: the disappearance of borders within the Schengen area requires this kind of European agency. For too long, however, the Schengen area has clearly shown its limits and its perversity. Today, in the face of the migration invasion, it is more necessary than ever to denounce the Schengen agreements and to re-establish strict control at the borders of the Member States. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ My mandate is to reject further EU integration, and therefore the establishment of a pan-EU agency for law enforcement training.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the creation of this new European agency.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Police College (CEPOL) is the agency responsible for training law enforcement officers. CEPOL is not a traditional training institution and is trained throughout the EU and is mostly implemented by a network of national police training colleges. March 2013 The Commission has presented a proposal for a training system for law enforcement officials. This training system aims to identify and address gaps in the current training of law enforcement officers on cross-border issues. It applies to law enforcement officers of all grades and is based on current training at national and EU level and is provided through modern training tools such as specialised courses, joint curricula, online learning materials and exchange programmes. I support the current proposal for a regulation modernising the legal basis of CEPOL, which is compatible with the changes provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon (including the role of the European Parliament and national parliaments) and empowers it to implement the principles of the law enforcement training system set out in the abovementioned Commission Communication.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes any attempt to ‘Europeanise’ police training and operation in Europe. We feel that British people are best placed to decide how their police services operate (all MEPs voted against as recommended).

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation, which aims to adapt the missions of the European Police College (CEPOL) to the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty and to enable it to develop and certify new training initiatives responding to the evolution of serious crime (cybercrime, financial analysis, data protection, human trafficking, etc.).

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as the Union's internal security needs are constantly evolving, resulting in increasing demands for police forces and law enforcement officers. CEPOL is the competent agency for training in coercive functions; it is not a classically styled training institute, as its courses are carried out across the EU and are mainly carried out by a network of national police training schools.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European Union agency for the training of law enforcement agencies (Cepol) to improve cross-border cooperation between the relevant national authorities to counter the threat posed by organised crime and transnational crime. This proposed regulation aims to modernise The legal foundations of Cepol by adapting them to the Lisbon Treaty. However, I cannot endorse this text since it would be tantamount to supporting Schengen, the two being totally linked. I think that a control at national borders would be more effective than an umpteenth bureaucratic agency... So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the Coordination at European level of training activities on police matters by the European Police College (CEPOL), in order to improve cooperation between the police forces of the Member States, so I supported the text with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament its position on a future regulation establishing the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL). The EU's internal security needs are constantly changing, increasing the requirements for police forces and law enforcement officers. The right skills will be crucial to address future challenges and to ensure the safety of our citizens. In order to combat the growing threat of transnational and organised crime, it is essential that all relevant national law enforcement authorities engage in effective and smooth cross-border cooperation. Proper training of law enforcement officers is essential to promote and maintain such cross-border cooperation and to increase mutual trust. The European Police College (CEPOL) is the agency responsible for training law enforcement officers. CEPOL is not a traditional training institution and is trained throughout the EU and is mostly implemented by a network of national police training colleges. CEPOL's budget is relatively modest and its staff structure is limited. By supporting and coordinating training provided by European and national centres of excellence, this training system aims to identify and address gaps in the current training of law enforcement officers on cross-border issues.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's internal security has been seriously challenged recently and we can look at the like. There is therefore a fundamental need for properly trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border organised crime, cybercrime and terrorism. We need law enforcement officers who can act with full professionalism in today's migration crisis. Therefore, the existence of a modernised, efficient, independent and adequate cepol agency is vital. The new legislation modernises cepol's legal base and sets out the institution's priorities. This should include assessing the needs of strategic training at Union level, accreditation of training courses, a common curriculum, sharing positive examples and identifying the minimum knowledge that all police academies should include in their education programmes. CEPOL should be able to provide training and trainers at Union level. At the same time, cepol's reliance on national police academies and close cooperation with them was an important aspect of legislation. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthened the european police academy, CEPOL's headquarters in Budapest, and provided it with the strong legal basis and framework necessary for its proper functioning.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ This file sought to enhance the remit of CEPOL with a focus on strategic objectives, not exclusively training. The file also sought to enhance the autonomous nature of CEPOL and increase its funding. I, therefore, voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to modernise the legislative framework of the European Police College (CEPOL) is the correct step envisaged by the European Commission, taking into account the current challenges of serious cross-border crime and organised crime. To meet these challenges, an effective CEPOL Agency with adequate staff is needed. The modernised legislative framework proposed by CEPOL, enabling it to implement the Law Enforcement Training Programme and provide services to the wider European community with law enforcement powers, meets current needs.  I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL), repealing and replacing Council Decision 2005/681/JHA because I believe that CEPOL should serve not only as a support platform for cooperation between national bodies but also firmly involved in the application and service processes at European level.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This decision updates the mandate for the European Police College (CEPOL), which was established in 2005 as a Union entity with the aim of contributing to the training of senior police officers and officers of the Member States and facilitating cooperation between national police forces.  The objectives and modalities are updated in the organisation and coordination of training activities on police issues with a European dimension in order also to avoid duplication or overlap and to ensure better coordination of training activities for law enforcement officials.  In view of the work and mission of CEPOL, I voted in favour.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Union Agency for the Training of Law Enforcement Authorities (CEPOL) and repealing and replacing Council Decision 2005/681/JHA. CEPOL is the agency responsible for training law enforcement authorities. It is not a training institution in the traditional sense of the word: its courses take place throughout the EU and are mainly implemented by a network of national police academies. The proposal for a regulation modernises CEPOL's legal basis and brings it into line with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, entrusting CEPOL with the implementation of the principles of the new European law enforcement programme. Given that the European Parliament has repeatedly called on the Commission to adapt cepol's existing legal framework to the Treaty of Lisbon and to the new ambition defined in the European law enforcement agency training programme, so as to enable CEPOL to effectively implement the European law enforcement agency training programme and to respond to the interest of the wider community of law enforcement authorities, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The file seeks to enhance the remit of CEPOL with a focus on strategic objectives, not exclusively training. The file also seeks to enhance the autonomous nature of CEPOL and increase its funding. However, I co-signed an amendment which was tabled by my Group GUE/NGL to bring the CEPOL seat back to The Hague.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree that there is a need to modernise the legislative framework for the CEPOL agency to provide high-quality training for the police in order to tackle crimes more effectively.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to "Lisbonise", i.e. repeal and replace with an EU regulation, the JHA Council decision establishing a European Union Law Enforcement Training Agency (CEPOL). CEPOL is the agency responsible for training law enforcement authorities in the Member States: courses take place across the EU, mainly via the network of national police academies.  While the adaptation to the current legal framework is certainly positive, we believe that the governance structure of CEPOL could be further streamlined, primarily through better coordination with initiatives already under way and the relocation of the Agency from Budapest to The Hague – so as to cluster with the other agencies active in matters that are already there. This would help to free up funds that are desperately needed at the moment, especially in the area of migration policy. The proposed regulation, on the other hand, provides for an increase in CEPOL's budget (due to changes linked to its responsibilities).  For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report stressed that the European Police College must have sufficient powers to properly coordinate law enforcement training at EU level and to implement the principles established by the law enforcement training programme.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the EU's internal security needs are constantly evolving and, as a result, police forces and law enforcement officials are faced with increasing demands and therefore proper training is of the utmost importance. I am also convinced that focusing action on European added value, strengthening cepol's coordinating and supporting role, together with developing greater efficiency and better ating resources, are the main keys to achieving the objectives set.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Cepol, European Police Academy, is responsible for training security forces across Europe. The commission's amendment is essentially aimed at aligning the legal basis with the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and to instruct the agency to implement the European training programme for the security forces, amendments which are very welcome and are in line with what Parliament has repeatedly called for. This report, which I clearly support, introduces changes in three axes: focusing on the agency's activity in the European and cross-border areas, articulated with the European Security Strategy; strengthen cepol's coordinating role, without prejudice to the support provided to member states' training bodies; to make its administrative structure more efficient, as was the case with Europol. As a result of the new responsibilities, it warns of the need for adequate funding in the next budget year. I defended the agency's autonomy from an early age and I believe that the training of national police has contributed to greater mutual trust and, consequently, cooperation.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the proposal for a regulation updating the legal basis of CEPOL (European Police College) and aligning it with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, entrusting it with the implementation of the principles of the new European law enforcement agency training programme. The European Police College is not only a platform for support for cooperation between national bodies, but is also involved in the implementation and implementation of training activities at European level. In this respect, I believe that high-quality training for law enforcement officials is essential for the fight against the various forms of organised and cross-border crime. Only through smooth and effective cross-border cooperation will it be possible to counter the growing threat posed by organised crime.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to repeal and replace, through an EU regulation, the decision taken by the JHA Council, which established a European Union Law Enforcement Training Agency (CEPOL). CEPOL is the agency responsible for training law enforcement authorities in the Member States. Although the agency has a rather modest budget and also a limited staff, closer cooperation between the European Commission and the JHA agencies has been called for, so as to increase its efficiency, avoid duplication, un coordinate initiatives and unnecessary overlaps.  In addition, the proposed regulation gives new additions to CEPOL, which implies the need for new funding from the EU budget, which would be taken away from other JHA priorities, including immigration.  Another point of discussion relates to the location of the agency: the regulation stipulates that it is in Budapest. I have chosen to abstain, particularly in relation to the headquarters of the agency, which I believe should be located in The Hague, where Europol and Eurojust are also located, in order to increase its efficiency and reduce its costs.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This report has a dual objective: on the one hand, to change the headquarters of CEPOL (European Police School) to Budapest following the UK's decision not to maintain facilities on its territory; and, on the other hand, give CEPOL the mandate set out in the Commission Communication on the training of agents. We have maintained that this is a decision focused on washing the image of the Hungarian Government, which, in an interested way, grants the facilities to house CEPOL for free for the first four years. We cannot support the more belligerent attitude towards migrants or minorities in their own country, by mobilizing their security forces to gas attack refugees, to host the training of security agents. In addition, we understand that the CEPOL Training Communication does not include sufficient content relating to fundamental and procedural rights, especially given how they have been systematically violated, particularly at our borders, and that is why we have been against it. For both reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU desperately needs properly trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies capable of responding quickly and effectively at pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border organised crime, cybercrime and terrorism. Therefore, the existence of a modernised, efficient, independent and adequate cepol agency is vital. I voted in favour of this report because the new legislation modernises the legal basis of CEPOL and sets out the institution's priorities. CEPOL should be able to provide training and trainers at Union level.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation because through it the CEPOL is brought into line with the Lisbon Treaty and it moreover outlines the objectives and activities of CEPOL.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes a series of recommendations aimed at improving the effectiveness of the European law enforcement agency (CEPOL). The rapporteur is looking at several priorities to improve training in the prevention and detection of criminal offences, to strengthen cooperation networks on the management of illegal immigration flows and to ensure a sufficient budget to carry out its activities. In this context of migratory influx, it is indeed necessary to increase cooperation, training and the exchange of good practices between the EU's law enforcement agencies in order to ensure better application of European legislation. For these reasons, I supported this report.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's internal security has been seriously challenged recently and we can look at the like. We therefore desperately need well-trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border organised crime, cybercrime and terrorism. We need law enforcement officers who can act with full professionalism in today's migration crisis. Therefore, the existence of a modernised, efficient, independent and adequate cepol agency is vital. The new legislation modernises cepol's legal base and sets out the institution's priorities. This should include assessing the needs of strategic training at Union level, accreditation of training courses, a common curriculum, sharing positive examples and identifying the minimum knowledge that all police academies should include in their education programmes. CEPOL should be able to provide training and trainers at Union level. At the same time, cepol's reliance on national police academies and close cooperation with them was an important aspect of legislation. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthened the european police academy, CEPOL's headquarters in Budapest, and provided it with the strong legal basis and framework necessary for its proper functioning.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament and the Council's proposed regulation establishing a European Union agency for the training of law enforcement agencies (Cepol) which replaces an old Council JAI decision.  The aim of the new proposal is to give Cepol the appropriate legal mandate and resources to implement the training of law enforcement agencies. It also improves the governance of the agency by aligning it with the principles enshrined in the common approach of the Union's decentralised agencies.  The new regulation also aims to create a genuine European culture of policing through the establishment of European training and exchange programmes for all law enforcement professionals, including aspiring asylum seekers still in training.  My ALDE group and I would have preferred cepol's headquarters to be established in The Hague, next to Europol's, for more synergies between the two agencies. However, Parliament's resolution contains a provision calling on the Commission to submit a report on the efficiency of the decision to set up CEPOL's headquarters in Budapest via a cost-benefit analysis and impact assessment.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The eu's internal security has been seriously challenged recently and we can look at the like. We therefore desperately need well-trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border organised crime, cybercrime and terrorism. We need law enforcement officers who can act with full professionalism in today's migration crisis. Therefore, the existence of a modernised, efficient, independent and adequate cepol agency is vital. The new legislation modernises cepol's legal base and sets out the institution's priorities. This should include assessing the needs of strategic training at Union level, accreditation of training courses, a common curriculum, sharing positive examples and identifying the minimum knowledge that all police academies should include in their education programmes. CEPOL should be able to provide training and trainers at Union level. At the same time, cepol's reliance on national police academies and close cooperation with them was an important aspect of legislation. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthened the european police academy, CEPOL's headquarters in Budapest, and provided it with the strong legal basis and framework necessary for its proper functioning.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report on the European Police College on the training of law enforcement agencies deals with the guidelines it transmits to the various national police schools. Because it aims to fill gaps in police training on cross-border issues, this report is of course relevant. However, this additional funding to improve training does not need to be. Indeed, this European Police College should not exist. It is only an unfortunate consequence of the creation of the Schengen area. Without Schengen, border control would be much more effective, being provided by the states themselves, according to their sovereign and democratically decided policies. As a logical consequence of free trade dogma, these supranational policies have no place to be, so I voted against this report.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's internal security has been seriously challenged recently and we can look at the like. We therefore desperately need well-trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border organised crime, cybercrime and terrorism. We need law enforcement officers who can act with full professionalism in today's migration crisis. Therefore, the existence of a modernised, efficient, independent and adequate cepol agency is vital.  The new legislation modernises cepol's legal base and sets out the institution's priorities.
