This should include assessing the needs of strategic training at Union level, accreditation of training courses, a common curriculum, sharing positive examples and identifying the minimum knowledge that all police academies should include in their education programmes. CEPOL should be able to provide training and trainers at Union level. At the same time, cepol's reliance on national police academies and close cooperation with them was an important aspect of legislation. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthened the european police academy, CEPOL's headquarters in Budapest, and provided it with the strong legal basis and framework necessary for its proper functioning.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes any attempt to ‘Europeanise’ police training and operation in Europe. We feel that British people are best placed to decide how their police services operate (all MEPs voted against as recommended).

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 CEPOL is not a training institute within the traditional meaning of the term: courses take place throughout the EU, mainly carried out by a network of national police training institutes, and has a very modest budget (around EUR 8.5 million) and a simple staff (a total of around 40 people, including temporary officials/staff, contract staff and possible staff).  In 2013, about 8,250 police officers participated in about 100 CEPOL activities (courses, seminars, conferences and online seminars (webinars). In addition, around 450 police officers, trainers and investigators from 25 countries used CEPOL's European Erasmus-type Police Exchange Programme to spend time in another country's police force. The proposal for a Regulation under this update the legal basis of CEPOL, adapts it to the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and entrusts CEPOL with the application of the principles of the new police training programme, as set out in the Commission communication referred to above. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it endorses the Schengen system.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The new regulatory framework, following the failed merger between CEPOL and Europol, would allow CEPOL to effectively implement the European law enforcement training programme and respond to the interests of the wider community of law enforcement authorities. With a view to cost containment and closer cooperation between agencies, however, efficiency should be increased by avoiding duplication, un coordinate initiatives and unnecessary overlaps.  The real possibility of CEPOL and Europol share certain resources and services, in particular as regards administrative tasks (e.g. finance, personnel, information technology, logistics or security), would make it possible to achieve some savings and would certainly have positive effects due to increased contacts between operational and training staff. Such cooperation would, of course, be easier if both agencies were based in the same place.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation aims to update the legal basis of CEPOL (EU Agency for Police Training) by adapting it to the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon (including the role of the European Parliament and national parliaments) and entrusts CEPOL with the application of the principles of the new police training programme, as set out in the European Commission communication. The new legal framework that is now being proposed wants to allow CEPOL to implement a police training programme for all European law enforcement officers. In March 2015, the European Commission moved forward with a proposal to update europol's legal framework (European Police Office), where, among other amendments, it already proposed the 'merger' of CEPOL and EUROPOL in order to "bring together synergies between operationalisation in the application of the Law and the training of agents". Under the pretext of "ensuring the safety of European citizens", it is no more than seeking to create conditions for the establishment of a supranational policing structure, outside the democratic control of the Member States and therefore outside their Constitutions, that is, it is another step in the intention of federalising the EU in an area that goes to the heart of the sovereignty functions of states. We voted against it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as I believe it is just a geopolitical move to boost Hungary’s image after the recent scandals.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament welcomes the European Commission's proposal, as it has already asked Commission representatives on several occasions to bring CEPOL's existing legal framework into line with the Treaty of Lisbon and the new ambitions set out in the European Enforcement Training Scheme. The high quality of training of officers of authorities active in the fight against serious and organised cross-border crime is essential and, to this end, it is important to build a modern and efficient CEPOL agency with sufficient staff and funding. The proposal for a new regulation to reform CEPOL comes at a time when the European Union is forced to face ever-new pitfalls in protecting its internal security. Their successful management will require the extension of the Academy's powers and will not be possible without increasing financial resources. Additional powers should be conferred on CEPOL to properly coordinate law enforcement training at European Union level and to apply the principles enshrined in the enforcement training scheme.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that, in order to ensure its effectiveness and impact, CEPOL’s limited resources should be focused on a few thematic areas with a clear European added-value, by no means duplicating the work done at the level of the Member States, and in line with the principle of subsidiarity. Focusing on a more limited number of thematic areas would free resources to put more effort into quality and attractiveness. In order to use scarce resources efficiently, a more effective coordination among JHA Agencies providing training is important, exploiting synergies and eliminating duplication. Finally, I believe that sufficient funding should be safeguarded for CEPOL to properly execute its new tasks.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe in the importance of the CEPOL Agency and its European law enforcement training system being more effective. I confirm that CEPOL's core structure must remain unchanged, in particular by relying on a network of national police academies and working closely with them. The European Parliament has strongly advocated that CEPOL should continue to function as an independent agency of the Union. This strong support is supported by the conviction that CEPOL is able, on the one hand, to contribute to the development of a credible European law enforcement culture based on respect for fundamental rights and, on the other hand, to provide a value-for-money service to European taxpayers as an EU agency. It is therefore of the utmost importance to see that, as an EU agency, CEPOL will not only be a platform for cooperation between national bodies, but also a cornerstone of implementation and delivery at EU level.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the desire to adapt internal security at EU level to its constant evolution, resulting in increasing demands for law enforcement police forces. In this regard, we must continue to improve effective and smooth transnational cooperation between national authorities, and for this it is essential to have a modernised, effective cePOL agency with an appropriate organization chart.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the establishment of an EU Law Enforcement Training Agency (CEPOL). I believe that this institutionalised exchange in the EU is important, but I urge that the taxpayers' money earmarked for this purpose should be handled carefully and that duplication should be avoided.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Against the background of an ever-increasing profile of requirements, I have today advocated an intensification of the training of our police officers. In the area of transnational cooperation in particular, strengthening training is important and useful. This is the only way to guarantee a functioning European prosecution.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to update the legal basis of CEPOL so as to improve EU security through the implementation of a new training approach for EU law enforcement officers.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as up to date training of law enforcement officers is very important in today’s constantly changing security environment. By supporting this document, I am in favour of improving EU security through a better managed CEPOL. This legislative proposal promises to grant law enforcement greater resources which is my view is always a good step.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We have abstained, as We can not yet have a definite position on the suitability of the location of European bodies. This Commission proposal aims to locate CEPOL in Hungary or, as an alternative to the GUE/NGL Group, proposes to be transferred to The Hague in the Netherlands. We have considered it more appropriate to abstain because, while we consider it positive to relocate the location of Community bodies, preventing the headquarters of these bodies from always being located in the Central European countries, we also consider that, since CEPOL is an agency with a very small number of officials, locating its headquarters in The Hague, where Europol is already installed, would optimize resources and reduce costs.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's internal security has been seriously challenged recently and we can look at the like. We therefore desperately need well-trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border organised crime, cybercrime and terrorism. We need law enforcement officers who can act appropriately in today's migration crisis. Therefore, a cepol agency with modern, autonomous and adequate staff is vital. The new legislation modernises cepol's legal base and sets out the institution's priorities. This should include assessing the needs of strategic training at Union level, accreditation of training courses, a common curriculum, sharing positive examples and identifying the minimum knowledge that all police academies should include in their education programmes. CEPOL should be able to provide training and trainers at Union level. At the same time, cepol's reliance on and continued close cooperation with national police academies was an important aspect of legislation.  I voted in favour of this report, which strengthened the headquarters of the European Police College, CEPOL in Budapest, and provided it with the appropriate legal basis for its operation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report because the EU’s internal security needs are constantly evolving, resulting in increasing demands on police forces and law-enforcement officers. The right skills will be critical to meeting future challenges and safeguarding the security of our citizens. In order to counter the growing threat of transnational and organised crime, effective and smooth cross-border cooperation among all relevant national law-enforcement authorities is crucial. To foster and sustain this kind of cross-border cooperation and to enhance mutual trust, proper training of law-enforcement officers is paramount.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes any attempt to ‘Europeanise’ police training and operation in Europe. We feel that British people are best placed to decide how their police services operate (all MEPs voted against, as recommended).

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. CEPOL is the European agency in charge of the training of law enforcement agencies. The meeting of agents from different Member States is an enriching opportunity to confront practices and cultures. The counterpart of the great freedom of movement granted to citizens in the Schengen area has been the explosion of serious cross-border crime. Thus, in such a context, the agents of a Member State can no longer afford to work separately from their counterparts if they want to be able to effectively track down criminals and big bandits. In general, I support all initiatives to strengthen the resources of agencies and services in charge of combating cross-border crime and terrorism, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council establishing the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL) and on the repeal and replacement of Council Decision 2005/681/PUP, as I believe that providing quality training to police officers is essential for the EU's internal security.  There is a growing threat of international and organised crime, and more effective and coherent cooperation between police authorities across the Union is therefore needed. I believe that the legislative framework of CEPOL needs to be modernisation in order to achieve such a thing and that activities should be implemented at EU level, not just as a platform for cooperation between Member States, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report notes that effective and harmonious cross-border cooperation to combat organized and transnational crime is needed.  The report states that the current situation justifies modernising the legal basis of CEPOL (European Police College), which is a Union agency responsible for the training of law enforcement agencies. This reform aims to adapt CEPOL to the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty and to entrust the agency with the implementation of the new European programme on the training of law enforcement services (services that concern police, border guards, customs officers and prosecutors).  I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes any attempt to ‘Europeanise’ police training and operation in Europe. We feel that British people are best placed to decide how their police services operate. My fellow MEPs and I all voted against this report.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I have been supportive of all proposals aiming to strengthen European police and judicial cooperation. Therefore I also voted for this report promoting the legal basis of the European Police College and delegating to it the implementation of the new Law Enforcement Training Scheme.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Kinga Gul's report on the EU agency in charge of law enforcement training (Cepol). The report aims to strengthen Cepol to more effectively combat serious cross-border crime, including through the training of law enforcement officers. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report aims to strengthen the CEPOL Agency with further financial and legal resources and to encourage the merging of CEPOL and Europol. Neither financially nor structurally does such an approach make sense, which is why I reject this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it calls for a stronger framework to provide high quality training for law enforcement officers in the fight against organised cross-border crime.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The European Police College (CEPOL) is the agency responsible for training authorities to combat transnational crime. The current proposal for a regulation modernises cepol's legal basis, brings it into line with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and entrusts CEPOL with the implementation of the principles of the new European law enforcement programme.  I believe that the correct training of law enforcement officials is of great importance in combating this criminal case, and I therefore support Mrs Gál's report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the European Union Agency for the Training of Law Enforcement, CEPOL. I consider, of course, that effective and harmonious cross-border cooperation between the police services of the Member States is essential to counter the growing threat of transnational crime. In this context, it is important that the police officers involved receive quality training. This training, however, does not necessarily have to come from an EU body. In fact, it is itself responsible for a large number of problems. The disappearance of internal border controls (Schengen) and the lack of control at external borders have greatly contributed to the development of cross-border crime within the European Union.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it proposes to renovate CEPOL, created in 2005. However, I am opposed to this European police training agency, because its existence is consubstantial to that of the Schengen Agreement. CEPOL is also unnecessarily expensive, which the Brussels Commission has recognised by proposing to merge it into Europol. The British, who were hosting him, wisely expelled him.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This report has a dual objective: on the one hand, to change the headquarters of CEPOL (European Police School) to Budapest following the UK's decision not to maintain facilities on its territory; and, on the other hand, give CEPOL the mandate set out in the Commission Communication on the training of agents. We have maintained that this is a decision focused on washing the image of the Hungarian Government, which, in an interested way, grants the facilities to house CEPOL for free for the first four years. We cannot support the more belligerent attitude towards migrants or minorities in their own country, by mobilizing their security forces to gas attack refugees, to host the training of security agents. In addition, we understand that the CEPOL Training Communication does not include sufficient content relating to fundamental and procedural rights, especially given how they have been systematically violated, particularly at our borders, and that is why we have been against it. For both reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report stems from the need to address the growing threat posed by transnational and organized crime. To achieve this end, effective transnational cooperation between national authorities with coercive functions is necessary. In addition, for such cooperation to exist, the formation of law-bodies needs to be adequate.  This report aims to focus on few thematic areas the limited resources of CEPOL, in order to identify what training and capacity-building measures will be required in the future.  Similarly, it aims to strengthen CEPOL's coordinating and supporting role by identifying strategic training needs at EU level and defining minimum knowledge that all police training schools should include in their curriculum. Such a definition should be based on quality criteria; quality of both participants and trainers, as well as the learning environment and, obviously, curriculum.  Adequacy in the formation of coercive functions is necessary to meet developments in the EU's internal security needs, and I therefore consider this report to be of great importance.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EU's internal security needs are constantly growing, resulting in the need to create new police forces and police officers. Well-trained officers could play a key role in future challenges and keeping EU citizens safe, especially in the field of international and organised crime.  The European Police Academy is responsible for the legal implementation of trainings held throughout the Union. Their task is to define and address gaps in police training in cross-border matters, with a budget of only 8.5m euros. Close cooperation with European Commission, justice and home affairs agencies is needed to prevent unnecessary overlapping activities. All activities of the European Police Academy must be in line with European values and priorities, and the objectives achievable, realistic and timed. I supported MP Kinge Gál's report, as it is necessary to strengthen cross-border cooperation in the fight against crime in order to maintain public safety and public order, and only well-trained officers can do so. Croatia, like other Member States, will participate in trainings conducted within national police academies.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Police College can be described directly as an institution which also deals with the above tasks. In all our 28 Member States, for centuries , their often peculiar law enforcement systems have evolved and gradually reformed. Given that we live in the same common house, it is necessary to understand much better the mundane functioning of mutual legal principles. I would like to mark one very important moment for me as a Member representing Latvia. A few years ago, the Latvian Police Academy was closed, where for about twenty years, legal and academic education was acquired by law specialists, including, of course, a lot of people who later became police officers, or police officers themselves who wanted to improve their qualifications or simply improve various knowledge related to law. With the closure of the academy, its role was largely taken over by the National Police College, which implements a licensed first-level professional higher education programme. There, for example, the profession of officer of the medium commanding composition can be acquired, supplemented by appropriate specialisation. I am pleased that the GSC is actively cooperating with the European Police Academy, thus enabling latvian police force officers to exchange experiences with their foreign counterparts – and vice versa – on a more centralised basis. Hopefully, with the reform of the EPA, this cooperation will only become stronger.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – CEPOL was established in 2005 as an EU agency responsible for training law enforcement officers in individual Member States. Transnational and organised crime across EU borders requires quality and effective protection, for which training corresponding to the latest knowledge is needed. The proposed regulation will bring the Agency's legislation into line with the Treaty of Lisbon, introduce new modern training schemes and strengthen the Agency's coordinating and supporting role in law enforcement at EU level.  CEPOL is eu-funded, i.e. taxpayers' resources. It is therefore necessary to check the effectiveness of the spending of these funds. The Committee on Budgets therefore stressed the need for enhanced cooperation with other law enforcement authorities and, for reasons of efficiency and possible saving of resources and savings, proposed temporarily limiting the Agency's current headquarters in Budapest until 31.12.2015, with the Commission submitting a cost analysis and impact assessment by 30.11.2015, with the possible relocation of CEPOL's headquarters to The Hague, where the cooperating Europol agency is based.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Union agency for the provision of law enforcement training (NSA) and repealing and replacing Decision 200 5/681/JHA of the Council (COM(2014)0465), for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 28/10/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against it. Ideologically, we can only oppose this text, because to support it would be to recognise the usefulness and legitimacy of the Schengen area. We should not forget that, without the Schengen area, we would not need this agency, since border control would already be effective, since the Member States were provided at their respective borders. As for cooperation between police services, it would be left to the discretion of States, when necessary, without unnecessary expenditure of resources and resources. The cross-border issue constantly taunts the Brussels clutches and gives daily proof of its inefficiency (as evidenced by the free movement of terrorists and weapons). The solution, so simple, to return to the borders, is a no-brainer.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which endorsed an agreement reached between the European Parliament and national governments in the Council to replace the existing European Police College with an EU Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL). This agency will not affect the independence of each Member State’s national police force, but coordinate training particularly for cross-border crime. S&D MEPs pushed particularly for strong provisions for fundamental rights and data protection.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Police College (CEPOL) is a European Union agency dedicated to training and creating learning opportunities for law enforcement officers. CEPOL's activities are designed to facilitate the sharing of knowledge and best practice and to contribute to the development of a common European culture in the area of law enforcement. Given that high-quality training for law enforcement officials is essential in the fight against serious forms of organised and cross-border crime, it is necessary to ensure that CEPOL is modern, efficient and adequately staffed. The legal basis of CEPOL should therefore be modernised and brought into line with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, entrusting the European Police College with the implementation of the principles of the new European law enforcement programme. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. As the report aims to strengthen the CEPOL agency with financial and legal means and calls for the merger of CEPOL and Europol, I cannot support this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The rapporteur takes note that effective and harmonious cross-border cooperation to combat organised and transnational crime is needed. According to him, the current situation justifies modernising the legal basis of CEPOL (European Police College), which is an AGENCY of the European Union responsible for the training of law enforcement agencies. This reform aims to adapt CEPOL to the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty and to entrust the agency with the implementation of the new European programme on the training of law enforcement services (services that concern police, border guards, customs officers and prosecutors).  At the National Front, we believe that voting for this reform would be tantamount to endorsing the Schengen system. One does not go without the other: the disappearance of borders within the Schengen area requires this kind of European agency. For too long, however, the Schengen area has clearly shown its limits. Today, in the face of the migration invasion, it is more necessary than ever to denounce the Schengen agreements and to re-establish strict control at the borders of the Member States. The member therefore voted against this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the continuous evolution of the EU's internal security needs, it is important that the training of law enforcement authorities is appropriate to the constant challenges facing citizens' security. The proposal for a Regulation updates cepol's legal basis by strengthening the role of cepol by entrusting it with the principles of the new vocational training programme as set out by the European Commission.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the maximisation of the resources allocated to the European Police College (CEPOL ) whilst working within the competences outlined in the treaties.  I therefore chose to support this report as it highlights the need to strengthen CEPOL’s coordination and support role.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The fight against crime and terrorism takes place at all levels of power, including local ones. This reform aims to extend the powers of the European Police College of the European Union (CEPOL) to all law enforcement agencies in order to maximise the effectiveness of European tools. Through training, it is above all a question of ensuring better coordination between the various law enforcement agencies (police, customs, border guards) and of enshrining them in a European logic. Another great example of progress in securing our space of freedom.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Police College is responsible for training and upskilling in law enforcement. The proposed regulation modernises the legal basis of this agency in order to bring it into line with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon. CEPOL is thus to apply new principles and training schemes in the field of law enforcement, as the internal security needs of the EU and its citizens are constantly changing and evolving, to which law enforcement authorities need to be able to respond adequately and promptly. I therefore welcome the proposal, which will allow the challenges of guaranteeing the safety of our citizens to be faced more effectively.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Proposal for a Regulation of EP and of the Council on a EU agency law enforcement Training, because I support the final agreement and  result of the trilogue. The new technical adjustments will align the Regulation with the Lisbon Treaty and will outline the objectives and activities of Cepol.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In March 2013, the European Commission proposed the establishment of a European law enforcement training system. The aim of the scheme is to provide appropriate training for law enforcement officers in order to tackle transnational and organised crime, to encourage and maintain effective and smooth cross-border cooperation between national law enforcement authorities and to strengthen mutual trust. Law enforcement training is the responsibility of the European Police College (CEPOL). The proposal submitted by the Commission to establish a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Agency for Law Enforcement Training and repealing and replacing Council Decision 2005/681/IB entrusts CEPOL with the implementation of the principles of that new law enforcement training system and updates cepol's legal basis and brings it into line with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs tabled 30 amendments to the Commission's draft regulation, while at the same time recommending the adoption of the draft to Parliament. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union plays a relevant role in the security of European citizens and, as such, the simplification and improvement of the European Union Agency for Police Training (CEPOL) aims to provide high-quality training for law enforcement officers, an essential factor in tackling the growing threat of transnational organised crime. Cooperation between CEPOL and the Member States concerns the need to improve the organisation and coordination of police training activities at European level where CEPOL will act as a platform to support the internal security of the European Union. The protection of fundamental rights and human rights should be the basis of all its training activities, with regard to matters such as data protection, victim support and protection, privacy, among others. I am voting in favour of this proposal, taking into account society's growing needs to tackle conflicts and the increased organised crime, through modernisation in police training and cooperation between Member States and the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This Kinga report concerns the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European Union agency for the training of law enforcement agencies (Cepol) to improve cross-border cooperation between the relevant national authorities to counter the threat posed by organised and transnational crime.  This proposed regulation aims to modernise The legal foundations of Cepol by adapting them to the Lisbon Treaty. However, I cannot endorse this text, since it would be tantamount to giving a blank cheque to the Schengen policy, the two being totally linked. I think that a control at national borders would be more effective than an umpteenth bureaucratic agency... So I voted against this report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Police College (CEPOL) is the Agency responsible for law enforcement training. CEPOL is not a training institute in the traditional sense of the word – its courses take place across the EU, mainly implemented by a network of national police training colleges. I have voted for this report that will identify and address gaps in existing law enforcement training on cross-border matters by supporting and coordinating the delivery of training by European and national centres of excellence.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. The file seeks to enhance the remit of CEPOL with a focus on strategic objectives, not exclusively training. The file also seeks to enhance the autonomous nature of CEPOL and increase its funding.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because, like many other reports before it, it further inflates the EU's totally overburdened agency system – at the expense of taxpayers and the further curtailment of national powers.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report focuses on strengthening THE European law enforcement training programme pursued by CEPOL. The proposed regulation would provide CEPOL with a legal mandate and resources to implement the training programme, thereby providing training for police, border guards, customs officers and prosecutors, among others, to be more operational in combating cross-border crime.  It also proposes to Parliament to validate the creation of the CEPOL headquarters in Budapest, when it was originally planned in The Hague.  I am in favour of funding training for law enforcement officers, but I regret that, in this report, the European Union is gradually acquiring a comprehensive instrument of repression which casts a shadow over the objectives of our Union. So I voted against it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The regulation to be adopted will bring cepol's legal basis into line with the changes made to the Treaty of Lisbon. The training of law enforcement officers is essential to combat cross-border crime.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. In order to address the growing threat posed by transnational and organized crime, a key element is effective and fluid transnational cooperation among all competent national authorities with coercive functions. The role of transnational coordination and support must be based on training consistent with the reality in which we are living. Law enforcement cannot give rise to doubt, efficiency is a specific objective that we must achieve and, to this end, we must defend a realistic allocation of economic and personal resources. That we do not promise without promising, as is so often the case, but that we have a real ambition to do things right.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 After having seen the amended text, I can say that I agree overall with the meaning of the changes made: the improvement of the Union's law enforcement authorities, especially with the noble ultimate aim of protecting human rights and the individual. I welcome the EU's continued commitment to working by all means and policies to up to its principles and I am honoured to be able to contribute to them. My contribution is, on this occasion, to say that I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The European Police Academy (CEPOL), which was established as an EU agency in 2005 by Council Decision 2005/681/PUP1, has been entrusted with training activities for senior police officers. It aims to facilitate cooperation between national police forces by organising courses with the European dimension of policing.  It also sets out common guidelines on specific topics, disseminates research and best practice, coordinates exchange programmes for senior police officers and instructors and can participate in specific projects as a partner of EU grant beneficiaries.  The EU has witnessed an increase in serious and organised crime over the last decade. Transnational crime can only be combated through cross-border cooperation between police, customs, border police and other authorities. If those authorities are not adequately trained and there is insufficient mutual trust, their cooperation will not be effective.  In such a context, strategic and operational objectives in the fight against organised and serious cross-border crime and terrorism should be supported by consistent, recognised and high-quality training in specialised and priority areas at central level for EU law enforcement officers involved in transnational cooperation.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This Kinga report concerns the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European Union law enforcement agency (Cepol) to improve cross-border cooperation between the relevant national authorities to counter the threat posed by organised and transnational crime.  This proposed regulation aims to modernise The legal foundations of Cepol by adapting them to the Lisbon Treaty. However, I cannot endorse this text, since it would be tantamount to giving a blank cheque to the Schengen policy, the two being totally linked. I think that a control at national borders would be more effective than an umpteenth bureaucratic agency... So I voted against this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support my colleague Kinge Gal's report on the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council establishing the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL) and the repeal of Council Decision 2005/681/PUP. CEPOL's activities have been redefined to raise awareness and knowledge about international and European law enforcement instruments, union authorities and in particular Europol, Eurojust and Frontex, their actions and roles, as well as legal aspects of police cooperation.  CEPOL will promote common respect and understanding of fundamental rights in law enforcement including data privacy, data protection and the protection of victims and witnesses. Cepol's main objectives are to strengthen the network of cooperation between law enforcement agencies in managing illegal immigration flows and developing, coordinating and implementing training to support Member States and participate in Union missions. In addition, joint curricules are planned to raise awareness and knowledge about shortcomings in the common approach to cross-border criminal phenomena, in particular in relation to terrorism, cybercrime, financial investigations and participation in Union missions.  In order to ensure the full autonomy and independence of CEPOL and to enable the objectives and tasks entrusted to it to be properly performed, a sufficient amount of revenue resulting mainly from contributions from the Union budget is required.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed a new regulation for the European Police College (CEPOL). The aim of this proposal is to adapt the existing legal framework, in which CEPOL operates, to the dictates of the Treaty of Lisbon and to create high-quality training for police officers.  The EU's current internal security needs are constantly evolving and, as a result, police forces and law enforcement officials are faced with increasing and varied demands. A modern, efficient and adequately staffed CEPOL agency is vital.  My vote in favour of this resolution is due to the fact that such a proposal is particularly suitable for contributing to the fight against forms of organised and cross-border crime.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the face of increasing threats to the safety of European citizens, the European Parliament has adopted a text to promote and strengthen the role of the European Law Enforcement Agency (CEPOL). I believe it is important to harmonize our action at European level in order to combat cross-border crime more effectively, and the first step is the training of European executives.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 CEPOL is an agency of the European Union (EU), designed for the training of national police authorities, in order to promote cross-border cooperation. Without a training institute within the traditional meaning of the term, CEPOL uses a network of national police training academies for the effective realization of the courses. The role of this agency in training on organised and transnational crime should be noted, with particular emphasis on EU-related issues. Taking into account the EU's internal security needs and the need to adapt its bodies to them, the European Parliament is called upon to adopt at first reading the proposal for a Regulation, which updates cepol's legal basis. The amendments requested by this report understake a new legal basis, which adapts the agency's legislation to the proposals contained in the Commission's communication to the European police training programme. In these terms, the group for which the training is intended is extended, new tasks are attributed to the agency and the competencies in the areas of research for training are extended, enabling a forward-looking approach in the construction of curriculum plans. It is subject to meeting the indicated proposals that I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes any attempt to ‘Europeanise’ police training and operation in Europe. We feel that British people are best placed to decide how their police services operate (all MEPs voted against, as recommended).

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The European Police School (CEPOL) is the competent agency for training in coercive functions. The proposed Regulation modernises the legal basis of CEPOL, adapts it to changes introduced under the Lisbon Treaty (including the role of the European Parliament and national parliaments) and entrusts CEPOL with the implementation of the principles of the new European Programme for the Training of Coercive Services. In its positioning, which I have supported, Parliament stresses the need to promote CEPOL's cooperation with training centres in Member States and other agencies with EU coercive functions to create indirect effects through enhanced cooperation, and calls on the Commission to present a comprehensive analysis of administrative cooperation between EU agencies and in cases where such cooperation can create synergies in the future.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which further states that CEPOL was created to improve, by implementing, training in and of preventing and detecting criminal offences, maintaining public order and participating in EU police missions, cooperation between law enforcement agencies and promoting a coherent training policy at European level. I have also particularly supported amendments that focus on the defence of human rights and fundamental freedoms in a repressive context.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The constant evolution of European internal security needs entails increasing demands from security forces and police officers, making it necessary to provide them with adequate qualifications to meet new and complex challenges and ensure the safety of European citizens. The European Police Academy is the agency responsible for police training and, although not a training institute within the traditional meaning of the term, it is the body responsible for training law enforcement officers across the EU, carried out mainly through national police training institutes. The amendment tabled by the Commission seeks, on the one hand, to update the legal basis of this Academy by adapting it to the amendments arising from the Treaty of Lisbon and, on the other hand, to instruct it to adopt the principles of the new police training programme.  I enthusiastically support this report, which aims to make the CEPOL Agency more effective by strengthening its coordinating role and increasing efficiency of its administrative structure, as well as a more coherent and rigorous implementation of the European Police Training Programme, through a greater focus on European and cross-border areas, articulated with the European Security Strategy.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Union Agency for the Training of Law Enforcement Authorities (CEPOL), as I believe it is necessary to improve cross-border police cooperation between Member States in order to ensure the security of European citizens.  In line with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, the report proposes an update of CEPOL's legal basis and introduces a new European law enforcement training regulation that provides police officers with specific expertise and knowledge in the field of international security.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the text aims to improve training activities on police matters with a European dimension in order also to avoid duplication or overlap and to ensure better coordination of training activities for officials of the authorities responsible for combating crime.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We have abstained, as We can not yet have a definite position on the suitability of the location of European bodies. This Commission proposal aims to locate CEPOL in Hungary or, as an alternative to the GUE/NGL Group, proposes to be transferred to The Hague in the Netherlands. We have considered it more appropriate to abstain because, while we consider it positive to relocate the location of Community bodies, preventing the headquarters of these bodies from always being located in the Central European countries, we also consider that, since CEPOL is an agency with a very small number of officials, locating its headquarters in The Hague, where Europol is already installed, would optimize resources and reduce costs.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This report has a dual objective: on the one hand, to change the headquarters of CEPOL (European Police School) to Budapest following the UK's decision not to maintain facilities on its territory; and, on the other hand, give CEPOL the mandate set out in the Commission Communication on the training of agents. We have maintained that this is a decision focused on washing the image of the Hungarian Government, which, in an interested way, grants the facilities to house CEPOL for free for the first four years. We cannot support the more belligerent attitude towards migrants or minorities in their own country, by mobilizing their security forces to gas attack refugees, to host the training of security agents. In addition, we understand that the CEPOL Training Communication does not include sufficient content relating to fundamental and procedural rights, especially given how they have been systematically violated, particularly at our borders, and that is why we have been against it. For both reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. The objectives of CEPOL are to increase knowledge of the national police systems and structures of the Member States and to improve cross-border police cooperation within the European Union, to improve knowledge of international instruments and the Union and to provide adequate training in respect of democratic guarantees.  I voted in favour of the new regulation because I believe it is essential to update cepol's legal basis in order to improve EU security through the implementation of a new training approach for EU police officers. CEPOL will train law enforcement officers of all levels by providing the knowledge and expertise necessary for the prevention and fight against cross-border crime, promoting effective cooperation with colleagues from other Member States, EU agencies, third countries and international organisations.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because I am against any EU-funded training.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislation as it places more focus on EU added value, insofar as it ensures that the work of CEPOL is better managed and organised, covering areas such as cooperation with EU agencies and protection of fundamental rights, particularly in relation to data protection. There should be more adequate funding for CEPOL and it should be given the resources to carry out its tasks in relation to combating cross-border crime. This legislative proposal is promising in that regard.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting a legislative resolution on Regulation (EC) No 2005/681/JHA of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL). Effective cross-border cooperation between all relevant national enforcement authorities plays a key role in combating transnational and organised crime. The proposed regulation modernises CEPOL's legal basis and reconciles it with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Police College (CEPOL) is an EU agency responsible for training and educating law enforcement officers and on issues of fundamental importance to the security of the EU and its citizens.  The training itself covers a variety of topics, from leadership to law enforcement techniques, cooperation at EU level and economic crime. The aim of the activities is to facilitate the exchange of knowledge and good practice and to contribute to the creation of a common European law enforcement culture.  The proposal for a regulation brings about the modernisation of CEPOL's legal basis and its alignment with the changes introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, and the Agency is committed to implementing the principles of the new law enforcement training programme.  The renewed legal framework would enable CEPOL to effectively implement the law enforcement training programme, thus benefiting other European law enforcement agencies. As there is a growing threat of transnational and organised crime, effective and unsue cross-border cooperation between all relevant national law enforcement authorities is therefore of paramount importance.  I agree that CEPOL should be maintained as an EU agency that not only serves as a support platform for cooperation between national authorities, but must also be firmly rooted in implementation and enforcement at European level, which is why I supported this report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because the EU has witnessed an increase in serious and organised crime in the last decade and the rise of increasingly diverse causes of crime. Transnational crime can only be combated through cross-border cooperation between police, customs, border police and other authorities. If those authorities are not adequately trained and there is insufficient mutual trust, their cooperation will not be effective.  The fight against organised and serious cross-border crime and terrorism needs to be supported through consistent, recognised and high-quality training, in specialised and priority areas at central level for EU law enforcement officers involved in transnational cooperation.  Providing the knowledge and skills necessary for law enforcement officials at all levels, to effectively prevent and combat cross-border crime through effective cooperation with counterparts in other Member States, EU agencies, third countries and international organisations, is necessary to improve the general social situation.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Under new rules, CEPOL will be able to equip law enforcement officials of all ranks with the knowledge and skills they need to prevent cross-border crime effectively through cooperation with their colleagues in other Member States, EU agencies, third countries and international organisations. CEPOL will also be enabled to deliver essential training to third countries, particularly on counter-terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the Initiative of the European Parliament and the Council on the establishment of the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL). I support the initiative because I believe THAT CEPOL is necessary to enhance cooperation between law enforcement authorities in the Union in the field of preventing, detecting and researching criminal offences, maintaining peace and order and carrying out police missions.  CEPOL should do so by placing particular emphasis on the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the context of law enforcement. Such training at Union level must focus on thematic areas which have clear added value for the Union and must be accessible to law enforcement officers of all levels and from all Member States.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal as it makes cross-border cooperation more streamlined in particular, without interfering with the competences of the Member States.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU Agency for Training in Crime Detection and Investigation (CEPOL). In the European Union, we are currently facing major challenges that we must face with one voice and determination. And we can expect that in the future.  CEPOL can be a means of improving the culture of criminal detection and investigation, a means of improving trust between Member States and improving cross-border cooperation. Crucially, however, CEPOL is given the necessary powers as soon as possible to carry out its mission effectively. The Agency will have a clear mandate with clear objectives and tasks.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The ESA, as the only specialised body dealing exclusively with law enforcement training, should be able to assist the European institutions in identifying the priorities to be met through training. Furthermore, for the effectiveness and impact of the EIA, its limited resources (approximately EUR 8.5 million) should focus on a few thematic areas, without in any way overlapping the work carried out at Member State level, and in harmony with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's internal security has been seriously challenged recently and we can look at the like. We therefore desperately need well-trained law enforcement officers and law enforcement agencies who can respond quickly and effectively at Pan-European level to challenges such as cross-border organised crime, cybercrime and terrorism. We need law enforcement officers who can act with full professionalism in today's migration crisis. Therefore, the existence of a modernised, efficient, independent and adequate cepol agency is vital. The new legislation modernises cepol's legal base and sets out the institution's priorities. This should include assessing the needs of strategic training at Union level, accreditation of training courses, a common curriculum, sharing positive examples and identifying the minimum knowledge that all police academies should include in their education programmes. CEPOL should be able to provide training and trainers at Union level. At the same time, cepol's reliance on national police academies and close cooperation with them was an important aspect of legislation. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthened the european police academy, CEPOL's headquarters in Budapest, and provided it with the strong legal basis and framework necessary for its proper functioning.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it supports the Commission's ideas on the basis of sound justification for the fact that this important European agency can continue more effectively, relying on the modern curriculum used for new types and methods of cross-border organised crime, and to continue its legal basis in line with the framework of the Treaty of Lisbon. It also duly justiates the need to expand and modernise CEPOL's activities in order to adapt to new international and European challenges. To this end, I can accept that the Agency can manage more financially, but also more efficiently and sparingly. However, I strongly oppose any proposal to take CEPOL's headquarters from Budapest with a narrow-minded budgetary approach under the pretext of austerity, renewing the attempt to merge with Europol in The Hague, which has already failed, for good reason, against the strong opposition of the Council and the EP. The report also reflects CEPOL's multifaceted and useful activities to date, for which the Budapest headquarters provides adequate infrastructure and conditions in all respects. The fact that the emergence of an important European institution has also had an incentive to strengthen modern policing in a new democracy has been partly symbolic of European political importance when choosing a seat. This aspect has become even more important in today's unfavourable political environment in Hungary, so I would like to pay particular attention to the seat issue in any future parliamentary work on CEPOL.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The European Police College (CEPOL) is the Agency responsible for law enforcement training.  Although CEPOL’s budget is about EUR 8.5 million, the institution contributes to training police enforcement personnel in skills that are needed for meeting future challenges and safeguarding the security of our citizens The current proposed regulation aligns CEPOL with the Lisbon Treaty, by modernising its legal basis and entrusting CEPOL with the implementation of the principles of the new Law Enforcement Training Scheme. This procedure would enable CEPOL to effectively implement the Law Enforcement Training Scheme and to serve the broader European law enforcement community, and at the same time deliver its contribution to the construction of a genuine European law enforcement culture. Now, more than ever, we need skilled police enforcement to counter the growing threat of terrorism, transnational and organised crime, and other security challenges. For this reason I voted in favour of this current report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The internal security imperatives of the European Union are constantly evolving, making it increasingly difficult for police forces and law enforcement officials. They will not be able to meet the challenges ahead and preserve the security of EU citizens without the necessary skills. Effective and harmonious cross-border cooperation between all the relevant national law enforcement authorities is essential to counter the growing threat of transnational and organized crime. In this context, it is crucial that law enforcement professionals receive quality training in order to encourage and maintain cooperation of this magnitude and to strengthen mutual trust. The Stockholm programme therefore called for strengthening training on EU-related issues and making it systematically accessible to all law enforcement professionals concerned. The European Police College (CEPOL) is the agency responsible for the training of law enforcement agencies. In view of the provisions proposed in the text, I voted in favour.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims at establishing a European Union agency for law enforcement training (CEPOL). CEPOL, the abbreviation for European Police College, is the Agency responsible for law enforcement training. It has a budget of around EUR 8.5 million and its courses are mainly implemented by national police training colleges. The proposed regulation modernises CEPOL’s legal basis, brings it in line with the changes introduced by the Lisbon Treaty and entrusts CEPOL with the implementation of the principles of the new Law Enforcement Training Scheme proposed by the Commission in March 2013. I welcome this proposal, since better trained staff can make a bigger contribution to fighting serious and organised cross-border crime.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Union Agency for Crime Detection and Investigation (CEPOL) training and repealing and replacing Council Decision 2005/681/JHA, as I believe that effective and unsocrity between relevant detection and investigation is essential in response to the growing threat of transnational and organised crime, and that appropriate training of staff is essential in order to promote and strengthen mutual trust.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We have abstained, as We can not yet have a definite position on the suitability of the location of European bodies. This Commission proposal aims to locate CEPOL in Hungary or, as an alternative to the GUE/NGL Group, proposes to be transferred to The Hague in the Netherlands. We have considered it more appropriate to abstain because, while we consider it positive to relocate the location of Community bodies, preventing the headquarters of these bodies from always being located in the Central European countries, we also consider that, since CEPOL is an agency with a very small number of officials, locating its headquarters in The Hague, where Europol is already installed, would optimize resources and reduce costs.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's internal security needs are constantly changing, making it increasingly difficult for police forces and law enforcement officers. Only with the right preparedness can we guarantee compliance with the challenges of the future and the protection of the security of European citizens. Effective and seamless cross-border cooperation between all relevant national law enforcement authorities is key in order to tackle transnational and organised crime, which is an increasing threat. Law enforcement training is the responsibility of the European Police College (CEPOL). CEPOL is not a training institution in the traditional sense: training takes place throughout the Union and is primarily provided by a network of national police academies. CEPOL is headquartered in Budapest, which is particularly important. That is why, as a Hungarian Member, I supported the Gál report.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation establishing the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL) provides for a legal framework for a new CEPOL with more extensive objectives and a more modern governance model, which repeals and replaces CEPOL, as established by Council Decision 2005/681/JHA.  The European Police College (CEPOL) is the agency responsible for law enforcement training, its courses being carried out in all the Member States of the Union, mainly provided by a network of training colleges belonging to national police.  The proposal for a regulation provides for the extension of the CEPOL mandate so that it can carry out and coordinate learning activities for law enforcement personnel, regardless of rank, as well as customs officials and other relevant categories of officials dealing with cross-border issues. At the same time, CEPOL's objectives are updated and clarified so that the Agency addresses specific thematic areas in criminal or police matters where training at EU level can bring added value to the national level. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We have abstained, as We can not yet have a definite position on the suitability of the location of European bodies. This Commission proposal aims to locate CEPOL in Hungary or, as an alternative to the GUE/NGL Group, proposes to be transferred to The Hague in the Netherlands. We have considered it more appropriate to abstain because, while we consider it positive to relocate the location of Community bodies, preventing the headquarters of these bodies from always being located in the Central European countries, we also consider that, since CEPOL is an agency with a very small number of officials, locating its headquarters in The Hague, where Europol is already installed, would optimize resources and reduce costs.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour because the report welcomes the inclusion of an overall framework of respect for human rights, which is foreseen in the final text as well as the inclusion of the reference to the desired gender balance in the main managing structure of CEPOL, the Management Board. Nevertheless, I regret that the seat of CEPOL is located in Budapest. The Hague, together with EURPOL, would make more sense and save significant costs.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution addressing the European Police College (CEPOL) because the EU’s internal security needs are constantly evolving, resulting in increasing demands on police forces and law enforcement officers. The right skills will be critical to meet future challenges and safeguard the security of our citizens.  In order to counter the growing threat of transnational and organised crime, effective and smooth cross-border cooperation among all relevant national law enforcement authorities is key. To foster and sustain this kind of cross-border cooperation and to enhance mutual trust, proper training of law enforcement officers is paramount. I believe it is important to acknowledge the importance of the role CEPOL has in its training activities, promoting common respect for, and understanding of, fundamental rights in law enforcement, such as privacy, data protection and the rights, support and protection of victims, witnesses and suspects of crime, including safeguarding the rights of victims of gender-based violence.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This report has a dual objective: on the one hand, to change the headquarters of CEPOL (European Police School) to Budapest following the UK's decision not to maintain facilities on its territory; and, on the other hand, give CEPOL the mandate set out in the Commission Communication on the training of agents. We have maintained that this is a decision focused on washing the image of the Hungarian Government, which, in an interested way, grants the facilities to house CEPOL for free for the first four years. We cannot support the more belligerent attitude towards migrants or minorities in their own country, by mobilizing their security forces to gas attack refugees, to host the training of security agents. In addition, we understand that the CEPOL Training Communication does not include sufficient content relating to fundamental and procedural rights, especially given how they have been systematically violated, particularly at our borders, and that is why we have been against it. For both reasons, we voted against the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Police Academy (AEP) is the agency responsible for police training. The proposal for a Regulation under this update the legal basis of CEPOL, adapts it to the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and entrusts CEPOL with the application of the principles of the new police training programme, as set out in the Commission communication referred to above. On several occasions, the European Parliament has asked the Commission to adapt cepol's legal framework to the Treaty of Lisbon and to the new ambition in the European Police Training Programme. Quality training for law enforcement officials is essential to combat serious and organised transnational crime. The new legal framework will enable CEPOL to better implement the police training programme and serve all European law enforcement officers.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. As the report aims to strengthen the CEPOL agency with financial and legal means and calls for the merger of CEPOL and Europol, I cannot support this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced of the importance of ensuring certain safety standards within the EU. Every day the field of security offers new challenges: it is therefore essential to give all possible support to the police forces that are called upon daily to meet these new needs. In order to combat crime efficiently, cross-border barriers must be broken down and full cooperation between officials from different European countries must be allowed. Proper training and an exchange of excellent practices between European countries are now a vital need to protect and promote the safety of citizens.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report. The report calls for an increase in knowledge of the national police systems and structures of the Member States and for cross-border police cooperation in the European Union. While this seems to be a useful instrument for international cooperation, it is in fact a springboard for the introduction of Brussels-led law enforcement, and this is a blatant violation of the competence of the Member States. Member States are explicitly responsible for their law enforcement authority. While the report contains some good points, I abstained from the final vote.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report concerning the European Police College CEPOL. Its main objective was to modernise the legal basis of this agency in line with the changes brought about by the Treaty of Lisbon. According to this report, while the main structure as well as CEPOL's objectives will remain unchanged, the Agency will focus more on a narrow number of topics related to cross-border cooperation within the European Union, focusing in particular on law enforcement. As CEPOL works closely with police academies in individual Member States, for example by developing curricula for police academies, organising various trainings and seminars or exchange programmes of officers, thereby contributing to their training and acquiring new knowledge and skills in the fight against cross-border crime, I consider the preservation and support of CEPOL to be important.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation seeks to update cepol's legal basis by adapting it to the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon (including the role of the European Parliament and national parliaments) and entrusts CEPOL with the application of the principles of the new police training programme, as set out in the Commission communication. The proposed new legal framework will allow CEPOL to implement a police training programme for all European law enforcement officers. On 27 March 2015, the Commission moved forward with a proposal to update the legal framework of EUROPOL (European Police Office), where, among other amendments, it already proposed the 'merger' of CEPOL and EUROPOL in order to "bring together synergies between operationalisation in the application of the Law and the training of agents". Under the pretext of "ensuring the safety of European citizens", it is no more than seeking to create conditions for the establishment of a supranational policing structure, outside the democratic control of the Member States and therefore outside their Constitutions, that is, it is another step in the intention of federalising the European Union, subtracting sovereignty from Member States in matters so sensitive to the freedoms and guarantees of individuals. We voted against it.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system.  That is why I voted in favour of this Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency, as it improves transparency, regulation and supervision, particularly with regard to central information and disclosure of these operations, as well as minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees. These transactions include major loans and securities repurchase agreements, which are exchanged for entities and activities outside the regular banking system (i.e. so-called shadow banking). Our group has worked to add some improvements to the Commission's proposals which we consider particularly important. Among them, its scope, to cover new financial transactions in its definitions. We have also increased reporting obligations to ensure that all information is provided to the competent authority.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the implementation of the capital markets union is not an opportunity to deregulate the financial sector.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it lays the groundwork for the development of new speculative bubbles to be pushed through the future creation of the Capital Market Union. This report, which represents the result of the informal three-way dialogues, proposes to regulate the notification of securities transactions within the EU, facilitating their mobility. The co-legislators start from the basis that the economic crisis was generated by financial speculation and its lack of financing of the real economy and, to solve it, propose an even greater financing of the real economy, aiming to change the bank financing of economic activity by introducing values for the financing of the productive fabric. This will have serious consequences on the translation of financial market volatility into the productive fabric, which is why I voted against it.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe it improves transparency, regulations and supervision in relation to securities financing transactions mainly related to securities lending and repurchase agreements between entities and activities outside the regular banking system.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The regulation referred to here establishes rules to make securities financing transactions transparent, which are generally referred to as shadow banking and which correspond to a phenomenon with blurred outlines comprising a whole set of entities whose financial intermediation activities are referred to as "parallel". These, in fact, are not part of traditional banking. These transactions thus benefit from almost non-existent regulation and borrow attractive channels (low taxed and involving high interest) but dangerous (no public guarantees). They are the work of investment banks, mutual funds, insurers, pension or money funds, private equity firms or hedge funds. Flexible regulation of these activities is absolutely necessary, especially since the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers in 2008. Indeed, the opacity of the transactions generated by shadow banking, by not identifying the owners of the securities and their real value, is partly responsible for the spread of the crisis in the United States and then in the world by ricochet.  The European regulations that were before us mitigate the risk inherent in this type of activity, in particular by imposing more transparency. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This will extend the powers of ESMA, including the power to draft Regulatory and Implementing Technical Standards for the Commission to adopt. I note the reference to ‘administrative sanctions’ including fines of up to 10% of turnover. I further note the power which Article 27 gives to the Commission to adopt delegated acts. For these reasons I voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, as the committee recommended on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to increase transparency in securities financing transactions. The global financial crisis between 2007 and 2008 revealed overly speculative practices, important regulatory gaps, as well as shortcomings such as inefficient supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system. The European Union has taken various measures to make the banking system stronger and more stable, including stricter capital requirements, better governance rules and supervisory and resolution regimes. Progress made towards the banking union is also very important. The crisis has also revealed the need to increase transparency and strengthen monitoring not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in areas where non-bank lending activities are carried out, i.e. in the shadow banking sector. The new transparency rules provide for the provision of data on SFTs drawn up by all market participants, both financial and non-financial entities, including information on the structure of the underlying collateral, where the underlying collateral can or has been used, and the applicable value reductions. In order to minimise the additional operating costs of market participants, the new rules and standards should be based on existing infrastructure and procedures in place in the field of OTC derivatives.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this text, which represents a real step forward in terms of transparency in securities financing transactions. It updates EU rules on payment services by reducing the cost of invoices payable, allowing new market players to use mobile and online tools to make payments on behalf of a customer. The rules in this file aim to make online payments safer by establishing data protection and accountability rules for all online payment service providers.
