By 2014, interbank fees had already been capped and additional costs prohibited for consumer cards in accordance with the Multilateral Interbank Commissions (IJC) Regulation for Card Payment Transactions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the transparency of securities financing transactions covers all transactions that use assets to generate financing. This is therefore an important part of the shadow banking activity carried out by economic agents not under the constraint of banking legislation. This shadow finance is dangerous, as it is not controlled and its growth is exponential.  Last June's trilogue resulted in an agreement on transparency obligations that is welcome but still insufficient. A simple register will not suffice!! The rapporteur goes further by proposing, for example, the stricter framework for the reuse of security, a particularly harmful practice.  I have decided to vote in favour of this report to frame this practice. As such, I recall that I recently tabled a motion for a resolution on the limitation of shadow banking activities and that further efforts in this area will have to be pursued.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is necessary to improve control and transparency both in the traditional banking sector and in credit intermediation sectors such as securities financing operations. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this measure.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Since 2008, the global financial crisis since 2008 revealed large regulatory gaps in the financial system, oversight problems, market opacity, and overly complex products. Since then, the EU has been adopting a set of measures aimed at building a stronger and more stable banking system. The Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency is in addition to these measures. It improves the transparency, regulation and supervision of securities financing operations in terms of central information, disclosure of such transactions and notification to investors, and minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees, which, among others, I have supported it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the regulation proposed by the Commission on transparency of securities financing transactions. The global financial crisis has revealed overly speculative practices, important regulatory gaps, as well as shortcomings such as inefficient supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system. The Union has taken a number of measures to make the banking system stronger and more stable, including stricter capital requirements, better governance rules and supervisory and resolution regimes. Parliament calls for it to be borne in mind that the main function of the financial sector should be the diversion of capital to the real economy in order to finance it, not asset speculation. In its activities in the field of combating shadow banking, the Financial Stability Board and the European Systemic Risk Board identified the risks posed by securities financing transactions (SFTs). In particular, the lack of transparency in the use of SFTs prevented regulators and supervisors and investors from correctly assessing and monitoring risks similar to banking risks and interconnectedness in the financial system during the period before and during the financial crisis. The new transparency rules provided for in this Regulation therefore provide for the provision of data on SFTs drawn up by all market participants, both financial and non-financial entities, including information on the structure of the underlying collateral where the underlying collateral can or has been used, and the applicable value reductions.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report as well as efforts to make the securities transaction even more transparent and with even greater scrutiny than before. This report highlights a number of measures that should further improve transparency in securities transactions, from expanding the scope of the regulation, reporting obligations, etc.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 As a result of the global financial crisis, which broke out in 2007-2008, excessive speculative activities, serious regulatory gaps, an ineffective supervisory framework, opaque markets and some far too complicated products in the financial system have surfaced.  In this context, the European Union has adopted a number of measures to strengthen and stabilise the banking system. Furthermore, the Union wants to strengthen capital requirements, rules on improving governance and measures on banking supervisory and resolution regimes. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reporting and transparency of financing operations through financial instruments, because there is a need for an improvement in transparency in this regard and monitoring, by respecting the fundamental rights and principles recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, in particular the right to the protection of personal data and respect for private and family life.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. This Regulation lays down rules on the transparency of securities financing (SFT) operations and on re-use. An reporting and safeguard obligation is established with regard to the SFT; the trading data re-registers are registered with ESMA. Any right of counterparties to the re-use of financial instruments received as collateral is subject at least to the conditions laid down in this Regulation (ENF amendments call for a ban on re-use). The Commission may adopt implementing acts on the equivalence and recognition of data re-data on negotiations with regard to a third country. Administrative penalties are provided for infringements if a Member State does not provide for criminal sanctions. This measure is part of the measures taken after the 2007-2008 financial crisis to fill regulatory gaps in the financial system and remedy the ineffectiveness of supervision, market opacity and the excessive complexity of financial products. The crisis has highlighted the need to improve transparency and control not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in sectors where credit intermediation similar to banking, known as the 'shadow banking system', takes place.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system.  That is why I voted in favour of this Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency, as it improves transparency, regulation and supervision, particularly with regard to central information and disclosure of these operations, as well as minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees. These transactions include major loans and securities repurchase agreements, which are exchanged for entities and activities outside the regular banking system (i.e. so-called shadow banking). Our group has worked to add some improvements to the Commission's proposals which we consider particularly important. Among them, its scope, to cover new financial transactions in its definitions. We have also increased reporting obligations to ensure that all information is provided to the competent authority.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the implementation of the capital markets union is not an opportunity to deregulate the financial sector.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Securities Financing Regulations are part of a package of legislation proposed by the Commission aimed at creating greater transparency in the shadow banking system. The shadow banking system is the set of activities and actors contributing to the non-bank financing of the economy. Like all regulations on the shadow banking system, it is put in place to create rules equivalent to those to which banks are subject to avoid the transfer of financial transactions from the traditional banking system, which has been heavily regulated since the crisis, to the shadow banking system.  Securities financing operations are a rapid and necessary means of financing the real economy. However, without regulation for greater transparency, they can lead to destabilization of the financial market, as in 2008.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reporting and transparency of securities financing operations.  It is well known that financial crises have caused the proliferation of speculative activities that have exploited regulatory gaps in the system, ineffectiveness of supervision, opacity of markets and excessive complexity of products. The so-called 'shadow banking system' was born, which tends to escape the control of the bodies responsible for the traditional banking sector and may have a real risk of repeating other serious financial crises. There is therefore a need to improve transparency and information, in order to limit the accumulation of leverage within physiological and instrumental limits to the capital market. The aim of this legislation is therefore to increase the transparency of securities financing operations, with efficient reporting of trading data.  The adverse effects are in fact very serious for the proliferation of over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives transactions. As indicated in the report, I agree that it is appropriate to report information on financing operations concluded by each operator, financial or non-financial entities, and I therefore voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with securities financing in relation to the lending of securities (e.g. stocks, bonds, asset-backed securities etc.) in return for cash. Typical transactions are repos, reverse repos, buy-sell back transactions or sell-buyback transactions and collateral swaps, which are all used by most banks in order to increase liquidity in the market.  These financial instruments pose a major threat to financial stability. In the wake of the financial crisis, the EU has to some extent tried to reform the regular banking sector. As a result of the ‘tougher’ regulation of banks, it is safe to assume that banks will try to shift their financial activities such as securities financing transactions (SFTs) to the shadow banking sector, as it is basically non-regulated (shadow banks are credit institutions like Lehman Brothers that operate outside the regular banking sector). This regulation seeks to prevent a migration to shadow banking by increasing transparency and reporting on SFTs outside the normal banking sector.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which highlights the need to improve transparency in the traditional bank sector and non-bank credit activities following the global financial crisis of 2008.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the ECON Commission we supported an approach aimed at strengthening transparency requirements. In particular, we have called for all exemptions for banks and all those involved in this type of transaction to be removed, for information obligations to be increased, for professional secrecy to be removed and for tougher penalties to be imposed.  We have also called for a ban on re-use to be introduced into the regulation, i.e. a ban on recommiting securities offered as collateral against a new securities financing operation in order to avoid the creation of collateral chains and to limit the risk of contagion and the application of 6% minimum guarantee margins (haircuts) on collateral in order to reduce excess leverage and limit the risk of contagion of operations.  Our improvements were not included in the final text further weakened during the trialogues with the Council and the Commission on exemptions, disclosure requirements and sanctions. I therefore voted against.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The Global Financial Crisis that broke out in 2007-2008 brought to light many speculative activities, significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system. Thus, the Union has adopted a number of measures to make the banking system stronger and more stable, including by strengthening capital requirements with rules on improved governance and supervision and with resolution regimes.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I recall that the global financial crisis that erupted between 2007 and 2008 highlighted the lack of prudence in the financial system. The Union has already taken a number of measures to increase the soundness and stability of the banking system, and it should be noted that securities financing operations are used by other financial counterparties, such as credit institutions, and non-financial counterparties, and create specific risks for entities holding shares or are clients of those counterparties. Credit institutions should therefore communicate their financing operations through securities. In order to ensure an efficient regulatory framework for the shadow banking system, the progress made in introducing and implementing coherent obligations at international level continues to be crucial: the Commission should submit regular reports to the European Parliament and the Council with a view to strengthening the supervision and regulation of the shadow banking system and, therefore, explaining the progress of the measures taken by the Union and the main jurisdictions of third countries.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 With the global financial crisis, the perception of excess speculative activity, serious regulatory gaps in the financial system, the ineffectiveness of current supervisory instruments and the negative influence on the economy of the so-called "shadow banking system" has increased. The crisis has therefore highlighted the need to improve the transparency and control of financial transactions through securities.  The lack of transparency and harmonised tax rules between Member States has so far caused national regulatory and supervisory authorities considerable difficulties in assessing and understanding the real risks that individual operators pose to the system. I welcome this report because the proposed new rules for this regulation provide for the reporting of information on financial transactions concluded by all market participants. Risk information will be accessible through the relevant European and national authorities. The regulation is an essential legislative instrument because it aims to strengthen financial stability in the European Union, increasing the transparency of certain market activities and introducing rules in financing operations, which guarantee an efficient regulatory framework for the entire banking system.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal was presented last year by the European Commission together with the well-known Bank Structural Reform to prevent banking activities from moving from the traditional system to the shadow banking system, as it is less regulated. The package was supposed to be the last piece of the financial system reform agenda after the 2008 financial crisis, but in practice the proposal did not introduce any real regulation. Moreover, the Commission has amply demonstrated that it has no intention of regulating shadow banking. On the contrary, today he is promoting it with the proposal to create the Capital Markets Union. After supporting an approach in committee to strengthen transparency requirements and proposing amendments (which were not included in the compromise text) which provided for the elimination of all exemptions for banks and all those involved in this type of transaction, to increase disclosure requirements, to impose stricter penalties , regulation on the prohibition of reuse and application of mandatory minimum collateral guarantee margins of 6% in order to reduce excess leverage and limit the risk of contagion of operations. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it lays the groundwork for the development of new speculative bubbles to be pushed through the future creation of the Capital Market Union. This report, which represents the result of the informal three-way dialogues, proposes to regulate the notification of securities transactions within the EU, facilitating their mobility. The co-legislators start from the basis that the economic crisis was generated by financial speculation and its lack of financing of the real economy and, to solve it, propose an even greater financing of the real economy, aiming to change the bank financing of economic activity by introducing values for the financing of the productive fabric. This will have serious consequences on the translation of financial market volatility into the productive fabric, which is why I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the legislative resolutions aiming at improving the transparency, regulation and supervision of the Securities Financing Transaction Regulation in central reporting. It aims also at disclosure of SFTs and also the reuse to investors and minimum requirements for reuse of collateral. I am in favour of the fact that the scope of the regulation was extended whereas SMEs were exempted from the regulation.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to improve the financial stability of the Union by increasing transparency in certain market activities, particularly in securities financing operations. Securities financing transactions are the borrowing, sale or lending of securities to create liquidity, facilitate financing or simply disclose their value. The 2008 financial crisis highlighted the flaws in the financial regulatory system and the need to increase transparency and oversight of the traditional banking sector and non-bank lending institutions. In particular, the report proposes that the way investment funds use financing transactions be disclosed to investors and the public. Considering that transparency is one of the key measures to reform the financial sector, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it creates more financial stability in an important market, but without unnecessarily disturbing the market and its stakeholders. With this regulation we are transferring the SFT market into a better regulated framework. The proposed regulation delivers binding transparency and reporting requirements in 3 key areas;  firstly all SFT transactions will have to be reported to supervisors so that they can monitor systemic risk. Secondly we have ensured transparency towards investors so that they can make transparent investment decisions. And thirdly assets can only be reused within certain parameters and with prior consent. In essence, we have created transparency towards supervisors and investors with a minimal burden for all stakeholders.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Excess speculative activity in European financial markets, the complexity of traded products and the lack of an adequate regulatory framework were some of the main causes of the 2008 financial crisis. The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reporting and transparency of securities financing operations builds a levee on these problems through important synthesis work among the main disciplines in this area at European level.  In particular, European standards are rising in the shadow banking system, which has been an amplifier of the financial crisis through the spread of toxic products in national financial markets. Another important element is the increased cooperation between the authorities present at European level in the supervision of financial markets, for example the central banks of the European system and the competent authorities. Therefore, this text adds a fundamental element to that regulatory framework, which the European Union is equipping itself with both to monitor the markets more closely and to restore the centrality of the economic fabric in the financial markets.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report on the transparency of securities financing transactions is an interesting approach. By proposing an obligation to be transparent and reporting transactions in a central repository and by forcing listed companies using this type of transaction to inform their investors, it is moving in the right direction. However, this report is only a watered-down version of previous versions. While the Soru report strictly framed the reuse of security and the Directive on Structural Reform of the Banking Sector proposed to separate speculative and risky banking activities, the latter version abandoned these important points. Noting, however, that this report proposes welcome regulations on this sector that is not closely monitored, I voted in favour.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Soru report in support of improving transparency and monitoring securities financing transactions, in line with international measures. This legislation is in line with the international work in this area and introduces a reporting requirement for Securities Financing Transactions (SFTs), re-hypothecation and securities.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Increasing the transparency of securities financing markets is important to ensure equivalent conditions of competition.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation responds to the need to strengthen the transparency of financing markets through securities and, therefore, the financial system. In order to ensure a level playing field and international convergence, this Regulation follows the recommendations made by the EFC.  It establishes a framework at Union level under which information on SFTs can be efficiently provided to trade repositories and investors. Therefore, regulatory and supervisory authorities may face less transparency with regard to these activities, preventing them from obtaining an adequate overview of the risks associated with securities financing operations. This would only aggravate the already well-proven links between the regulated banking sector and the shadow banking system in certain markets.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system. That is why I voted in favour of this Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency, as it improves transparency, regulation and supervision, particularly with regard to central information, disclosure of these operations, as well as minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees. These transactions include major loans and securities repurchase agreements, which are exchanged by entities and activities outside the regular banking system (i.e. so-called shadow banking). Our group has worked to add some improvements to the Commission's proposals, which we consider particularly important. Among them, its scope, to cover new financial operations in its definition. We have also increased reporting obligations to ensure that all information is provided to the competent authority.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the implementation of the Capital Markets Union does not provide an opportunity to deregulate the financial sector.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The stated objective of this proposal for a Regulation is to increase transparency and monitoring of financial activities outside the traditional banking sector, i.e. the shadow banking sector ("shadow"). It was this type of financial products that was behind the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers and, therefore, the 2007/2008 financial crisis. It was not because of lack of transparency or notification that the crisis was triggered, but because of the very characteristic of the "products". On the other hand, any changes that have since been made to legislation to increase the level of regulation, or which are still in the pipeline, will always remain insufficient. The solution is to prohibit financing operations through securities. It should be necessary: or prohibit commercial banks from selling the credits they grant to companies and individuals (the possibility of selling credit leads to less force in risk analysis and, on the other hand, those who grant credit are the ones who best know the implicit risk – with successive sales, the information is lost); or prohibit the securitisation of credit (post-securitisation classification is made by rating agencies, to which investment banks pay the "good ratings"). And in any case, a separation of commercial banking from investment banking should be promoted. We voted against it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as not enough transparency guaranteed.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Increasing the transparency of securities financing markets is important to ensure equivalent conditions of competition, which is why I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on reporting and transparency in relation to securities financing transactions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the outcome of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on reporting and transparency of securities financing transactions, building up transparency, regulation and supervision of SFT in central reporting.  I would like to express my strong support for the following additions to the original Commission proposal: first of all, the extension of the regulation’s objective by including new financial operations within the range of SFTs and requiring reports of transactions from all the entities engaged in SFTs with exception of SMEs and ESCB; secondly, the reporting obligations of information to the competent authority as soon as it is possible; thirdly, the preparation of a report from the Commission on the introduction of a haircuts framework that includes also developments at international level and in particular the ongoing work of the Financial Stability Board on this subject; last but not least, the granting of a phased implementation of the SFT regulation by type of counterparty, linking it to the finalisation of Level 2 measures.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the global financial crisis has exposed excessive speculative activity, significant regulatory deficiencies and supervisory efficiency problems in a financial system characterised by market opaqueness and overly complex products. The crisis has also highlighted the need to increase transparency and control not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in the area of so-called shadow banks carrying out non-bank lending activities, the proportion of which has been alarming and now represents around half of the regulated banking system. In view of the above, in order to prevent a recurring major financial crisis, a solution should be found to excessive leverage in the financial system, in particular where this excessive rate leads to an increase in shadow bank activities. It is important to recall that the primary task of the financial sector is not to speculate on assets, but to provide the capital needed to finance a productive economy.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the finding, following the global financial crisis of 2007 and 2008, that there are significant regulatory gaps in the financial system. The EU has already taken a number of measures to make the banking system more robust and stable. However, the crisis has highlighted the need to improve transparency and supervision, not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in areas where non-banks carry out credit activities. It is important to remember that the primary function of the financial sector should be to direct capital towards financing the productive economy, not asset speculation, so we must legislate accordingly.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed in the financial system significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products.  That is why I voted in favour of this Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency, as it improves transparency, regulation and supervision, particularly with regard to central information and disclosure of these operations, as well as minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees. These transactions include major loans and securities repurchase agreements, which are exchanged for entities and activities outside the regular banking system (i.e. so-called shadow banking). Our group has worked to add some improvements to the Commission's proposals which we consider particularly important. Among them, its scope, to cover new financial transactions in its definitions. We have also increased reporting obligations to ensure that all information is provided to the competent authority.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the launch of the Capital Markets Union is not an opportunity to deregulate the financial sector.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system.  That is why I voted in favour of this Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency, as it improves transparency, regulation and supervision, particularly with regard to central information and disclosure of these operations, as well as minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees. These transactions include major loans and securities repurchase agreements, which are exchanged for entities and activities outside the regular banking system (i.e. so-called shadow banking). Our group has worked to add some improvements to the Commission's proposals which we consider particularly important. Among them, its scope, to cover new financial transactions in its definitions. We have also increased reporting obligations to ensure that all information is provided to the competent authority.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the launch of the Capital Markets Union is not an opportunity to deregulate the financial sector.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution establishing the Agreement between the Council and the EP on the Securities Financing Transactions Regulation, because these transactions play a significant role in the financial sector and provide liquidity to the secondary debt market, and contribute to an efficient allocation and better use of capital. I therefore agree with the need for this new piece of sectoral financial legislation, which will enter into force in the near future, because, with a view to the creation of the Capital Markets Union (CMU), it already makes a significant contribution to increasing the transparency and security of the financial markets, while ensuring the necessary liquidity of this market, which is important for the financing and use of liquidity. The new regulation aims to achieve precise objectives: the obligation to report to a directory of data on all securities transactions, which will make it possible to know the size and link between the traditional banking system and the shadow banking system when carrying out securities transactions, increasing transparency between investment funds operating in shadow banking and investors , and, finally, more detailed regulation of the re-use or re-mortgage of securities.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the transparency of securities financing transactions, as I warmly welcome more honesty and transparency in this area. For me, the basis and guide is the traditional principle of the honourable merchant, to which we must give a new European dimension.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. It is important to draw the right conclusions from the financial crisis in 2007-2008. Triggering factors such as excessive speculation and ineffective supervision have led, among other things, to this crisis. That is why I voted in favour of greater transparency in the context of securities financing operations in the future, in order to ensure better protection through an early response.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will ensure that securities financing transactions will be more transparent in the future. The underlying reason for the securities financing transactions report is to make our banking system safer, increase transparency and improve supervision. These instruments play a significant role in the financial sector in that they ensure liquidity in the secondary debt market, contribute to an efficient settlement and allow for better employment of capital. This agreement not only strengthens the reporting obligation, it also improves the collection of data on the transactions, enabling better monitoring of risk concentrations and identifying counterparty exposures. It is important we do not focus merely on regulating the banking sector but also tackle other means through which highly risky activities continue within our financial services sector. This is critical for the success of the capital markets union.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The economic and financial crisis that began in 2008 has exposed a number of shortcomings in the financial system, such as significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision and overly complex products. Some of the deficiencies observed need to be corrected. I therefore support this Regulation, which seeks to increase the transparency of securities financing operations, the opacity of which has in the past prevented regulatory and supervisory authorities, as well as investors, from correctly assessing and controlling the corresponding risks.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the transparency of securities financing operations. The adoption of this regulation, which proposes measures to avoid excessive leverage and rules on the transparency of financing operations, is a necessary measure to date. The crisis we are still experiencing has broken out as a result of financial speculation and serious regulatory loopholes. We can no longer expect legislative shortcomings in a sector such as finance which should devote capital to financing the productive economy and not to speculative activity.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report, because while we share the objective of improving the transparency of financial transactions, we believe that the final result of the text is such a slight development that, in the end, it implies maintaining the situation of opacity that favours shadow banking and financial speculation.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on Transparency of securities financing transactions because making lending and re-use of securities more transparent to foster financial stability without putting an additional administrative burden on the management of funds is necessary for channelling money into the real economy.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed in the financial system significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products.  That is why I voted in favour of this Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency, as it improves transparency, regulation and supervision, particularly with regard to central information and disclosure of these operations, as well as minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees. These transactions include major loans and securities repurchase agreements, which are exchanged for entities and activities outside the regular banking system (i.e. so-called shadow banking). Our group has worked to add some improvements to the Commission's proposals which we consider particularly important. Among them, its scope, to cover new financial transactions in its definitions. We have also increased reporting obligations to ensure that all information is provided to the competent authority.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the launch of the Capital Markets Union is not an opportunity to deregulate the financial sector.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it aims to enhance financial stability in the EU by increasing the transparency of certain market activities, such as securities financing transactions (SFTs), re-hypothecation and other financing structures having an equivalent economic effect to SFTs. The global financial crisis highlighted the need to improve transparency and monitoring, not only in the traditional banking sector but also in areas where non-bank credit activities take place, so-called ‘shadow banking’.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the reporting and transparency of securities financing transactions, as an agreement reached on a trilogue is supported, and the proposal aims to strengthen financial stability in the EU by increasing transparency regarding various banking activities, such as securities financing transactions, including repo transactions, securities lending or other contracting goods , lending of securities or goods from the other contracting party, transactions involving the purchase of a security and its re-sale (buy-sell back) or transactions involving the sale of a security and its re-purchase (sell-back) and collateral swap transactions. It enables the creation of leverage, pro-cyclicality and interconnections in financial markets.  The main function of the financial sector should be to focus capital on financing the productive economy, not on asset speculation. This legislative framework achieves more transparent lending creation and reuse of securities, fosters financial stability without additional administrative burden when managing the funds needed to channel money into the real economy.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text establishes rules to make securities financing transactions transparent, commonly referred to as shadow banking.  "Shadow banking" refers to a phenomenon with blurred outlines comprising a whole set of entities whose financial intermediation activities are called "parallels". These, in fact, are not part of traditional banking. These operations thus benefit from almost non-existent regulation and borrow attractive channels (little or no taxed and high interest) but dangerous (no public guarantees). They are the work of investment banks, mutual funds, insurers, pension or money funds, private equity firms or hedge funds. Flexible regulation of these activities is absolutely necessary, especially since the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers in 2008. Indeed, the opacity of the transactions generated by shadow banking, by not identifying the owners of the securities and their real value, is partly responsible for the spread of the crisis in the United States and then in the world by ricochet.  The European regulations we have passed mitigate the risk inherent in this type of activity, in particular by imposing more transparency.  I voted for it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Renato Soru's report on the transparency of securities financing transactions. This report is part of the desire to regulate the shadow banking system. Indeed, if securities financing operations contribute to market liquidity and allow central banks to refinance, they can lead, without regulation, to strong market destabilization, as we saw in 2008. This text therefore aims to mitigate these negative effects by creating rules equivalent to those to which banks are subject. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report provides for better supervision of financial markets without having to forego the instruments necessary for the real and financial sectors. The amendments adopted as a whole allow for good overview and transparency measures.  I therefore agree with this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it aims to make the financial sector more transparent and more stable. It is crucial that we managed to increase the transparency of these transactions by strengthening the reporting obligations and the supervisory role and at the same time by reducing double reporting.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation. I believe that this measure is capable of achieving the objective that this Parliament has set itself with it: to make a contribution to strengthening the financial stability of the Union. In fact, the regulation adopted today introduces important rules on financial transparency for certain financing operations, and specifically for securities financing.  I took a positive view of the fact that the rule primarily designed for small investors – that is, citizens – who need, in terms of investment, a regulatory framework that will ensure maximum transparency in their financing operations.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the transparency report on securities financing transactions. This is an important part of non-bank credit activities. This parallel finance is dangerous in many respects: by the colossal amounts it represents, by its opacity, by the excessive use of leverage, by the diffusion of risk to a chain of mis-identified investors, etc.  The trilogue concluded on 17 June 2015 reached an agreement on transparency and reporting obligations to a central repository. For listed companies using these transactions, it will also be necessary to inform investors. It is therefore a step in the right direction. Nevertheless, it remains insufficient.  The initial report provided a fairly strict frame, for example, for the reuse of security, while the version that is put to the vote is less restrictive. I believe that these operations should be prohibited. Moreover, the real reform that needs to be carried out to avoid the dispersion of risk is the separation of banking activities. Ending universal banking is a more effective bulwark against the contagion of financial sector risks. This point is now, alas, stalled.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed in the financial system significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products. That is why I voted in favour of this Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency, as it improves transparency, regulation and supervision, particularly with regard to central information and disclosure of these operations, as well as minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees. These transactions include major loans and securities repurchase agreements, which are exchanged for entities and activities outside the regular banking system (i.e. so-called shadow banking). Our group has worked to add some improvements to the Commission's proposals which we consider particularly important. Among them, its scope, to cover new financial transactions in its definitions. We have also increased reporting obligations to ensure that all information is provided to the competent authority. In this regard, it is important to ensure that the launch of the Capital Markets Union is not an opportunity to deregulate the financial sector.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it lays the groundwork for the development of new speculative bubbles to be pushed through the future creation of the Capital Market Union. This report, which represents the result of the informal three-way dialogues, proposes to regulate the notification of securities transactions within the EU, facilitating their mobility. The co-legislators start from the basis that the economic crisis was generated by financial speculation and its lack of financing of the real economy and, to solve it, propose an even greater financing of the real economy, aiming to change the bank financing of economic activity by introducing values for the financing of the productive fabric. This will have serious consequences on the translation of financial market volatility into the productive fabric, which is why I voted against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. U2012 The existence of regulatory loopholes following the increase in speculative activities generated in the financial system following the outbreak of the 2007 global financial crisis creates the need for the EU to take steps to make the banking system stronger and more stable, as is the case in this report.  This requires improving transparency and supervision in the traditional banking sector. Similarly, another very important point to consider are the credit activities carried out by non-banks; what is known as the shadow banking system.   Another objective of this report is to minimize the additional operating costs of market participants. Moreover, in the field of investment funds, full transparency is particularly important, as making investments with incomplete or incorrect information can result in numerous losses for investors.  For these reasons, I support this report, as it will help to improve the transparency of securities financing markets and, therefore, the financial system, whose main function should be to direct capital towards financing the productive economy, not asset speculation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The complexity and opacity of SMEs makes it difficult to identify other contracting parties and monitor risk concentrations. The Financial Stability Board and the European Systemic Risk Board identified the risks of securities financing transactions. The new rules should apply to those laid down in Directives 2009/65/EC and 2011/61/EU. I supported Representative Renato Soru's report because of the importance of publishing all reliable and detailed information related to the use of securities financing transactions. Existing periodic reports need to be supplemented with additional information, so this Regulation lays down stricter rules on informing other contracting parties about reuse.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 In business in any country of the world, there is undeniably a principle of trade secret that must be respected in order to be able to develop and compete with other companies successfully enough. But its possibility of its existence can be accepted when it concerns a variety of unique goods, invention patents, recipes for food and other examples, but not when it comes to the scope of taxation and respect for the principle of transparency. One of the reasons why the current global financial crisis began about 7-8 years ago was precisely the lack of such transparency and the boom in speculative activities, including in the real estate market. One of the main efforts of this proposal for a regulation is to deal directly with the possibility of a crisis by promoting greater transparency in securities financing transactions. Companies, including companies primarily employed in financial transactions, can undeniably also function successfully in a context of greater transparency. Moreover, in such circumstances, any type of business must also function, since it is undoubtedly not only about closer cooperation with the supervisory authorities for financial transactions, but also for partners involved in securities financing transactions, i.e. the direct colleagues of the companies themselves. Greater transparency, the introduction of coordinated and standardised principles for the functioning of international financial and securities markets and further promotion are at least a partial guarantee that, if not fully, what happened a few years ago will be possible, at least in a coordinated and effective manner, in the shortest possible time.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Speculative SFTs in the non-banking sector are detrimental to the EU economy and are a source of risk within the current financial system, which is not clearly defined and regulated. The Regulation introduces increased transparency through its requirements and measures (e.g. reporting obligations for all types of SFTs). This can also be of assistance to investors themselves, while respecting the protection of fundamental rights, in particular the right to the protection of personal data, the right to respect for private and family life, the freedom to conduct a business and property rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on reporting and transparency in relation to securities financing transactions, because it is not complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 28/10/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which brings vital transparency to the financial sector. I particularly welcome the reporting obligations and supervisory role which this legislation will introduce.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the proposal for a regulation on the transparency of securities financing operations. The regulation aims to improve the transparency of the lending of securities and repurchase agreements. This proposal will increase financial stability by ensuring that information on securities financing operations is efficiently communicated to the competent authorities. In addition, it will introduce measures to improve transparency, such as monitoring the accumulation of the financial systemic risks related to security financing operations and the re-use by banks and intermediaries of collateral provided by customers.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. In financial markets, the development of complex transactions (whether long-term, short or temporary) has been exponential since the early 2000s. The regulator is forced to monitor financial innovations remotely. This is the case for temporary securities financing transactions (CTT), where an operator may repo securities he owns in exchange for consideration. These transactions are used massively by banks for refinancing purposes, but are very poorly informed. European and national regulatory authorities are not informed of the potential reuse, for example, of repurchased securities. This creates chains of interdependence that can lead to contagion in the event of a crisis.  The Soru report sets out three basic rules: an obligation to report counterparties to the European Securities Authority, an obligation to inform investors, and a limitation on the possibility of re-employment of resealed securities. While the problem of financial innovation must probably be taken further upstream, I support any regulation that supports moderation in complex transactions, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report does not bring significant improvements to monitor and tame financial markets without sacrificing the tools necessary for the real and financial industries. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The regulation referred to here establishes rules to make securities financing transactions generally referred to as shadow banking transparent. This term refers to a phenomenon with blurred outlines comprising a whole set of entities whose financial intermediation activities are called "parallels". These, in fact, are not part of traditional banking. These operations thus benefit from almost non-existent regulation and borrow attractive channels (little or no taxed and high interest) but dangerous (no public guarantees). They are the work of investment banks, mutual funds, insurers, pension or money funds, private equity firms or hedge funds. Flexible regulation of these activities is absolutely necessary, especially since the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers in 2008. Indeed, the opacity of the transactions generated by shadow banking, by not identifying the owners of the securities and their real value, is partly responsible for the spread of the crisis in the United States and then in the world by ricochet.  The European regulations we have passed mitigate the risk inherent in this type of activity, in particular by imposing more transparency.  So the congressman voted in favour.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Problems relating to securities financing operations have been identified and, with a view to minimising risks and increasing the transparency of such transactions, the proposal for a Regulation introduces certain measures. It is necessary to improve transparency in the field of monitoring the accumulation of systemic risks associated with securities financing operations in the financial system, as well as the reporting of such transactions to investors. I have presented my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it stresses the need to increase transparency and monitoring of so-called ‘shadow banking’ to avoid excess exposure of investors to systemic risks.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It is likely that Member States will adopt divergent national measures that could create obstacles to the proper functioning of the internal market and be harmful to market participants and financial stability. It is therefore necessary to prevent such distortions and obstacles from appearing in the Union. Technical standards in the financial services sector should ensure consistent harmonisation and ensure adequate protection for depositors, investors and consumers across the EU. In order to ensure an effective regulatory framework for the shadow banking system, progress in introducing and implementing internationally consistent requirements is essential.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 As the global financial crisis has exposed significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, market opacity and very complex products in the financial system, I welcome the Regulation on SFTs, the main purpose of which is to combat securities financing transactions from developing without proper supervision, including outside a regulated banking system. I agree that transparency is important so that the authorities concerned and all market participants are adequately informed about how the markets operate and of the scale and nature of any potential risk, which increases credibility. The recent past has shown that when confidence in the value of assets, the safety of counterparties and investor protection collapsed, deposits on the wholesale market were taken out en masse, leading to a sudden reduction in leverage and the need for public safety nets.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Regulation on reporting and transparency of securities financing transactions (SFT-R), which aims at improving transparency, regulation and supervision of SFT in central reporting, disclosure of SFTs and reuse to investors and minimum requirements for reuse of collateral. I am also glad with the final result to exclude SMEs and the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) from the scope of the Regulation.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has submitted a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the notification and transparency of securities financing transactions. The global financial crisis of 2007-2008 also highlighted the need to increase transparency and control not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in the area of so-called shadow banks carrying out non-bank lending activities, which now represent around half of the regulated banking system. Shortcomings in the activities in question, such as those of banks, can also cause damage to the regulated financial sector. In the wake of the global financial crisis, the Eu has committed itself to establishing a banking union and structural reform of the banking sector in order to create a more robust and stable banking system. However, the introduction of structural measures affecting banks may result in some activities being transferred to less regulated areas, such as the shadow banking sector. This is why the binding transparency and notification requirements for SSTs set out in the Regulation proposed by the Commission are necessary. The transparency rules contained in this Regulation therefore complement the rules on structural reform in the Union. Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs tabled a number of amendments to the draft regulation in its report, but at the same time recommended the draft to Parliament for adoption. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The need to enhance the transparency of securities financing markets has led to the creation of this Regulation with a view to ensuring a level playing field in international competition and convergence. The assessment and control of banking risks and the level of interconnection of the financial system by investors, regulators and supervisors can only be effective if there are conditions of transparency in the course of operations. To this extent, efficiency and the provision of specific information on securities financing operations (SFTs) will be enhanced, i.e. relating to repurchase transactions, securities or commodity lending, lending through securities or commodities, buy/resell or sell/repurchase transactions, liquidity swaps and collateral swaps. I am voting in favour of this Regulation because it responds to the need for transparent supervision and market formation, establishing a stronger banking system, capable of avoiding situations of financial instability and promoting the proper functioning of the internal market in the Member States.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This Soru report concerns the transparency of securities financing transactions, which relate to all transactions that use assets to generate financing. This is therefore an important part of the shadow banking activity carried out by economic agents not under the constraint of banking legislation. This shadow finance is dangerous, as it is not controlled and its growth is exponential. Last June's trilogue resulted in an agreement on transparency obligations that is welcome but still insufficient. The rapporteur goes further by proposing, for example, the stricter framework for the reuse of security, a particularly harmful practice. I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on reporting and transparency of securities financing transactions.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a regulation on reporting and transparency for financing transactions builds on the Green Paper and the Communication on shadow banking published by the Commission in 2012 and 2013. Due to the complicated and opaque nature of financing transactions (SFTs), it is difficult to identify the parties and monitor the concentration of risks. I therefore appreciate that the proposal for a regulation focuses on reducing shadow banking and defining the risks arising from SFTs, thus contributing to increasing the transparency of the SFTs markets and, by extension, the entire financial system. The need for this regulation is also due to the fact that, following the structural reform of the Union banking sector, the activities currently carried out by traditional banks could be shifted to shadow banking.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This report was concerned with Securities financing in the lending of securities (e.g. stocks, bonds, asset-backed securities etc.) in return for cash. Typical transactions are repos, reverse repos, buy-sell back transactions or sell-buy back transactions and collateral swaps which are all used by most banks in order to increase liquidity in the market.  These financial instruments pose a major risk to financial stability. In the wake of the financial crisis, the EU has to some extent tried to reform the regular banking sector. As a result of the ‘tougher’ regulation of banks, it is safe to assume that banks will try to shift their financial activities such as SFTs to the shadow banking sector as it is basically non-regulated (shadow banks are credit institutions like Lehman Brothers that operate outside the regular banking sector). As such, this regulation seeks to prevent a migration to shadow banking by increasing transparency and reporting on SFTs outside the normal banking sector.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. On the one hand, I am in favour of transparency in the securities sector, as it ultimately has a positive impact on the protection of all economic operators. On the other hand, however, the measures must also be capable of actually promoting this transparency. It must not just be an increase in bureaucracy, with little practical benefit. However, this was the case here. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to increase the EU's financial stability and transparency.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because the security and transparency of the financial market need to be improved. It is necessary to prevent abuse and the possibility of relocating its activities to the shadow banking sector.   In view of the current situation and in order to increase the transparency of securities lending and repurchase agreements, uniform transparency and reporting requirements should be applied across the EU. In addition, monitoring of the increase in systemic risk associated with the use of securities financing transactions needs to be facilitated.  In particular, transaction data should be reported to trade repositories. The competent authorities shall have direct and immediate access to these data.  Transparency of re-pledge agreements is required. The new common rules on data provision and transparency and the provisions on re-collateralisation will help to strengthen financial stability in the Union.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I think that the voting session of this document is an excellent opportunity to give a boost to the resolution of the problem of the lack of transparency in the financial sector. I have found myself tabling amendments on several occasions, with the same intention, on motions for resolutions on this subject. I fully agree that a legally binding legislative text regulating precisely the progress of financing operations is finally adopted. I would vote in favour and I would be very pleased with the positive outcome of the vote in the whole House.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I believe that more regular reporting and more transparent securities financing transactions would have a significant impact on financial market stability and investment security in financial instruments. The more types of such transactions are covered by the proposal for a regulation that deals with this report, the more likely it is to be more transparent about financial market activities.  Greater availability of information is also needed for all contracting parties when conducting transactions. That is why I agree with the Commission's initial legislative proposal, which states that credit institutions and companies should inform the public about their activities in securities financing transactions as part of their regular public reports. The Croatian banking system is small and therefore even more susceptible to external influences and possible manipulations.  Since most banks in Croatia are foreign-owned, shadow banking can be a significant problem because unfortunately domestic banks are too dependent on foreign centrals. I therefore hope that this proposal for a regulation will raise the level of regulation and reduce the risks that accompany securities financing transactions.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This Soru report concerns the transparency of securities financing transactions, which relate to all transactions that use assets to generate financing. This is therefore an important part of the shadow banking activity carried out by economic agents not under the constraint of banking legislation. This shadow finance is dangerous, as it is not controlled and its growth is exponential.  Last June's trilogue resulted in an agreement on transparency obligations that is welcome but still insufficient. The rapporteur goes further by proposing, for example, the stricter framework for the reuse of security, a particularly harmful practice. I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support colleague Renato Soru's report on the transparency of securities financing transactions. As the global economic and financial crisis has revealed excessive speculative activity since 2007, the Union has adopted a number of measures to make the banking system firmer and more stable, including stricter capital requirements, rules on improved governance and supervision and a resolution mechanism. In this context, progress in the establishment of the Banking Union is also decisive.  However, the crisis also highlighted the need to improve transparency and supervision, not only in the traditional banking sector, but also in the areas of non-bank credit activities known as the "shadow banking system". In particular, the lack of transparency in the use of SMEs prevented regulatory and supervisory authorities as well as investors from properly assessing and monitoring the risks at issue similar to bank risks and the level of interconnection in the financial system in the period before and during the financial crisis.  In order to ensure an effective regulatory framework for shadow banking, progress in introducing and implementing coherent requirements at international level remains essential. The Commission should report regularly to the European Parliament and the Council on the G20 plan, aimed at strengthening the supervision and regulation of shadow banking, and should also present the state of play of the measures taken within the Union and the main competences of third countries.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 June 2015, the Council and the European Parliament reached political agreement on the proposal for a regulation on the reporting and transparency of securities financing operations, known as the Securities Financing Transactions (SFTR).  This proposal, presented by the Commission in January 2014, is aimed at implementing the framework of intervention approved by the Financial Stability Board, an international body responsible for monitoring the global financial system, consisting of eleven recommendations on risks related to the lending of securities and sales transactions with a repurchase commitment in the shadow banking system.  The proposal for a regulation focuses on improving the transparency of securities lending and repurchase agreements, in order to enable the competent authorities and all relevant market players to properly understand the functioning of the market, the extent and nature of potential risks, and to develop effective and efficient intervention tools to prevent systemic risks. I believe that the international financial system must be properly controlled by means of clear and easily applicable measures. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main objective of these provisions is to enhance the supervision and transparency of securities financing transactions. The rules are in line with international work in this area and require the reporting of securities financing, pawning and securities lending transactions. That is why I have washed the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In order to promote a more transparent banking system, the European Commission has proposed a package of legislative measures. In this context, the European Parliament has adopted a regulation encouraging greater transparency for securities financing transactions. These transactions mainly involve loan or borrowing transactions of securities and commodities.  I am in favour of a more transparent banking system, in order to avoid certain abuses and to limit the instability of financial markets (as in 2008).

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Securities financing operations are, in essence, a form of collateralized financing, which enables a temporary exchange of assets as collateral for loan or repurchase transactions through securities. Taking into account the so-called "shadow banking system", in which non-bank credit activities are carried out with scale and expression to contaminate the regulated financial sector, and also taking into account the specific risks posed by securities financing operations (which intensify indebtedness and pro-cyclical design and interdependence in financial markets), it is essential to ensure the transparency of transactions , the analysis of which will enable the development of effective and efficient policy instruments to prevent systemic risks. Whereas all efforts must be directed towards preventing excessive leverage of the financial system, resulting in another major financial crisis, I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Since 2008, the global financial crisis since 2008 revealed large regulatory gaps in the financial system, oversight problems, market opacity, and overly complex products. Since then, the EU has been adopting a set of measures aimed at building a stronger and more stable banking system. The Regulation on the notification of securities financing operations and their transparency is in addition to these measures. It improves the transparency, regulation and supervision of securities financing operations in terms of central information, disclosure of such transactions and notification to investors, and minimum requirements for the reuse of guarantees, which, among others, I have supported it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. With the 2007-08 global financial crisis revealing excess speculative activity, significant gaps in financial sector regulation, as well as ineffective supervision, opacity of markets and excessive complexity of financial products, I supported this report, which notably points out that the primary function of the financial sector must be to direct capital towards financing the productive economy and not asset speculation. The crisis has also highlighted the need to improve transparency and monitoring not only of the traditional banking sector but also in sectors where non-bank lending activities are taking place. Today's text contributes to this.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on the transparency of securities lending operations as it aims to strengthen and improve financial stability in the European Union. The report introduces new rules on financial transparency such as the obligation to report and communicate securities financing operations to investors.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report, because while we share the objective of improving the transparency of financial transactions, we believe that the final result of the text is such a slight development that, in the end, it implies maintaining the situation of opacity that favours shadow banking and financial speculation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it lays the groundwork for the development of new speculative bubbles to be pushed through the future creation of the Capital Market Union. This report, which represents the result of the informal three-way dialogues, proposes to regulate the notification of securities transactions within the EU, facilitating their mobility. The co-legislators start from the basis that the economic crisis was generated by financial speculation and its lack of financing of the real economy and, to solve it, propose an even greater financing of the real economy, aiming to change the bank financing of economic activity by introducing values for the financing of the productive fabric. This will have serious consequences on the translation of financial market volatility into the productive fabric, which is why I voted against it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The global financial crisis has highlighted the presence of over-speculative activity and the existence of serious regulatory gaps in the financial system, also highlighting the ineffectiveness of supervision, the opacity of markets and the excessive complexity of products. Due to the lack of harmonised transparency rules, national authorities have often encountered many difficulties in comparing micro-level data from different Member States and thus understanding the real risks that individual operators pose to the system. It is necessary to prevent such distortions and obstacles from being created in the Union.  This Regulation responds to the need to increase the transparency of securities financing operations. Thanks to this new regulatory framework, securities financing operations can be efficiently reported in trading data re-available and communicated to investors. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because it extends the Commission’s power.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it aims to make the financial sector more transparent. It is crucial that we manage to increase the transparency of these transactions by strengthening the reporting obligations and the supervisory role and, at the same time, by reducing double reporting.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider capital management to finance a productive economy rather than asset speculation to be a major function of the financial sector. The last global financial crisis, which occurred in 2007-2008, exposed excessive speculative activities in the financial system, significant regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, market opacity and overly complex products. It is necessary to clarify and regulate certain banking and financial products and instruments.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Following excessive speculative activities in the financial sphere, it is essential to ensure effective supervision, transparency of markets, simplification of complex products and increased transparency of transactions. This will not only make the banking system more reliable and stable, but will also provide greater protection for our citizens.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report since the global financial crisis that erupted in the period 2007-2008 revealed speculative activities, important regulatory shortcomings, inefficient supervision, opaque markets and too complex products in the financial system. The Union has adopted a number of measures to strengthen and strengthen the banking system, such as stricter capital requirements, a resolution mechanism and rules on improved governance and supervision.  Looking at this context, progress in establishing a Banking Union is also decisive. The crisis also pointed to one more thing, which is that transparency is needed not only in the banking system, but also in the areas of non-banking credit activities known as the "shadow banking system". Of concern is the fact that the number of activities recorded in the areas of the 'shadow banking system' is already the same as half of the regulated banking system, and activities and shortcomings can contaminate the regulated financial sector.  It should therefore be recalled that the main function of the financial sector is to focus capital on financing production rather than asset speculation.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to make the financial section more transparent and more stable. It is crucial that we are successful in increasing the transparency of these transactions by strengthening the reporting obligations and the supervisory role and at the same time by reducing double reporting

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Global Financial Crisis of 2008 revealed a number of speculative activities, important regulatory shortcomings, inefficient oversight and opaque financial markets. The European Union has adopted a number of measures to improve the regulation of the banking system, including stricter capital requirements, more efficient supervision, etc.  However, supervision and greater transparency are not only necessary in the traditional banking sector, but also in the area of non-bank credit activities known as the 'shadow banking system'. The size of "a shadow banking system is already equal to half of a regulated banking system.  The complexity and opacity of SMEs makes it difficult to identify other contracting parties and monitor the concentration of risks. All these shortcomings can contaminate the regulated financial sector. It is important to recall that the main function of the financial sector should be to focus capital on financing the productive economy rather than on asset speculation.
