I support this proposal because it highlights better regulation in three main areas: monitoring systemic risks associated with securities financing transactions, disclosing information about such transactions to investors whose assets are involved in such transactions, and contractual transparency in situations where financial institutions use their clients' collateral for their own borrowing.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ I did not support the proposal. It is based on the notion that the 2007-2008 financial crisis was the result of excessive speculative activities, lack of regulation and supervision, and so on. However, the exact opposite is true – the financial sector is already the most regulated sector of the economy today, and the financial crisis was the result of excessive and not insufficient central planning. The high regulatory burden represents high barriers to market entry and therefore economic activities are concentrated in the hands of far fewer players, which also increases the number of 'too big to fail' players. The second problem is the moral hazard itself associated with rescuing "too big to fail" financial entities. Finally, speculative and unsustainable financial activities would not have been possible to the extent that the ECB and other central banks had not provided cheap money to the market at artificially low interest rates. However, the proposal further increases the regulatory burden on the financial sector and will therefore ultimately intensify these problems.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reporting and transparency of SFTs. We all remember very well one of the main causes of the economic and financial crisis, the consequences of which we still feel today.  No one supports speculative activities, legislative gaps and ineffective controls. By adopting this report, we will, inter alia, improve communication between competent authorities and mutual assistance and cooperation, which will also contribute to greater transparency of SFTs.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Increasing the transparency of securities financing markets is important to ensure equivalent conditions of competition.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the notification and transparency of securities financing transactions. The notification and transparency of SSTs is a prerequisite for the development of a transparent and resilient European financial system. I agree with the report's finding that unregulated banking and shadow banking should be held back, as this is in Europe's key interest. This is why a legal framework is needed to ensure the transparency of the SSTs system for the market surveillance authority. In particular, I support the suggestion that uniform requirements at international level need to be introduced and implemented in order to ensure an effective regulatory framework for shadow bank activities.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I have of course voted in favour of this text which advocates transparency in financial flows and helps to hinder the speculation that led to the 2008 crisis and the tragedy experienced by millions of people as a result of the enrichment and lightness of a few.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as a way to enhance financial stability in the EU by increasing transparency of activities that qualify as shadow banking. The Commission proposal focuses in particular on securities financing transactions (SFTs) that comprise a variety of secured transactions with similar economic effects to lending or borrowing securities and commodities and to repurchase or reverse repurchase transactions. The regulation introduces three main measures to improve transparency: monitoring of the build-up of systemic risks; disclosing information to the investors; and setting minimum conditions to be met by the parties involved. An important feature of the draft regulation is that it fosters financial stability without putting an additional administrative burden on the management of funds that channel money into the real economy.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on reporting and transparency of SFTs and their transparency supported, as I believe that this regulation will strengthen the transparency of financial markets in securities and, consequently, the whole financial system, and establishes a Union framework that allows effective reporting of information on SFTs, trades and investors.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report, because while we share the objective of improving the transparency of financial transactions, we believe that the final result of the text is such a slight development that, in the end, it implies maintaining the situation of opacity that favours shadow banking and financial speculation.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The global financial crisis of 2007-2008 exposed excessive speculative activity, significant regulatory deficiencies and supervisory efficiency problems in a financial system characterised by market opaqueness and overly complex products. In order to create a more robust and stable banking system, the Union has adopted a number of measures, including a tightening of capital requirements, rules on better governance and supervision, and resolution mechanisms. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report, because while we share the objective of improving the transparency of financial transactions, we believe that the final result of the text is such a slight development that, in the end, it implies maintaining the situation of opacity that favours shadow banking and financial speculation.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this text, because it extends transparency to these instruments which involve borrowing and lending securities or pledging them as collateral.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on reporting and transparency of securities financing transactions. The financial crisis that emerged in 2007-2008 has revealed excessive speculative activities, important regulatory gaps, ineffective supervision, opaque markets and overly complex products in the financial system.  I agree that the crisis has also highlighted the need to improve transparency and monitoring not only in the traditional banking sector but also in areas where non-bank credit activities take place, called ‘shadow banking’. In order to ensure the effective implementation of the reporting of securities financing transactions, a phased implementation of the requirements by counterparties is necessary. This should consider the effective ability of the counterparties to comply with the reporting obligations.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. During the last part-session, the Securities Financing Transactions (SFT) Regulation was voted on, i.e. securities financing operations. The proposal was presented last year by the European Commission together with the Bank for Structural Reform. The initial objective was to prevent banking activities from moving from the traditional banking system to the less regulated shadow banking system. The reform package, which was initially very ambitious, did not introduce really meaningful regulation in practice. On the contrary, today the Commission has amply demonstrated that it is heading in the opposite direction with the creation of the Capital Markets Union. In the ECON Committee, we supported an approach aimed at strengthening transparency requirements in order to reduce over-leverage and to limit the risk of contagion of operations. But our demands were not included in the text and the result was a watered-down compromise. During the negotiations with the Council and the Commission, the regulation was further weakened and watered down. That is why we thought it appropriate to vote against it in plenary. By voting against, we wanted to deplore yet another failed attempt by this Europe, which is incapable of acting on the causes of the crisis and unfit to defend the interests of European citizens and businesses.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it lays the groundwork for the development of new speculative bubbles to be pushed through the future creation of the Capital Market Union. This report, which represents the result of the informal three-way dialogues, proposes to regulate the notification of securities transactions within the EU, facilitating their mobility. The co-legislators start from the basis that the economic crisis was generated by financial speculation and its lack of financing of the real economy and, to solve it, propose an even greater financing of the real economy, aiming to change the bank financing of economic activity by introducing values for the financing of the productive fabric. This will have serious consequences on the translation of financial market volatility into the productive fabric, which is why I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation of Parliament and the Council concerned is part of the structural reforms of the EU banking sector and was published in the proposal of 29.01.2014 of the Structural Reform of Banking. The aim of the regulation is to increase transparency and monitoring of financial activities outside the traditional banking sector, at a time when so-called "Shadow Banking" is once again growing inanely, once again endangering the entire stability of the financial system. It's not with regulation that we're going there. The solution lies in the public control of the financial system and the separation between retail banks and investment banks. Abandoning the financial system to a mere logic of accumulating profits will only lead to increased speculation at the expense of financing the real economy that today needs capital as bread to the mouth.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report does not bring significant improvements to monitor and tame financial markets without sacrificing the tools necessary for the real and financial industries. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the transparency of securities financing operations because I believe it is necessary to fill an existing regulatory vacuum regarding supervision and transparency in the traditional banking sector and in the so-called 'shadow banking sector', where non-bank entities carry out credit activities. The strong speculative activities carried out after the 2007 financial crisis have made it clear that new regulation, based on the principle of transparency, is needed to avert the risk of a new crisis.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The agreement reached with respect to the Regulation that improves the transparency of securities lending and repurchase operations will improve financial stability by ensuring that information for such transactions is notified to trading and investor records in collective investment institutions. Enhanced transparency will prevent banks and other financial intermediaries from trying to circumvent regulations by moving parts of their activities to the less regulated shadow banking sector. Securities financing operations, often carried out by the shadow banking sector, consist of any transaction that uses counterparty assets to generate financing.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal was presented last year by the European Commission together with the well-known Bank Structural Reform to prevent banking activities from moving from the traditional system to the shadow banking system, as it is less regulated. The package was supposed to be the last piece of the financial system reform agenda developed after the 2008 financial crisis but, in practice, the proposal did not introduce any real regulation.  Moreover, the Commission has amply demonstrated that it has no intention of regulating shadow banking. On the contrary, today, it is promoting it with the proposal to create the Capital Markets Union. In the ECON Committee, I took an approach aimed at strengthening the transparency requirements and also called for the ban on re-use to be introduced into the regulation, but my demands were not included in the compromise text voted on in the ECON Committee.  During the trialogues, the regulation was further weakened in terms of exemptions, disclosure requirements and sanctions; That is why I thought it appropriate to vote against it in plenary as well.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation of Parliament and the Council concerned is part of the structural reforms of the EU banking sector and was published in the proposal of 29.01.2014 of the Structural Reform of Banking. The aim of the Regulation is to increase transparency and monitoring of financial activities outside the traditional banking sector, i.e. the parallel sector. It was this type of financial products that was behind the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers and, therefore, the 2007/2008 financial crisis. It was not because of lack of transparency or notification that the "crisis" happened, but because of the very characteristic of the "products". On the other hand, any changes that have since been made to legislation to increase the level of regulation, or which are still in the pipeline, will always remain insufficient. The solution is to prohibit financing operations through securities. We voted against it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the Mass Electronic Surveillance of Citizens of the European Union, as it is a resolution explicitly condemning the mass espionage of European citizenship and governance structures by the US National Security Agency. In addition, the Resolution regrets the latest measures taken by certain countries of the Union, such as the United Kingdom, which endanger the security of citizenship data. Another issue that is important to us and which are reflected in the Resolution is the request for immediate suspension of the Safe Harbor Decision, which allows the transfer of personal data to the United States, as well as TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Program), as well as to express concern about the growing violation of fundamental rights through privacy limitation. We would have liked to see a more concrete reference made to the purchase and sale of personal data by private companies, which we strongly condemn, and that the aggravation of the approval of treaties such as TTIP would entail for the above issues.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report looks back at the mass surveillance scandals that have splattered U.S. intelligence agencies, particularly the NSA.  In general, this text is in line with the protection of privacy; it denounces the methods of data collection and the drift of States to make citizens potential criminals and calls on Member States to drop all prosecutions against Edward Snowden and provide him with political asylum. The report also stresses the importance of establishing, at the Member State level, monitoring bodies to ensure that special services do not exceed their role by carrying out a mass-record of individuals.  However, in terms of measures, the report calls for stronger EU data protection regulations. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose electronic mass surveillance of citizens.  I also believe that it is for national governments to determine their own laws.  Just because I believe that the UK Government has got the wrong policy, does not mean that I should automatically support the European Union overruling it.  I would rather the British Parliament adjusted its own attitude towards these issues.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which seeks to ask the Commission to ensure that all data transfers to the United States are subject to an effective level of protection.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which assesses compliance with the recommendations relating to the mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens. Parliament called on the US authorities and the Member States to ban general mass surveillance of citizens and the processing of large amounts of citizens' personal data, and condemned the reported actions of the intelligence services, which have seriously damaged the trust of EU citizens and their fundamental rights. It is a shame that too little has been done to protect the fundamental rights of EU citizens. I agree with the commission to ensure that all data in the US is subject to an effective level of protection. Both the Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive are necessary to protect the fundamental rights of individuals and that both legislation must therefore be regarded as a set to be adopted simultaneously in order to ensure that the EU enjoys a high level of protection in all circumstances in all circumstances in all data processing activities.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the notion that the state can monitor citizens who have committed no crime. We feel that if citizens are under reasonable legal suspicion then appropriate measure may be taken with proper civil liberties and legal safeguards. In terms of any monitoring and surveillance, the EU has no right to be involved in this process.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have endorsed this report, which follows Edward Snowden's revelations about massive NSA spying. The report stresses the need to strengthen the protection of European citizens from mass surveillance by intelligence agencies.  Recent ECJ decisions on the Safe Harbour agreement demonstrate the need to protect citizens' fundamental privacy rights. Here we must strike a balance between respect for privacy and the safety of citizens.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal for a follow-up resolution on mass electronic surveillance of citizens takes stock of the lack of measures taken by the European Commission, other EU institutions and Member States to address widespread surveillance.  While some aspects of this resolution are moving in the right direction (stopping the prosecution of Snowden, or stopping the transfer of data to the United States), the text is overly Europeanistic and calls for solutions that undermine the sovereignty of Member States, such as the Commission's invitation to sue certain Member States, to draw recommendations to Member States Etc. Thus, the Commission, through measures that seemed to go in the right direction, is in fact trying to control citizens and states more. Big Brother is watching you! So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 A mass surveillance system destabilizes the social system, in which mistrust and fear of such an organized society spread. Citizens' personal data are at the mercy of the interests of those who orchestrate this system. I therefore voted in favour of this motion for a resolution condemning mass surveillance.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it assesses parliament's assessment of the follow-up to its recommendations a year ago on the follow-up to the mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens. In a resolution adopted a year ago, Parliament called on the US authorities and the Member States to ban the general mass surveillance of citizens and the processing of large amounts of citizens' personal data, and condemned the reported actions of the intelligence services, which have seriously damaged the trust of EU citizens and their fundamental rights. Parliament therefore welcomed the investigations of the German Bundestag, the Council of Europe, the United Nations and the Brazilian Senate, the debate in several national parliaments and the work of many civil society actors, which increased general public awareness of mass electronic surveillance. However, he expressed great disappointment at the fact that many Member States and EU institutions have generally demonstrated indifference and reluctance to take seriously the problems identified in the resolution and to implement the specific recommendations set out therein, as well as the opacity and unwillingness to engage with Parliament in dialogue. In Parliament's view, the Commission's response to the resolution to date is totally inappropriate in the light of the findings and has therefore called for a report by December 2015 at the latest. take the action referred to in the resolution. Parliament also recalled that it reserves the right to bring an action for failure to act or to transfer certain commission budgetary resources to the reserve until it has taken appropriate action on all recommendations.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In an increasingly globalised world, security measures are becoming a necessity, especially those related to the fight against terrorism. They must be applied taking into account, on the one hand, privacy and data protection, fundamental rights, and respecting the rule of law and fundamental rights obligations, on the other. Since July 2013, the Committee on Civil Liberties and Home Affairs, tasked with investigating the mass surveillance of EU citizens, has held 15 hearings and relied on statements by EU and US experts: academics, journalists, civil society, security and technology specialists.  I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the actions taken following the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens, as it calls on the Commission to communicate the 13 recommendations on mass surveillance and the possibility of extending a habeas corpus as a fundamental legal instrument to guarantee the freedom of the person from arbitrary state action , adaptable to the digital age, especially when the right to privacy and respect for the integrity and dignity of citizens are at stake.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Every citizen is treated as a potential suspect. All this leads to the corrosion of the social system, to the lack of coherence and trust of society. Mass surveillance is wrong in principle. And it is even more so as set and not discussed in Italy. We are subject to American dictates for a frightening and absurd subjection when we consider what we are talking about, namely the data and information that today concern the entire life of every single citizen. I therefore confirm my vote in favour of this motion for a resolution condemning mass surveillance.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens.  In its resolution of 12 March 2014, the European Parliament called on the US authorities and the MEMBER States of the Union to prohibit indiscriminate mass surveillance activities and the massive processing of citizens' personal data, denouncing the actions of the reported intelligence services, which had serious repercussions on the confidence and fundamental rights of UNION citizens.  Following that resolution, with today's vote, we pointed out that the level of general awareness about mass electronic surveillance has increased. At the same time, however, the resolution stressed the general lack of a sense of urgency and will on the part of the majority of Member States and in taking seriously the issues raised in the resolution and following up the concrete recommendations contained therein, just as it considered the Commission's response to be insufficient.  In its resolution, Parliament also called on the Commission to follow up the demands made by December 2015 and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because some measures outlined fall within the area of national competence and should be left to Member States’ competences.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 In its resolution of 12 March 2014, the European Parliament called on the US authorities and EU Member States to ban indiscriminate mass surveillance activities and the massive processing of citizens' personal data, as well as denouncing the actions of reported intelligence services that have had serious repercussions on the trust and fundamental rights of UNION citizens.  The resolution indicates the possible existence of other reasons, such as political and economic espionage, in view of the capacity of the reported mass surveillance programmes. Today we have instructed the LIBE Committee to continue to monitor developments in this area and the follow-up to the recommendations contained in the resolution. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad that the motion on EU citizens’ fundamental rights in relation to electronic mass surveillance passed, albeit by a very narrow majority.  When it comes to protecting citizens who have come forward to reveal breaches of civil liberties performed by governments, a lot more needs to be done. If whistle-blowers are not protected we are effectively persecuting citizens who did not hold back information on wrongdoing, in the public interest. We understand that governments are increasing powers within their security and intelligence bodies in order to keep us safe from terrorist attacks; however, we must hold governments into account when our right to privacy is arbitrarily breached. Given that the ECJ invalidated the Safe Harbour Agreement, Parliament’s position is strengthened in pushing for a stronger framework to protect EU citizens’ rights. Thankfully, the ‘Snowden Effect’ has resulted in a win for privacy advocates. This month, in Ireland, the High Court ruled that the Data Protection Commissioner should examine whether to suspend transfer of Facebook users’ data from the EU to the US.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution records and warns of the apparent undermining of the fundamental right to privacy and the protection of personal data, when any information about human behaviour is considered potentially useful in combating future criminal acts, which necessarily leads to a culture of mass surveillance, where on which every citizen is treated as a possible suspect and which leads to an erosion of social cohesion and trust. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs is asked to continue to monitor developments in this area and the follow-up to the recommendations made in the resolution.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because I do not share the accusing tone of the proposers: the fundamental rights of each of us must be safeguarded but security is important and cannot be underestimated. Furthermore, I consider the recent legislative and judicial decisions taken in the United States to limit mass surveillance by the NSA, such as the adoption of the USA Freedom Act in Congress, to be negative: I believe that the situation for European citizens must remain unchanged, unless there is constructive dialogue between the parties and all opinions are taken into account. However, I remain relieved that the Commission has not taken account of Parliament's clear request to suspend the TFTP agreement, but I hope that the institutions and the Member States will seriously address the issues raised until a resolution is reached.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In a hyper-connected and globalised world, the right to privacy and data protection must necessarily be protected, as should the national security of individual Member States and european territory in general. In my opinion, the European institutions are doing their utmost to find the right compromise between security and the protection of personal data.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ I fully stand for privacy and fundamental rights. Mass surveillance programmes should be condemned and intelligence activities submitted to democratic oversight. However, I could not support the resolution today. It is not responsible to ask for the suspension of the TFTP agreement, which is a proven tool to prevent terrorism and an important legal framework to protect European citizens’ data. Asking that all legislation concerning data processing should stop or be revised after two years would create legal uncertainty, not protect citizens’ privacy.  Encryption, a useful tool, should not become the only solution to increase privacy online. Law enforcement authorities should be able to access data, in defined conditions, to investigate and persecute crime. Allowing greater EU IT independence, thinking that this would protect more EU citizens online, would lead to fragmentation of the internet and protectionism. While it is important to adopt at national level legislation that takes into account the situation of whistle-blowers, asking to give protection to Edward Snowden and for a European programme of protection of whistle blowers is not the way forward. It is all about finding the right balances. We need to protect privacy and ensure security for citizens. And today, this balance was not reached.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the Mass Electronic Surveillance of Citizens of the European Union, as it is a resolution explicitly condemning the mass espionage of European citizenship and governance structures by the US National Security Agency. In addition, the Resolution regrets the latest measures taken by certain countries of the Union, such as the United Kingdom, which endanger the security of citizenship data. Another issue that is important to us and which are reflected in the Resolution is the request for immediate suspension of the Safe Harbor Decision, which allows the transfer of personal data to the United States, as well as TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Program), as well as to express concern about the growing violation of fundamental rights through privacy limitation. We would have liked to see a more concrete reference made to the purchase and sale of personal data by private companies, which we strongly condemn, and that the aggravation of the approval of treaties such as TTIP would entail for the above issues.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which asks the President to call on the Secretary-General of the Council of Europe to furnish an explanation of the manner in which EU internal law ensures the effective implementation of the provisions of the Convention of Human Rights related to this subject and I look forward to this analysis. I also voted in favour of granting protection and prevent the extradition of Edward Snowden because I recognise his status as whistle blower. I voted against amendments calling for the suspension of the Terrorist Finance Tracking programme agreement because I am of the view that this programme generated intelligence that helped detect terrorist plots and trace their authors. An EU-US Agreement on the exchange of financial information should ensure protection of EU citizens’ privacy. I have supported this resolution as I believe that we need to deal with such a delicate matter very carefully, and only in extreme circumstances resort to curtailing our citizens rights to privacy.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. In this resolution, MEPs take stock of the European Commission's action on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens, believing that citizens' rights to protect EU data are still at risk. MEPs call on the Commission to immediately present alternatives to the Safe Harbor Agreement, which the EU Court of Justice recently ruled dangerous, concerning the transfer of personal data of citizens to the United States. However, this resolution is questionable in that it denounces the recent decisions of some Member States, including France, to expand the surveillance capabilities of intelligence agencies. Considering that these measures are balanced and aimed at strengthening the fight against terrorism, I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. – This resolution is a response of the European Parliament to the many cases of mass data collection by various foreign intelligence services. These incidents should make us extra vigilant about how we handle our data and the agreements we conclude with third countries on this. In this context, it is also important that whistleblowers are adequately protected.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the follow-up to the European Parliament's resolution of 12 March 2014 on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens because the content of this report is problematic. Indeed, I cannot support, through this report, the political message addressed to the American partners as well as the attacks against a number of countries, including France. As a result of the enactment of the Intelligence Act, which was passed by the National Assembly last July, France is suspected of organising massive surveillance of citizens, as are the United Kingdom, Germany and the Netherlands. It also suspends the EU-US terrorism financing surveillance programme, which is essential for identifying the perpetrators of the attacks, as was the case for those in Boston in 2013.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 We, the European People's Party, believe that the privacy and fundamental rights of our citizens must be adequately protected. At the same time, we need to strike a balance between general security and an individual's right to privacy. We support security standards for mobile and online communication, a reliable European information cloud, balanced data protection and a european security service. Today's decision has ideological claims that have nothing to do with mass surveillance. We, the members of the Fidesz Hungarian People's Party delegation, voted against the resolution because we believe that it is up to the national parliaments to strike a balance between protecting freedoms and ensuring national security.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The LIBE report concerns the protection of personal data, the security of internet privacy and the cooperation of Member States in combating eavesdropping and mass surveillance of authorities, companies and citizens of Member States.  Typical examples are the recent revelations of electronic surveillance and wiretapping of French Presidents' conversations by the US National Security Agency (NSA), the NSA's cooperation with the German intelligence service (BND), the Snowden revelations, etc. Electronic surveillance and surveillance must be governed by legal, ethical and technological rules, in line with the principles and standards laid down in the UN Civil and Social Rights Treaty. Uncontrolled mass surveillance is a violation of private and family life. In addition, all agreements relating to exchanges of information, based on surveillance and collection of information in the fight against terrorism, this financing and common crime, exchanges of legal purpose information, and exchange of personal data with third countries should be covered by transparency, legality, necessity and proportionality. The protection of individuals who disclose illegal surveillance and criminal activities by intelligence services must be a top priority of every rule of law.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the notion that the state can monitor citizens who have committed no crime. We feel that if citizens are under reasonable legal suspicion then appropriate measure may be taken with proper civil liberties and legal safeguards. In terms of any monitoring and surveillance, the EU has no right to be involved in this process.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a resolution to urge the Commission to take further action to ensure that the rights of EU citizens regarding electronic surveillance are properly protected, and to urge Member States to grant protection to Edward Snowden as a ‘human rights defender’. It is in the interest of my constituents in Wales to ensure that data transfers between them and the US are subject to effective levels of protection, to safeguard their privacy and human rights.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The rights of European citizens continue to be in jeopardy following the revelations of surveillance programmes made by Snowden in 2013. I regret the limited progress made in this area and I believe it is necessary for the Commission to present alternatives to the decision on the Safe Harbor data transfer system to the USA, which the CJEU has declared invalid. The new laws on information services in several EU countries also deserve some reservation. This resolution aims to take a view to the follow-up to the recommendations made by the European Parliament, surveillance bodies in several Member States and their impact on the fundamental rights of EU citizens and transatlantic cooperation in the field of justice and home affairs.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 I take on the words of Edward Snowden, international defender of human rights, for whom he is required to withdraw all criminal charges and offer him protection: "I do not want to live in a world where everything I do or say is recorded. This is something that I am not prepared to accept or support."  Indiscriminate mass surveillance activities and the massive processing of personal data lead to unacceptable interference in the fundamental right to respect for private, family and professional secrecy. The actions of the intelligence services and the mass electronic surveillance programmes, which conceal political, economic and various interests of the companies that develop and manage them, undermine the confidence and fundamental rights of the citizens of the Union.  Measures are also needed to ensure that all personal data transferred to third countries are subject to an effective level of protection, equivalent to that guaranteed in the EU. The constant monitoring of developments in this area is also necessary. I am therefore in favour of my vote.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This resolution follows many of the recommendations made in the original 2014 document, particularly with regard to data protection, democratic control, the issue of whistleblower protection – such as the Snowden case in June 2013 – and internet neutrality. It goes further by proposing the status of "whistleblower and defender of human rights" and consequently its protection as such, and demands that the United States of America put an end to the espionage it has been carrying out. However, this resolution expressly condemns the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and France for their recent legislation on the subject, and in paragraph 21 it goes on to say that "the European Union and its Member States need a common definition of 'national security' in order to ensure legal certainty", i.e. a huge contradiction with the manifest defence of democratic control and national constitutions. It is one of other contradictions present in the report. For the foregoing, our vote of abstention.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe this issue must be dealt with in a robust manner.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: written \u2012 Despite the mass surveillance of citizens of The Member States of the European Union, laws have recently been adopted in some Member States that extend the possibilities for surveillance by intelligence authorities, including the new French Law on Intelligence Activities, in the United Kingdom it is the adoption of a law on data retention and investigatory powers, and in the Netherlands proposals for new legislation amending the Law on Intelligence and Security Services , which certainly does not send a positive message to the citizens of the Member States on the protection of their right to privacy. However, I welcome the opening of informal interinstitutional negotiations on the proposal for a general data protection regulation and the adoption by the Council of a general approach on the proposal for a directive on data protection. The Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive are essential for the protection of the fundamental rights of individuals and must therefore be seen as a package of measures to be taken simultaneously to ensure that all data processing activities in the European Union provide a high level of protection in all circumstances.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. – I am voting in favour of the LIBE Committee's report on the protection of personal data, the security of internet privacy and the cooperation of Member States in combating eavesdropping and mass surveillance of authorities, companies and citizens of Member States. Typical examples are the recent revelations of electronic surveillance and wiretapping of French Presidents' conversations by the US National Security Agency (NSA), the NSA's cooperation with the German Intelligence Service (BND), the Snowden revelations, etc. Electronic surveillance and surveillance must be governed by legal, ethical and technological rules, in line with the principles and standards laid down in the UN Civil and Social Rights Treaty. Uncontrolled mass surveillance is a violation of private and family life. In addition, all agreements relating to exchanges of information, based on surveillance and collection of information in the fight against terrorism, this financing and common crime, exchanges of legal information, and exchange of personal data with third countries should be covered by transparency, legality, necessity and proportionality. The protection of individuals who disclose illegal surveillance and criminal activities by intelligence services must be a top priority of every rule of law.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that, when giving special powers and capabilities to intelligence services in democratic societies, this should be done in order to protect fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law, citizens’ rights and the State against internal and external threats, and those powers must be subject to democratic accountability and judicial oversight; their application should be strictly scrutinised, as otherwise they lose legitimacy and they risk undermining democracy.  I therefore support the request to the Council and to the Commission to let us know if they consider EU citizens to be sufficiently protected against electronic mass surveillance. It is of the utmost importance that EU citizens know if there is any electronic mass surveillance they are subjected to, and in this case, that institutions work together to ensure that citizens’ fundamental rights are respected.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Together with the rapporteur, I welcome the investigations launched by the German Bundestag, the Council of Europe, the UN and the Brazilian Senate, the debates in a number of other national parliaments and the work of many civil society actors, which has contributed to increasing general awareness of mass electronic surveillance. At the same time, I would like to express my disappointment that neither most Member States nor the EU institutions show a willingness to act as a matter of urgency and to deal seriously with the issues raised in the resolution and to implement the specific recommendations contained there in it, and to lack transparency and dialogue with Parliament. I consider it important to call on the Member States to ensure that their current and future legislative frameworks and supervisory mechanisms governing the activities of intelligence agencies are in line with the standards set out in the European Convention on Human Rights and in all relevant EU legislation; calls on the Commission to promptly initiate an assessment of all provisions of the French Intelligence Act and to report on its compatibility with primary and secondary EU law.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against it, although always bearing in mind that widespread mass surveillance activities and the massive processing of citizens' personal data must be prohibited at all times, guaranteeing at all times the fundamental rights of EU citizens.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Technology is a source of knowledge and democratisation of knowledge and not a potential risk to citizens who access it. I therefore deplore any reckless and potentially risky use of the network for citizens and call for strong action by Europe to prevent any instrumental use of the private data of network users for commercial or any other type of speculation.  The EU stands ready to consolidate the commitments made in the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on mass electronic surveillance and to take all the measures at its possession to ensure that citizens have fundamental rights even in the digital age, first and for all freedom of navigation.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens because I believe that digitalisation now raises a serious problem of privacy and personal security. Recent Wikileaks investigations have revealed that in recent years the highest state and institutional authorities in the world's most important countries have been placed under surveillance and that this activity carried out by the US government agency NSA (National Security Agency) has not been sporadic, but constant and systematic.  I believe, in fact, that it is essential to guarantee citizens the protection of the right to freedom of opinion and expression in the digital age, and I therefore deplore the use of electronic control for political and economic espionage purposes.  I share the concern expressed by the rapporteur of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), Mr Moraes, about the adoption of laws passed in some Member States which de facto extend the powers of intelligence and secret services without first securing control mechanisms governing these activities. Finally, I welcome the opening of interinstitutional negotiations on the legislative package, which includes a general regulation on data protection and a directive on general guidelines.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the resolution 'Follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens', as I consider the approach set out in it to be wrong. It is also important for me to emphasise that the European Parliament's negotiators in the trilogue negotiations on the General Data Protection Regulation should guarantee that the 'chapter solution' for data protection at work adopted in the last legislature will be preserved in Article 82 and will not fall victim to ill-considered horse-trading.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I have spoken out against the possible suspension of the TTIP negotiations by the back door. The European Union has long benefited from free trade. An agreement with the United States offers many opportunities, especially for our small and medium-sized enterprises. We should not close our backs to these possibilities.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ Most EU Member States and the EU institutions have shown a lack of willingness to prohibit mass surveillance activities since the revelation made by Edward Snowden. On the contrary, some of them have even adopted laws that extend surveillance capabilities of intelligence bodies, such as France and the UK. I therefore welcome and support this resolution that condemns, once more, the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens by European and American intelligence and calls for the safeguarding of EU citizens’ fundamental rights.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution. While it contains some relevant requests, it also asks the Commission for things that are impossible for it given its pro-American bias. The Commission is in a very poor position to act, having pushed to the SWIFT agreement for the transfer of bank data or to the "Safe Harbor" programme, which allows the processing in the United States by private companies of personal data that they have collected from their European users. This agreement has just been annulled by the Luxembourg Court, on the initiative of a private Austrian citizen and not of the Commission, despite the repeated scandals that revealed the aid provided by those companies to the NSA in its widespread espionage operation. This important decision of the Court is largely symbolic. For it to be truly effective, the United States would have to give up its national security over any other consideration, and not just softly agree to grant Europeans a right of recourse similar to that of their nationals. The Commission has neither the will nor the courage: it is a ban on transfers that must be targeted, not this wave "Safe Harbor 2" that we will be served in 2016.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this text on the follow-up to the 2014 Resolution, as it is much more forceful than the original resolution on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens. This resolution arose as a result of Edward Snowden's revelations about the NSA's mass espionage of citizens and politicians in Europe. This follow-up text incorporates important and positive aspects, such as the mention of two CJEO rulings on the subject. Mass surveillance legislation in the UK, France and the Netherlands is identified and called into question for opening the door to the legalisation of mass surveillance. The text warns the Commission of the freezing of its budget if it does not follow the recommendations of the EP, which strengthens the role of Parliament, a democratic body. The text also underlines the importance of encryption (coding) and calls for a repeated call to suspend the TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Programme) agreement. Finally, we are in favour of this text on the follow-up to the Resolution because, at the same time, it calls for legislating to protect whistle blowers, which we in Podemos.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Griesbeck (ALDE), in writing. If I welcome the adoption of this strong European Parliament resolution on the fight against mass surveillance of European citizens - the resolution denounces the massive surveillance programmes of the intelligence services, insists on the fundamental right of European citizens to privacy, reiterates our calls for the suspension of Safe Harbor and the TFTP. On the other hand, I deeply regret that my amendment and the paragraph asking the European Commission to assess the French intelligence law in the light of the European treaties and the European Charter of Fundamental Rights have been rejected, following a revolting manoeuvre by the French Socialists.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. In June 2013, Edward Snowden's revelations about mass electronic surveillance to which European citizens were exposed sounded like an electroshock in Europe. Parliament had responded promptly by launching an investigation to assess the extent of the violation of citizens' rights and to make recommendations accordingly. It must be noted that a year and a half later, too little has been done.  That is why I supported this follow-up resolution proposed by my English colleague, Claude Moraes, in order to call - once again - the Commission to take immediate action to ensure that all personal data transferred to the United States is subject to an effective level of protection. This resolution takes on a very particular significance with the recent decision in the Schrems case invalidating the Commission's decision on the Safe Harbor regime for data transfers to the United States. This decision only confirms Parliament's long-standing position. The Commission will have to look not only at the impact of this judgment, but also on possible alternatives. Meeting is taken at the end of 2015 with the Commission, let's hope that Parliament's requests will not remain this time dead letter...

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 12 March 2014 on the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens because I believe that inquiries by the German Bundestag, the Council of Europe, the UN and the Brazilian Senate, the debates in several other national parliaments and the work of numerous civil society actors have contributed to the raising of general awareness regarding electronic mass surveillance.  However, I am disappointed by the overall lack of sense of urgency and willingness shown by most Member States and the EU institutions in terms of seriously addressing the issues raised in the resolution and implementing the concrete recommendations contained therein, as well as by the lack of transparency towards or dialogue with Parliament.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats voted in favour of the resolution on the electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens. An amendment urged Member States to drop possible criminal charges against Edward Snowden. We have full respect for Snowden's important revelations and status as "whistleblowers" but do not believe that elected officials should interfere or try to influence the work of the courts. We therefore voted against this amendment.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 We, the European People's Party, believe that the privacy and fundamental rights of our citizens must be adequately protected. At the same time, we need to strike a balance between general security and an individual's right to privacy. We support security standards for mobile and online communication, a reliable European information cloud, balanced data protection and a more European security service. The resolution has ideological claims that have nothing to do with mass surveillance. As a member of the Fidesz Hungarian People's Party delegation, we voted against the resolution because we believe that it is up to the national parliaments to strike a balance between protecting freedoms and guaranteeing national security.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose not to support this resolution as it attempts to link data protection to other legal instruments which, in reality, do not concern data protection at all.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. While I share the outrage at the practices that have been revealed about the massive surveillance of citizens' communications by the US agency NSA, I do not agree with the fullness of the statements contained in this resolution. A left-wing bloc, with a majority in the parliamentary committee in charge of these issues, has succeeded in enacting very controversial provisions based on personal convictions and ideologies. Unlike these Members, I do not believe that individual freedom should be systematically opposed to the security imperative. On the contrary, I see the development of freedoms in a safe space. It is in this spirit that I supported the adoption in France of the intelligence law which is the subject of a proper attack in this resolution. Similarly, how does the threat of blocking the European Commission's budgetary resources if it does not apply Parliament's recommendations to the letter make it clear what happened?  Why suspend the exchange of information with the United States on the financing of terrorism, an essential tool for identifying terrorists? It is for all these reasons that I voted against the resolution to follow up on the March 2014 resolution.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the motion for a resolution - follow-up to the adoption of the European Parliament's resolution on electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens on 12 March 2014, as it is an important topic to be addressed more attention and to take decisions more quickly, as the rapid development of technology also brings new opportunities for abuse and endangering the interests and rights of citizens. This welcomes initiatives by various institutions aimed at raising general awareness of electronic mass surveillance.  On the other hand, it warns of an overall lack of a sense of urgency and readiness by most member states and EU institutions in terms of seriously addressing this issue. It emphasises that both the Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive are necessary to protect the fundamental rights of individuals, and should therefore be treated as a package to be adopted simultaneously. This resolution calls for the immediate suspension of safe harbor as it does not adequately protect the personal data of EU citizens.  Welcomes the initiatives of the private ICT sector in terms of the development of cryptographic security solutions and privacy-enhancing online services. This considers that the fundamental rights of EU citizens remain at risk and too little has been done to ensure their full protection in the area of electronic mass surveillance.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text revisits the NSA case and proposes, on the whole, an increase in privacy protection; it denounces the methods of data collection and the drift of States to make citizens potential offenders, calls on Member States to drop all prosecutions against Edward Snowden and to provide him with political asylum. The report also stresses the importance of establishing, at the Member State level, monitoring bodies to ensure that special services do not exceed their role by carrying out a mass-record of individuals.  However, in terms of measures, the report calls for stronger EU data protection regulations.  I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow MEPs and I opposed the notion that the state can monitor citizens who have committed no crime.  We feel that if citizens are under reasonable legal suspicion then appropriate measure may be taken with proper civil liberties and legal safeguards. In terms of any monitoring and surveillance, the EU has no right to be involved in this process.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution to follow up on the European Parliament's resolution of 12 March 2014 on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens. The text increased the number of charges against the United States and member states, and called for the suspension of EU-US agreements on monitoring the financing of terrorism, which is essential for identifying the perpetrators of attacks, as was the case with those in Boston in 2013. On the other hand, some wanted to add topics that do not correspond to the original purpose of the resolution, the security of European citizens, such as the trade agreements of the European Union. Such a major concern for our fellow citizens deserved a more serious text. The text has been adopted, which I regret.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this resolution. It emphasises the right and protection of privacy for European citizens and condemns electronic mass surveillance.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as the EU must advance in its efforts to rebuild trust in citizens on the issue of mass surveillance by clamping down on arbitrary abuses of the fundamental right to privacy.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The Data Protection Regulation, as well as the Data Protection Directive, are necessary to protect people's fundamental rights. This issue is certainly a sensitive one, having to reconcile opposing requirements, such as security and the protection of personal data.  I decided to say no because not all the concerns raised by my political group were shared during the negotiations, and I believe that the final text is far from a desirable outcome.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens, because it calls for European solutions that undermine the sovereignty of the Member States. It is not for the European Parliament (or the European Commission) to interfere in the internal affairs of the Member States. Having said that, I have supported certain amendments and important parts of the resolution which I share, including paragraph 47, which warns against the culture of mass surveillance in which every citizen is considered a potential suspect. I also, of course, voted in favour of recital E, which underlines "the targeted surveillance of the communications of the last three presidents of the French Republic, French ministers and the French ambassador to the United States; that this large-scale strategic and economic espionage by the NSA over the past ten years has targeted all the structures of the French state as well as the main French companies."

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it infringes on the sovereignty of States under the pretext of ensuring the protection of personal data.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the Mass Electronic Surveillance of Citizens of the European Union, as it is a resolution explicitly condemning the mass espionage of European citizenship and governance structures by the US National Security Agency. In addition, the Resolution regrets the latest measures taken by certain countries of the Union, such as the United Kingdom, which endanger the security of citizenship data. Another issue that is important to us and which are reflected in the Resolution is the request for immediate suspension of the Safe Harbor Decision, which allows the transfer of personal data to the United States, as well as TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Program), as well as to express concern about the growing violation of fundamental rights through privacy limitation. We would have liked to see a more concrete reference made to the purchase and sale of personal data by private companies, which we strongly condemn, and that the aggravation of the approval of treaties such as TTIP would entail for the above issues.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. In the resolution, Parliament calls on the Members of the European Union and the US authorities to cease mass surveillance and the costly processing of citizens' personal data, and expressed dissatisfaction with the actions of the intelligence services affecting citizens' fundamental rights and their trust in the system. The proposal also expresses concern about the possible existence of other motives such as political espionage. These are the reasons for the need to initiate the protection of fundamental rights in the digital age. Compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union is important and the level of consumer protection must not be lower than that established by Directive 95/46/EC. The resolution calls, inter alia, on the Commission to ensure the protection of all data transferred to the US, for national parliaments to monitor intelligence activities on the basis of thorough analysis, and to prepare a European strategy for greater IT independence.  I supported the European Parliament's resolution, as it is necessary to ensure citizens' privacy and the right to freedom of thought and expression in the digital age, and to do so we need dialogue with civil society and restoring lost trust.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Regardless of the historical and culturally developed social life format of any society – based on the principles of individualism or collectiveism – private life must undoubtedly be easily accessible to any person. This applies not only to physical being in your home, but also to all the information that is available in one way or another and exists for everyone, from social networks to telephone calls. Of course, surveillance measures can be allowed in cases of people suspected of having committed various types of crime or any terrorist activity, but this must also be done on the basis of the principles of legality and with the permission of the court. If the European Union and its authorities, as well as our Member States, really respect their obligations with regard to the privacy and other inausable rights of EU citizens, the facts of mass espionage that have been learned in recent years will be both properly investigated and the necessary measures will be adopted to guarantee people the opportunity to live without a doubt that someone is following every step of them. This also applies to the exchange of personal information with our allies. In other words, I unequivocally support this resolution and hope that the responsible authorities will take this into account, not because it came from the European Parliament, but because otherwise i would have to ask how to live in a genuinely legal and safe country or in a community of states where something like that is tolerated?

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Digitalisation and electronic communication not only represent an asset to society, but also a threat, as they can be used for the misuse of personal data, the commission of crime, international organised crime and the spread of terrorism around the world.  Recent events around the world have shown that these funds can also be misused by national intelligence services themselves. This damages citizens' fundamental rights and undermines the foundations of the rule of law.  All this requires the adoption of measures that establish a precise and duly justified framework for the control of electronic surveillance so as not to infringe legitimate rights. I support the Commission's proposed measures and actions in this area. However, it is important to stress that any measures must comply with laws, international treaties and conventions, must protect citizens' fundamental rights and must not harm the interests of the rule of law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on mass electronic monitoring of EU citizens, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 28/10/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ This report concludes Parliament’s investigation into mass surveillance of European citizens. It makes clear that surveillance has been widespread and has not contained adequate data protection and privacy provisions. There has not been sufficient judicial or political oversight, and we have not seen enough action from either the Member State governments nor the Commission to rectify this. Parliament will take this forward in our work on data privacy.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. A year and a half ago, shortly after Edward Snowden's revelations about large-scale espionage across the Atlantic, the European Parliament officially began to investigate mass surveillance of European citizens. A resolution of Parliament - devoid of influence - later, the Moraes report finds that surveillance remains massive on our continent, and that it is rarely subject to any political or legal control. There has been insufficient progress on the part of both the European Commission and the Member States. I am the the reason why the report acknowledges the need to do more to protect the personal data of European citizens.  Among other things, the Moraes report welcomes the decision of the European Court of Justice which, on 6 October, invalidated the European Commission's decision to introduce a Safe Harbour regime for data transfers to the United States. He also called on the Twenty-Eight to drop all prosecutions against Edward Snowden and offer him protection. In line with my fight to protect citizens' personal data in trade agreements (including TTIP, and TISA), I voted for this report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The law and the protection of privacy are highlighted and electronic mass surveillance is condemned by renewing the resolution. I therefore support this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this motion for a resolution as it failed to focus on the main issue at hand which is that of mass surveillance of EU citizens. The EU should be safe for all citizens. Security and counter-terrorism are a top priority.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report looks back at the mass surveillance scandals that have splattered U.S. intelligence agencies, particularly the NSA.  In general, this text is in line with the protection of privacy: it denounces the methods of data collection and the drift of States to make citizens potential criminals, it calls on Member States to drop all prosecutions against Edward Snowden and to provide him with political asylum. The report also stresses the importance of setting up member states to ensure that special services do not overstep their role by mass-checking individuals.  However, in terms of measures, the report calls for stronger EU data protection regulations. So I voted against this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on large-scale electronic surveillance of EU citizens. I would ask the Commission to respond to the calls made by the successive Resolutions of the European Parliament. The relationship between the US and the EU is essential for both sides. The revelations on surveillance have compromised this relationship and it is essential that measures be taken to ensure the restoration of this trust, taking into account cooperation on a large number of issues of common interest.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It was crucial that Parliament again decided on the issue of mass surveillance by following up on its 2014 resolution, which itself followed the revelations made by Edward Snowden. Not all of the recommendations made by Parliament last year have been fully followed, and not all of the guarantees requested have been made. Parliament therefore remains before the question and reiterates its requests, which have not yet been satisfactorily answered. Parliament - and in particular its LIBE committee of which I am a member - remains fully committed to this issue and will continue its work to ensure that the fundamental rights and freedoms of European citizens are respected.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The Resolution on Electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens outlines new evidence on the topic, the status of new legislation, and inquiries enacted in Member States after the NSA spying scandal. It provides non-legislative recommendations in the field of IT surveillance trying to ensure that European citizens’ fundamental rights are well protected and not under threat from different mass surveillance techniques. The outcome of the vote is even more important given the recent ruling of the European Court of Justice invalidating Safe Harbour.  I voted in favour of the resolution, because in my personal opinion collection of information and personal data of the European citizens need to be subject to an effective level of protection, especially when this data is transferred to the US. Having said that, however, I did not support some parts of the resolution calling for the suspension of the Terrorist Finance Tracking Programme (TFTP) agreement and calling for European common definition of national security, which in my opinion are competences of the Member States. We need to find a proper balance between national security and European citizens’ fundamental rights, without sacrificing one principle for another.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Writing. Two recent court decisions, I am referring to data retention and 'safe harbour', allow us to take a closer look at the EU legislative process. We are politicians and, of course, political balance is at the heart of our work. However, this must in no way lead EU or national legislation to disregard fundamental citizens' rights. The protection of privacy and data protection is firmly anchored in our Basic Laws. Our task is to protect them and not always have to take the detour through the ECJ to ensure this. Our task as the European Parliament is to ensure this protection and I therefore call on all Members to always consider this and to act accordingly. In the vote, therefore, I also insisted that the negotiations on the EU Data Protection Regulation be concluded quickly and that the Council take account of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, so that we have a good foundation for all further legislation.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I argue that data and information flows, which dominate the daily life of our day and are part of the integrity of anyone, must be protected and secure. Data protection and privacy are fundamental rights.  It is important to stress that security measures, such as counter-terrorism measures, should be applied in accordance with the rule of law and be subject to fundamental rights obligations. I express my concern at the rapporteur's consideration when he says that the fundamental rights of EU citizens remain in danger and that little has been done to ensure the full protection of such rights in the event of large-scale electronic surveillance, while also deploring the limited progress made in ensuring the protection of whistleblowers and journalists. I would like to support strict monitoring and monitoring of large-scale electronic surveillance of EU citizens by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This proposal for a follow-up resolution on mass electronic surveillance of citizens takes stock of the lack of measures taken by the European Commission, other EU institutions and Member States to address widespread surveillance.  While some aspects of this resolution are moving in the right direction (stopping the prosecution of Snowden, or stopping the transfer of data to the United States), the text shows a strong Europeanism and advocates solutions that undermine the sovereignty of Member States, such as the commission's invitation to sue certain Member States, to draw up recommendations to Member States (as if the Commission were in the best position) etc.  So I voted against it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution that calls for the immediate suspension of the Safe Harbour Decision as it does not provide adequate protection of personal data for EU citizens.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because I find it unacceptable how the situation and the decisions taken as a result of the US disclosures of the supervision of officials from EU Member States are unacceptable.  I have opposed and will always oppose the mass surveillance of citizens, because I believe that there are sufficient legal means by which intelligence services can do their job and identify potential dangers without trampling on citizens' rights and freedoms.  In this context, and following the revelations made by Edward Snowden and Wikileaks that the NSA has overseen all the structures of the French state over the past 10 years, I find it difficult to understand how France adopted a new law in June 2015 expanding the surveillance capabilities of the national intelligence services.  I want us to live in safe societies, where potential dangers to society and the state are identified and annulled, but I cannot accept that on the basis of this argument the right to privacy of citizens in good faith is infringed.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 As important as I consider this subject to be, a number of amendments have departed from the original intention and the assignment, namely the protection of citizens' rights, towards anti-Americanism. Unfortunately, the report was seized on by Members who chose to abuse it politically, which degraded it as a whole, and therefore I did not support it in the final vote.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Electronic mass surveillance is an instrument that is incompatible with my conviction of bourgeois folly. To place millions of people per se under general suspicion, I find outrageous. I therefore voted in favour of this report and against mass surveillance.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. It is important to strike a balance between freedom of the internet, privacy and electronic surveillance. There can be no doubt about any doubt about the mass electronic surveillance of people and the invasion of their privacy. The EU must, in cooperation with the US, find a way to encourage transatlantic cooperation between technology companies, while protecting the rights of private individuals. In addition, it is important that as many countries as possible join the EU Convention on Cybercrime.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. In a changing environment of non-existent security, which is 'difficult and sophisticated' in the Commission's words, it is incredible that we find ourselves with such inoperability on the part of the institutions. Not only is there a lack of knowledge, but there is no willingness to legislate. Parliament said so a year ago and immobility remains present, including by limiting the powers of national supervisory authorities. Fortunately, the Court is not a participant in this immobility and has invalidated safe harbour. The ruling makes it clear that now national data protection authorities can review data transfers to the U.S. for each individual case. It is a step in favour of defending free citizens.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – It should be noted that mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens is a particularly serious problem, which even translates into a culture of mass surveillance.  Many countries do not deal with this problem properly or are not addressing it at all, leading to a loss of public cohesion and confidence. In addition, mass electronic surveillance can have particularly dire consequences.  The capabilities of the intelligence services in the field of surveillance cannot be allowed to continue to be extended. It is necessary to ensure that the legal systems comply with the requirements of the European Convention on Human Rights and with all relevant Union legislation. The Commission must therefore play a more active role in ensuring that national legislation complies with EU primary and secondary legislation. The right to privacy and the protection of personal data must be properly implemented. Mass surveillance in a democratic society must be prevented.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
