text: Writing. \u2012 At EU level and not only has a huge network of monitoring systems and instruments of repression been set up, with the Schengen Treaty and the complex databases of the SIS I and II, VIS systems, the Directive on the monitoring of telephone and electronic/internet communications, in cooperation with the respective monopolies inters with their own interests. It is therefore hypocritical for the EU to show its interest and its supposed concern about developments in the countries that are strengthening the workers' 'file'. The resolution conceals that all kinds of monitoring, collection and processing of personal data, including biometrics, even children, and above all those who are engaged in political and trade union action, in particular communists, trade unionists of the class labour movement and other militants, have been imposed. It seeks to set a model for the protection of personal data of the EU, which even makes recommendations in the USA, while the exchange and interconnection of information is a given, but also the fierce competition between them and all kinds of secret services of the Member States, the Europolice, as well as the respective services of third countries. The protection of workers' democratic rights and freedoms presupposes the overthrow of the capitalist system which will allow both the release from the EU and the abolition of all these reactionary mechanisms.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The absence of a clear definition of national security opens up room for arbitrariness and allows EU executives and intelligence communities to violate fundamental rights and the rule of law.  I think it is important for the services to carry out their extremely complex tasks and protect us, but it should be noted that fundamental rights to privacy and the protection of personal data are clearly compromised in a situation where any information on human behaviour is considered potentially useful in combating future crimes, which necessarily results in a culture of mass surveillance in which every citizen is treated as a potential suspect , thereby eroding social connectivity and trust in services.  They should not exceed their authority. Any decision on the use of surveillance technology should be based on a detailed assessment of necessity and proportionality, as there is also a serious threat to the obligation to keep professional secrecy of regulated occupations, such as doctors, journalists and lawyers.  The EU should contribute to the development of international principles at UN level in line with the UN International Agreement on Civil and Political Rights in order to establish a global data protection framework, including specific data collection restrictions for national security purposes.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This proposal for a follow-up resolution on mass electronic surveillance of citizens takes stock of the lack of measures taken by the European Commission, other EU institutions and Member States to address widespread surveillance. While some aspects of this resolution are moving in the right direction (stopping the prosecution of Snowden, or stopping the transfer of data to the United States), the text shows a strong Europeanism and advocates solutions that undermine the sovereignty of Member States, such as the Commission's invitation to sue certain Member States, to draw up recommendations to Member States (as if the Commission were in the best position) Etc. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒In 2012, Parliament earlier in the resolution called on the US authorities and EU Member States to ban general mass surveillance and mass processing activities of citizens' personal data, and condemned the reported activities of intelligence services that seriously undermined the trust of EU citizens as well as their fundamental rights.  The resolution also warned of the possible existence of other motives, such as political and economic espionage, given the capacity of the mass surveillance programmes it was notified of. One of the results of this Resolution is the launch of the 'European Digital Habeas Corpus programme for the protection of fundamental rights in the digital age' with eight concrete activities and ordered the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs to inform Parliament within one year of the extent to which the recommendations were applied.  The Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive are necessary to protect the fundamental rights of individuals and should therefore be seen as a package and adopted simultaneously to ensure a high level of protection of all data processing activities in the EU in all circumstances. When adopting the package, the objective of strengthening the rights and protection of individuals in relation to the processing of their personal data should be achieved. The recent ruling declaring the safe harbour agreement so far invalid is the best reminder of the urgency of the situation and the urgent need for our response to protect our citizens' fundamental right to protect their data.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote against stems from the fact that not enough has yet been done to safeguard the fundamental rights of European citizens following revelations about mass surveillance activities by US intelligence services.  It is important to ensure that all data transfers to the US are subject to an effective level of protection, equivalent to that guaranteed within the EU. I hope that the European Commission will reflect on possible alternatives to Safe Harbour.  I am convinced that a common EU strategy must be formulated as soon as possible in order to ensure greater cyber independence on our continent, greater respect for privacy and, above all, democratic and effective control of intelligence activities.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In its resolution of 12 March 2014, Parliament has given its own proposals to the Council and the Commission in order to shed light on certain key issues relating to the surveillance programmes and bodies of the United States of America and several Member States, and their impact on the fundamental rights of citizens of the European Union (EU). It is in this context that Parliament invites the Commission to comment on the follow-up to this report and to report on the progress made in promoting and protecting the right to freedom of opinion and expression of EU citizens. In a climate of large-scale surveillance, it is important that the European Commission, as the 'guardian of the Treaties', redoubles its efforts to respond to the challenges of the data protection legal framework. Considering that the recommendations drafted by the rapporteur are a decisive contribution to ensuring that EU personal data continue to benefit from the necessary adequate protection, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the notion that the state can monitor citizens who have committed no crime. We feel that if citizens are under reasonable legal suspicion then appropriate measures may be taken with proper civil liberties and legal safeguards. In terms of any monitoring and surveillance, the EU has no right to be involved in this process.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Edward Snowden's revelations about the NSA's mass surveillance have sparked a worldwide awareness. A real electroshock pushing us to act to preserve our privacy. In its resolution of 12 March 2014, the European Parliament called for a ban on mass surveillance activities. The follow-up resolution adopted today reminds Member States and the Commission of their responsibilities to protect the personal data of Europeans. I voted in favour of this important text, which is consistent with my convictions. The resolution assesses whether the recommendations made in 2014 were followed. Of course, there are some positives. In particular, the data protection package is expected to be adopted soon, which is an undeniable step forward for European citizens. The Court of Justice has just overturned the Safe Harbour decision, confirming our concerns about this scheme. Despite this, MEPs believe that the EU's response remains disappointing and insufficient in the face of challenges, especially in terms of protecting whistleblowers. Member States and the Commission must now take all necessary measures to protect fundamental rights in the digital age.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In the past parliamentary term, a resolution was adopted in which Parliament called on US authorities and Member States to prohibit widespread mass surveillance activities. The Resolution launched a 'European digital habeas corpus' which included specific actions for the protection of fundamental rights in the digital age. Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties was tasked with addressing within one year the assessment of the degree of follow-up to the recommendations. This Resolution shows the widespread unwillingness of most Member States and EU institutions to address the issues raised in the Resolution, but also points to the progress made in certain respects, such as the start of interinstitutional negotiations on the draft General Data Protection Regulation or the CJEC judgment of 6 October 2015 declaring the Commission's decision on the port regime invalid U.S. insurance. This Resolution calls on the Committee on Civil Liberties to continue to monitor the follow-up to the recommendations made in the 2014 Resolution. That is why I support this Resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In the context of this resolution, which I supported but which my political group voted against, I have had the opportunity to vote on amendments such as the one calling on eu Member States to drop all prosecutions against Edward Snowden and therefore prevent his extradition or other provisions which are concerned about laws recently taken in some Member States that extend the surveillance capabilities of intelligence services.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the text rightly denounces insane mass surveillance in which every citizen is treated as a potential suspect.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this text on the follow-up to the 2014 Resolution, as it is much more forceful than the original resolution on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens. This resolution arose as a result of Edward Snowden's revelations about the NSA's mass espionage of citizens and politicians in Europe. This follow-up text incorporates important and positive aspects, such as the mention of two CJEO rulings on the subject. Mass surveillance legislation in the UK, France and the Netherlands is identified and called into question for opening the door to the legalisation of mass surveillance. The text warns the Commission of the freezing of its budget if it does not follow the recommendations of the EP, which strengthens the role of Parliament, a democratic body. The text also underlines the importance of encryption (coding) and calls for a repeated call to suspend the TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Programme) agreement. Finally, we are in favour of this text on the follow-up to the Resolution because, at the same time, it calls for legislating to protect whistle blowers, which we in Podemos.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the Mass Electronic Surveillance of Citizens of the European Union, as it is a resolution explicitly condemning the mass espionage of European citizenship and governance structures by the US National Security Agency. In addition, the Resolution regrets the latest measures taken by certain countries of the Union, such as the United Kingdom, which endanger the security of citizenship data. Another issue that is important to us and which are reflected in the Resolution is the request for immediate suspension of the Safe Harbor Decision, which allows the transfer of personal data to the United States, as well as TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Program), as well as to express concern about the growing violation of fundamental rights through privacy limitation. We would have liked to see a more concrete reference made to the purchase and sale of personal data by private companies, which we strongly condemn, and that the aggravation of the approval of treaties such as TTIP would entail for the above issues.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report because I do not wish to see the EU legislate on this subject. I do, however, recognise the issues in connection with mass surveillance.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the resolution on follow-up to the EP resolution of 12 March 2014 on electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens today on the grounds that it departed significantly from the intention originally pursued, i.e. to address the protection of the rights of EU citizens. The revelation of secret mass surveillance programmes of EU citizens by the US National Security Agency (NSA) is undoubtedly a very serious finding. In this respect, I support the work of the European Parliament and believe that unjustified interference with the fundamental rights of EU citizens, which are guaranteed by the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, must be avoided. In my opinion, the rights of European citizens must be protected above all by a high-quality legal framework in this area. This objective needs to deepen dialogue with the other EU institutions, the Member States and, last but not least, the US. The European Parliament has already made considerable efforts in this area and the other EU institutions need to cooperate fully. However, I do not think that the right way to improve any cooperation is to make ultimative demands and threaten lawsuits or promise of impunity for Snowden.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ We need a common definition of national security so that the European Union and the Member States can guarantee legal certainty and prevent violations of citizens' fundamental rights and the rule of law. I believe that fundamental rights to privacy and the protection of personal data remain at risk and that sufficient action has not been taken to ensure the full protection of citizens in the event of electronic mass surveillance.  I call for the development, under initiatives such as the Digital Single Market, of a European strategy for greater independence in the field of information technologies and greater online privacy that will boost the growth of the IT industry in the EU, so I do not support this proposal.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted against the proposal. I fully agree with the need to respect citizens' privacy and respect for their rights, including in electronic communication. However, the proposal goes beyond the competences of the European Union and the principles laid down in the EU's basic treaties, according to which national security and secret services are the competence of the Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The LIBE report concerns the protection of personal data, the security of internet privacy and the cooperation of Member States in combating eavesdropping and mass surveillance of authorities, companies and citizens of Member States.  Typical examples are the recent revelations of electronic surveillance and wiretapping of French Presidents' conversations by the US National Security Agency (NSA), the NSA's cooperation with the German intelligence service (BND), the Snowden revelations, etc. Electronic surveillance and surveillance must be governed by legal, ethical and technological rules, in line with the principles and standards laid down in the UN Civil and Social Rights Treaty. Uncontrolled mass surveillance is a violation of private and family life. In addition, all agreements relating to exchanges of information, based on surveillance and collection of information in the fight against terrorism, this financing and common crime, exchanges of legal purpose information and the exchange of personal data with third countries should be covered by transparency, legality, necessity and proportionality. The protection of individuals who disclose illegal surveillance and criminal activities by intelligence services must be a top priority of every rule of law.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a resolution because I think it is right that the EP is monitoring the issue, as we must prevent violations of the most fundamental rights of our citizens by using increasingly modern means. The report also provides an accurate picture of the open or unresolved issues raised by last year's Parliamentary resolution and also makes proposals for solutions, both in the context of relations with the US and within the EU, which I can support. The issue is of particular importance to me as a Hungarian Democrat and a Socialist politician, because it is precisely the government of my own country that is preparing for a serious infringement on the same subject. Under the pretext of 'protecting public order', it prepares a further package of measures to implement almost unlimited police control of individuals' IT communications and, moreover, a general facial recognition system for the general population, which is not linked to a specific law enforcement purpose. In today's political environment in Hungary, citizens have reason to fear that power will arbitrarily use these modern instruments to restrict freedoms of personality, assembly and expression. With the adoption of this decision and the report, I hope that the EP and the Commission will also closely monitor this serious development in the Member States in the future and, if necessary, take action to defend the democratic rule of law in Hungary.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which defends citizens' rights, the protection of privacy and respect for fundamental rights. It also highlights the Commission's lack of courage in its strategies to counter mass surveillance effectively and with respect for human rights!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed adoption of this resolution against mass surveillance of European citizens, with a view to protecting their fundamental right to privacy.  In the resolution from March 2014, Parliament called on the US authorities and the Member States to prohibit blanket mass surveillance activities and bulk processing of personal data of citizens. In spite of it, revelations of alleged electronic mass surveillance continued. According to Wikileaks, there has been a large-scale espionage by the NSA on French political representatives.  The resolution touches also on surveillance within the EU, expressing concern about the mass surveillance by German foreign intelligence agency BND in cooperation with the NSA. The resolution presents a complex analysis of the issue, covering areas such as the Data Protection Package, the EU-US umbrella agreement, Safe Harbour, the TFTP agreement, democratic oversight, private companies, and rebuilding trust, which is an overriding goal of the resolution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Motions for resolutions - I rejected the european parliament's resolution of 12 March 2014 on electronic mass surveillance of EU citizens, as I believe it is a violation of the fundamental right to privacy and the protection of the personal data of EU citizens.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this text on the follow-up to the 2014 Resolution, as it is much more forceful than the original resolution on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens. This resolution arose as a result of Edward Snowden's revelations about the NSA's mass espionage of citizens and politicians in Europe. This follow-up text incorporates important and positive aspects, such as the mention of two CJEO rulings on the subject. Mass surveillance legislation in the UK, France and the Netherlands is identified and called into question for opening the door to the legalisation of mass surveillance. The text warns the Commission of the freezing of its budget if it does not follow the recommendations of the EP, which strengthens the role of Parliament, a democratic body. The text also underlines the importance of encryption (coding) and calls for a repeated call to suspend the TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Programme) agreement. Finally, we are in favour of this text on the follow-up to the Resolution because, at the same time, it calls for legislating to protect whistle blowers, which we in Podemos.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In its resolution cited, Parliament called on the US authorities and Member States to ban comprehensive mass surveillance activities and the bulk processing of citizens' personal data, and condemned the public activities of the intelligence services which have seriously affected the trust and fundamental rights of EU citizens. I supported the motion to follow up the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this text on the follow-up to the 2014 Resolution, as it is much more forceful than the original resolution on mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens. This resolution arose as a result of Edward Snowden's revelations about the NSA's mass espionage of citizens and politicians in Europe. This follow-up text incorporates important and positive aspects, such as the mention of two CJEO rulings on the subject. Mass surveillance legislation in the UK, France and the Netherlands is identified and called into question for opening the door to the legalisation of mass surveillance. The text warns the Commission of the freezing of its budget if it does not follow the recommendations of the EP, which strengthens the role of Parliament, a democratic body. The text also underlines the importance of encryption (coding) and calls for a repeated call to suspend the TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Programme) agreement. Finally, we are in favour of this text on the follow-up to the Resolution because, at the same time, it calls for legislating to protect whistle blowers, which we in Podemos.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this text, which sends a clear message that Parliament is highly disappointed by the lack of action from Member States and EU institutions to protect citizens’ rights against electronic mass surveillance by intelligence services.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on this resolution because I agree that EU citizens’ fundamental rights remain in danger and that too little has been done to ensure their full protection in case of electronic mass surveillance. I also supported this because I want to express my disappointment about the limited progress in ensuring the protection of whistle-blowers and journalists.  It is important to address the question of other personal data exchange with third countries, of the protection of the rule of law and of the fundamental rights of EU citizens, and of an European strategy for greater IT independence and democratic and neutral internet governance. This is why I believe that more needs to be done and further recommendations should be sent on this matter.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the Mass Electronic Surveillance of Citizens of the European Union, as it is a resolution explicitly condemning the mass espionage of European citizenship and governance structures by the US National Security Agency. In addition, the Resolution regrets the latest measures taken by certain countries of the Union, such as the United Kingdom, which endanger the security of citizenship data. Another issue that is important to us and which are reflected in the Resolution is the request for immediate suspension of the Safe Harbor Decision, which allows the transfer of personal data to the United States, as well as TFTP (Terrorism Financing Monitoring Program), as well as to express concern about the growing violation of fundamental rights through privacy limitation. We would have liked to see a more concrete reference made to the purchase and sale of personal data by private companies, which we strongly condemn, and that the aggravation of the approval of treaties such as TTIP would entail for the above issues.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have been concerned in recent years as the revelations have come out surrounding the use of mass surveillance techniques in relation to online data. The right to a private life is a right that is critical to the functioning of any decent society and that does not change when we go online. I was particularly eager to ensure that there is an effective level of protection to data transfers to the US in the wake of the striking down of Safe Harbour. The desire for safety is important, and the threats that the security forces protect us from are also real. However, we should not allow these facts to override the very freedoms that we are fighting protect. It is too easy to sacrifice real freedom for perceived security, hence why I have supported this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. In the absence of action by the States and the Commission, the European Parliament adopted a resolution calling for the implementation by the Commission and states of concrete measures to combat mass surveillance and the EP recommendations adopted in March 2014, following Edward Snowden's revelations about the NSA's mass surveillance scandal. In addition to condemning the inaction of the European institutions, the resolution warns against decisions to collect general and massive personal data which threatens the fundamental right to privacy and the protection of personal data in the fight against terrorism and crime. The resolution is also concerned about the adoption or proposals for intelligence laws in many Member States that extend the surveillance capabilities of the intelligence services. I deeply regret that the vote removed the part relating to the French law which is particularly infringing on civil liberties. The vote improved the resolution and rejected attempts by the European right to weaken the text. I voted in favour of this text showing that rights and freedoms are always threatened.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Parliament called on the US authorities and Member States to ban surveillance and large-scale processing of citizens' personal data and denounced the actions of the identified intelligence services which severely affected the trust and fundamental rights of EU citizens. We are deeply concerned about some recent legislative acts by certain Member States that expand the surveillance capabilities of intelligence agencies. We fear that this security drift that seeks to ride the wave of terrorist attacks and the climate of fear instilled among citizens is understake fundamental rights. This calls for a deep reflection on the new phenomena of security, terrorism, its root causes, without which nothing good can come out of this debate.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The law and protection of privacy are highlighted and electronic mass surveillance is condemned by renewing the resolution. I therefore support this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution on the mass electronic surveillance of EU citizens because I believe that we must do more to protect European citizens from all forms of mass surveillance by intelligence agencies.  It is clear that mass surveillance is widespread, used indiscriminately and out of all legal control. With this resolution, we are calling on the Member States to take all necessary measures to gain the confidence of the citizens, which was lost as a result of the Edward Snowden revelations. Furthermore, in the face of the Court of Justice's ruling on Safe Harbour (which invalidated the Commission's decision that the US ensures an adequate level of protection of personal data transferred from the EU), it is essential that the EU finds an alternative to the safe harbour regime and provides an even stronger personal data protection framework.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The European Parliament has adopted a resolution in which it opposes mass surveillance of the population. It also calls for an end to the prosecution of former intelligence and whistleblower Edward Snowden. The first amendment was passed by a majority of 70 votes, the second in favour of Edward Snowden with a majority of 2 votes, the votes of the two AfD deputies. All the other members of our ECR Group voted against. The AfD is the party of civil rights. It stands for the liberal rule of law, in which there is no place for indiscriminate mass surveillance. I am particularly pleased that the European Parliament is also calling for Snowden to be rehabilitated. Snowden has made a significant contribution to making the extent of mass surveillance known. He opened our eyes. He deserves thanks for that, not prosecution. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. \u2012 The EPP firmly supports the provision of a high level of protection for the personal data and privacy of European citizens and recognises that the legislation of the Member States governing the activities of the intelligence services must comply with the standards of the European Convention on Human Rights and all relevant Union legislation. At the same time, it respects the judgments of the European Court of Justice, which set as the ultimate rule in the processing of personal data the principle of proportionality and what is strictly necessary for the objective pursued. In this context, we support this report and vote in favour of anything that serves these purposes.  However, we cannot and must not tolerate extreme populist views, which believe that freedom can be promoted without security. Provisions interfering with the national laws of the Member States with a clear demand for the withdrawal of democratically passed laws, provisions preventing Member States from defining the concept of their national security sovereignly and requiring the suspension of important ongoing EU agreements with third States, on the pretext that they infringe the security of personal data by object, are excessive and alter the substance of the resolution. , relating to mass surveillance.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 At EU level and not only has a huge network of monitoring systems and instruments of repression been set up, with the Schengen Treaty and the complex databases of the SIS I and II, VIS systems, the Directive on the monitoring of telephone and electronic/internet communications, in cooperation with the respective monopolies inters with their own interests. It is therefore hypocritical for the EU to show its interest and its supposed concern about developments in the countries that are strengthening the workers' 'file'. The resolution conceals that all kinds of monitoring, collection and processing of personal data, including biometrics, even children, and above all those who are engaged in political and trade union action, in particular communists, trade unionists of the class labour movement and other militants, have been imposed. It seeks to set a model for the protection of personal data of the EU, which even makes recommendations in the USA, while the exchange and interconnection of information is a given, but also the fierce competition between them and all kinds of secret services of the Member States, the Europolice, as well as the respective services of third countries. The protection of workers' democratic rights and freedoms presupposes the overthrow of the capitalist system which will allow both the release from the EU and the abolition of all these reactionary mechanisms.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. This resolution follows many of the recommendations made in the original 2014 document, particularly with regard to data protection, democratic data control, the issue of whistleblowers – such as the Snowden case in June 2013 – and internet neutrality. It goes further by proposing the status of "whistleblower and defender of human rights" and consequently its protection as such, and demands that the United States of America put an end to the espionage it has been carrying out. However, this resolution expressly condemns the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and France for their recent legislation on the subject, and in paragraph 21 it goes on to state that "the European Union and its Member States need a common definition of 'national security' in order to ensure legal certainty", i.e. limits the democratic control of citizens in these matters and ignores the National Constitutions. For this reason, we abstained, although we agree with much of the text.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. A year longer, the economic situation remains critical: the recovery is slow and fragile, unemployment rates are falling but remain excessively high, and poverty is at alarming levels, with one in four people in the EU in poverty.  That is why I did not vote in favour of this report. Because I believe that a true fiscal responsibility timetable is needed compatible with sustainable growth and quality job creation. Because the gap between the 10% it has the most and the least multiplied in the EU by up to seven in some countries, therefore fairer fiscal policies based on redistributive policies are needed. Because the reduction in unemployment has been based on precariousness and wage cuts.  Citizens need no more words or analysis. They need change, action and, above all, fair solutions to the real problems they face every day. A strong signal must be sent to the Commission and the Member States in favour of a European minimum wage framework or a minimum European income for insertion.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The European Semester is the annual process by which the Commission assesses Member States' budgetary commitments and assesses their conformity with the principles of economic governance (including deficit and debt limits), proposing, where appropriate, further reforms or cuts to agree. That is to say, the European Semester is a mechanism to legitimize and allow the Commission to intervene regularly in the affairs of the Member States, always offering the same recipe: social cuts, privatisations, labour reforms and increasingly destructive competition. I voted against it because we have repeatedly spoken out against this governance framework and strongly oppose the attempts of the rapporteur and majority groups to strengthen this process, involving representative trade unions and national parliaments, or by extending it towards 'social' objectives. This cannot legitimize a process which, by its very construction, pursues objectives far from the interests of the working majority.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. 'One has to stop all this nonsense. In EU philosophy, in the world of the pseudo-religious ideal of the currency union, one must, of course, move forward, from semester to semester, to a single economy, in the honour and glory of the single currency. Otherwise, it won't work. It is then repeatedly observed that there is still no stability in the system, so that we have to go further in streamlining the member state and cultural differences, which were once regarded – in a distant past – as the wealth and strength of the European continent, but which are now – as befits a full religious system – dismissed as sins and referred to as 'nationalism' and 'populism' if anyone dares to refer to them. That's why they stop all this nonsense, because it's dangerous alchemists who threaten to make the whole thing explode. Only a return to European cooperation from free and independent states can prevent the worst. I therefore reject this report in its entirety.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The European Semester is an instrument for the Commission to steer the economic policies of EU countries. Its objective is to harmonize growth conditions and maintain public finances that respect convergence criteria. It therefore poses a threat to the budgetary sovereignty of the Member States. I therefore voted against this report which promotes the European semester.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The Rosati report seeks Commission interference in pension reforms, amongst other matters, and therefore I voted against it.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contained the idea of a treasure trove for the euro area. The European Semester is a laudable instrument that must be treated more seriously and disciplined by the European authorities.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to discuss the implementation of the priorities of the European Semester for economic policy coordination. The aim of the European Semester process is to ensure integrated economic policy coordination at EU level through the various macroeconomic and fiscal surveillance measures necessary to manage convergence and interdependence between Member States. Economic forecasts for next year show signs of economic recovery: positive growth rates, rising inflation and a better overall fiscal position. However, the foundations for economic growth are still very unstable. I agree that the main priorities of economic policy should be the promotion of investment, the implementation of the necessary structural reforms, fiscal responsibility and the improvement of member states' employment policies.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which once again advocates austerity measures without thinking about the well-being of citizens. The text suggests making the Recommendations of the European Commission on the budgetary, macro-economic and structural reform plans of the EU Member States mandatory. These recommendations are often untenable, such as the pension at age 67, the reduction of social rights,... Despite more than five years of failure, the watchword remains the same: austerity! It is essential for jobs and growth to resume investing heavily in the real economy. Without any real will on this issue, there is a risk that we will remain in the current economic situation for a long time to come.  The first step, however, was that Parliament rejected this text on the European Semester for the first time, reflecting the growing challenge to the dogma of austerity.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns the establishment of the European Semester, which aims to put the budget of the Member States under the benevolent control of the European Commission and the Council of Ministers. It thus aims to ensure the maintenance of public finances according to criteria that are not justified by any serious economic study. Thus, a country that does not meet the criteria arbitrarily set out will have to follow the Commission's recommendations. This far too vague report does not point in any way towards another economic policy, but rather promotes ultra-liberal reforms or the proposal of own tax resources for the EU.  I cannot vote in favour of this text because the European semester is the austere counterpart to the single currency and the report is meant to be benevolent towards it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the governance of the European institutions, where there are serious shortcomings in the area of democracy, transparency and the principle of subsidiarity, and also in view of the progressive reduction in the sovereignty of the Member States on the recommendation of Europe, my vote on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies is negative.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. A year longer, the economic situation remains critical: the recovery is slow and fragile, unemployment rates are falling but remain excessively high, and poverty is at alarming levels, with one in four people in the EU in poverty.  That is why I did not vote in favour of this report. Because I believe that a true fiscal responsibility timetable is needed compatible with sustainable growth and quality job creation. Because the gap between the 10% it has the most and the least multiplied in the EU by up to seven in some countries, therefore fairer fiscal policies based on redistributive policies are needed. Because the reduction in unemployment has been based on precariousness and wage cuts.  Citizens need no more words or analysis. They need change, action and, above all, fair solutions to the real problems they face every day. A strong signal must be sent to the Commission and the Member States in favour of a European minimum wage framework or a minimum European income for insertion.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's position on the implementation of the priorities of the European Semester for economic policy coordination 2015. Parliament welcomed the fact that the economic recovery is slowly gaining momentum and is expected to increase GDP in the euro area by 1.9% in 2016 and the EU by 2.1%. Parliament also notes with concern that Member States have made different levels of commitments in implementing the country-specific recommendations of the previous year and that overall implementation has been weak. The report therefore reiterated the need for a coordinated policy in the Union and stressed the importance of implementing country-specific recommendations in order to ensure consistent and equitable implementation of the economic governance system in all Member States. Unfortunately, the lack of implementation of country-specific recommendations in some Member States hampers the creation of an environment conducive to growth and investment.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the so called ‘Revamped European Semester’  which contained a number of very worrying provisions. It offers absolutely no way out of the prevailing austerity narrative and in fact this report sets out to ‘institutionalise austerity’ as it proposes the intensification of austerity policies. The immediate priorities are on boosting competitiveness and structural convergence, imposing fiscal policies and gradually making the convergence process ever more binding and therefore impacting directly on Member States ability to implement their own legislation. In effect this report aims to deny citizens any real political choices when electing their governments. The whole aim is to bind Member States to essential economic and fiscal policies at an EU level.  It should be patently clear that European economic governance cannot override democratic choices at the national level.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Coordinated stimulation of private investment, maintaining commitments to structural reforms and taking on a policy of budgetary responsibility are the guidelines that the EU budget should take into account as a matter of priority. In this context, significant budgetary allocations were recorded in 2015, both in the Cohesion Policy Budget, by reporting commitment appropriations for the previous programming period that were not used to the current financial year, and by adopting the European Fund for Strategic Investments Regulation, as well as increasing funding dedicated to eradicating youth unemployment. Limiting the number of priorities and publishing the country and euro area-specific analysis to an earlier time frame than in previous years confirms the functioning of the mechanism underpinning the European Semester. I believe that by facilitating access to finance for SMEs and implementing a monetary policy aimed at stimulating investment and requiring the rapid implementation of recent measures, the European Semester remains an important factor in economic growth and consolidation. I was in favour of this report because I believe that the Member States must contribute more strongly to the implementation of structural reforms, with a view to increasing the competitiveness of businesses and increasing employment.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The final vote on the ECON Committee's report on the implementation of the priorities of the so-called "European Semester" can only be negative. Of course, some of the issues touched on are important, but the text does not leave room for much recrimination with regard to governance that is completely opaque, un democratic and does not take account of the principle of subsidiarity. If today we have procedures such as the 'European Semester' and continued interference by Brussels in the day-to-day affairs of the Member States, we owe it to the PPE+S&D partner, which has seen the adoption over the years of legislation that has progressively reduced the sovereignty of our Member States. Consequently, we cannot in any way take into account a document which, in any case, endorses the concept of 'recommendations' by which Europe leaves the Member States less and less room for manoeuvre, both technical and political, every year.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. A year longer, the economic situation remains critical: the recovery is slow and fragile, unemployment rates are falling but remain excessively high, and poverty is at alarming levels, with one in four people in the EU in poverty. name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted against Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of the priorities for 2015. Although economic recovery is finally catching a glimpse, its foundations are still very fragile due to numerous structural deficiencies in the European Union and regional economic divergences. This can lead to uneven growth and a lack of international competitiveness. Strong efforts should therefore be made to develop effective instruments to support economic growth, such as the promotion of investment, the implementation of structural reforms in the product, service and labour markets, budgetary responsibility and the improvement of employment policy.  These growth factors, including in the context of achieving the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, are essential to pursue the overall objective of making the EU more competitive overall, without weakening worker protection or undermining the European social model.  Unfortunately, the text of the proposal contains only weak measures and I therefore voted to reject it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the so called ‘Revamped European Semester’  which contained a number of very worrying provisions. It offers absolutely no way out of the prevailing austerity narrative and in fact this report sets out to ‘institutionalise austerity’ as it proposes the intensification of austerity policies. The immediate priorities are on boosting competitiveness and structural convergence, imposing fiscal policies and gradually making the convergence process ever more binding and therefore impacting directly on Member States ability to implement their own legislation. The whole aim is to bind Member States to essential economic and fiscal policies at an EU level.  It should be patently clear that European economic governance cannot override democratic choices at the national level.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report. I particularly welcome the fact that ‘the improvement of the Member States’ employment policies’ is one of the four main policy priorities identified by the Commission in this year´s cycle. Although there are very modest signs that youth and long-term unemployment rates are improving, they remain alarmingly high in most Member States and large differences persist. I believe that employment is the best tool to fight poverty and social exclusion. Member States should focus all their energy and resources on facilitating access to the labour market, in particular for young people and the long-term unemployed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Our many proposals for a review of this procedure have largely been rejected by the final compromise, as they are irreconcilable with the report's basic approach of defending the Commission's neoliberal strategy, based on austerity, structural reforms and liberalisation.  However, we have tried as far as possible to improve the text by supporting the inclusion of references to social aspects, but these do not, however, change the substance of the report's basic message. I therefore voted against.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Semester process aims to ensure integrated economic policy coordination at EU level through a combination of macroeconomic and budgetary surveillance tools, which is essential for monitoring convergence and managing Member States' interdependence. High unemployment rates in most Member States are noted with concern. In order to increase employment indicators, there should be a shift from taxation of labour to other sources.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt I had to abstain on the report as I have several concerns about the three main pillars of 2015: the coordinated relaunch of investments, the renewed commitment to structural reforms and the pursuit of budgetary responsibility. In fact, despite these strategies, economic recovery is still slow, especially given its fragile foundations.  In addition, another fact to note, unemployment rates continue to be high in most Member States and I note with concern the fact that young people have a problem.  I believe that increasing investment and reforming national labour markets are the key measures to be taken to boost the economy, which is unfortunately still suffering from the crisis, and to achieve the only desirable objective: to increase employment rates.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester process aims to ensure integrated coordination of economic policies at EU level through a combination of macroeconomic and fiscal supervision instruments in order to guide convergence and manage member states' interdependence. I think it is good to underline the economic growth forecasts for 2016 and the pace of falling unemployment rates, which shows that, although slowly, the economic recovery is gaining ground. To this end, it is to be welcomed the entry into force of the Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (programme to boost public/private investment in the EU), as well as budgetary results, the transition of appropriations to unused commitments in 2014 from 2007-2013 to 2015, 2016 and 2017, the start-up of operational programmes related to the Cohesion Fund and the new approach to streamlining the European Semester. I regret that the Single Market remains not a specific pillar of the European Semester, contrary to the European Parliament's call to this end, and I regret the weak results of some Member States in fiscal consolidation and the lack of commitment to the implementation of the Country-Specific Recommendations. I support greater involvement of national parliaments in the discussion of the European Semester.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester is seen as an appropriate framework for policy coordination within the EU. Unfortunately, a high rate of unemployment still persists in most Member States: the country-specific recommendations (SRRs), which should provide individual Member States with guidance on the measures needed to boost growth and sound public finances, have been implemented unseably. SDRs are too simplified and new reforms do not automatically translate into stronger growth and better jobs.  I therefore felt it appropriate to abstain because I consider it a priority to urgently resolve the problem of the inadequacy and obsolescence of policies to tackle long-term unemployment and also to improve policy coordination at national and European level.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The European Semester is the annual process by which the Commission assesses Member States' budgetary commitments and assesses their conformity with the principles of economic governance (including deficit and debt limits), proposing, where appropriate, further reforms or cuts to agree. That is to say, the European Semester is a mechanism to legitimize and allow the Commission to intervene regularly in the affairs of the Member States, always offering the same recipe: social cuts, privatisations, labour reforms and increasingly destructive competition. I voted against it because we have repeatedly spoken out against this governance framework and strongly oppose the attempts of the rapporteur and majority groups to strengthen this process, involving representative trade unions and national parliaments, or by extending it towards 'social' objectives. This cannot legitimize a process which, by its very construction, pursues objectives far from the interests of the working majority.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted down this report for two main reasons, in particular because the report stresses that one way to combat unemployment is to have flexible labour markets, when such flexible labour markets can have a negative impact on the individual workers. Furthermore, it tries to link together wages in line with productivity which can also have a negative impact on workers. The European Parliament has been fighting hard to ensure that there is a change in direction in the economic policy led in Europe. This report includes several elements of this new policy direction, however these key issues mean that employees’ interests are being overlooked. Moreover I voted against amendments which impose the removal of subsidies by 2020. Whilst agreeing with the principle we need to bear in mind that different Member States have different requirements and a one-size-fits-all approach does not work.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the European Parliament's opinion on the 2015 priorities of the European Semester. The European Semester plays a key role in coordinating Member States' economic and budgetary policies, with the aim of boosting growth and investment. At present, the economic situation of the European Union is characterized by a stagnation of GDP (stable in the euro area and marked by an increase of 0.2% in the EU-28 in the second quarter of 2014), a remarkably low inflation (0.3% in August 2014) and a record unemployment rate of 11.5% in the euro area and 10.2% in the EU-28 in July 2014. The report focuses on a range of priorities focused on modernising economies, structural labour market reforms, banking union, immigration policy, energy policy and increasing sources of financing for SMEs. However, the report mentions objectives outside the competence of the European Union, for example on the level of wages, which is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted against this report which was eventually rejected by Parliament. In essence I very much support the process and the Commission’s three-pillar strategy of fiscal consolidation, boosting investment and structural reforms as well as the effort to streamline the European Semester process. Here it is important for Member States to step up their efforts in all three areas. However a number of crucial elements were lost, such as no binding country-specific recommendations and the ability for national parliaments to vote on national reform programmes. In general the report was becoming more of a social report than a constructive report that looks at the most effective and coordinated way to achieve economic convergence. I could not vote in favour of a report that has lost much of its intended purpose.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In the context of the European semester, it is unfortunately clear that the majority of the European Commission's recommendations to the Member States are not being implemented.  The operation of the semester must therefore be improved. National parliaments should be more involved in the development of socio-economic reforms. Recommendations should be more restrictive.  Finally, it is essential to properly assess the social impacts upstream.   That is the meaning that the European Parliament's report should have taken.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Politics is the art of compromise. Unfortunately, today this quote could not be applied. Parliament failed to express its views on EU economic governance – a topic of great importance in the current economic climate.  Regrettably, I voted against this report as a result of a negotiation process which  left the ALDE proposals for a better and competitive Europe unconsidered. We, the Liberals, disagree that CSR should allow extensive fiscal flexibility which would give a possibility to deviate from the deficit targets. In addition, we do not comprehend how social indicators could be put on a par with economic ones in the framework of the European Semester – the first not always being measurable. I do hope for a better cooperation next year so that the European Parliament could again express its views on such  an important matter.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report concerned the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policy and its implementation of priorities for 2015. A compromise report promoting the Juncker plan, it is balanced as it makes the big gap between interesting proposals and unacceptable considerations. While he criticised the lowering of the retirement age, he said he favoured own resources for the European Union. As an instrument of economic tutelage imposed on us by Brussels, this European Semester seeks to strengthen its power over our sovereign policies. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on this report. Although I support the recommendations for structural reforms, that the EU should be more globally competitive, and indeed the benefits of the Capital Markets Union for SMEs, the report makes some reference to a Fiscal Union and the recommendations are largely non-binding for the UK.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the support of small and medium-sized enterprises from the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the recognition that Monetary Union has trapped some of its members in a currency that has harmed them, are evidence that this report is moving in the right direction.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 Order lines are important in the various economies of the European Union, and we need control and coordination. However, although I voted in favour in the final vote, I would like to point out that there are many elements on which the European level should not decide: the Commission's recommendations should not be binding, and the countries' own constitutional rules must determine how national parliaments handle budget votes and the like.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The Commission's spring 2015 economic forecast indicates growth rates of 2.1% in the EU and 1.9% in the euro area for 2016. At the level of annual consumer price inflation rate, both in the EU and in the euro area, there should be an increase from 0.1% in 2015 to 1.1% in 2016, which does not reflect the risk of deflation predicted by the European Central Bank. However, unemployment in the EU remains unacceptably high, but is on a pace to decline, with unemployment expected to fall to 9.2% in the EU and 10.5% in the euro area in 2016. I stress the importance of access to finance for businesses, in particular SMEs, which are the backbone of the EU economy. In this context, it is noted that the currently low interest rates in force have proved insufficient to encourage investment in the required volume. The Commission should make proposals to reverse this situation.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester procedure has operationalised the practical implementation of the EU legislative response framework to the deep crisis in which it has plunged as a result of the continued momentum of divergence between its Member States, in particular with regard to economic governance legislation. Neoliberal policies that generate inequality and crisis have not been called into question. On the contrary, it is the intention of Economic Governance and the European Semester to create new and enhanced conditions for its continuation. In other words, not only do they not solve anything, but they aggravate economic and social problems, especially in countries like Portugal. The so-called fiscal consolidation policies have generated never-before-seen unemployment, intolerable levels of poverty, inequalities and social injustices, alongside a debt (public and external) never seen before. The European Fund for Strategic Investments, the prospects for deepening EMU or the future of the European Semester are nevertheless nothing more than leaks ahead. The current framework, also determined by the Budgetary Treaty, promotes an almost absolute constraint to the development of an alternative, sovereign, development policy based on progress and social justice. This report guarantees this course of confrontation with democracy, of economic and social setback of a civilizational dimension. Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Amendment 12 because I would like to see Ireland leave the Eurozone. This clause would facilitate that.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The economic forecasts for the coming year indicate an economic recovery with positive growth rates, an increase in inflation and an improvement in the fiscal outlook, also in view of significant fiscal efforts and structural reforms in many Member States. Nevertheless, the economic and financial situation and employment situation in the EU will only improve by implementing ambitious structural reforms. The high unemployment rate in several Member States remains a very worrying factor. Flexible labour markets play a key role in the fight against unemployment, and it should also be switched from labour taxation to other sources in the future.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the entire report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies: the implementation of the priorities for 2015, because the support of small and medium-sized enterprises from the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the recognition that monetary union has trapped some of its members in a currency that has harmed them, are evidence that this report is moving in the right direction.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to welcome the own-initiative report by Mr Rosati. Taking into account the latest budgetary measures adopted, it has been necessary to introduce them into the objectives of the annual growth survey. Although the economic recovery is slowly gaining ground, the fundaments of the recovery are delicate due to the EU’s structural weaknesses and regional economic discrepancies.  Therefore, I am glad that the report includes several elements of a new economic policy direction that strengthens the synergy of Member States’ national policies: more investment and less austerity, recognition of the real consequence of frontloaded austerity measures, and surplus countries to make more efforts in pushing demand. I consider an improvement of the report the removal of further fiscal consolidation, and the criticism of rigid laws on labour and trade unions. Labour market reforms should be sustainable by increasing investment alongside reform of national labour markets, and taking measures to boost the economy in order to increase job creation rates. However, I have to say that I am concerned about the expansion of ‘zero-hour contracts’ because I believe that all types of contractual arrangements should give workers access to a core set of rights and adequate social protection.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I appreciate that the economic recovery is slowly starting, as GDP in the euro area is expected to grow by 1.9% in 2016 and 2.1% in the EU. At the same time, I am concerned that the fundamentals of recovery are fragile, among other factors, due to the underlying structural weaknesses and regional economic differences in the Union, the resulting uneven growth and low international competitiveness. I also welcome the fact that in the 2015 CSR, the Commission focuses on the following four main priorities for economic growth: boosting investment, implementing structural reforms in the markets for products, services and labour, responsible budgetary management and improving employment policy. I consider it important to emphasise the importance of these growth-enhancing factors, including the achievement of the Europe 2020 strategy objectives and the overall objective of enhancing the Union's competitiveness globally.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of promoting the necessary measures to boost economic growth and job creation while maintaining the health of public accounts. There is no doubt that the European Semester remains the appropriate framework for policy coordination within the EU, but to improve its effectiveness we must continue to streamline its design.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ

A strong signal must be sent to the Commission and the Member States in favour of a European minimum wage framework or a minimum European income for insertion.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. A year longer, the economic situation remains critical: the recovery is slow and fragile, unemployment rates are falling but remain excessively high, and poverty is at alarming levels, with one in four people in the EU in poverty.  That is why I did not vote in favour of this report. Because I believe that a true fiscal responsibility timetable is needed compatible with sustainable growth and quality job creation. Because the gap between the 10% it has the most and the least multiplied in the EU by up to seven in some countries, therefore fairer fiscal policies based on redistributive policies are needed. Because the reduction in unemployment has been based on precariousness and wage cuts.  Citizens need no more words or analysis. They need change, action and, above all, fair solutions to the real problems they face every day. A strong signal must be sent to the Commission and the Member States in favour of a European minimum wage framework or a minimum European income for insertion.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the European Semester because I believe it goes in the direction outlined by the recent package presented by the Commission for the implementation of the first phase of the report of the five Presidents aimed at strengthening the European Semester, completing EMU and, ultimately, implementing convergence between the states of the eurozone. This convergence can realistically only be achieved if the eurozone has an effective budgetary capacity. Therefore, it is more necessary than ever to build an embryo of EU fiscal policy, even under constant treaties. In addition, employment and social problems must be a priority within the European Semester. Unemployment, particularly long-term unemployment, is one of the main causes of social inequality. Hence the need for efficient labour markets, capable, on the one hand, of promoting a high level of employment and, on the other, of absorbing external shocks without causing further unemployment. Efficient and robust labour markets can contribute to a more inclusive EU and to a more flexible functioning, particularly within shared rules, of EMU. They will contribute to the achievement of the ultimate objective: to build a deeper, fairer EMU for its citizens, in other words to develop, and deepen over time, its social dimension.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report 'European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policy: Implementing the Priorities for 2015' today, as in the latest version, due to many amendments from the Greens and the Left, it no longer meets the importance of the European Semester as an important fiscal and economic policy instrument. The semester is not a social bouquet.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. High debt and low direct investment are problems that many countries within the EU face. In particular, a coordinated economic policy is of great benefit to many states. The priorities of this report will help to ensure that the economies of these countries continue to grow in the future and, above all, sustainably.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Rosati report which, thanks to our group’s efforts, opens the door for a change in direction in European economic policy: more investment and less austerity, recognition of the real consequence of frontloaded austerity measures, surplus countries to do more efforts in pushing demand, labour market reforms to be sustainable.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester process is designed to ensure that Member States keep their budgetary and economic policies in line with the EU commitments. The greater the efforts by Members States to stick to their country-specific recommendations, the better. Nevertheless, the outcome of today’s vote perhaps reflected worrying elements of the report, which lacked clarity overall.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report because we oppose the European Semester mechanism as a whole, even though the final text has incorporated many considerations that we share (e.g. those that point to the need to improve the quality of employment). The European Semester aims to subject government budgets to a european Commission audit that ensures the fulfilment of certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of ill-called structural reforms. We don't share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because many Member States, in particular in the euro area, are faced with similar macroeconomic challenges including, most importantly, high debt ratios (both public and private), lack of competitiveness and excessively low investment. Unsustainable levels of debt have a discouraging effect on investment and so a coordinated approach is therefore required in tackling these issues. The four main priorities for economic growth are: boosting investment, implementation of structural reforms in product, service and labour markets, fiscal responsibility and improving employment policy. The report stresses the importance of these growth drivers. In the context of achieving the goals set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy and the overall objective of making the EU globally more competitive, this should be done without weakening workers’ protection or undermining the European social model.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report provides a statement on the Commission's annual budgetary recommendations to EU Member States. It welcomes, first of all, the Commission's focus on structural reforms, investment, fiscal responsibility and improving conditions in labour markets. It also notes that the future of the European Economic Area is threatened by the EU's fundamental structural weaknesses and the structural difference between regions. However, this important analysis is opposed to demands that ALFA cannot support in any way. For example, the report calls for an economic and fiscal union, minimum wages or an EU tax. That is why I rejected this report. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the report on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination, as key amendments to the ALDE Group were not accepted.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester process is an important part of monitoring economic reform across the European Union. From this viewpoint, it is important that all Member States follow the country-specific recommendations. It was disappointing that this report did not go far enough in this regard. In my opinion the text is too long and lacks a clear focus, so I did not vote in favour of it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Dariusz Rosati's report on country-by-country priorities for economic policies in the context of the European Semester. The report focused on structural reforms and improving competitiveness while improving public finances.  The text has not been adopted, which I regret.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Semester is the main vehicle for budgetary harmonisation within the EU. It is the main macroeconomic policy tool for this committee and marks the transition from Monetary Union only to Economic Union. However, the wide divergences in the budgetary situation of the Member States do not give much room for optimism in the short term and the existing proposals, such as the 'Five Presidents' Report', are only causing us anxiety and reflection.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report takes a strong approach to subsidiarity and endorses the efforts that need to be made to overcome the crisis, most notably structural reforms. However, it is also committed to greater involvement of the Member States, i.e. the national parliaments. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report comments on the European Semester, in more detail on the Commission's annual budgetary recommendations to EU Member States. It welcomes, first of all, the Commission's focus on structural reforms, investment, fiscal responsibility and improving conditions in labour markets. It also notes that the future of the European Economic Area is threatened by the EU's fundamental structural weaknesses and structural differences between regions. However, this important analysis is opposed to demands that ALFA cannot support in any way. For example, the report calls for an economic and fiscal union, minimum wages or an EU tax. That is why I am opposed to the report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the European semester for the coordination of economic policies. The European Semester remains the European Commission's instrument for steering the economic policies of EU countries.  As such, it poses a creeping threat to sovereignty, through country-by-country recommendations, which are a real roadmap for national governments. The Rosati report is balanced on the assessment of the economic situation, but in reality often lacks objectivity on the seriousness of the indicators.  As is often the case with compromises, it mixes some relevant observations with unacceptable considerations.  He promotes the Juncker plan, ultra-liberal-inspired structural reforms (particularly in the labour market) and says he supports clean resources for the EU. As a corollary of the single currency in its current form, and as a vehicle for a certain tutelage of Brussels over national economic policies, it is therefore not possible to support the concept of the European Semester.  As for the Rosati report, it contains relevant criticisms but, overall, there is too much evidence in favour of strengthening this mechanism to be approved.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it accentuates the ultra-liberal drift of EU economic policy. It was rejected by a very large majority, which is a divine surprise.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. The N-VA has decided not to support this report. There are good elements in it, such as the reference to the positive role of flexible labour markets in the fight against unemployment, the importance of a budget in order and the need for structural reforms. But that message is being watered down too much by references to things that do not belong in this report and messages going in the opposite direction.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The European Semester is the annual process by which the Commission assesses Member States' budgetary commitments and assesses their conformity with the principles of economic governance (including deficit and debt limits), proposing, where appropriate, further reforms or cuts to agree. That is to say, the European Semester is a mechanism to legitimize and allow the Commission to intervene regularly in the affairs of the Member States, always offering the same recipe: social cuts, privatisations, labour reforms and increasingly destructive competition. I voted against it because we have repeatedly spoken out against this governance framework and strongly oppose the attempts of the rapporteur and majority groups to strengthen this process, involving representative trade unions and national parliaments, or by extending it towards 'social' objectives. This cannot legitimize a process which, by its very construction, pursues objectives far from the interests of the working majority.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report comments on the European Semester, in more detail on the Commission's annual budgetary recommendations to EU Member States. It welcomes, first of all, the Commission's focus on structural reforms, investment, fiscal responsibility and improving conditions in labour markets. It also notes that the future of the European Economic Area is threatened by the EU's fundamental structural weaknesses and the structural difference between regions. However, this important analysis is opposed to demands that ALFA cannot support in any way. For example, the report calls for an economic and fiscal union, minimum wages or an EU tax. That is why I voted against the report, as did my party and group colleagues. In the end, we achieved a great success, as the report was rejected by a majority of the votes in plenary.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Implementing specific recommendations, fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and boosting investment has helped Member States reduce debt, deficits and unemployment and achieve higher economic growth rates. This is confirmed by the spring economic forecasts.   For 2016, the growth rate of 2.1 percent in the European Union and 1.9 percent in the eurozone is projected.
