While unemployment remains at a very high level, the Commission has predicted that unemployment will fall to 9.2% in the European Union and to 10.5% in the eurozone in 2016. Debt and deficits in the EU are also projected to shrink to 86.9% and 2% of GDP, or 92.5% and 1.7% of GDP in the eurozone in 2016.  I supported my colleague Rosati's report, in particular because of the importance of the European Semester as a strategic mechanism for linking economic policies and encouraging Member States to implement structural reforms in the fields of labour market, education system, state administration, fostering innovation and entrepreneurship with a view to building a competitive and growing Economy of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Effective economic or any other planning and policy implementation is not possible without an overall analysis of past results and their consideration for further development of the strategy. I am therefore pleased that we approved this report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the first half of 2015. Although at least two other reports on the implementation of the European Union's regional policy have already been addressed during this part-session, it is to be concluded that Europe's regions still differ greatly in their economic development. The same applies to economic recovery and potential growth in the next sector. On the one hand, the member states' own options also vary considerably in terms of financial and other available resources. On the other hand, countries would like countries to cooperate more actively and coordinate their respective economic recovery and further development measures, both interconnectedly and with the Union's transnational institutions, firstly the European Commission, which regularly makes various recommendations. Of course, budget deficits must not be uncontrolled: thus increasing debt and also possibly ignoring the commitments made in relation to the 3% GDP deficit, Member States should certainly devote more investment directly to measures to stimulate economic recovery.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – In its 2015 country-specific recommendations, the Commission recommended four main priorities for economic growth: strengthening investment, implementing structural reforms in product and service markets and labour markets, fiscal responsibility and improving employment policy. The current situation shows that the rate of implementation of these recommendations by the Member States is low, which ultimately translates into high unemployment. Measures must therefore be taken to make national governments and parliaments more active in these areas so that the fulfilment of the tasks set out, the provision of support and the creation of adequate transparent conditions by Member State governments and Union bodies lead to increased competitiveness, economic growth, increased employment and the improvement of the lives of citizens across the EU.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Semester on the coordination of economic policies: implementation of the priorities for 2015, because it is not complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 28/10/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester is the annual cycle of policy guidance from the Commission for the fiscal and structural reform policies of each Member State. The Commission provides country-specific recommendations and monitors the implementation of commonly agreed policies with national governments. These measures are designed to ensure Member States are not heading for financial difficulties which would put all Member States at risk. The S&D Group has fought hard to include more social criteria and to ensure any recommendations to labour market reform do not weaken workers’ rights or promote precarious employment but in fact strengthen the European social model and promote sustainable growth.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of the priorities for 2015. In order to relaunch the recovery, it is of the utmost importance that economic policy aims to promote investment, accelerate structural reforms and pursue growth-oriented consolidation of public finances. There is a need to promote investment and improve employment policy by implementing structural reforms relating to the labour market, the education system and financial services for SMEs.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I am in favour of the principle of subsidiarity, which is emphasised in the report. Unfortunately, at the same time, the report deals with areas in which the EU has no competence, such as.B. regretting that recommendations on environmentally hazardous subsidies, ecological tax reform and the promotion of renewable energy have been dropped in the country-specific recommendations. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination and priorities for 2015. The European economic recovery is starting to show signs, with a 1.9% increase in GDP in the euro area and 2.1% in the EU in 2016. The signs of economic recovery based on significant fiscal efforts and structural reforms undertaken by many Member States were decisive for this recovery. The implementation of the necessary structural reforms and fiscal responsibility have been key to laying the foundations for economic growth that, while still fragile, requires concerted efforts to strengthen investment and improve member states' employment policies.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it stresses the need for increased cooperation and coordination between Member States to tackle the problems of high debt, lack of competitiveness, and low investment.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The European Semester is now the engine of our economic governance. The aim is to ensure coherence and strengthen convergence in a common space. However, the recommendations are not sufficiently implemented, slowing the convergence of our economies and thus weakening our common economic space. I regret that the European Parliament did not agree on this report, which had the merit of calling for a strengthening of this mechanism. It is important that we be ambitious in this regard. Our economies need to be reformed structurally so that they can show vitality in a globalized world.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing \ u2012 For 2015, the priorities defined by the Commission include promoting investment, implementing structural reforms, fiscal responsibility and increasing employment. I am pleased that we are seeing some economic recovery in the EU. However, the persistent problem remains the high level of debt, the lack of competitiveness in many areas and, above all, the low level of investment. It is necessary to recognise the importance of linking inflows of investment to the market, in particular in the services sector, to the creation of new jobs in the Union, as well as the importance of implementing ambitious structural reforms, which many states continue to delay. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of member states' readiness and willingness to cooperate more closely in the implementation of the European Semester.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I am fully convinced that Europe and the Member States need to ensure a change in direction in the economic policy led in Europe, so that citizens do not have to pay for the consequences of the economic crisis. This report includes several elements of this new policy direction: more investment and less austerity, recognition of the real consequence of frontloaded austerity measures, surplus countries to do more efforts in pushing demand, labour market reforms to be sustainable, nevertheless at the end I could not support the final vote because some of the amendments adopted during the plenary vote were not in line with my principles.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the European Semester process is to ensure integrated economic policy coordination at EU level through a combination of macroeconomic and budgetary surveillance instruments. As part of the annual cycle of the European Semester, country-specific recommendations advise individual Member States on the measures needed to boost growth while allowing for the maintenance of sound public finances.  At the same time, most Member States implement these recommendations to a very small extent. Parliament's draft resolution tabled by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs therefore proposes that only by implementing ambitious structural reforms will the economic, financial and employment situation of the Union improve and that these structural reforms are an important precondition for more concrete results for EU initiatives such as the ESSI. The draft also proposes to establish that the unemployment rate is very high in most Member States and that flexible labour markets have an important role to play in combating unemployment, and that an increase in employment rates would have to move from labour taxes to other sources of taxation. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I argue that data and information flows, which dominate our daily lives and are part of the integrity of anyone, must be protected and secure. Data protection and privacy are fundamental rights.  It is important to stress that security measures, such as counter-terrorism measures, should be applied in accordance with the rule of law and be subject to fundamental rights obligations. I express my concern at the rapporteur's consideration when he says that the fundamental rights of EU citizens remain in danger and that little has been done to ensure the full protection of such rights in the event of large-scale electronic surveillance, while also deploring the limited progress made in ensuring the protection of whistleblowers and journalists. I would support that there should be close monitoring and monitoring of large-scale electronic surveillance of EU citizens by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns the establishment of the European Semester, which is a europeanist ceremony aimed at putting the Member States' budget under the benevolent supervision of the European Commission and the Council of Ministers. It thus aims to ensure the maintenance of public finances according to criteria that are not justified by any serious economic study. Thus, a country that does not meet the criteria arbitrarily set out will have to follow the Commission's recommendations (which are not councils of friends) which are not distinguished by their originality as they aim to make ever more deregulation. This report spares the goat and the cabbage and remains unclear except with regard to the promotion of ultraliberal reforms or the proposal of own tax resources for the EU.  I cannot vote in favour of this text because the European semester is the austere counterpart to the single currency and the report is meant to be benevolent towards it. So I voted against it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of 2015 priorities because it would have instated structural reforms that are a serious condition for EU initiatives such as EFSI.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I considered that it did not provide the necessary clarity that such a report could have had.  The rapporteur correctly identified some worrying economic issues at EU level, but unfortunately continued by adding to this report many topics that require wider debate. Unfortunately, this report addresses too many issues, including topics against which I have a different political position; so I had to vote against this document.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 The Dariuzs Rosati report represents an effort to find a balanced view of the European Semester and to contribute to improving this instrument important for economic policy coordination. I regret that, in some cases, the left-wing part of the spectrum, in particular, rejects even the obvious economic laws and presents proposals that could plunge Europe back into the economic problems from which it is now so difficult to get out. I believe that the need for a responsible and long-term sustainable budgetary policy is as indisputable as the need for structural reforms in many countries. And in these areas, the European Semester must play an essential role. Despite some problematic amendments, I supported the report, and I regret that Parliament as a whole rejected it.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I voted against the so called ‘Revamped European Semester’  which contained a number of very worrying provisions. It offers absolutely no way out of the prevailing austerity narrative and in fact this report sets out to ‘institutionalise austerity’ as it proposes the intensification of austerity policies. The immediate priorities are on boosting competitiveness and structural convergence, imposing fiscal policies and gradually making the convergence process ever more binding and therefore impacting directly on Member States ability to implement their own legislation. In effect this report aims to deny citizens any real political choices when electing their governments. The whole aim is to bind Member States to essential economic and fiscal policies at an EU level.  It should be patently clear that European economic governance cannot override democratic choices at the national level.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because it contains some positive aspects. However, this report also continues to work towards centralised management of national industrial policies from Brussels, which I cannot support.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which would like to show the European Parliament's support for the policies relating to the European semester. The European semester enshrines a European liberalism that wants ever more fiscal austerity, social burden relief and labour market reforms to move towards growth that has become a priority on solidarity and cohesive policies. Although the report calls for more attention on the social impact of austerity policies, it does not call into question the generalisation of this model in EU policies.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The European Semester process aims to ensure the coordination of integrated economic policies at EU level through the use of combined macroeconomic and budgetary surveillance tools. The European Commission draws up country-specific recommendations, but nevertheless member states carry out less than 10%, which is not enough. It is important that the specific recommendations for countries are more binding, which will ensure more effective economic development and reduce the unemployment problems.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – The democratic dimension in the economic governance package needs to be strengthened more closely. It should be noted that economic and social disparities are increasing in the EU. At present, one in four people are experiencing poverty. In addition, excessive overruns in current accounts pose a significant risk that needs to be addressed better. I believe that consideration should be given to replacing austerity policies with a new sustainable and democratic system that allows Member States to pursue their own economic policies.  In view of the current situation of some countries, it is appropriate to establish an international multilateral system for the debt-cutting of sovereign debt. In addition, consideration should be given to revising the Treaty and setting a withdrawal clause in the euro area and extending the option of opting for.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The European Semester Report highlights positive expectations such as a slow strengthening of the economic recovery and a GDP growth projection for 2016, but also warns of regional economic disparities and weaknesses and uneven growth and weak international competitiveness. I welcome the Commission's recommendations for this year 2015 and call for an even stronger commitment to meet the proposed priorities, in particular those aimed at reducing high youth unemployment, which has hit us hard in Croatia.  The percentage of young unemployed aged 18-30 in Croatia exceeds 40%. I also believe that it would be a good idea to introduce stricter controls on the implementation of the European Semester, namely the implementation of CSRs in order to accelerate economic recovery and equalize economic growth. In Croatia, especially in the last few months, there has been a wide debate about the misfits of the state education system with the current needs of the labour market, which significantly affects unemployment.  I take the opportunity to call on the Commission to take into account this in future recommendations as well. Taking into account the overall context of the report, its positive and negative sides, as well as the inability to reach a compromise, I remained reticent about the text of the resolution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report concerns the establishment of the European Semester, which is a European ceremonial aimed at putting the Member States' budget under the benevolent supervision of the European Commission and the Council of Ministers. It thus aims to ensure the maintenance of public finances according to criteria that are not justified by any serious economic study. Thus, a country that does not meet the criteria arbitrarily set out will have to follow the Commission's recommendations (which are not councils of friends) which are not distinguished by their originality as they aim to make ever more deregulation. This report spares the goat and the cabbage and remains unclear except with regard to the promotion of ultraliberal reforms or the proposal of own tax resources for the EU. I cannot vote in favour of this text because the European semester is the austere counterpart to the single currency and the report is meant to be benevolent towards it. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ One of the important problems of economic policy coordination at Union level is the very low level of implementation of CSR recommendations. For this reason, I support the efforts under this 2015 priority implementation report, to involve national parliaments at an earlier stage of the European Semester process, to include more precise proposals and to publish earlier, and perhaps most importantly, to take greater account of the social dimension of the whole process, especially in the context of structural reforms.  Only with closer cooperation between Member States, exchange of good practices and greater involvement of national actors can it be possible to ensure the effectiveness, but also democratic legitimacy of this process. While there are signs of economic recovery and growth at EU level, much more needs to be done to achieve policy priorities in economic cooperation.  In this light, I would like to highlight some extremely important social emphasises and achievements within the report itself; emphasis placed on financing and investment through EFSI with a view to creating quality jobs, achieving social and economic cohesion, reducing inequalities and improving public services; the requirement to increase wages as a means of combating poverty and for better jobs and the possibility to extend preventive restructuring and debt resolution programmes from banks to families at risk of homelessness.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policies. This report is the European Parliament's assessment of country-specific recommendations (CSR). CSRs are a central part of the European Semester, which in turn is an important instrument for preventing economic crises, especially sovereign debt crises.  The report highlights many crucial points, which I believe will be central to future initiatives to address the European Union's economic challenges. The text refers to the importance of continuing the process of structural reforms in order to promote growth and employment.  We must pursue a coherent project of economic and monetary union which requires coordination between the economic and monetary policies of the Member States, in line with the European Union's macroeconomic and fiscal surveillance framework. Efforts must be concentrated on promoting investment and improving the employment policy of the Member States.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester process provides a number of guidelines following the evaluation of the Commission's "national reform programmes" and "stability or convergence programmes". In this regard, the report here provides a summary of the main conclusions of the exchange of views organised by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament. A vast majority of participants considered that the strengthening of the implementation rate and the effectiveness of the country-specific recommendations drawn up in the framework of the European Semester include the involvement of national parliaments. In this sense, the report calls for the earlier involvement of national parliaments, i.e. in the preparation of action programmes. Because I believe that the sharing of experience on the European Semester process and its promotion by counterparties are of vital importance for structural reforms and for improving the economic situation that depends on them, I voted in favour of the above-mentioned draft resolution.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The initiative report on the European Semester for Policy Coordination, put to a vote by MEPs on 29 October, presented several proposals to further coordinate the economic and structural policies of EU Member States. The main issues were partly to stimulate investment and support employment while continuing to clean up the public accounts. Despite the laudable objective of this report, it lacked profound relevance and coherence as to what actions to take. That is why I voted against this text, which was also overwhelmingly rejected by the European Parliament (only 91 votes in favour, 409 votes against and 131 abstentions).

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. A year longer, the economic situation remains critical: the recovery is slow and fragile, unemployment rates are falling but remain excessively high, and poverty is at alarming levels, with one in four people in the EU in poverty.  That is why I did not vote in favour of this report. Because I believe that a true fiscal responsibility timetable is needed compatible with sustainable growth and quality job creation. Because the gap between the 10% it has the most and the least multiplied in the EU by up to seven in some countries, therefore fairer fiscal policies based on redistributive policies are needed. Because the reduction in unemployment has been based on precariousness and wage cuts.  Citizens need no more words or analysis. They need change, action and, above all, fair solutions to the real problems they face every day. A strong signal must be sent to the Commission and the Member States in favour of a European minimum wage framework or a minimum European income for insertion.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because the text does not give rise to legitimate criticism of governance that is completely opaque, un democratic and does not take into account the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report because we oppose the European Semester mechanism as a whole, even though the final text has incorporated many considerations that we share (e.g. those that point to the need to improve the quality of employment). The European Semester aims to subject government budgets to a european Commission audit that ensures the fulfilment of certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of ill-called structural reforms. We don't share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The European Semester is the annual process by which the Commission assesses Member States' budgetary commitments and assesses their conformity with the principles of economic governance (including deficit and debt limits), proposing, where appropriate, further reforms or cuts to agree. That is to say, the European Semester is a mechanism to legitimize and allow the Commission to intervene regularly in the affairs of the Member States, always offering the same recipe: social cuts, privatisations, labour reforms and increasingly destructive competition. I voted against it because we have repeatedly spoken out against this governance framework and strongly oppose the attempts of the rapporteur and majority groups to strengthen this process, involving representative trade unions and national parliaments, or by extending it towards 'social' objectives. This cannot legitimize a process which, by its very construction, pursues objectives far from the interests of the working majority.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not wish to see the Commission involved in pension reforms.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Looking at current macroeconomic indicators, there are signs of recovery in EU markets. However, it should be emphasised that its foundations are fragile, which negatively affects the EU's even growth and international competitiveness. The EU single market remains fragmented and is affected by a lack of innovation. Some Member States have persistent macroeconomic imbalances (high levels of public and private debt, large current account gaps, excessive risks in the financial sector). The persistently high unemployment rate in most Member States is a worrying phenomenon. Attention is drawn to the need for significant structural reforms, as well as a focus on creating the conditions for flexible labour markets, adapting education systems to labour market needs and transferring the tax burden from work to other areas.  Furthermore, the very low level of implementation of the recommendations for individual Member States should be emphasised, which makes it difficult to coordinate national economic policies with European recommendations. It should be noted that this year the number of countries under the excessive deficit procedure has decreased from 11 to 9. A step in the right direction is the entry into force of the Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which is intended to stimulate private and public investment in the EU. There is a need to further improve the business environment in the EU and to increase productivity levels by combining public and private education with innovation policy.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ I was glad to vote in favour of this report. I believe that in the context of the low economic growth and persisting high unemployment rates currently witnessed across Europe, it places the right emphasis on the need to implement necessary structural reforms, to boost investments, to ensure fiscal responsibility and to promote flexible labour markets. The report also rightly points out that sound economic governance is needed in order to ensure that investments made through the European Structural and Investment Funds, and the European Fund for Structural Investments bring about the anticipated results. Finally, I agree that the Commission should tackle the issue of the Country Specific Recommendations' low implementation level in several Member states as such failings lead to maintaining obstacles to growth and investment-friendly environments.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The report comments on the European Semester, in more detail on the Commission's annual budgetary recommendations to EU Member States. It welcomes, first of all, the Commission's focus on structural reforms, investment, fiscal responsibility and improving conditions in labour markets. It also notes that the future of the European Economic Area is threatened by the EU's fundamental structural weaknesses and the structural difference between regions. However, this important analysis is opposed to demands that ALFA cannot support in any way. For example, the report calls for an economic and fiscal union, minimum wages or an EU-own tax. That is why I am opposed to the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ I am very pleased that the European Union has focused on strengthening investment, implementing structural reforms in the product and services markets and labour markets, fiscal responsibility and improving employment policy as the main priorities for economic growth. It is important to achieve the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, as they can make Europe more competitive, thereby generating economic growth, increasing employment and promoting entrepreneurship throughout its territory.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Union's economic recovery is slowly strengthening and EU GDP growth is expected in 2016 of 2.1%.  However, the recovery lies on fragile foundations primarily due to structural weaknesses and major regional economic disparities. Many Member States face similar macroeconomic challenges, the most important of which are high levels of debt (public and private) that discourage investment and poor competitiveness. We need a coherent approach when addressing these problems, and I welcome the Commission's recommendations, which focus on four main priorities for economic growth: boosting investment, implementing structural reforms in product, service and labour markets, fiscal responsibility and improving employment policy. We need to provide more effective access to finance, especially for SMEs, which form the basis of the EU economy.  I welcome the decrease in youth unemployment rates, but I point out that they are still worrying in many Member States, including Croatia, which is third on the list with the highest percentage of unemployed young people according to a new report by the International Labour Organisation. I call on Member States to make effective use of all available resources to implement the Youth Employment Initiative. I support this report and appreciate the Commission's work in simplifying the European Semester process and call for more decisive efforts to guide and coordinate Member States' economic policies.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the message in writing \ u2012. I agree with the calls for improved competitiveness and the implementation of structural reforms. However, I fundamentally disagree with many of the measures proposed or welcomed by the report that will damage the EU economy, such as greater integration of the euro area, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, youth employment programmes and so on.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementing the priorities for 2015. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Budgets, I supported the committee's opinion, which points out that a new system of own resources must be put in place to help bring about a real overhaul of the EU funding regime without eu citizens having to pay higher taxes.  In the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, we also draw attention to the lack of payment deficits, which are mainly due to inadequate payment ceilings and insufficient budgetary resources, in 2015.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The spirit of Parliament's report is that there is no other way but to continue and deepen existing policies, with budgetary discipline in particular. Parliament welcomes the fact that the countries observed by the Commission on high debt have been reduced, but does not note that the countries in a memorandum do not receive annual macroeconomic recommendations from the Commission. In its recommendations, the report also welcomes the Commission's White Paper on deepening EMU and insists on the continuation of budgetary discipline, although it highlights the difficulty that southern Member States have in getting back on their feet due to the (violent) internal devaluation to which they are subjected. The report does not substantially criticise the Commission's report on the completion of EMU, but instead supports all those economic policies that destroy both the social fabric of the EU Member States and any hope for sustainable social development. It briefly reaffirms the EU's commitment to austerity policies and the further economic alignment of Member States' policies with the EU.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted to reject the report. The main reason for my decision is that the report continues to refer to structural reforms that do not even take into account social aspects at the level of mention. This is a significant step backwards from the previous year's report and foresees a huge and unfair burden on citizens. I also fundamentally believe that the report does not take sufficient account of the interests of European citizens. In addition to the above, I would like to briefly underline two other reasons. It is positive that the report contains a call for attention to the creation of quality jobs, but it is a big mistake that the report does not even reflect on practices in the Member States, such as the Public Works Programme in Hungary, which puts workers in a significantly vulnerable position. However, the use of the employment rate would also be justified, but this is not the case in the report. I also strongly reject the European Parliament declaring in this report that it 'recognises that the setting of minimum wages falls within the competence of the Member States', as this is unfortunately still harmful to workers in many Member States. I believe in a kind of ifyment in this area. In other words, parliament here should encourage common thinking and not make erroneous declarations. However, it is forward-looking that the report encourages the Commission to make proposals on how to ensure that the Recommendations of the European Semester are implemented and applied more effectively and consistently.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester provides the opportunity to ensure that economic policy is coordinated at the EU level through a combination of macro-economic and fiscal tools.  As a part of the annual procedure, country-specific recommendations are given to Member States on measures to boost growth and maintain sound public finances. These recommendations are based on the policy priorities identified in the Commission’s last Annual Growth Survey and have been endorsed by the European Council. The economic forecasts for 2016 indicate signs of slow economic recovery, with 2.1% in the EU and 1.9% in the euro area. While this modest growth is owing to fiscal and structural reforms undertaken by many Member States, more actions are needed to ensure the foundations of the economic recovery are solid. To achieve that will require a change in the direction of the EU’s economic policy. As a Social Democrat, I welcome the current report, and the main elements of this new policy: more investment and less austerity, implementation of structural reforms in the labour markets, improving employment policy particularly for the youth and long-term unemployed. I believe the four key priorities for economic growth will help to address the growth drivers that can allow the sustainable recovery Europe urgently needs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted against this text because all our key votes were rejected. The text in the end suffered the same fate, which I welcome.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it does not go far enough and because I disagree with a number of points. Moreover, in my opinion the text is too long and the wording is sometimes not really appropriate. The European Semester process is an important tool for monitoring economic reform across the European Union and it deserves a serious report, not an accumulation of ideological provisions.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 In my report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: I abstained from implementing the priorities for 2015, as in principle the content of the report is satisfactory, but I do not support certain parts of the report.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The report comments on the European Semester, in more detail on the Commission's annual budgetary recommendations to EU Member States. It welcomes, first of all, the Commission's focus on structural reforms, investment, fiscal responsibility and improving conditions in labour markets. It also notes that the future of the European Economic Area is threatened by the EU's fundamental structural weaknesses and the structural difference between regions. However, this important analysis is opposed to demands that ALFA cannot support in any way. For example, the report calls for an economic and fiscal union, minimum wages or an EU tax. That is why I am opposed to the report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the European Semester process is to ensure integrated economic policy coordination at EU level through a combination of macroeconomic and budgetary surveillance instruments, which is necessary to manage convergence and manage member states' interdependence. As the report lacked any meaningful social aspects, I did not support the package in the final vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report because we oppose the European Semester mechanism as a whole, even though the final text has incorporated many considerations that we share (e.g. those that point to the need to improve the quality of employment). The European Semester aims to subject government budgets to a european Commission audit that ensures the fulfilment of certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of ill-called structural reforms. We don't share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted against this report , of which I have been shadow rapporteur for the Green Group, as I believe it supports a neoliberal vision of economic coordination in the EU, in which austerity and massive cuts in rights are the only recipe. None of the contributions in the field of ensuring social rights and environmental protection were incorporated into the report.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution aiming to ensure integrated economic policy coordination at EU level through a combination of macro-economic and fiscal surveillance tools, which are necessary for steering convergence and managing the interdependence of Member States. The text addresses the most important challenges European citizens are facing, such as economic prospects and challenges for the EU, CSRs – priorities and objectives, setting up recommendations for improving social and economic conditions, addressing budgetary policies, employment and social policy, the internal market, etc.  I also agree that much more must be done in terms of prevention, and I agree with the need to support investment in early intervention and in high-quality, accessible and inclusive services, including in education from an early age, family and community support, social services and sustainable healthcare systems. An increased demand for services could also lead to important job creation in the social sector, if addressed effectively. Furthermore, the health and social care sectors represent crucial areas for investment in pursuit of sustainable economies.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted against this strongly contradictory report on the European Semester, which will not reach the Commission because it was rejected by an overwhelming majority in this Parliament. Indeed, the report has been totally inadequate to express a clear, coherent and common-sense position on the controversial six-month procedure, through which the Commission makes recommendations to the various Member States on the economic measures to be taken on the basis of what it considers to be priorities for growth, namely austerity, structural reforms, liberalisation of the labour market and the attraction of private capital. Unfortunately, Parliament has missed yet another opportunity to denounce the total failure of this rigid and senseless procedure for coordinating and monitoring national economic policies and to call for a radical review of them so that the Member States can democratically decide on the policies necessary to revive the economy and respond to the needs of its citizens. In any case, I consider it absolutely positive that a politically impossible compromise has not been reached on a report whose basic message was to defend austerity and structural reforms, not least because this confirms the impossibility of reaching a consensus on a single economic model between states that have completely different economies and social preferences.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The European Semester is the annual process by which the Commission assesses Member States' budgetary commitments and assesses their conformity with the principles of economic governance (including deficit and debt limits), proposing, where appropriate, further reforms or cuts to agree. That is to say, the European Semester is a mechanism to legitimize and allow the Commission to intervene regularly in the affairs of the Member States, always offering the same recipe: social cuts, privatisations, labour reforms and increasingly destructive competition. I voted against it because we have repeatedly spoken out against this governance framework and strongly oppose the attempts of the rapporteur and majority groups to strengthen this process, involving representative trade unions and national parliaments, or by extending it towards 'social' objectives. This cannot legitimize a process which, by its very construction, pursues objectives far from the interests of the working majority.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester, which operationalises economic governance and therefore represents the real weapon of submission of national states to the neoliberal creed, not only does not solve anything, but aggravates economic and social problems. In Portugal, fiscal consolidation has generated more unemployment, more poverty, more social inequalities and a public debt never seen in the history of our democracy. But Europe, like 25 million unemployed and 120 million poor, is not making progress, despite the billions of euros from the ECB injected into the financial system. The European Fund for Strategic Investments, the document of the five Presidents or the intention to align the calendar of the European Semester are only dedilatory maneuvers aimed at avoiding confrontation with reality. Economic governance promotes a macroeconomic framework incompatible with any economic recovery policy. Look at the Finnish example, once a model of virtues when it comes to budgetary discipline, but which did not escape recession and also ended up breaking the deficit limit.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I am in favour of the principle of subsidiarity, which is emphasised in the report. Unfortunately, at the same time, the report deals with areas in which the EU has no competence, such as.B. regretting that recommendations on environmentally hazardous subsidies, ecological tax reform and the promotion of renewable energy have been dropped in the country-specific recommendations. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I see it as an observation of the need to fight for a change in European economic policy. The recipe for Europe to emerge from the darkness of a crisis that has gripped it all this time is to increase investment and abandon the path of austerity. This is now a clear fact that the European political class cannot ignore. This report includes many elements for change: more investment and less austerity, recognition of the real consequences of the austerity measures implemented so far, commitment by surplus countries to boost demand.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester is a powerful tool for making European policy more effective, but it must include strong social and sustainability pillars, and prioritise social inclusion. The Semester must strengthen Social Europe, not weaken it. The reforms included in CSRs must not amount simply to more austerity, or reduction in social protections, public services or workers’ rights. Social impact assessments must be carried out, and CSRs must aim to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. It is also important to remember that austerity and the economic crisis have had a disproportionate impact on women. The Commission and Member States must include a gender perspective in policy-making when laying out and implementing CSRs.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The coordination of economic and budgetary policies within the European Union is the key to the European Semester and is part of the European Union's economic governance framework. It is our responsibility to contribute to ensuring convergence and stability in the European Union, helping to ensure healthy public finances, promoting economic growth, preventing excessive macroeconomic imbalances and implementing the Europe 2020 Strategy. The path to the exit from the crisis goes through a narrowing of economic governance and continuing reforms at the national level, this is the only recipe.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Semester, which operationalises economic governance and therefore represents the real weapon of submission of national states to the neoliberal creed, not only does not solve anything, but aggravates economic and social problems. In Portugal, fiscal consolidation has generated more unemployment, more poverty, more social inequalities and colossal public debt. The European Fund for Strategic Investments, the document of the five Presidents or the intention to align the calendar of the European Semester are only decising things. Economic governance promotes a macroeconomic framework incompatible with any economic recovery policy, hindering the country's development possibilities. We voted against it.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the text in no way questions the economic rules and instruments used over the last five years, despite the manifestly ineffective or even counterproductive results. We continue to insist on the blind belief that austerity and structural reforms are the only possible ways to boost growth, increase competitiveness and combat unemployment.  The report even calls for a strengthening of the six-month procedure, as the Commission considers that the lack of economic recovery is due solely to the weakness with which the Member States have applied the 'recommendations' sent to them. There is therefore a lack of a critical analysis of the procedure, which recognises its failure as an instrument of economic governance and raises the problem of the undemocratic nature of this mechanism, through which the fiscal sovereignty of states is ceded to the technical offices of the European Commission.  The procedure for correcting the macroeconomic and social imbalances generated by the single currency is vaguely referred to in the text without any emphasis being placed on using it as a means of recovery. I welcome the call for Member States to introduce a national citizenship income, however, this reference is not enough to make the report sustainable.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The post-oral resolution on long-term unemployment is motivated by a proposal for a Commission Recommendation which is overly generalistic, does not provide for new economic resources and does not allow Member States to be linked to its implementation.  For its part, the text of the Resolution has raised, as demanded by the Socialists: (i) a relationship between the parado and the employment services within the most balanced and fair labour integration contract with the worker, respecting his rights and professional expectations and avoiding forcing him to accept precarious jobs; (ii) to take into account not only their requalification needs but their environment and social needs; (iii) that new economic resources be mobilized to combat this problem as was done with the Youth Employment Initiative and that countries with greater financial difficulties are provided with co-financing instruments to enable rapid implementation of it. The resolution is also in time for the EPSCO Council in December this year to take it into account before its final decision, as the representative of the Luxembourg Presidency advanced. For these reasons we have decided to support the Resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The European Union's economic policies, its obsession with austerity and its lack of commitment to social and regional cohesion are some of the structural causes of the rapid growth of the long-term unemployment rate and its concentration in countries on the European periphery. Even if the Council Recommendation will not rectify this neoliberal approach, I do consider it positive that funds should be released and policies developed to alleviate some of the effects of this high unemployment rate. However, there is a risk of repeating the errors of the Youth Guarantee now: the lack of participation of the social partners in the design, implementation and management of the policies to be developed; insufficient funds (especially in those countries most punished by cuts); facilitating new subsidies to businesses rather than opting for really effective job training and guidance policies. That's why I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This text gives too much power to the European Commission and lacks realistic solutions. As usual, a lot of wishful thinking and little concrete action on behalf of workers. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The aims of the report itself are laudable enough, but national parliaments should be discussing such matters.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I advocate European mobility and apprenticeships in response to the unemployment scandal in Europe.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to improve the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. As a result of the economic crisis and its consequences, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007, accounting for half of all unemployment, i.e. 12 million people or 5% of the EU's active population for a long time. This proposal calls for more ambitious efforts to ensure that long-term unemployed are registered in employment services in order to ensure full accounting. assess the personal potential and needs of the long-term unemployed and the jobs they would give priority to before the 18 months of unemployment and propose a tailored, balanced and comprehensive return contract between the long-term unemployed and the services concerned no later than 18 months of unemployment. I support the calls for Member States to harmonise the EU's funding for national policies to tackle long-term unemployment.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. As a result of the economic crisis, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment, or more than 12 million people. In 2014, more than 60% of the long-term unemployed had been unemployed for at least two consecutive years. These figures are highly worrying because long-term unemployment drives people out of the labour market due to the erosion of their skills and professional networks. Therefore, I fully support the Employment Commission resolution on the Council's recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market.  This resolution is based on three main objectives: to significantly improve the registration of the long-term unemployed in an employment service so that they are all taken into account; assess the individual potential, needs and preferences of the long-term unemployed before they reach 18 months of unemployment; propose an understandable, balanced and adapted professional integration agreement between the long-term unemployed and the services concerned no later than 18 months of unemployment.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. With this recommendation, the Council wants to make an individual assessment and an employment integration agreement systematic for each long-term unemployed person.  The idea of organising this approach seems to be approved by all, but its implementation raises a few questions: lack of financial and human resources, difficulty in making appropriate job or training proposals and, above all, how to encourage the unemployed to take an interest in the contract system. For the time being, this arrangement remains non-binding and does not have additional financial resources.  I believe that the revenues mentioned as usual will not have an impact on the unemployment situation beyond the mere announcement effect. The discrepancy between the magnitude of the phenomenon and the weakness of the resources deployed will do the rest. The European Semester continues to draw an economic framework away from social concerns, and massive job destruction continues across Europe. It is clear that the long-term unemployed need to be reintegrated, but again, the Union is not making concrete proposals; So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the EU, with its crazy austerity policies, has helped to prolong the current economic crisis, resulting in the loss of thousands of jobs and long-term unemployment for a large number of European citizens, I wanted to support this text, which urgently calls on the Council to take action so that the long-term unemployed can be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. Many points in the resolution are positive and underline important measures to reach the long-term unemployed and open up opportunities for them to re-enter the labour market. However, the resolution does not say anything about the austerity policies pursued by the European Union, which in many cases have been imposed on the Member States. It is a fundamental cause of mass unemployment in the EU. Combating long-term unemployment and the crisis in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed not only in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems. Since the resolution does not have the broader perspective, I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The post-oral resolution on long-term unemployment is motivated by a proposal for a Commission Recommendation which is overly generalistic, does not provide for new economic resources and does not allow Member States to be linked to its implementation.  For its part, the text of the Resolution has raised, as demanded by the Socialists: (i) a relationship between the parado and the employment services within the most balanced and fair labour integration contract with the worker, respecting his rights and professional expectations and avoiding forcing him to accept precarious jobs; (ii) to take into account not only their requalification needs but their environment and social needs; (iii) that new economic resources be mobilized to combat this problem as was done with the Youth Employment Initiative and that countries with greater financial difficulties are provided with co-financing instruments to enable rapid implementation of it. The resolution is also in time for the EPSCO Council in December this year to take it into account before its final decision, as the representative of the Luxembourg Presidency advanced. For these reasons we have decided to support the Resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. I am pleased that the Commission has finally issued such a long-awaited Council recommendation on long-term unemployed. Of course, the Council recommendation may not be enough to rapidly improve the situation of the long-term unemployed, and it is therefore necessary to call on the Member States to achieve concrete results. Importantly, any programmes for the reintegration of the long-term unemployed are adapted to the needs of the labour market and are developed in close cooperation with the social partners. It is necessary to call on Member States to reconcile the financing of national policies provided by the EU to address long-term unemployment, in particular from the European Social Fund, with appropriate national funding. In addition, it is necessary to encourage Member States to motivate employers, including in the spirit of corporate social responsibility, to actively offer job vacancies to the long-term unemployed. Cooperation between the Commission and the Member States and the Member States, and at national level, the social partners representing the unemployed, civil society organisations representing the unemployed, local and regional authorities, public and private employment services, social and health service providers, local and regional education and training institutions, as well as the active involvement of employers in order to better understand business requirements and needs, is therefore essential for the effective implementation of this Recommendation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today made recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment. The novelty of the decision comes as the Union has finally recognised the need to address the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time, as their numbers and proportions have increased significantly in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and public debt crisis, and at the same time there are large differences between Member States. It is therefore particularly important that the decision adopted today included the need to take into account local and regional conditions in the fight against long-term unemployment, in addition to respecting the current treaties. The decision also name specific EU Member States with particularly severe employment crises: Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. Hungary have been able to significantly increase employment in recent years and keep the number of citizens looking for a long-term job below the EU average. This Hungary germany and the Czech Republic in the European rankings, which is a significant achievement. At the same time, there are still many tasks to be solved, we must continue to work and remain open to all options and working solutions.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal for a recommendation because, once again, the European Union is not providing a concrete solution to the integration of the long-term unemployed, which is a key issue.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Long-term unemployment has had different effects at Member State level, taking into account various factors such as the effects of the economic crisis, the macroeconomic situation, the economic structure and the functioning of national labour markets. The identification of an action plan to identify integration policies must take these aspects into account and a single formula for this would not give the expected results. Vulnerable groups are particularly at risk of long-term unemployment and social policies are required in support of them, taking into account priority social reintegration programmes.  Long-term unemployment creates major imbalances that lead to social exclusion, and unfortunately the effects are reflected in children's growth and education levels. The increase in the period of unemployment corresponds to the deepening crisis that families experiencing this problem are going through.  The fight against long-term unemployment involves a set of measures aimed at structural reforms comprising joint actions in sectors: economic, employment, budgetary policy, investments in human capital. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution in the belief that a strategy with multiple sectoral objectives is the concrete solution to this challenge.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution calls for the prompt adoption of the proposal for a Council recommendation on the integration of the longterm unemployed into the labour market. I am voting in favour, although we must bear in mind that this is an attempt to remedy a problem caused by the EU itself with its completely wrong and pro-cyclical economic policies (austerity)!

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The post-oral resolution on long-term unemployment is motivated by a proposal for a Commission Recommendation which is overly generalistic, does not provide for new economic resources and does not allow Member States to be linked to its implementation.  For its part, the text of the Resolution has raised, as demanded by the Socialists: (i) a relationship between the parado and the employment services within the most balanced and fair labour integration contract with the worker, respecting his rights and professional expectations and avoiding forcing him to accept precarious jobs; (ii) to take into account not only their requalification needs but their environment and social needs; (iii) that new economic resources be mobilized to combat this problem as was done with the Youth Employment Initiative and that countries with greater financial difficulties are provided with co-financing instruments to enable rapid implementation of it. The resolution is also in time for the EPSCO Council in December this year to take it into account before its final decision, as the representative of the Luxembourg Presidency advanced. For these reasons we have decided to support the Resolution.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council's recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. The Member States of the Union are all affected by the scourge of unemployment. Since the 2008 crisis, the number of people out of work has increased significantly. We need a European strategy to solve the problem of long-term unemployment in the European Union. Social policy remains a national competence. Nevertheless, we must be open to our neighbours and share our best practices in this area. Effective labour market reintegration structures for the long-term unemployed must be put in place that are both adapted to the specifics of the country's labour market but also that are tailored to the needs and skills of job seekers.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on a Council recommendation on the integration of the longterm unemployed into the labour market. In fact, due to the long economic crisis, long-term unemployment has almost doubled compared to 2007, affecting more than 12 million people, with very different percentages between Member States. In this context, support should be provided for proposals to increase the registration of the longterm unemployed in employment services, to assess their needs, preferences and potential and to offer a personalised, balanced and comprehensible "job placement agreement". Effective coordination between all the parties concerned must also be developed, especially in close cooperation with the social partners, in order to be able to implement reintegration programmes geared to the needs of the labour market. The text has highlighted all these elements and I have therefore voted in favour of it.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it presents measures which will help to bring the long-term unemployed back to work and alleviate the problems associated with long-term unemployment.  Long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007, and we have to address the reasons behind this rise. For the long-term unemployed, measures must be targeted and quick. One of the most important factors is for the long-term unemployed not to lose faith in their abilities and not to be discouraged in their search for a successful job opportunity. This can only be done through efficient lifelong learning and reskilling strategies which prevent people from distancing themselves from the labour market.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to influence the agreement on long-term unemployment, which will be discussed at the EPSCO (Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer) Council meeting on 7 December. The report highlights the serious consequences of the economic and financial crisis on unemployment and the need for 'counselling' that adapts to the specific needs of each individual. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 There are now 12 million longterm unemployed in Europe; before the economic crisis there were half of them. Alarming rates are recorded in Italy, Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece, with dramatic economic and social repercussions and on people's daily lives. Often the very absence of resources resulting from the state of unemployment and the discouragement of the failure to realize one's aspirations lead to a lack of interest in working life and to a growing distance from the world of work, with a further aggravation of the problem.  In order to break this vicious circle, it is necessary, first of all, to invest in the continuing training of those in disadvantaged conditions, in order to increase their skills and skills and facilitate their entry or re-entry into the world of work. But these efforts would be of no use without public intervention to support the economy, especially in those regions with a high rate of structural unemployment (including Sicily, where the employment rate is less than 50%). The active cooperation of all those involved is also necessary, with an exchange of best practices at local level and between Member States. Only in this way will it be possible to move closer to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and, above all, to our aspirations. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The resolution calls on Member States to combine EU funding – in particular through the European Social Fund – of their national policies to tackle long-term unemployment with appropriate national funding. It stresses that the budgetary constraints faced by some Member States (particularly those under budgetary adjustment programmes) should not prevent the recommendation from being implemented quickly. It calls on the Commission to explore possibilities for rapid access to EU funding and to mobilise, where possible, additional resources, as was done in the case of the Youth Employment Initiative. It stresses the need to allocate appropriate funding to certain Member States in order to strengthen the administrative capacity of employment services.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution because I remain doubtful that a Council recommendation cannot be sufficient to remedy the situation of the long-term unemployed quickly and I encourage individual Member States to take concrete action. I would also like to stress that unemployment rates are different for individual Member States. Europe can do very little to remedy this situation, but I call on the individual States, especially my own country, Italy, which remains one of the most difficult states, to put in place concrete remedies and strategies for this problem which, unfortunately, affects a large part of the European population in this period of crisis.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2007, due to the economic crisis affecting Europe, long-term unemployment has doubled, representing half of total unemployment, i.e. more than 12 million people. Long-term unemployment often leads to poverty, inequality, social exclusion, and gradually isolates people from the labour market due to deteriorating skills, loss of contact with professional networks and loss of work rhythm. I support this motion for a resolution because I believe it is essential, in order to combat long-term unemployment, to significantly improve the registration of the long-term unemployed in employment services; assess the potential, individual needs and employment preferences of the long-term unemployed before they reach 18 months of unemployment and provide an "integration in employment agreement" between the long-term unemployed and the services concerned. I advocate the creation of one-stop shops, where the unemployed person benefits from the presence of a professional responsible for his/her process. Member States should integrate EU funds into their national policies in order to use adequate national funding to combat long-term unemployment.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to promote the inclusion of the longterm unemployed in the labour market, sustainable measures to promote the competitiveness of the economy should also be promoted. In order to encourage increased supply on the labour market, new jobs must be created through the promotion of policies that encourage small and medium-sized enterprises to recruit staff.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to highlight the serious consequences of the economic and financial crisis and unemployment, the consequent risk of social exclusion and the difficulty of reintegration into society. Emphasis is made on the need for counselling adapted to the particular needs of each individual, the role of employment services and the need for specific training programmes in the field of work.  On the basis of these proposals, which call for improvements to the employment crisis and its consequences, I welcome this.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The European Union's economic policies, its obsession with austerity and its lack of commitment to social and regional cohesion are some of the structural causes of the rapid growth of the long-term unemployment rate and its concentration in countries on the European periphery. Even if the Council Recommendation will not rectify this neoliberal approach, I do consider it positive that funds should be released and policies developed to alleviate some of the effects of this high unemployment rate. However, there is a risk of repeating the errors of the Youth Guarantee now: the lack of participation of the social partners in the design, implementation and management of the policies to be developed; insufficient funds (especially in those countries most punished by cuts); facilitating new subsidies to businesses rather than opting for really effective job training and guidance policies. That's why I abstained.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's decision on the integration of long-term unemployed persons into the labour market made recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment. An essential novelty of the decision is that the Union has recognised that the situation of more than 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time also needs to be addressed, with half of the unemployed now in this category. Their number and proportion have increased significantly in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and sovereign debt crisis. The decision also 1999, which has a particularly serious employment crisis in the EU, including Portugal, Croatia, Spain and Greece, as well as Slovakia. The Decision focuses on the proper reintegration of the unemployed, the need for training programmes at work and the need for close cooperation between the Commission and the bodies and organisations of the Member States in order to improve the situation of the unemployed and create jobs. I voted in favour of the decision.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which deals with the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. I agree with the recommendation to ambitiously step up the registration of the long-term unemployed through an employment service aiming at full coverage,  assessing the individual potential, needs and job preferences before they reach 18 months of unemployment. Furthermore, it is positive to see suggestions such as the need to offer a tailor-made, balanced and comprehensible ‘job integration agreement’ between the long-term unemployed and the services involved, at the latest by the time the person concerned reaches 18 months of unemployment.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution addresses the multiple barriers faced by the long-term unemployed, including poverty, skills erosion and health problems. As a result of the economic crisis, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment. More than 12 million people, or 5 per cent of the EU workforce, are long-term unemployed. In 2014, more than 60 per cent of these unemployed people had been unemployed for at least two consecutive years. Noting that the rate of the long-term unemployed remains high, while European labour markets are showing signs of recovery, I support this resolution calling on Member States to intervene without delay.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. – As the economic climate gradually improves, it is time to look at how we can reactivate the long-term unemployed in the European Union. Some of the concerns are the focus on more training and more use of a targeted activation policy. The long-term unemployed must also be able to use it elsewhere, and so retraining is also very important in order to continue to use this human capital. This will benefit society as a whole.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council's recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market, although I doubt that a simple recommendation is sufficient to encourage Member States to act. Nevertheless, through this resolution, we insist that this Council recommendation should be aimed at all long-term unemployed, including those who have not registered with public employment services and those who have been unemployed for less than 18 months (between 12 and 18 months). In addition, the resolution stresses the importance of aligning actions for the long-term unemployed with those directed towards the short-term unemployed and unemployed young people. Thus, through this vote, we propose a single point of contact to facilitate the support of the unemployed.

name: Andor DELI
