text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today made recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment. The novelty of the Decision is manifested in the fact that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time must also be addressed, as their numbers and proportions have increased significantly in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and public debt crisis, and at the same time there are large differences between Member States. It is therefore particularly important that the decision adopted today included the need to take into account local and regional conditions in the fight against long-term unemployment, in addition to respecting the current treaties. The decision also name specific EU Member States with particularly severe employment crises: Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. Hungary, unlike them, has been able to significantly increase employment in recent years and keep the number of citizens looking for work for Hungary long time below the EU average, putting them in the European rankings between Germany and the Czech Republic, which is Hungary significant achievement. At the same time, we still cannot sit back: we must continue to work and remain open to all options and working solutions.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The European Parliament's decision adopted today made recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment. The novelty of the decision is manifested in the fact that the Union has finally recognised the need to address the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time, as their numbers and proportions have increased considerably in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and public debt crisis, and at the same time there are large differences between Member States. At the same time, we still cannot sit back: we must continue to work and remain open to all options and working solutions.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The long-term unemployment rate differs greatly from one Member State to the other. In Czech Republic, where the unemployment rate is one of the lowest in the EU, it currently reaches 2.3 %. The most important element in fighting the long-term unemployment is to  maintain the skills of the jobseeker. We need to focus on the jobseeker’s continuous education and reskilling in order to match his or her skills and qualifications to the demand on the labour market. With this resolution, Parliament has made an innovative proposal to the Member States to be able to tackle long-term unemployment across Europe and I fully support it. It suggests an individual approach towards long-term jobseekers through a ‘job integration agreement’, stipulated between the jobseeker and employment services. Such agreement would assess the individual’s potential and suggest the approach to be taken for his or her reintegration at the labour market before reaching 18 months of unemployment. I urge the Member States to commit to this recommendation for the sake of a competitive Europe with a dynamic labour market.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The proposal examines the services offered to the long-term unemployed with a view to their reintegration into the labour market and proposes concrete actions to strengthen them. However, due to the fact that the whole process also provides for the involvement of non-state actors and more specifically social NGOs of unknown economic and fiscal elements and interests, which, if not all, in the vast majority of them do not serve the purpose for which they were created, but on the contrary policies which are completely contrary to the public and social interest, while the economic recovery shows no improvement or signs of improvement in the EU labour market. , there is no reason to fund them and that is why we are voting against this proposal.

At the same time, we still cannot sit back: we must continue to work and remain open to all options and working solutions.

text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. For the Center Party and the ALDE Group, the fight against unemployment is one of the most important issues. More people in work means that more people can stand on their own two feet, and that also means a more stable economic situation in Europe. Overall, the resolution was good, but I would like to clarify two of my votes. Firstly, I think it is important that the social partners take an active part in the fight against unemployment. Secondly, I do not think it is necessarily a good policy to support public employment services more economically. In Sweden, the Center Party has put forward a number of proposals on how the employment service can be changed and reformed in order, among other things, to open up to private employment services. I believe that this is a more important part of the fight against unemployment than focusing on public employment services.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the economic crisis and its consequences, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment, i.e. more than 12 million people, who make up 5% of the EU's working population. In 2014, more than 60% of the long-term unemployed had been out of work for at least two consecutive years. The long-term unemployment rate differs significantly between Member States, ranging from 1.5 % in Austria to 19.5 % in Greece, with member states with the highest long-term unemployment rates being Italy, Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. I therefore consider it necessary to significantly improve the registration of the long-term unemployed with employment services, with a view to comprehensive coverage, assess the potential, individual needs and employment preferences of the long-term unemployed before they reach 18 months of unemployment and provide an 'employment integration agreement' between the long-term unemployed and the services concerned , which is adapted, balanced and intelligible, within a maximum period of 18 months after the start of the period of unemployment.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Long-term unemployed workers are an easy target of workforce devaluation policies aimed at increasing exploitation. The goal is to make labor cheaper, increase the extraction of added value, unpaid working time, i.e. exploitation. Jobs are urgently needed. There is an urgent need to boost sectors of the economy, such as industry, where these jobs can be created. There is an urgent need to boost public employment, addressing serious shortcomings, particularly with regard to public services. The State itself, assuming its status as a producer (and not a mere "regulator"), can and must make a direct contribution to this.  But it is also necessary to fulfill the principle that a permanent job corresponds to an effective employment bond and that the various precarious working modes are converted into effective contracts, when they respond to permanent needs. It is therefore urgent that, in the strategies to be adopted by the Council, the false solutions for the creation of professional traineeships or pseudo-contracts for temporary integration into the labour market are not repeated, which only increase the exploitation of workers, without giving them a viable and dignified solution for their lives.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Amendment 20 as it stresses the need to ensure the participation of social partners in the definition, planning and implementation of the proposal.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ In order to effectively combat long-term unemployment, it is essential that there is cooperation in this process between all parties involved in the reintegration of long-term unemployed people, including civil society. It is essential to pay attention to all long-term unemployed, including those who are not registered, and not only to those who have been unemployed for 18 months or more. I consider it paramount that Member States' policies on short-term and youth unemployment are fully in line with those aimed at tackling long-term unemployment. It is therefore essential that Member States link the financing of their national policies aimed at tackling long-term unemployment from European Union funds, in particular through the European Social Fund, with adequate national funding.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The proposal examines the services offered to the long-term unemployed with a view to their reintegration into the labour market and proposes concrete actions to strengthen them. However, due to the fact that the whole process also provides for the involvement of non-state actors and more specifically social NGOs of unknown economic and fiscal elements and interests, which, if not all of them, however, do not serve the purpose for which they were created, but on the contrary policies which are completely contrary to the public and social interest, while the economic recovery and signs of improvement in the EU labour market show no improvement. , there is no reason to finance them and that is why I am voting against this proposal.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that we must deal efficiently with the multiple barriers many long-term unemployed people face, such as poverty, skills erosion and health problems. I support the possibility of creating sustainable jobs for the long-term unemployed, especially in countries and regions with high structural unemployment. We need more flexibility in national budgetary rules and to improve the link between skills and jobs for the reintegration and employability of the long-term unemployed. Member States should ensure the quality of jobs for the long-term unemployed and avoid them ending up in precarious employment. Considering long-term unemployed differences between Member States, our goal must be a successful implementation across them, ensuring identification and exchange of best practices. The situation of long-term unemployed citizens must be improved, by all means.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's initiative to propose a Council recommendation on the integration of long-term unemployed persons into the labour market, and I would like to stress that the earlier submission of the proposal and its adoption by the Council could have partially prevented the emergence of today's level of long-term unemployment. Like the report, I am concerned that a Council recommendation may not be sufficient to remedy the situation of long-term unemployed people quickly and urges the Member States to achieve results in this area as soon as possible. First of all, I support the three main elements of the proposal, namely the extension of the registration of long-term unemployed persons in an employment service, with a aim of full registration, an assessment of the specific skills, needs and job preferences of long-term unemployed persons before the 18th month of unemployment and the offer of a personalised, balanced and easy-to-understand labour market integration agreement between long-term unemployed persons and the services concerned at the latest when the 18th month of unemployment is reached.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the serious consequences of long-term unemployment, more considering it has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment, i.e. more than 12 million people. Therefore, from the EU institutions, as well as from the Member States, we must continue to work to provide solutions for the better integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. text: in writing. The post-oral resolution on long-term unemployment is motivated by a proposal for a Commission Recommendation which is overly generalistic, does not provide for new economic resources and does not allow Member States to be linked to its implementation.  For its part, the text of the Resolution has raised, as demanded by the Socialists: (i) a relationship between the parado and the employment services within the most balanced and fair labour integration contract with the worker, respecting his rights and professional expectations and avoiding forcing him to accept precarious jobs; (ii) to take into account not only their requalification needs but their environment and social needs; (iii) that new economic resources be mobilized to combat this problem as was done with the Youth Employment Initiative and that countries with greater financial difficulties are provided with co-financing instruments to enable rapid implementation of it. The resolution is also in time for the EPSCO Council in December this year to take it into account before its final decision, as the representative of the Luxembourg Presidency advanced. For these reasons we have decided to support the Resolution.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Long-term unemployment is a matter of great concern: the figures show that it has doubled since 2007: this affects half of total unemployment, affecting more than 12 million people, or 5% of the EU's working population. Commissioner Thyssen is paying new attention to how to deal with this serious social emergency, the message that the European Parliament has sent with this resolution is very concrete and in-depth: more efforts are needed on the part of the Member States to introduce more 'personalised' strategies, to be adapted to the complexity of the different situations using all the programmes and support instruments that Europe has introduced in recent years. It is precisely the real intention to proceed with concrete action before the phenomenon of longterm unemployment becomes chronic and impossible to solve.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I do not agree with the Council's recommendation on the reintegration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market, as it ignores the needs of those affected and ignores the real problems.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I have today campaigned to combat long-term unemployment. The long-term unemployed in particular lead to a greater imbalance in society and also face the challenges of social exclusion personally.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given it is clear we need to take decisive action fight long-term unemployment. We need to give people the tools to adequately integrate themselves into the employment market.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as it concerns the integration of the long-term unemployed back into the labour market. It is imperative that a person who experiences long term unemployment is assisted so that he/she could retrain his/her skills. The measure allowing for a ‘job integration agreement’ between a jobseeker and an employment service is to be commended as it assures the best approach for re-integration. Given that as Europeans we are still experiencing the after-effects of the financial crisis, certainly in Spain, I welcome this initiative.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution. It analyses the complexity of the situation of the long-term unemployed with a similar approach to our positions, mentioning deficiencies in statistics and social, economic, family, professional, health and integration consequences for long-term unemployed, among others. The text focuses on three main components: (1) ambitious reinforcement of the registration of the standing in an employment service for their full coverage; (2) assessment of the individual potential and employment needs and preferences of the long-term unemployed before they have been unemployed for 18 months; 3) offer of a comprehensive labour integration agreement between employee and employment service before 18 months of unemployment.  However, among the negative aspects, there is no reference to economically strengthening public employment services, too much emphasis is placed on aid to employers for the integration of these unemployed without prioritizing the importance of implementing policies that have proved effective. Reference is also made to the European Semester and country-specific recommendations, an approach we reject.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Thursday 29 October, I voted in favour of a proposal by the European Commission to put in place three concrete measures in the Member States to facilitate the reintegration of the long-term unemployed (more than one year) into the labour market. The Commission proposes, first, to facilitate the registration of the long-term unemployed with the employment services, then to offer an individual assessment to determine their needs and potential and finally to put in place agreements for professional integration between the unemployed and public employment services (these are personalised plans of action to guarantee return to work). I welcome these measures, which aim to significantly improve the services offered to this category of unemployed people to help them quickly find a job. Today, nearly 12 million people have been unemployed for more than a year in Europe. This represents half of the total number of unemployed in Europe. In France, almost half of the unemployed are affected. It is therefore this category that must become a priority for the European Union because the longer the duration of unemployment, the more difficult it is to return to work.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. As a result of the economic crisis, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and currently accounts for half of total unemployment in the EU. It affects 12.1 million people, 61% of whom have been unemployed for more than two years. These alarming figures call for targeted action on long-term unemployment. That is why I supported this Parliament's resolution which echoes the Commission's recent proposal on the subject. The acuteness of the problem stems from the fact that the longer the duration of unemployment, the more problematic the return to employment. Among the measures envisaged, we call for a more active registration of the long-term unemployed. We also want job seekers who have been unemployed for more than 12 months to receive individualised follow-up. They should also be offered a professional integration agreement before reaching 18 months of unemployment, with a concrete and personalized plan to return to the labour market. For Parliament, it is crucial that this three-step approach does not fail to integrate all stakeholders, including non-governmental actors such as social NGOs working with the long-term unemployed.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. The post-oral resolution on long-term unemployment is motivated by a proposal for a Commission Recommendation which is overly generalistic, does not provide for new economic resources and does not allow Member States to be linked to its implementation.  For its part, the text of the Resolution has raised, as demanded by the Socialists: (i) a relationship between the parado and the employment services within the most balanced and fair labour integration contract with the worker, respecting his rights and professional expectations and avoiding forcing him to accept precarious jobs; (ii) to take into account not only their requalification needs but their environment and social needs; (iii) that new economic resources be mobilized to combat this problem as was done with the Youth Employment Initiative and that countries with greater financial difficulties are provided with co-financing instruments to enable rapid implementation of it. The resolution is also in time for the EPSCO Council in December this year to take it into account before its final decision, as the representative of the Luxembourg Presidency advanced. For these reasons we have decided to support the Resolution.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today made recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment. The novelty of the decision comes as the Union has recognised the need to address the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time, as the number of unemployed has increased significantly in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and public debt crisis. In this respect, there are large differences between Member States, so it is particularly important that the decision adopted today also includes the need to take into account local and regional conditions in the fight against unemployment, in addition to respecting the current treaties. The decision also name specific EU Member States with particularly severe employment crises: Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. Hungary, unlike them, has been able to significantly increase employment in recent years and keep the number of long-term citizens looking for work below the EU average, so Hungary currently ranks between Germany and the Czech Republic in the European rankings, which is Hungary significant achievement. At the same time, we still cannot sit back: we must continue to work and remain open to all options and working solutions.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Resolution on the very welcome proposal from the Commission for a Council Recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. Long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 accounting for half of total unemployment, representing 5% of the EU’s active population, although this does vary significantly across Member States. These continuing levels of long-term unemployment tend to disproportionally affect society’s most vulnerable members and jeopardise efforts to attain the Europe 2020 headline targets of 75% employment of 20- to 64-year-olds and at least 20 million fewer people in, or at risk of, poverty and social exclusion.  The proposal has a three pronged approach: to better measure long term unemployment by increased registration and supports; assessing the individual potential, needs and job preferences of the long-term unemployed before they reach 18 months of unemployment; and offering tailor made ‘job integration agreements’ between long-term unemployed persons and the services involved. It is important to note with such job integration agreements that the authorities must acknowledge equally their responsibilities to the unemployed person as well as vice versa and that the individual’s personal qualifications and experience should be respected.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this motion which aims to highlight the need to reach out to the long-term unemployed, including those who are unregistered. I agree that not only do we additionally need to reach out to those who have been unemployed for 18 months or more, but it is paramount that Member State policies target short-term unemployment (less than 12 months) and youth unemployment. This will fit in seamlessly with policies aimed at tackling long-term unemployment.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ Unemployment in the East of England rose by 9 000 in the last quarterly figures which were published, showing not just the fragility of economic recovery but the continuing challenge to find ways to help those suffering long-term unemployment in particular. Recently I was privileged to help out at a European-funded project to help jobless run by Community Action Hertsmere in Hertfordshire. I have been honoured to join similar EU-funded schemes around my constituency run by the Prince’s Trust and the YMCA. They do a brilliant job in helping raise confidence for people whose long-term unemployment means low self-esteem is one of the biggest barriers to finding work. My real sadness is that whilst I am working for European projects to provide this help, the Government of my country is more interested in benefit sanctions to drive unemployment statistics down and to leave people still unemployed but also penniless. We have to do better.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Council's recommendation to include the long-term unemployed in the labour market, as the longer period of unemployment progressively distances people from the labour market, creates an erosion of skills and professional contacts and contributes to the loss of work rhythm. Among the many shortcomings, there are certainly too long absences from the labour market that increase mental and physical health problems, social exclusion, pension problems and at worst the transfer of poverty to the next generation.  I believe that it is important to react already when a person is unemployed for a full 12 months, while 18 months of unemployment is already time to urgently take measures related to the registration of the long-term unemployed through the employment office and to ensure an assessment of the individual potential, needs and preferences for the job.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow MEPs and I voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the Council's recommendation proposal on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. The aim of this recommendation is to give Member States guidelines to facilitate the return to employment of the long-term unemployed, in particular by strengthening personalised support. This category of unemployed makes up half of the unemployed in the European Union, so it was essential to take concrete action to support them in returning to work. The resolution was adopted, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The proposal is constructive and provides a good basis for ideas to reintegrate the long-term unemployed into the labour market. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today made recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment. The novelty of the decision is manifested in the fact that the Union has finally recognised that the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time also needs to be addressed, as their numbers and proportions have increased considerably in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and sovereign debt crisis, and at the same time there are large differences between Member States. It is therefore particularly important that the decision adopted today included the need to take into account local and regional conditions in the fight against long-term unemployment, in addition to respecting the current treaties. The decision also name specific EU Member States with particularly severe employment crises: Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. Hungary has been able to significantly increase employment in recent years and keep the number of citizens looking for work for Hungary long time below the EU average, which ranks germany and the Czech Republic in the European rankings, which is Hungary significant achievement. At the same time, we still cannot sit back: we must continue to work and remain open to all options and working solutions.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Long-term unemployment currently affects 12 million people in the EU, or half of the unemployed. The long-term unemployed are "difficult clients" of intermediary agencies, usually low-skilled, with a narrow range of skills or unregulated issues of residence and recognition of qualifications, as in the case of immigrants; harder for them to enter and stay in the labour market. The necessary measures, such as personalised services and programs, are expensive and not always available. Despite the cost and scale of long-term unemployment, only 20% of anti-unemployment programmes affect them. I therefore support the EC guidelines for Member States to improve assistance to the long-term unemployed in returning to work: an individual assessment and advice for the unemployed for more than 12 months and a written agreement on professional integration, offering a concrete, individual plan to return to work before the end of 18 months of unemployment.  In the context of these efforts, I would like to draw attention to the social economy and the institutions of social cooperatives, which effectively manage the potential of the long-term unemployed and the excluded. An example of the use of this institution is the Polish organization from Poznań "BARKA", which helped thousands of excluded in Poland and abroad, restoring them to the social mainstream through work. BARKA bases its method on social cooperative institutions and social support programmes built at the level of local governments. I therefore call for greater integration of social cooperatives and the social economy into European policies against long-term unemployment.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Due to the economic crisis, long-term unemployment has doubled compared to 2007 figures and accounts for half of total unemployment. This has led to an increase in poverty, inequalities and social exclusion, undermining efforts to achieve the main objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.  I have chosen to vote in favour because the main components of the proposal are aimed at the reintegration into working life of the longterm unemployed. Finally, I would like to point out that the only way to reverse this trend is to return to investment, create new jobs and give as much support as possible to small and medium-sized enterprises, the engine of our economy.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market, because it gives too much power to the European Commission, and does not provide enough realistic solutions. Once again, it is a matter of many wishful thinking and little concrete action. Paragraph 13, on the other hand, wants to put in place strict monitoring of Parliament's recommendation through, among other things, the European Semester, whose effectiveness and legitimacy I do not recognise.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The post-oral resolution on long-term unemployment is motivated by a proposal for a Commission Recommendation which is overly generalistic, does not provide for new economic resources and does not allow Member States to be linked to its implementation.  For its part, the text of the Resolution has raised, as demanded by the Socialists: (i) a relationship between the parado and the employment services within the most balanced and fair labour integration contract with the worker, respecting his rights and professional expectations and avoiding forcing him to accept precarious jobs; (ii) to take into account not only their requalification needs but their environment and social needs; (iii) that new economic resources be mobilized to combat this problem as was done with the Youth Employment Initiative and that countries with greater financial difficulties are provided with co-financing instruments to enable rapid implementation of it. The resolution is also in time for the EPSCO Council in December this year to take it into account before its final decision, as the representative of the Luxembourg Presidency advanced. For these reasons I supported the Resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The European Union's economic policies, its obsession with austerity and its lack of commitment to social and regional cohesion are some of the structural causes of the rapid growth of the long-term unemployment rate and its concentration in countries on the European periphery. Even if the Council Recommendation will not rectify this neoliberal approach, I do consider it positive that funds should be released and policies developed to alleviate some of the effects of this high unemployment rate.  However, there is a risk of repeating the errors of the Youth Guarantee now: the lack of participation of the social partners in the design, implementation and management of the policies to be developed; insufficient funds (especially in those countries most punished by cuts); facilitating new subsidies to businesses rather than opting for really effective job training and guidance policies. That's why I abstained.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Due to the effects of the economic crisis, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007, affecting as many as 12 million people, or 5 percent of the Union's active population. It welcomes the initiative, but at the same time expresses concern that it alone will not be sufficient, but that more intensive participation and greater activity by Member States is expected.  It is required to speed up the registration of the long-term unemployed through the Employment Service, assess needs and individual potential before reaching 18 months of unemployment. Long-term unemployed people need counselling and preparation for successful re-entry into the labour market. It calls on the Commission to consider options for faster access to EU funds and mobilise additional resources and maintain good cooperation with Member States and for Member States to take into account regional differences in the design of plans. I supported the proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament, as urgent measures are needed to tackle long-term unemployment. Croatia is among the Member States with the highest rate of long-term unemployment.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The basis for the existence of any economic system is people who work in a wide range of professions, i.e. employees. With the gradual reform of the socio-economic structure of the world's regions over the last few decades, a large number of people became unemployed and, worse still, continue to be longer periods, often for more than a year or a half. In addition, this applies to people with a wide range of qualifications. This situation is not normal, so both the responsible local authorities of the European Union and the Member States, especially those where this problem has existed for a long time, must do as much as possible to eliminate it. It is perfectly understandable that this cannot be achieved within a month or one year, but in the past, tens and even hundreds of thousands of long-term unemployed will be reintegrated into the labour market the better. Consequently, I also support the Commission's proposal to establish an appropriate monitoring system for the effectiveness of the processes for implementing the necessary measures. It is not easy enough to distribute financial resources to achieve this objective. Comprehensive programmes should be drawn up to cover long-term retraining of the unemployed, the extension of knowledge, the provision of the necessary assistance and other objectives. Of course, measures of this kind are already being implemented in our Member States, but unfortunately it is not possible to call them fully effective, because the same youth unemployment is still abnormally high.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Long-term unemployment affects 12 million people, which is 5% of the economically active population in the EU, with large disparities between the different regions of the Union. Long-term unemployment has negative consequences for countries' economies, but also, above all, for the deterioration of people's professional and private lives and for their social exclusion. I therefore support the Commission's proposal to draw up recommendations for the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market and to promote the creation of sustainable and quality jobs, while at the same time ensuring continuous supervision of the implementation of these recommendations.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. ‒ Of the EU population, 9.6% is unemployed, and of these more than half, 5%, are long-term unemployed. 62% of long-term unemployed have been off work for at least 2 consecutive years. Only 24% of long-term unemployed are covered by unemployment benefits. Long-term unemployment can lead to poverty and social exclusion. It contributes to passing on poverty down generations in jobless households and lowers rates of academic achievement. I support this vote because addressing long-term unemployment would promote sustainable economic and social growth. Additionally, in the long term, it will take financial pressure off the Member States’ public spending and finance.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in the written statement (Rule 162(12) of the Rules of Procedure) on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. The ENF Group had tabled a number of amendments, for nothing, which gives a deeply Europeanist text, which calls for ever more Europe to get out of the difficulties of the crisis. We recognise the need to reintegrate the unemployed into the labour market, and we welcome the Commission's interest in it, but, as always, the EU is taking the problem upside down. We keep saying this, but the best way to reintegrate the unemployed is to create jobs, and this can only be done by supporting businesses and job creation, fighting unfair competition from low-cost countries and social dumping.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The reintegration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market is, in my view, an important undertaking, as it is crucial for the economic prosperity of Europe and the EU Member States. Especially in times of crisis, long-term unemployed must be supported by well-invested projects.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation. The integration of the long-term unemployed is hugely important and requires specific and sensitive assistance. I hope we can learn best practice across the EU to implement strategies in the Member States which have a lasting and positive impact.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. Long-term unemployment is an economic but also social problem, so it is essential to adapt long-term unemployed reintegration programmes to the needs of the labour market. The active involvement of employers through understanding the requirements and needs of this type of unemployed is essential in order to support certain specific training programmes.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report due to the recommendation that Member States develop work training programmes that will increase the employability of workers and also aid in the development of long-term jobs. If the Union is to overcome the current economic downturn we must do so in a way that supports our citizens and increases competitiveness on the global market.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Long-term unemployment in Europe has doubled since the economic crisis of 2007. 60% of those unemployed have to make do for more than two years without an income from a professional activity. As the period of unemployment continues, not only are work-related competences and skills lost, but also increases the risk of social exclusion and poverty. The re-attractive strengthening of the economy has not yet had a positive effect on structural unemployment. Additional measures are therefore needed to reintegrate the long-term unemployed into the labour market. Firstly, employment organisations, and all the partners involved in the labour market, should not wait for long-term unemployed to prepare them for the labour market. The earlier a return to the labour market starts, the greater the chances of a new job. In addition, the basis for a successful support project for the unemployed will always be to teach unemployed people new skills and competences tailored to the rapidly changing requirements of the labour market. The better the unemployed, and in particular the long-term unemployed, are prepared for the modern labour market, the greater the chance of a sustainable job.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I fully agree with the Resolution that as a result of the economic crisis and its consequences, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment, or more than 12 million people, representing 5% of the EU’s active population, and that over 60% of the long-term unemployed had been out of work for at least two consecutive years in 2014.  Long term unemployment often leads to poverty, inequalities and social exclusion and progressively distances people from the labour market. Therefore, I fully endorse the recommendations suggested in this non-legislative Resolution stressing the need to reach out to all the long-term unemployed and calling for close cooperation between, and effective coordination of, all parties involved in the reintegration of the long-term unemployed (including civil society organisations).

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In its proposal for a parliamentary resolution, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs welcomes this initiative by the Commission, but expresses concern that a Council recommendation will not be sufficient to remedy the situation of long-term unemployed persons quickly and therefore urges the Member States to achieve results in this area as soon as possible.  It also supports the three main elements of the proposal, (1) (1) extending the registration of long-term unemployed persons, seeking full registration, (2) assessing the specific skills, needs and job preferences of long-term unemployed persons before the 18th month of unemployment, and (3) offering a personalised, balanced and easy-to-understand labour market integration agreement between long-term unemployed persons and the services concerned no later than the 18th month of unemployment.  However, it points out that this approach should not exclud non-state actors, such as NGOs working with long-term unemployed persons, from the process. Finally, it stresses the need to help all long-term unemployed persons, not just those who have been unemployed for at least 18 months, and considers it particularly important that member states' policies on short-term unemployment (less than 12 months) and youth unemployment (including the Youth Guarantee) are fully aligned with long-term unemployment policies.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 It should be noted that long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment, i.e. more than 12 million people, representing 5% of the EU's working population, and that in 2014 more than 60% of the long-term unemployed had been out of work for at least two consecutive years. Long-term unemployment has serious personal consequences, such as poverty, inequality and social exclusion, affecting vulnerable people who normally occupy a disadvantaged position in the labour market. I believe that the economic recovery should be more dynamic, as it does not currently provide sufficient momentum to significantly reduce the high rates of structural unemployment. I support the need to reach out to all long-term unemployed, including the unregistered, the need to adapt all long-term unemployed reintegration programmes to labour market needs, and I reiterate my call on Member States to integrate EU funds, including through the European Social Fund, into their national policies in order to use adequate national funding to combat long-term unemployment.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the Council's recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market aims to make an individual assessment and an employment integration agreement systematic for each long-term unemployed person. However, it is to make it appear that the long-term unemployed are unemployed only by their own will or by a lack of competence or training. However, the vast majority of France's 2.4 million long-term unemployed are unemployed due to the national production deficit, which reaches 8% compared to 2007. The solution to this report lies in 'always more Europe'. We cannot continue to pay for the deleterious effects of Brussels policies with cosmetic patches that give good conscience to beautiful European souls.  So I voted against it.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Commission's proposal to put in place three concrete measures in the Member States to facilitate the reintegration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. The Commission proposes first to facilitate the registration of the long-term unemployed with the employment services, then to offer an individual assessment to determine their needs and potential, and finally to put in place agreements for professional integration between the unemployed and public employment services. I welcome these proposals, which clearly show the importance that the Commission attaches to the fight against unemployment.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market because Romania, like other EU states that are not among the countries with the highest long-term unemployment, has problems managing these citizens and reintegrating them into the labour market.  It is very difficult for someone who is unemployed for more than 18 months to find a job, and this worsens with the passage of time due to the erosion of skills. Also, long-term unemployment costs are very high for national budgets, resulting in the reduction or discontinuation of the benefits due.  In these circumstances, I support the position of the rapporteur, who is concerned about the weight and delay with which the Commission and the Council are proposing measures to reintegrate these citizens into the labour market as soon as possible. I also think it is very important that all these steps on the unemployed are also started in cases where they have been unemployed for less than 12 months, thus preventing their long-term unemployment.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. It is true that the long-term unemployed urgently need more support to reintegrate into the labour market. However, I abstained because the aspects that i consider crucial, such as the promotion of training, were significantly under-represented.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The number of unemployed in the EU Member States is worrying and it is important that countries are able to use EU funds, also provide adequate public funding, and that cooperation works at national level, at local government level and between the private sector and training institutions. It is also very important to provide the unemployed with the necessary training opportunities.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – The economic policy objective of each country is full employment. To this end, jobs should be accelerated in Europe, a revitalised economy and social justice. At present, however, the number of long-term unemployed in Europe is only increasing. Long-term unemployment is a particularly complex problem, as even with the creation of new jobs, long-term unemployed are often struggling to successfully return to the labour market. It is therefore essential that individual assessments are also provided to these persons and a specific and personalised return plan is adapted. The involvement of the social partners in the preparation, planning and implementation of the council proposal presented must be ensured at both EU and national level. Employers should be encouraged to play an active role in the development of partnerships with public authorities. They should also be offered targeted financial incentives. There is also a need to increase the financial and administrative capacity of public employment services.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. Away from the problems and against the real needs of the long-term unemployed was the resolution on the "integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market". "Reintegration programmes for the needs of the labour market" and "better understanding of business requirements and needs" were some of the cut and stitched in the needs of the capital in order to recover the profitability of monopolies. This will be based on the unravelling of the labour force and the "armies" of the unemployed used in capitalism as a threat to the generalisation of miserable working conditions and hunger wages for those who work. The resolution encourages so-called 'social dialogue' between businesses and workers, so that the unemployed are "trained" to bow their heads to employers' demands. The "one-stop talk" and the "personalised approach" for the unemployed promote the idea of an "individual solution", so that the unemployed do not meet in the fight with the rest of the unemployed, workers and the grassroots for their common interests. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the resolution and supports a coherent framework of demands for unemployment benefit for all unemployed people without conditions, full and free health care, etc. in the direction of conflict and overthrow of the capitalist system, the beginning of the end of unemployment.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this resolution because it is necessary to accelerate an economic recovery that does not currently provide sufficient impetus to reduce the high unemployment rate, one of the most pressing problems that negatively affect the individual, lead to poverty, inequality and social exclusion. It disproportionately affects vulnerable groups of people who are disadvantaged in the labour market, both in Croatia and in other EU member states. More than 12 million people are long-term unemployed in the EU, which is 5% of the working population, and Croatia is among the Member States with the highest rates, as as many as half of all unemployed are long-term unemployed. Furthermore, due to an unsuccessful job search, a fifth of people lose confidence, get discouraged and become inactive in looking for work, which is then reflected in their families. Statistics show that in 2014 in eu countries more than 60% of the long-term unemployed have not worked for at least two consecutive years! It is therefore necessary to be actively involved in solving this problem in order to reach all the long-term unemployed, including those not registered at employment services. It is important to focus on short-term unemployment (less than 12 months), especially for young people, to include other actors, such as NGOs working with the long-term unemployed, and to motivate employers to actively start offering them vacancies.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the Council's recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market aims to make an individual assessment and an employment integration agreement systematic for each long-term unemployed person. However, it is to make it appear that the long-term unemployed are unemployed only by their own will or by a lack of competence or training. However, the vast majority of France's 2.4 million long-term unemployed are unemployed due to the national production deficit, which reaches 8% compared to 2007. The solution to this report lies in 'always more Europe'. We cannot continue to pay for the deleterious effects of Brussels policies with cosmetic patches that give good conscience to beautiful European souls.  So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Due to the economic crisis and its consequences, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment, i.e. unemployment. more than 12 million people, which is 5% of the EU's working population. In 2014 alone, more than 60% of long-term unemployed have not worked for at least two consecutive years.  This is alarming data calling for urgent action by the European Union, which is why I support the European Parliament's dorpinos and the adoption of this resolution. I also welcome the Commission's initiative to propose a Council recommendation on the inclusion of long-term unemployed in the labour market, as earlier publication of proposals and consensus in the Council could partially prevent the long-term unemployment we are witnessing today. It is essential that programmes to reintest long-term unemployed into the labour market focus on labour market needs and designed in close cooperation with social partners.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad that Parliament voted positively in regard to the Council’s recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. However, I am disappointed that this proposal did not come earlier, because it might have been able to prevent some of the long term unemployment that we see today.  What we must focus on now is reaching out to all of those affected by long term unemployment so that we can start to help them. To do this we need cooperation at all stages of the process and across all of society as well. I also call on the Member States to match EU funding in order to help solve the issues of those facing long term unemployment. In addition, when Member States are solving their issues nationally, they need to take into account regional differences, such as those between rural and urban areas. With these measures and many others in the report, we can better assist those who are struggling with long term unemployment.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, the longterm unemployment rate varies considerably from one Member State to another, from 1.5% in Austria to 19.5% in Greece. The Member States with the highest longterm unemployment rates are Italy, Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. In 2014, more than 60% of the longterm unemployed had been out of work for at least two consecutive years.  This type of unemployment is gradually driving people out of the labour market because of the erosion of their skills and the loss of their work rate. In addition, long-term unemployment has very high costs for society due to the waste of skills and the increase in social spending. This undermines efforts to achieve the main objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, namely to achieve an employment rate of 75% for people aged 20-64.  That is why I support the adoption of this motion for a resolution. In the text of the Council recommendation there are proposals, such as the registration of the long-term unemployed in employment services and the assessment of the individual needs of the long-term unemployed, which I think are very positive.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the post-economic crisis, the unemployment rate in the EU has risen sharply and the long-term unemployed now account for 12.1 million people, or 5% of the EU's labour force. The European Parliament has approved a Council recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. This text sets out certain priorities and proposes specific actions to guide the social and employment policies of the Member States.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Sensitive to the impact of unemployment on the lives of the citizens of the Member States, the Commission presented on 17 September 2015 a proposal for a Council Recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. This Recommendation follows the conclusions of the analysis of support services to reintegrate the long-term unemployed into the labour market. The document has since been examined by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the rapporteur welcomes the proposals contained in the above-mentioned Recommendation, which greatly benefits from the contribution of the European Parliament. Considering the European Union's responsibility to combat long-term unemployment and also considering the contribution of this report, which points to specific actions to improve and strengthen the personalised support available in the Member States, I voted in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative resolution as we oppose any EU interference in our employment policies. The resolution called for EU surveillance of long-term unemployment recommendations and to give instructions to Member States through country-specific recommendations. It is burdensome EU legislation that is costing jobs and preventing job creation. Also the policy of open borders to 500 million people which the Tories and Labour party supports makes it harder for British people to find jobs and supresses their wages. Only the people we democratically elect in our own countries should decide employment law, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The post-oral resolution on long-term unemployment is motivated by a proposal for a Commission Recommendation which is overly generalistic, does not provide for new economic resources and does not allow Member States to be linked to its implementation.  For its part, the text of the Resolution has raised, as demanded by the Socialists: (i) a relationship between the parado and the employment services within the most balanced and fair labour integration contract with the worker, respecting his rights and professional expectations and avoiding forcing him to accept precarious jobs; (ii) to take into account not only their requalification needs but their environment and social needs; (iii) that new economic resources be mobilized to combat this problem as was done with the Youth Employment Initiative and that countries with greater financial difficulties are provided with co-financing instruments to enable rapid implementation of it. The resolution is also in time for the EPSCO Council in December this year to take it into account before its final decision, as the representative of the Luxembourg Presidency advanced. For these reasons we have decided to support the Resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution. It analyses the complexity of the situation of the long-term unemployed with a similar approach to our positions, mentioning deficiencies in statistics and social, economic, family, professional, health and integration consequences for long-term unemployed, among others. The text focuses on three main components: (1) ambitious reinforcement of the registration of the standing in an employment service for their full coverage; (2) assessment of the individual potential and employment needs and preferences of the long-term unemployed before they have been unemployed for 18 months; 3) offer of a comprehensive labour integration agreement between employee and employment service before 18 months of unemployment.  However, among the negative aspects, there is no reference to economically strengthening public employment services, too much emphasis is placed on aid to employers for the integration of these unemployed without prioritizing the importance of implementing policies that have proved effective. Reference is also made to the European Semester and country-specific recommendations, an approach we reject.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The European Union's economic policies, its obsession with austerity and its lack of commitment to social and regional cohesion are some of the structural causes of the rapid growth of the long-term unemployment rate and its concentration in countries on the European periphery. Even if the Council Recommendation will not rectify this neoliberal approach, I do consider it positive that funds should be released and policies developed to alleviate some of the effects of this high unemployment rate.  However, there is a risk of repeating the errors of the Youth Guarantee now: the lack of participation of the social partners in the design, implementation and management of the policies to be developed; insufficient funds (especially in those countries most punished by cuts); facilitating new subsidies to businesses rather than opting for really effective job training and guidance policies. That's why I abstained.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not wish to see the Commission involved in the UK jobs market.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation because I want to see an EU strategy for addressing long-term unemployment. Although I do not believe that the recommendation will go far enough in some cases, this represents a step in the right direction and this is a great reason to have the United Kingdom remain in the European Union.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report because it acknowledges one of the most serious problems of our labour markets today. Although unemployment has been diminishing in many parts of the European Union, long-term unemployment is increasingly prevalent. According to Eurofund, in 2014, 49% of the unemployed in Europe were long-term unemployed, a trend on the increase. Research demonstrates that long-term absence from the labour market usually leads to a poor employment outlook, a diminished future salary and even disengagement from society. This is why I am glad the Commission in its proposal has started to recognise the severity of this problem.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Long-term unemployment is a burning problem for many European countries as well as slovakia. It is important to find solutions to combat this problem. I support the main components of this proposal, namely the ambitious strengthening of the registration of the long-term unemployed, the assessment of the individual potential, needs and preferences of the long-term unemployed, the provision of a specifically tailored, balanced and comprehensible 'agreement on labour integration'. Nevertheless, I believe that we should also combat unemployment by promoting entrepreneurship and creating better conditions for new businesses, start-ups and start-ups.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because long-term unemployment doubled in the post-economic crisis period. Over 12 million people, i.e. 5% of the EU's working population is long-term unemployed and in 2014 more than 60% of the long-term unemployed have not worked for at least two consecutive years. Every year, one in five unemployed people stop looking completely for work.   The unemployment rate at this level is worrying. What Member States need to do is provide quality jobs for the long-term unemployed and avoid their precarious employment. While member states' social, economic and budgetary conditions vary greatly, the long-term unemployed form a very heterogeneous group and therefore face diversity that results in unemployment. A large number of people are starting to lose confidence and thus cannot reach their personal potential.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The great economic crisis has caused long-term unemployment, which has doubled since 2007 and is considered responsible for half of total unemployment, or more than 12 million people, representing 5% of the EU's active population.  The long-term unemployment rate varies considerably between Member States, with the rate in Austria at 1.5%, while in Greece it is 19.5%. The Member States with the highest long-term unemployment rate are Italy, Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia and Greece. It is therefore necessary to continue to work on an economic recovery that at the moment is still failing to significantly reduce high percentages of structural unemployment, and therefore I support this proposal.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted against the proposal. In fact, the proposal introduces many measures that will further intensify the problems of unemployment in the long term, such as calls for greater redistribution into anti-unemployment programmes, a call for greater initiative by public authorities to help the unemployed find a job, to highlight today's programmes to combat employment and so on.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. The global economic and financial crisis that has hit us is still present with frightening consequences.  In addition to the huge number of young people in the European Union – around 5 million young people under the age of 25 were unemployed in the European Union last year – we are also facing rising persistent unemployment, which has doubled since 2007. We need swift and effective measures that will boost employment, especially in regions with high levels of structural unemployment.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the resolution on the reintegration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market, because it underlines the need to reintegrate the long-term unemployed into the labour market with policies aimed at all the long-term unemployed and not only the registered. Unfortunately, more emphasis is placed on personalised "labour integration agreements" and individual development, rather than asking for state investment to create jobs, but these strategies also have their significance, which we recognise. It is also stressed in the resolution that any programme for the reintegration of the long-term unemployed must be drawn up in close cooperation with the social partners. This, according to the resolution, always translates into calling on Member States to actively involve employers in the supply of work to the long-term unemployed, but also for the employment services of the Member States to assist SMEs in the creation of such guidance programmes. Finally, the resolution calls for improved the economic and administrative capacities of public employment services in order to be able to play a central role in the implementation of this proposal, and calls on the Commission and the Member States to assess how they will support specific in-work training programmes, as well as operational development and investment projects that have created sustainable quality jobs for the long-term unemployed.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution adopted today made recommendations for the next European Council meeting on employment policy in order to address long-term unemployment. The novelty of the decision is manifested in the fact that the Union has finally recognised the need to address the situation of the nearly 12 million European citizens who have been out of work for a long time, as their numbers and proportions have increased considerably in recent years, in particular as a result of the financial and public debt crisis, and at the same time there are large differences between Member States. It is therefore particularly important that the decision adopted today included the need to take into account local and regional conditions in the fight against long-term unemployment, in addition to respecting the current treaties. The decision also name specific EU Member States with particularly severe employment crises: Portugal, Slovakia, Croatia, Spain and Greece. Hungary, unlike them, has been able to significantly increase employment in recent years and keep the number of citizens looking for work for Hungary long time below the EU average, putting them in the European rankings between Germany and the Czech Republic, which is Hungary significant achievement. At the same time, we still cannot sit back: we must continue to work and remain open to all options and working solutions.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion because it aims to create a better European Union. The economic crisis and its consequences have doubled the number of long-term unemployed since 2007 and an EU-wide solution is needed to address this situation. I believe that meaningful action, reliable statistics and monitoring are needed in this area. For example, don't include Hungary in your employment data if you have a job abroad, or count them as a statistical unit even if you've only worked an hour a month. There should be no public works programme that provides a salary of around EUR 150 per month as modern slavery. Instead, I propose that governments adopt the recommendations of the motion, including the need to develop specific job training programmes and business development and investment plans that create sustainable and quality jobs for long-term unemployed people. This is because long-term unemployment often leads to poverty, inequalities and social exclusion and disproportionately affects vulnerable people at risk in the labour market.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I supported the text and the three main measures of the proposal: (i) to significantly improve the registration of the long-term unemployed with an employment service so that they are all taken into account; (ii) assess the individual potential, needs and preferences of the long-term unemployed before they reach 18 months of unemployment; and (iii) propose an understandable, balanced and appropriate professional integration agreement between the long-term unemployed and the services concerned at the latest when the person concerned reaches 18 months of unemployment; Individualized assessment should take place before the person reaches 12 months of unemployment so that the professional integration agreement can be put in place before he reaches 18 months of unemployment; the three-step approach should not fail to integrate, if necessary, non-governmental actors, such as social NGOs working with the long-term unemployed, into the overall process.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which draws attention to the fact that more than 12 million people in the EU have been unemployed for a long time, with the situation becoming more severe since the 2007 economic crisis. It warns that long-term unemployment often leads to poverty and has huge societal costs. Therefore, the resolution welcomes the proposal for a Council Recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market and equally urges Member States to take action. It stresses the need to reach out also to unregistered long-term unemployed and to exercise an individual approach. Importantly, it calls on the Commission and the Member States to assess how to support business development and investment plans to create sustainable and quality jobs for the long-term unemployed.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Motions for resolutions - Council recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market, as I believe that long-term unemployment has a negative impact on people, gradually losing their skills, which can lead to personal distress, poorer use of human capital, loss of economic potential and an increase in social expenditure.  An increased rate of transition of long-term unemployed into employment would contribute to sustainable growth, while also relieving public finances.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ I support the initiative by the Commission on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market and the three main components of the proposal. However, Member States should consider regional differences. Labour taxation systems of some Member States can hardly promote creation of new jobs. There should also be no obstacles for freedom of movement in the European Union. For example, in the Baltic region freedom of movement of workers is now compromised by disproportionately high professional linguistic requirements.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution. It analyses the complexity of the situation of the long-term unemployed with a similar approach to our positions, mentioning deficiencies in statistics and social, economic, family, professional, health and integration consequences for long-term unemployed, among others. The text focuses on three main components: (1) ambitious reinforcement of the registration of the standing in an employment service for their full coverage; (2) assessment of the individual potential and employment needs and preferences of the long-term unemployed before they have been unemployed for 18 months; 3) offer of a comprehensive labour integration agreement between employee and employment service before 18 months of unemployment.  However, among the negative aspects, there is no reference to economically strengthening public employment services, too much emphasis is placed on aid to employers for the integration of these unemployed without prioritizing the importance of implementing policies that have proved effective. Reference is also made to the European Semester and country-specific recommendations, an approach we reject.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The number of long-term unemployed has doubled since 2007 due to the economic crisis and its consequences, and now half of the unemployed fall into this category: more than 12 million people, or 5% of the EU's active population. More seriously, in 2014, more than 60% of the long-term unemployed were already unemployed for at least two consecutive years. Sustainable job creation is one of the Union's most important tasks, which is why I supported the report.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2007, as a result of the economic crisis and its consequences, long-term unemployment has doubled and accounts for half of total unemployment. Specifically, more than 12 million people do not currently have a job. At the same time, statistics show that in 2014, more than 60% of all long-term unemployed had not had a job for at least two consecutive years. The European Parliament resolution welcomes the Commission's initiative to propose a Council recommendation on the integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market. The proposals contained in this recommendation are very ambitious, but a sustained effort by member States is needed to ensure that they are indeed implemented and implemented.  At the same time, it is necessary for the economic recovery to become more dynamic, as it does not currently provide sufficient incentives to significantly reduce the high rate of structural unemployment.  Through the provisions included, the resolution calls on the European Commission to examine options for rapid access to EU funding and to mobilise additional resources where possible, as was the case with the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the motion for a resolution. It analyses the complexity of the situation of the long-term unemployed with a similar approach to our positions, mentioning deficiencies in statistics and social, economic, family, professional, health and integration consequences for long-term unemployed, among others. The text focuses on three main components: (1) ambitious reinforcement of the registration of the standing in an employment service for their full coverage; (2) assessment of the individual potential and employment needs and preferences of the long-term unemployed before they have been unemployed for 18 months; 3) offer of a comprehensive labour integration agreement between employee and employment service before 18 months of unemployment.  However, among the negative aspects, there is no reference to economically strengthening public employment services, too much emphasis is placed on aid to employers for the integration of these unemployed without prioritizing the importance of implementing policies that have proved effective. Reference is also made to the European Semester and country-specific recommendations, an approach we reject.

name: Ivo VAJGL
