text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it is crucial that we address the topic of long-term unemployment. As a result of the economic crisis, long-term unemployment has doubled since 2007 and accounts for half of total unemployment, or more than 12 million people, representing 5% of the EU’s active population; over 60% of the long-term unemployed were out of work for at least two consecutive years in 2014.  Long-term unemployment often leads to poverty, inequalities and social exclusion, and disproportionately affects vulnerable people who are in a disadvantaged position on the labour market. I agree with the proposed actions¸ addressing this issue: (i) ambitiously stepping up the registration of the long-term unemployed through an employment service aiming at full coverage; (ii) assessing the individual potential, needs and job preferences of the long-term unemployed before they reach 18 months of unemployment; and (iii) offering a tailor-made, balanced and comprehensible ‘job integration agreement’ between the long-term unemployed and the services involved, at the latest by the time the person concerned reaches 18 months of unemployment.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about an issue of the utmost importance to Europe, as long-term unemployment is a major problem in multiple EU countries that have been hit by the economic crisis. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The European Union's economic policies, its obsession with austerity and its lack of commitment to social and regional cohesion are some of the structural causes of the rapid growth of the long-term unemployment rate and its concentration in countries on the European periphery. Even if the Council Recommendation will not rectify this neoliberal approach, I do consider it positive that funds should be released and policies developed to alleviate some of the effects of this high unemployment rate. However, there is a risk of repeating the errors of the Youth Guarantee now: the lack of participation of the social partners in the design, implementation and management of the policies to be developed; insufficient funds (especially in those countries most punished by cuts); facilitating new subsidies to businesses rather than opting for really effective job training and guidance policies. That's why I abstained.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Long-term unemployment is not a problem relating to one Member State or even to Europe, but one that we must come to terms with if the promise of the European Union is to be fulfilled by all our citizens. I was, therefore, proud to vote on this resolution. We must do more, more effectively, to give people the tools to exit long-term unemployment and utilise their talents for the common good. Too often we patronise people in long-term unemployment, and presume that they need to be harshly punished to force them into gainful work, when almost all are striving for work but have not been given the tools to adequately integrate themselves into the employment market.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. In 2014, more than 12 million workers, or 5% of the EU labour force, are long-term unemployed and 62% have been unemployed for at least two consecutive years. The consequences of long-term unemployment are considerable and deleterious: increased household poverty, skills erosion, higher incidence of health problems, increased risk of social exclusion, poverty and inequality. The Council's objective is to increase the return to employment of the long-term unemployed. The specific objectives are to increase coverage of registration and support for the long-term unemployed, to ensure continuity and coordination between the services concerned and to "increase the effectiveness of interventions aimed at both long-term unemployment and employers". The far-right group took advantage of the resolution to engage in an exercise in demagoguery proposing simplistic amendments. In the end, I abstained because, while I agree with these objectives to improve the rapid return to employment of the long-term unemployed, the recommendations of the Council and the European Parliament prioritise the competitiveness of businesses and are part of the austerity measures and the European Semester.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. 'u2012' Long-term unemployment is an excellent tool at the service of policies that want to make labour cheaper and more exploited. If a worker is over 12 or 18 months without being employed, he should already be very happy with any crumb.  The previous right-wing government in Portugal, with this idea in mind, created an internship program for the long-term unemployed, directly contributing to the replacement of employment with rights for precarious employment, to the direct reduction of wages and, moreover, subsidizing this reduction of wages with social security money. We understand the need to bring unemployment down. However, there are minimal rules, many of them relating to human dignity. First of all, it is also necessary to create jobs on solid bases, with growth of the real economy, and that the principle that a permanent job corresponds to a permanent job. All these precarious work models should be converted into effective contracts when they respond to permanent needs.  Everything else is rhetorical exercises to disguise exploitative policies.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The reintegration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market is, in my view, an important undertaking, as it is crucial for the economic prosperity of Europe and the EU Member States. Especially in times of crisis, long-term unemployed must be supported by well-invested projects.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Council recommendation on the integration of the longterm unemployed into the labour market because we cannot allow this human capital to be lost. It is up to Europe to build the conditions for the relocation of these people through greater effectiveness of active labour policies and training systems that exploit the potential offered by new economies and digital.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. This resolution is another consequence of the failure of the euro monetary union, which has caused major social problems and upheavals in various Member States. However, due to historical, cultural and, above all, economic differences, labour and social policy are among the national tasks of the Member States. The AfD sees these two principles as an immovable basis for the future development of the EU. These must not be sacrificed to a 'harmonisation' due to the euro rescue policy. Long-term unemployment is a particular problem in several EU crisis countries. Its solution is a national task. The causes are often inadequate reforms of national encrusted labour markets and decision-making structures. The reorganisation of the monetary system sought by the AfD would be accompanied by a devaluation of the currencies of the southern countries of Europe and could make an important contribution to restoring their competitiveness, thereby leading to new growth and new jobs, especially for young people and the long-term unemployed. Moreover, employment relationships in the crisis countries are unduly protected at the expense of the young generation. Similarly, minimum wage regulations there prevent new entrants from entering the labour market. Without appropriate reforms in these crisis states, European aid will also be of no value. That is why I voted against the resolution.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: In writing. This clear text is what the European Union needs to combat long-term youth unemployment. The scourge of unemployment affects too many young Europeans and, beyond the economic cost, these are human tragedies that cannot be accepted. That is why the report rightly advocates a rapid reaction for the newly registered unemployed, so as not to let them sink into long-term unemployment. By advocating a rapid assessment of their potential and needs, as well as by proposing an appropriate and balanced professional integration agreement (including using non-governmental organizations with a good knowledge of the subject and already working with long-term unemployed), the report proposes concrete ways to combat this scourge.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), in writing. Away from the problems and against the real needs of the long-term unemployed was the resolution on the "integration of the long-term unemployed into the labour market". "Reintegration programmes for the needs of the labour market" and "better understanding of business requirements and needs" were some of the cut and stitched in the needs of the capital in order to recover the profitability of monopolies. This will be based on the unravelling of the labour force and the "armies" of the unemployed used in capitalism as a threat to the generalisation of miserable working conditions and hunger wages for those who work. The resolution encourages so-called 'social dialogue' between businesses and workers, so that the unemployed are "trained" to bow their heads to employers' demands. The "one-stop talk" and the "personalised approach" for the unemployed promote the idea of an "individual solution", so that the unemployed do not meet in the fight with the rest of the unemployed, workers and the grassroots for their common interests. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the resolution and supports a coherent framework of demands for unemployment benefit for all unemployed people without conditions, full and free health care, etc. in the direction of conflict and overthrow of the capitalist system, the beginning of the end of unemployment.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. Long-term unemployed workers are an easy target of policies that want to make labour cheaper and more exploited. There is an urgent need to boost sectors of the economy, such as industry, that create jobs. But it is also necessary to fulfil the principle that a permanent job corresponds to an effective employment bond and that all these precarious work models are converted into effective contracts when they respond to permanent needs. It is therefore urgent that, in the strategies to be adopted by the Council, the false solutions for the creation of professional traineeships or pseudo-contracts for temporary integration into the labour market are not repeated, which only increase the exploitation of workers, without giving them a viable and dignified solution for their lives.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The European Aviation Safety Agency is currently the authority providing authorization for the flight of remotely piloted aircraft (RPAS) only when the mass of aircraft exceeds 150 kg. In view of this situation, the European Commission has submitted a proposal for a European regulatory framework that takes into account the characteristics of RPAS (weight, scope of operations, speed) and the nature of their use (recreational or professional).  While I support the Commission's intention to eliminate this 150 kg threshold and replace it with an appropriate regulatory framework, as well as to create a regular information mechanism among Member States addressing RPAS incidents and sharing good practices, I abstained in this report. The Commission does not provide guarantees for a clear division of civilian and military use or for the espionage of drones. In addition, it stresses that the "very dynamic" Israeli manufacturing sector, clearly for military use (used for espionage and extrajudicial and extraterritorial executions), facilitates the integration of a civilian and military air navigation service into Israeli airspace. That is why I have not supported this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This text establishes a balanced Eu regulation. The idea is to model the supervision of civilian drones on what is already being done in international regulations in the field of civil aviation.  In order to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations, the development of international rules is not aberrant in this case since national airspace is constantly crossed by foreign aircraft.  The report insists that EU regulations are balanced by ensuring the security of people, data and privacy protection and the development of this new sector.  Furthermore, the report reminds us that all actors must be involved in the development of EU rules: Member States, the Commission, relevant national authorities, SMEs, commercial operators, law enforcement, etc. Finally, I underline the fact that this report does not in any way target military drones, the regulation of which must remain the exclusive responsibility of the Member States.   So I voted in favour of the Foster report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about harmonisation, taking power away from member states and heavy-handed regulation which could stifle investment or technological advance. On a technical point, I note the intention to remove the 150kg threshold and believe that this will impact further upon Member States.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ensure that drones do not threaten public safety or privacy, as commercial services using drones take off and their recreational use becomes even more popular.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for the safe use of RPAS in civil aviation. In order to ensure the safe use of drones, new proportionate rules are needed to avoid an unnecessary burden on the development of this new industry. Over the last 15 years, this industry has grown significantly. Unmanned aircraft are used to maintain huge cereal fields, humanitarian disaster zones and the fight against forest fires. I agree with the need to ensure that unmanned aircraft are operated only by well-trained operators. In addition, drones shall be equipped with obstacle detection and avoidance technology to ensure that RPAS systems do not endanger the safety of manned aircraft, and that no-fly areas such as airports and other critical infrastructures are taken into account.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this resolution in which the European Parliament votes in favour of legislation that sets the guidelines for the use of civilian drones. Users should be trained with information on privacy and personal data protection. Aircraft should be equipped with detection and avoidance technology to ensure that the safety of piloted aircraft is not jeopardized and that densely populated areas and no-fly zones such as airports are taken into account. Similarly, the use of drone systems by law enforcement and intelligence services should, of course, respect the fundamental right to privacy, data protection, free movement and freedom of expression. Finally, data protection authorities in Member States should share specific data protection guidelines for drones used for commercial purposes.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour, as there is still no harmonisation in the EU to regulate the use of drones in the civil aviation sector. Rules must be created which, by not imposing disproportionate burdens on SMEs and protecting data and privacy, they deal with air navigation suitability, certification specifications, commercial and recreational uses, the identity of the drone and owner/operator, the authorisation of pilot training organisations, pilot training and licensing, operations, responsibilities and insurance, data and privacy protection, geo-fencing and overflight zones.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems (RPAS) in civil aviation should regulate the use of drones in the civilian sector. International regulations governing the use of civilian drones are necessary to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations. The rapporteur rightly considers that harmonisation at European level is a useful step in the process of drawing up global rules, but this EU legislation must be balanced, particularly with regard to data protection and privacy, which must be guaranteed without penalising SMEs producing drones.  Finally, the report notes that it is particularly important that all stakeholders cooperate and therefore it is essential that the Commission is not alone in charge. So I voted for this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the report is acceptable and balanced. I think it is important that citizens' safety is guardsed against the safe use of remotely piloted aerial systems by civil aviation, so I voted in favour of it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have chosen to abstain from voting on this report. The report focuses on drones in civil aviation and highlights the importance of the protection of personal data, the right to privacy and other fundamental rights, which is a good thing. However, I cannot support the wording which emphasises that integrated civil-military air navigation services make it easier to integrate RPAS into Israeli airspace. I will never be able to support a report legitimising drones for military purposes or Israel's war on Palestine.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on the safe use of RPAS in civil aviation. These professionally used RPAS also bring significant benefits in various areas of civil use, and their added value is growing as the distance from the apparatus to the remote control increases. The use of these systems is very diverse and can be further developed in the future, for example by contributing to security checks and monitoring of infrastructure (railway tracks, barriers and energy installations), as well as to assessing natural disasters, carrying out (environmentally responsible) precision farming activities, developing media production, conducting aviation thermographs or delivering consignments to remote regions. We can anticipate that new applications will be developed soon in the near future. Parliament therefore considers that the lack of harmonised Regulation at Union level may hinder the development of the European market for RPAS, as authorisations at national level are not generally recognised in other Member States. Welcomes, therefore, the adoption of the Commission legislative proposal in this area by the end of 2015. New regulatory standards will be established for civil RPAS covering safety, security, privacy, data protection, insurance and liability aspects. The Commission aims to enable EU industry to become a global leader in this emerging technology business.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Over the past 15 years, the use of remotely operated aircraft systems, commonly known as drones or drones, has grown rapidly, and those designed for hobby and recreation are becoming increasingly popular. This technology was developed primarily for military purposes, but is now applied for commercial purposes, thereby moving legislative boundaries. Accordingly, it is necessary to regulate its use in a quality way at EU level.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This is a matter of concern at a time when nuclear power plants or other sensitive buildings, such as denominational schools, are being flown over by unidentified drones. The absence of national regulations leaves the field open to relatively new European legislation in this area. It must be balanced: neither too restrictive nor too liberal. By insisting, like the rapporteur, on the need to involve all stakeholders (civil aviation, companies manufacturing these devices, commercial operators of these drones, law enforcement, etc.) in the drafting of legislation on this eminently strategic sector, I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Drones or remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) are a subject of concern to us and to which we must give greater interest.  I agree that the use of drones has benefits such as a real opportunity to stimulate job creation, as well as a source of innovation and growth for years to come, but we need to consider the challenges of these remotely piloted aircraft. It is about safety, security and respect for citizens' rights, which need to be addressed before civilian drones can be widely used in the European Union. I voted in favour of the report on the safe use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (SAPDs) in the field of civil aviation because, like the rapporteur, I am in favour of them and recognise their advantages, but I believe that a number of appropriate policies are absolutely necessary, which protect privacy and ensure data protection.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The report by the Committee on Transport seems complete. It touches both on the importance of developing the industry that produces this type of aircraft and on the issue of safety. There are, in fact, important problems relating to respect for privacy and the personal data of citizens connected with this issue. All in all, this text appears to be balanced. Under existing treaties it would be illusory to think that aircraft of this type can only be regulated by national rules. Clearly, especially for some political groups, the subject of these aircraft is linked to the particular sensitivity of their use, including military use. It should be borne in mind that, to date, rules relating to these devices exist or are being developed in Austria, Croatia, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Ireland, Poland, the Czech Republic, Spain and the United Kingdom.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Unmanned aerial vehicles and drones are new technologies with high potential for innovation and economic growth. The European Union must adapt its market to this technological change by establishing rules that allow European entrepreneurs to compete in the field and respect the privacy of citizens. It is with technological innovation framed by harmonised and relevant security rules that the European economy will recover. Civilian drones have considerable job creation potential. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the safe use of remotely piloted aerial systems (RPAS), commonly known as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), in the civil aviation sector. This technology is widely applied to commercial use, ensuring significant benefits for different civil uses, and may be further extended to other fields in the future. All Member States carry out activities in this field, which are considered legal only if there is national legislation in this area.  Unfortunately, authorisations issued by one state are generally not mutually recognised in other countries and the absence of harmonised regulation at EU level risks severely restricting the development of a European market for RPAS systems. In view of the fact that this resolution has highlighted the need to achieve adequate and efficient legislation in this area, I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is aimed at regulating the use of civil drones in Europe. At present there are only national regulations with no EU or global regulations on civil use.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the rapporteur that we should treat the safe use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) as a new type of aircraft and its services should be developed for industry to invest. In addition, in order to integrate RPAS to the European airspace, there is a need to develop new technology and standards.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which aims to send a political signal to the European Commission to establish harmonised regulation at European (and global) level for the use of drones in the civil aviation sector.  The text calls on the Commission to introduce clear rules on the internal market and international trade for production, sale, purchase, trade and use. In particular, rules on air navigation suitability, certification specifications, commercial and recreational uses, the identity of the drone and owner/operator, the authorisation of pilot training organisations, pilot training and licensing, operations, liability and insurance, data and privacy protection, geo-fencing and overflight prohibition zones are required.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the safe use of remote-controlled aircraft systems (RPAS), commonly known as unmanned aerial vehicles, in the field of civil aviation. The Commission proposes to address the issue of RPAS operations in a future European policy framework. It stipulates that any regulation adopted must favour the development of the commercial RPAS market and at the same time the public interest.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because so-called drones are being widely used with the most diverse applications and harmonised European legislation is therefore becoming desirable. It is inconceivable that, as is the case in Italy, the same rules apply to a 2.5 kg appliance as civil aircraft. It is inconceivable that a fast-growing sector should be suffocated by too stringent rules and that investment should run away in neighbouring countries where the laws are more reasonable.  Action must be taken and coordinated to ensure that the great potential of this innovation is realised for the benefit of companies and workers.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for the LIBE Commission, I have sought to ensure that the new challenges posed by this new technology to the protection of fundamental rights, security, police forces and public order are discussed and taken care of. To this end, I advocated and secured a European approach, calling for the process national and European industry and bodies; advocated and ensured that the regulatory framework was as technologically neutral as possible; advocated and secured an approach that did not stifle the industry that is now beginning to flourish.  This report, which I support, reflects precisely this approach. On the one hand, recommending a set of measures to have a single European market, as well as taking the lead in setting global standards. And, on the other hand, recognizing the challenges and welcoming the recommendations of the LIBE Commission, such as the need for traceability, a legal framework appropriate to the enhancing effect of new technologies, such as cameras and thermal sensors, or stimulating investment in privacy and security technologies. Once diagnostics are done, advanced solutions and lines of action, now is the time to act.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The last fifteen years have seen a rapid growth in the use of "remotely piloted aerial systems (RPAS)", commonly known as "unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs)" or drones. This technology, which is essentially designed for military purposes, is now also applied to commercial use, which means that the uses of RPAS systems have varied widely and may be further extended to other fields in the future. Operational activities are legal only where national legislation in force in this area is in force. In fact, all operations carried out by unmanned aerial vehicles must obtain specific authorisation: the lack of regulation at European level could hinder the development of a European market in RPAS systems. That is why I believe that this area urgently needs legislative harmonisation at European level, while respecting data protection and privacy.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The directive aims to regulate the use of remotely piloted aerial systems (RPAS), known as UAV (unmanned aerial vehicles), in the civil aviation sector. Europe is a leader in the use of RPAS systems for the civil sector with 2 500 operators.  There is currently no harmonisation between EU Member States carrying out actions in the field of production or production activities. The report calls for drones to be regarded as aircraft and for the operators to be responsible for their use. The main problems concern traffic management, the need to identify drones taking into account the characteristics of weight, operational scope and speed and nature of use.  I am voting in favour of introducing clearer rules on the internal market and international trade for the production, sale and purchase, trade and use of drones.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The European Aviation Safety Agency is currently the authority providing authorization for the flight of remotely piloted aircraft (RPAS) only when the mass of aircraft exceeds 150 kg. In view of this situation, the European Commission has submitted a proposal for a European regulatory framework that takes into account the characteristics of RPAS (weight, scope of operations, speed) and the nature of their use (recreational or professional).  While I support the Commission's intention to eliminate this 150 kg threshold and replace it with an appropriate regulatory framework, as well as to create a regular information mechanism among Member States addressing RPAS incidents and sharing good practices, I abstained in this report. The Commission does not provide guarantees for a clear division of civilian and military use or for the espionage of drones. In addition, it stresses that the "very dynamic" Israeli manufacturing sector, clearly for military use (used for espionage and extrajudicial and extraterritorial executions), facilitates the integration of a civilian and military air navigation service into Israeli airspace. That is why I have not supported this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for a clear harmonised and proportionate EU regulatory framework of remotely piloted aircraft systems also known as drones. The report suggests a risk based approach ensuring safety, guaranteeing adequate protection of citizens respecting fundamental rights of privacy and data protection, stimulating investments and innovation in the industry and the creation of sustainable and innovative jobs. As I believe that this report encourages an appropriate balance between the development of this industry and the respect of rights to privacy I have supported it in Parliament.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report makes a number of recommendations aimed at making European industry one of the world's leading players in the automated aircraft technology market. This market raises new challenges regarding the safety, security and respect of citizens' rights. The lack of harmonised regulations in Europe and validated technologies is the main obstacle to opening up this market. This report therefore calls for the introduction of a balanced regulatory framework recognised at the international level, allowing the sector to develop without imposing unnecessary constraints on it. On the other hand, it draws attention to the importance of public support and the principle of user responsibility. Considering that this market represents a real opportunity for job creation, innovation and economic growth for years to come, I supported this report.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. I think it is important that a general harmonised framework with a European certificate and training is drawn up for the safe use of drones, without wanting to enact a plethora of rules. After all, technology is evolving very quickly. A continued focus on research and development is therefore indispensable. The installation of an ID chip to enable traceability of the driver can improve safety. Clear European privacy rules are needed.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The deployment of RPAS systems poses important regulatory challenges, in particular in terms of security, certifications and privacy protection. The European Parliament's objective is to set clear guidelines for the adoption of the aviation package expected by the end of 2015.  In regulating this sector, it will be essential to guarantee citizens an adequate level of protection, promoting innovation and stimulating investment in order to create new opportunities and jobs. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to establish a proportionate regulatory framework at Community level that allows the safe integration of RPAS systems into European airspace.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In order to enable more secure integration of drones in European airspace, it is imperative to have an ad hoc legislative framework. Future rules should ensure privacy and data protection and be based on a risk assessment; a balance must be struck between the commercial development of civilian drones and the safety of goods and people.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Unmanned vehicles are becoming a reality in our daily lives, and exploiting their potential is an opportunity to create jobs and bring economic and innovation development. At the same time, security brings new challenges in the protection of human rights. This is why it is necessary to establish rules on unmanned civilian vehicles at EU level. A Community set of rules will help to maintain competitiveness, increase jobs, including support for SMEs and make the greatest possible use of technology, which could have a positive impact on technology in other industries. The report contains recommendations that could serve as an inspiration to the European Commission in the light of its own legislative proposal, which it intends to publish at the end of 2015. The report is in line with both the Programme of the European People's Party and the Hungary, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the safe use of drones in civil aviation. Commercial services are increasingly using them and their use for recreational purposes is becoming increasingly popular. The resolution stresses that drones have the potential to stimulate economic growth and job creation, but calls for all safeguards relating to privacy and data protection, including mandatory registration of drones and their identification chip equipment. This is to facilitate accident investigations and the arrest of criminals who use them illegally.  The Commission must support the search for "detection and avoidance" technologies to enable drones to avoid collisions with other airspace users. "Geo-tracking" technologies must also be developed and used to prevent drones from flying over no-fly zones, such as airports and nuclear power plants. Finally, the resolution supports the rules proposed by the Commission to help national authorities and other qualified bodies manage validation and surveillance activities during cross-border drone sales and the provision of services.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Unmanned vehicles are becoming a reality in our daily lives, and exploiting their potential is an opportunity to create jobs and economic and innovation. At the same time, it brings new challenges in the area of security and the protection of human rights. This is why it is necessary to establish rules on unmanned civilian vehicles at EU level. A Community set of rules will help to maintain competitiveness, increase jobs, including support for SMEs and make the greatest possible use of technology, which could have a positive impact on technology in other industries. The report contains recommendations that could serve as an inspiration to the European Commission in the light of its own legislative proposal, which it intends to publish at the end of 2015. The report is in line with both the Programme of the European People's Party and the Hungary, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report concerned the regulation of civilian drones to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations. Thus, this text proposes a balanced conciliation, without penalizing companies producing drones too much. By not pouring into overly strict regulation while filling the legal void associated with the recent mass arrival of civilian drones on the market, this report has found a middle ground. I just wished that the use of these civilian drones would be regulated, that I would protect the industry in this sector, and I voted for this report.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Unmanned vehicles are becoming a reality in our daily lives, and exploiting their potential is an opportunity to create jobs and bring economic and innovation development. At the same time, it brings new challenges in the area of security and the protection of human rights. This is why it is necessary to establish rules on unmanned civilian vehicles at EU level. A Community set of rules will help to maintain competitiveness, increase jobs, including support for SMEs and make the greatest possible use of technology, which could have a positive impact on technology in other industries. The report contains recommendations that could serve as an inspiration to the European Commission in the light of its own legislative proposal, which it intends to publish at the end of 2015. The report is in line with both the Programme of the European People's Party and the Hungary, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. By approving this report, we request that the use of drones be regulated, in the face of the proliferation of these devices, in order to ensure the safe use of these devices and to prevent them from being able to violate the privacy of individuals, both in professional and recreational use within the civil sphere.  We need without delay European legislation to ensure the proper development of this much-growing activity in order to take advantage of the potential it has but also to address the problems that misuse can create. The proliferation of these devices represents important opportunities in terms of investment, innovation and job creation throughout the supply chain and for the benefit of society. However, we cannot forget that we must protect the public interest, especially issues related to privacy, data protection, accountability and civil liability.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – We have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The tele-piloted aircraft sector, also known as unmanned aerial vehicles, urgently needs European and global rules to ensure the development of a competitive European sector, protect privacy and safety and clearly distinguish between professional use and recreational use. RPAS used in a professional framework also currently bring significant benefits for civilian use in a number of areas, such as safety inspections and infrastructure monitoring, assessment of the severity of natural disasters, carrying out precision agricultural operations, content production, aerial thermography or delivery of orders in isolated areas.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it is above all necessary to establish regulations for drones.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the civilian use of so-called "drones", taking into account their dissemination, the issues it poses, in terms of safety, recreational and others. This is the starting point for the defence of a specific, more complete and up-to-date regulatory framework. The stepped ground generates some mistrust, particularly with regard to the use of this type of technology for military purposes, which is not present in the report (apart from a brief but enlightening reference to the capacity of the Israeli control system to combine civilian and military use), and that public funding for the development of these technologies will then be used militarily. The issue of data protection and information for people is also problematic. Being addressed in the report, it is without the depth that was required, these being equipment that can easily constitute means of surveillance and access to personal data, by governments, companies and individuals. This is already a common practice today, which will tend to increase with the facilitation of the use of drones – unless this issue is properly safeguarded. Something to which this report does not contribute. We abstained.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Any regulatory framework on the safe use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) in the field of civil aviation must be adequate to enable the sector to grow and avoid unnecessary burdens on the emerging industry. Moreover, each framework must strive for global adoption in order to stimulate research and development. It is therefore important in the future that RPAS be treated as new types of aircraft that require appropriate risk-based rules for each operation, european Union rules for the safe provision of RPAS services are developed so that the sector can invest, and technologies and standards must also be developed to enable the full integration of RPAS into European airspace and, last but not least, positive public acceptance. necessary for the future growth of this sector.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 According to the report on the safe use of remote-controlled aircraft systems commonly known as unmanned aerial vehicles in the field of civil aviation, these systems are to be used for a wide range of purposes such as disaster management, search and rescue, environmental protection as well as law enforcement and surveillance. However, its use also entails significant risks which are not prevented, as strict rules are required, which have not yet been institutionalised. Such risks arising from the use of these new technologies are the surveillance and tracing of persons and objects and the violation of fundamental rights, such as the right to privacy and the protection of personal data. Finally, it poses risks to public safety, as these systems may or may not intentionally harm people and infrastructure. For the above reasons I am voting against this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Clearly it is about time to have a harmonised and proportionate EU regulatory framework on the use of remotely piloted aircraft systems and to set out clear guidelines to the Commission for the outlining of the upcoming aviation package, expected by the end of 2015. In order to reach this objective, we must ensure a ‘risk-based approach’ in line with the Riga Declaration ensuring ‘safety’; we must guarantee an adequate protection of citizens which respects fundamental rights of privacy and data protection; we have to ensure that investments and innovation in the industry are stimulated; and we must make efforts in order to create sustainable and innovative jobs. I support the compromises included in the report, such as the removal of the 150 kg threshold by the Commission, and the ‘detect-and-avoid’ technology for RPAS flying beyond visual line of sight.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that the RS sector urgently needs European and global regulation that allows the cross-border development of such systems, and that a clear European legal framework is needed to ensure investment in a competitive European sector of RSMs and to develop the sector; stresses that, in the absence of swift action, there is a risk of not fully exploiting the economic potential and positive effects of SPACED systems. I accept and fully support the following five principles for the future development of RFF systems set out in the Riga Declaration, which state that RFF systems should be treated as new types of aircraft and proportionate rules should be laid down on the basis of the risks associated with their activities; Union rules on the safe provision of services with RSEs should be laid down in order to allow sectoral investment; develop technology and specifications for the full integration of the RSTD into European airspace; social acceptance should be responsible for the use of these systems in order to increase services provided by key SPACED systems and operators of TSMs should take responsibility for the use of such systems.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of taking into account that the regulatory framework should be provided, promote the growth of the sector and avoid the imposition of unnecessary burdens that hinder the development of an emerging industry. It is therefore necessary to develop EU legislation for the safe provision of RPAS services that favours investments in the industrial sector.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote demonstrated the need for regulation of a sector, that of remotely piloted aerial systems, which is constantly growing. Europe has a leading role in this area and it needs to be legislated in such a way as to protect this primacy, so as to help businesses and encourage job creation, while protecting all citizens from possible risks.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the excellent report 'Safe use of remotely piloted flight systems (RPAS) in the field of civil aviation' by my group colleague Jacqueline Foster. Her report is dedicated to a very important issue and to a technology that is changing our lives at a rapid pace. We must now set the legislative course for this.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Today's report advocates a proportionate legal framework for remotely piloted flight systems. This enables the fast-growing industry to remain capable of growth in the future, while ensuring that this happens within a fixed legal framework.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on safe use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) in the field of civil aviation. Given civilian drones are becoming increasingly common across European airspace it is imperative that EU rules are put in place to ensure they are used safely and responsibly. I welcome Parliament’s call for laws that recognise the potential benefits of drones, which are used for a wide range of tasks, from checking crops in fields to filming at music festivals, whilst also guaranteeing the privacy and data protection of citizens.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The use of drones has experienced rapid growth. This technology, initially developed for military use, has great potential for safety inspections and infrastructure control (rail tracks, dams and power plants), natural disaster assessment, precision agricultural work, aerial thermography or even the delivery of packages in isolated areas, so rapid development of new applications can be envisaged in the near future. Given that the lack of harmonised legislation at EU level could prevent the development of a European drone market, we call for European-wide legislation in this report to ensure the investment and development of a competitive European sector in this field, while providing adequate protection for citizens' privacy and data protection. Moreover, the early adoption of a European framework could lead to the development of global rules on the use of drones.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Civilian drones have many uses, both economical and recreational. The supervision of this use is necessary to ensure the safety of air traffic, populations and sensitive areas, but also the protection of data and privacy. For once, European harmonisation is desirable, provided that it is based on clear, proportionate rules, and properly articulated with national and international rules. This is in order not to hinder the expansion of this very recent sector, and particularly dynamic in France. I agree with Mrs Foster's moderation, which refuses any regulatory haste and insists on the participation of all stakeholders - including SMEs, law enforcement and civil society organisations - in the development of regulations. That is why I voted for his report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Foster report.  With the multiplication of commercial services using drones and the growing popularity of their use for recreational purposes, it is necessary to ensure that these devices do not create security or personal privacy risks.  There is also a need for a clear legal framework, at European and global level, that can ensure the investment and development of the sector in Europe in order to promote its competitiveness in the external market. To ensure that these remotely controlled devices do not penetrate exclusion zones on critical infrastructures or pose a danger to other aircraft and also to prevent illegal uses, the text proposes to drive the development of detection, geoperie, anti-interference and anti-kidnapping technologies. On the other hand, drone design standards must incorporate privacy and data protection safeguards.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Unmanned vehicles are becoming a reality in our daily lives, their potential is a chance to create jobs and economic and innovation development. At the same time, it presents new challenges in the area of security policy and the protection of human rights. This is why it is necessary to establish rules on unmanned civilian vehicles at EU level. A Community set of rules will help to maintain competitiveness, increase jobs, including support for SMEs and make the greatest possible use of technology, which could have a positive impact on technology in other industries. The report contains recommendations that could serve as an inspiration to the European Commission in the light of its own legislative proposal, which it intends to publish at the end of 2015. The report is in line with both the Programme of the European People's Party and the Hungary, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report because the RPAS market poses a real opportunity to foster job creation and a source of innovation and economic growth for years to come. However the lack of harmonized regulations across Europe and of validated technologies forms the main obstacle to open the RPAS market to integrate RPAS in European non-segregated airspace. It is vital to unlock the EU RPAS market with a combination of new and existing regulatory action dealing with all the relevant issues, including the insertion of safety, security, privacy and data protection requirements within existing EU rules in these areas.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Safe Use report on remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS), commonly known as drones, in civil aviation, as this market creates great opportunities for future investment, innovation and job creation. Of course, I think very clear legislative frameworks and European and global regulations of such remotely operated aircraft systems (RPAS) should be set to ensure their adequate use and the development of this competitive European sector beneficial to society.  Furthermore, Member States should provide some training to professional users and owners of remotely operated aircraft systems and provide manuals or product information that will clearly explain the rules at national and EU level applicable when using such a system, in particular including rules concerning privacy, data protection and security.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The Foster report introduces balanced EU regulations.  The aim is to model the supervision of civilian drones on what is already being done in the field of international regulations in the field of civil aviation.  To ensure the safety of air traffic and populations, the development of international rules is not aberrant in this case since national airspace is constantly traversed by foreign aircraft.  This text insists that European regulations are balanced by ensuring the security of people, the protection of data and privacy as well as the development of this new sector. The report also stresses that all actors are involved in the development of EU rules: Member States, Commission, relevant national authorities, SMEs, commercial operators, police, etc. However, this report does not target military drones, whose regulations must remain the exclusive responsibility of the Member States.   I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow MEPs and I have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jacqueline Foster's report on the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems (RPAS) in civil aviation. This promising sector in terms of jobs and innovation suffers from a lack of European legislation. The legal vacuum, particularly in terms of protection and security, is one of the main obstacles to the development of a leading industry in this field in Europe. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. Developing a single legal framework for the drone industry will directly lead to more investment and innovation. This means boosting the national economy, thereby safeguarding existing jobs and even enabling more jobs. A uniform regulatory approach in this area would also protect citizens from possible invasions of their privacy. The report therefore appears to be proportionate and necessary. In addition, aviation itself is regulated at this level.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as civilian drones are becoming increasingly common across European airspace, so we need EU rules that make sure they are used safely and responsibly. Labour welcomes the Parliament’s call for laws that recognise the potential benefits of drones, whilst also guaranteeing the privacy and data protection of citizens.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Foster's report on the safe use of remotely piloted air systems in civil aviation. European legislation needs to be updated and more proportionate rules drawn up if European industry is to become a world leader in the market for automated aircraft technology. Technology and standards must be strengthened to allow them to be fully integrated into European airspace.  With today's vote, we are concretely reiterating our support for this sector, which is essential for the advancement of RPAS air and remote piloting systems and for the growth of these services.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the safe use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in civil aviation. As is already the case in civil aviation, international regulations governing the use of civilian drones are necessary to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations.  The report insists that EU legislation is balanced: neither too restrictive nor too liberal. Foster believes that data protection and privacy must be guaranteed without penalising SMEs producing or using drones. Finally, it should be noted that the report emphasizes cooperation between all stakeholders in order to achieve the best possible legislation. For example, it calls for discussions and debates between Member States, the Commission, national regulatory authorities, SMEs and commercial operators, as well as civil society organisations and law enforcement. As a strategic sector (we remember the drones flying over French nuclear power plants), it is very important that the Commission is not the only one in charge of this issue.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to regulate the use of civilian drones, which is necessary to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations. And it has the merit of recommending that the Brussels Commission consult with the Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The European Aviation Safety Agency is currently the authority providing authorization for the flight of remotely piloted aircraft (RPAS) only when the mass of aircraft exceeds 150 kg. In view of this situation, the European Commission has submitted a proposal for a European regulatory framework that takes into account the characteristics of RPAS (weight, scope of operations, speed) and the nature of their use (recreational or professional).  While I support the Commission's intention to eliminate this 150 kg threshold and replace it with an appropriate regulatory framework, as well as to create a regular information mechanism among Member States addressing RPAS incidents and sharing good practices, I abstained in this report. The Commission does not provide guarantees for a clear division of civilian and military use or for the espionage of drones. In addition, it stresses that the "very dynamic" Israeli manufacturing sector, clearly for military use (used for espionage and extrajudicial and extraterritorial executions), facilitates the integration of a civilian and military air navigation service into Israeli airspace. That is why I have not supported this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Remote control of small models of aircraft has been active for decades, and an increased increase has occurred over the past 15 years with the advent of drones. This technology was originally intended for military purposes and is now also used for commercial purposes and because of its investment, innovation and job creation opportunities it has great potential for economic growth, so I supported MP Jacqueline Foster's report. Europe is at the forefront of the use of RPAS in the civilian sector with more than two thousand beneficiaries. The rules should cover them as a new type of aircraft based on the risk of each operation, then prescribe the safe provision of services, develop full involvement technology in European airspace and highlight the user's responsibility for its use. I supported Advocate Foster's report calling for the adoption as soon as possible of new laws concerning the use of remotely operated aircraft systems in civil society to ensure innovation and competitiveness and the safety of our citizens through the correct identification and use of RPAS.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The main idea behind this motion for a resolution is to develop and adopt, by the end of this year, the legal framework on which the use of so-so-so drones in the field of civil aviation within the EU would be based. The same applies to the technological development of this sector and the use of global navigation systems in the operation of drones. What is very important here is that all of this applies specifically to civilian, not military-type drones. In the second case, it is the states that have the right to adopt rules controlling their respective national practices, while in the civil field the responsible supranational bodies of the European Union could contribute positively to the development and implementation of common rules in practice. Over the last ten to fifteen years, the development and use of drone systems in the field of civil aviation has intensified to such an amount that this area can no longer be left unreconectioned: certification, configuration, interaction between drones and other flying facilities (including aircraft and helicopters, i.e. limitation of the flight altitude and permitted areas of drones), the exchange and availability of information, and, in general, the right to the collection and dissemination of such information , all these aspects should long be standardised. Civil-type drones are nowadays used in agriculture and research (e.g. in cases of hard-to-access areas) as well as in various types of filming (including personal use), simple recreation and much more.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the safe use of remote-controlled aircraft systems (RPAS), commonly known as Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, in the field of civil aviation, because it is documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 29/10/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. It provides for the implementation of international regulations governing the use of civilian drones, measures necessary to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations. The author stresses the need to have all actors (Member States, Commission, national regulatory authorities, SMEs, commercial operators, civil society and law enforcement) cooperate in order to obtain a balanced text, neither too restrictive nor too liberal, which allows both data protection and respect for privacy, without penalising drone manufacturers.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. As the number of remote-controlled flight systems in civil aviation increases, it only makes sense if their use is to be regulated accordingly. Not only can these unmanned aerial devices be used in civil aviation for purely private purposes, they can also be very effective .B disaster missions or infrastructural inspections. Appropriately sensible subsidies and regulations in this area should be welcomed.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This text establishes a balanced Eu regulation. The idea is to model the supervision of civilian drones on what is already being done in international regulations in the field of civil aviation.  In order to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations, the development of international rules is not aberrant in this case since national airspace is constantly crossed by foreign aircraft.  The report insists that EU regulations are balanced by ensuring the security of people, data protection and privacy, as well as the development of this new sector. Furthermore, the report recalls that all actors are involved in the development of EU rules: Member States, Commission, relevant national authorities, SMEs, commercial operators, law enforcement, etc. Finally, this report does not in any way target military drones, the regulation of which must remain the exclusive responsibility of the Member States. So I voted in favour of the Foster report.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which is a step towards effective EU rules on drones to ensure they are used safely and responsibly. The proliferation of the use of drones from crop management to recreational use means we need to update rules to reflect their use. I particularly support privacy and data protection being a key element of any upcoming legislation.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 While recognising advantages in the use of piloted aircraft systems, whether in the field of safety inspections or disaster assessment, it is also necessary to point out the possible unsafe and even illegal uses, the challenges of privacy, fundamental rights and security. I share the position set out in the approved document that it is necessary to create its own legal framework to ensure the proper treatment of all these issues, without undermining the development of a technological sector with great potential.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report argues that the growth of the market for drones may be stifled without EU-level legislation due to the fact that national regulations are not always recognised by other Member States. Therefore I chose to support this report as it is important that the Union does not lag behind its competitors in this sector.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The European Commission, and I share its ambition, wants to close the gap in the Union and develop a European drone market. To this end, a strict and rigorous framework must be put in place. The development of the drone cannot be at the expense of the right to privacy and data protection. While this technology has technological potential, it can also be particularly intrusive to privacy. It was therefore essential to limit and manage the risks of drift.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing \ u2012 RPAS technology, commonly known as drones or drones, records success and rapid growth in commercial and recreational field of use. For this reason, legislative boundaries are also being pushed, as the technology has a number of specificities and was even initially intended for military purposes only. The RPAS market is currently very prospective and there are many possibilities for its spread. The potential for economic growth is constantly growing, and we must therefore ensure that Europe maintains its leadership and maintains competitiveness. However, a clear legal framework must take into account the imperatives of security and the protection of privacy and personal data.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the safe use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) in the field of civil aviation, which sets out clear guidelines to the Commission for the outlining of the upcoming aviation package stressing that the future rules should address issues such as airworthiness, certification-specification, the identity of drones and of the owner/operator, insurance, liability and insurance, data protection and privacy, ‘geofencing’ and no-fly zones, etc.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ A vote for a timely piece of legislation creating the legal context for the development of an important technology of the future. It is all too often that legislators fail to react in time to technological change by creating the necessary rules for progress to take place in a way that is acceptable to society. The speed of law-making has become one of the variables defining and determining competitiveness in the global arena.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Previously, remotely controlled aircraft systems, which were previously primarily used for military purposes, have also rapidly progressed and expanded in civilian life. Parliament's draft resolution tabled by the Committee on Transport and Tourism argues that the telecommunications vehicle systems sector urgently needs European and global regulation enabling the cross-border development of such systems. It calls for a clear European legal framework for investment in a competitive European sector of SPACED aircraft systems and for the development of the sector. It proposes to adopt and fully support the five principles set out in the Riga Declaration for the future development of RFF systems. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The sector of telepiloted aircraft systems (RPAS) in the field of civil aviation, better known as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) or "drones", requires a careful selection of rules at European and global level that allow the development and investment of this sector.  Given their economic potential, as well as job creation along the supply chain and the need to protect the public interest, in particular on issues relating to privacy, data protection, accountability and civil liability, it is essential to create a European legal framework adjusted to the type of flights these aircraft carry out. The secure integration of telepiloted aircraft systems and a risk assessment is extremely necessary in the field of their operations. I am in favour of this motion for a resolution, stressing the need to create regulation on this subject within the European Union, promoting the development and innovation of the European RPAS market through European funding for research in this sector.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems (RPAS) in civil aviation. It is therefore, in plain language, to regulate the use of drones in the civilian sector to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations. This report is to be welcomed as it calls for discussions to take place between Member States, the Commission, national regulatory authorities and SMEs. It therefore does not leave the only Commission in the centre of decisions in the field.  On the other hand, on the merits, the legislative harmonization advocated is neither too restrictive nor too liberal. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I have obviously voted for this text. Parliament's positions on the future of drones strike the balance between protecting citizens and freedom of innovation for entrepreneurs. There is an urgent need for the EU to legislate on this issue in order to be able to determine the standards that will apply to the world in the future.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will better regulate EU wide rules on safety authorisations, safeguarding privacy and data protection on the use of remotely piloted aircraft systems.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Remotely controlled flight systems, so-called drones, are increasingly coming into the public spotlight, especially in the field of civil aviation. I voted in favour of the report in order to achieve a single European regulation and to take a step towards legal certainty.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This private member's report proposes to lay the groundwork for a European regulation to authorise and develop the use and management of drones for commercial and civilian purposes. Despite the fact that these unmanned aircraft systems have very interesting interests, whether for scientific tasks (air thermography) or commercial (delivery of parcels by air), these machines present a real risk to the protection of privacy and the safety of citizens. Proliferation would make control difficult, and the drifts we know across the Atlantic encourage us to be vigilant about its commercialization. I'm voting against it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The rapidly evolving drone market brings both opportunities and threats. There is a need to create a European legal framework for the use of civil drones, which, on the one hand, would enable this industry to be innovative and competitive in the world, but on the other hand to ensure the safety of people when using drones, as well as the protection of life, property and personal data.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. Action is needed to make the EU a business leader in this emerging technology. Only a stable legal framework enabling the EU will withstand a competitive struggle and ensure the right conditions for the development of the sector. Legal certainty on the legal framework must be ensured. In this context, a clear, harmonised and proportionate European and global regulatory framework must be developed. Across the EU, common regulatory standards for civil RPAS must apply, covering safety, security, privacy, data protection, insurance and liability aspects. A high level of safety, security and privacy will ensure public recognition and trust.   It should be noted that the new rules must clearly distinguish between the use of RPAS for professional purposes and leisure purposes. In addition, the regulatory framework shall ensure that remotely piloted aircraft do not affect the safety and functioning of the wider civil aviation system. Their level of safety shall be the same as that of manned aircraft.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 The technology of remotely controlled aircraft systems has recently progressed greatly and it is necessary to exploit its potential. Its application and benefits can already be seen in agriculture, dangerous and crisis situations, but also in the daily lives of citizens.  Some Member States have already started to create a legislative framework and it is necessary to create a common legal framework, in order to achieve economic growth in this segment and become competitive, as lately the EU has lagged behind the US and Israel in this segment. I believe that creating a legislative framework will strengthen the market within the European Union, achieve economic growth and create new jobs, especially in combination with other technologies. The legislative framework must allow for the flight of RPAS in airspace which is not separate, in order to be accessible to all citizens.  However, possible abuses of this technology should also be taken into account, in particular the impact on the privacy and physical integrity of citizens. The safety of citizens should come first.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report concerns the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems (RPAS) in civil aviation. It is therefore, in plain language, to regulate the use of drones in the civilian sector to ensure the safety of air traffic and populations. This report is to be welcomed as it calls for discussions to take place between Member States, the Commission, national regulatory authorities and SMEs. It therefore does not leave the only Commission in the centre of decisions in the field. On the other hand, on the merits, the legislative harmonization advocated is neither too restrictive nor too liberal. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Technology developed primarily for military purposes is now being applied for commercial purposes, thereby moving legislative boundaries. Today, RPAS used for professional purposes also provide significant benefits for a variety of civilian use, and their added value increases with the distance between the aircraft and the remote pilot (so-called out-of-sight flights). RPAS, the use of which is varied and could be extended to additional areas in the future, can, for example, be used for safety inspections and supervision of infrastructure (railways, dams and power plants), for the assessment of natural disasters, (environmentally responsible) precision farming, media production, aerothermography or delivery of consignments to remote regions. In the near future, the rapid development of new application methods can be foreseen, as demonstrated by the innovation and dynamism of the RPAS industry. Taking into account the growing importance and capability to use RPAS, I support five key principles for the future development of the RPAS set out in the Riga Declaration: - RPAS should be covered by proportionate regulations as new aircraft types based on the risks of each operation; – EU rules on the safe provision of RPAS services should be drafted to enable the sector to invest; – technology needs to be developed and standards developed to allow for the full integration of RPAS into European airspace; – public acceptance is key to growth in the field of RPAS services; – the RPAS user is responsible for its use.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Commission proposes to address the safe use of remotely operated aircraft systems (RPAS) operations in future European policy frameworks. He says any regulation should help develop a commercial RPAS market, protecting the public interest. The new standards govern the operations of state RPAS operations to cover security, privacy, data protection, insurance and liability. The Commission is aimed at enabling European industry to become a global leader in new technologies.  The legal proposal should be adopted by the end of 2015, where the Commission sets out new standards covering the following areas: EU rules on the security of authorisations representing the responsibility of EASA (European Aviation Safety Agency) in developing EU standards for RPAS, and privacy and data protection, control to ensure security (in particular in the protection of information where legal obligations are included, such as air traffic management , operator and telecom service), and a clear framework for accountability and insurance. For all of the above, I support rapporteur Jacqueline Foster's report.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ RPAS are being developed and operated all over the world, and Europe is currently home to the largest number of civilian operators. I am glad that Parliament has taken on this issue because RPAS are surely going to be more prevalent in the future, and we need to ensure that their use is safe for their operators as well as other manned and unmanned aircraft.  Some of the key issues are: whether there should be a distinction between professional and recreational use; the question of out of sight flights; and areas where operation would be considered unsafe. These are only some of the hurdles that must be tackled and more will present themselves as we go further down this road. However, I believe it is necessary that we start taking on these issues early because RPAS are here to stay and can be useful for industries, as well as recreation.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
