text: in writing. \u2012 Remotely piloted aerial systems (RPAS) could be used to provide services of different kinds such as infrastructure monitoring (rail tracks, dams and energy installations), natural disaster assessment, precision agricultural operations, media production and parcel delivery in isolated regions. The proper development of this sector could represent a great potential for stimulating economic growth and the creation of new jobs.  However, existing national authorisations for the use of RPAS are not mutually recognised in the Member States, which prevents the development of a European market for remotely piloted aerial systems and related services. Therefore, it appears necessary to propose European standards in order to ensure a favourable investment framework and to promote the development of a European RPAS sector, which is globally competitive.  I support this motion for a resolution, but we must not forget to look carefully at issues relating to security, privacy, data protection and civil liability.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the safe civilian use of remotely operated aircraft systems (RPAS). Although it is a technology primarily developed for military purposes, drones are increasingly used in the commercial sphere or among humans as a hobby. Unfortunately, they are now seen for the most part as a threat, a weapon, or as a tool to spy on. In my opinion, there needs to be legislation on the use of remotely operated aircraft systems. All Member States are operating in the RPAS area, whether in production or operation. The absence of unifying legislation could hamper the development of RPAS in the European Union. However, this legislation must clearly define the differences between the professional and recreational use of drones.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The purpose of the report on the civilian use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (BSP), commonly known as drones, is to ensure that any proposed EU regulations in this area comply with a global, harmonised and proportionate approach and are developed taking into account risks, which will promote the safe application of these systems and at the same time create unnecessary burdens for industry. Parliament stresses that the technology originally developed for military use is now increasingly commercial and provides significant social benefits through the ability to carry out safety checks on infrastructure, e.g. railway tracks, dams and power plants, assess natural disasters, carry out precision farming operations and media use capabilities. There is huge growth potential in this sector, from producer to end-user level, for both large companies and a supply chain of thousands of SMEs, and any policy framework at EU level must enable growth to be competitive globally for European companies. Parliament recognises the need to safeguard the public interest and stresses that, while security and security are paramount in all BSP activities and principles, data protection and privacy are also of paramount importance in order to gain public acceptance for the development of such services. I therefore support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The civil aviation drone market has a potential of more than 80 billion euros and 100,000 jobs by 2025 in Europe. European companies must maintain their position in the European and international market. In this context, the European Parliament has adopted a resolution on the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems (RPAS) in the field of civil aviation. The aim of this text is to encourage the development of the European market by supporting European companies while ensuring that the safety of European citizens is respected. As Vice-President of the Sky and Space Intergroup, I have fought for this report and I stress the need for European legislation if we are to support our European companies in the European and global markets.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission is preparing a proposal, to be adopted by the end of 2015, taking into account the Riga Declaration and the essential principles contained therein, regarding telepiloted aircraft systems (RPAS) and their inclusion in the "aviation" package. It is therefore in accordance with the principles set out in the Declaration that the European Union must now draw up a regulatory framework capable of balancing the need for full and secure integration into airspace with properly proportionate burdens, which do not result in investment and the consequent growth of the sector. In view of the fact that Parliament also has a role to play in building responses to the challenges ahead in the fields of aviation, I voted in favour of this report because I consider the recommendations made in committee on Transport and Tourism to be relevant.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this as this report supports the Commission’s proposal to remove the 150 kg threshold. Currently in the UK the CAA is responsible for anything up to 150 kg.  This is a further proposal to remove powers from the UK to the EU.  This report was proposed by a UK Conservative MEP and voted for by all UK MEPs except UKIP.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a report calling for the adoption of Eu-wide framework legislation on the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems, more commonly known as drones. These small flying machines, with increasing success, are currently exempt from harmonised legislation at European level. With the increasing use of drones by individuals for recreational or sometimes ill-treatment, there is a growing need to ensure that drones do not threaten public safety or privacy. The aim is to integrate drones into European airspace by mobilising technological means: installing an identification chip that would help trace the ill-intentioned owner, incorporating detection and avoidance software to avoid accidents or the addition of a geo-tracking program that would prevent drones from flying over no-fly zones. This would enable the safe and secure development of this booming sector whose cross-border trade is hampered by the lack of mutual recognition of national authorisations for drones and their operators. For its part, the Commission has indicated that it is preparing a legislative proposal that should be adopted by the end of 2015.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The drone industry is a growing sector, but it is evolving without a European regulatory framework. In fact, under 150 kilograms, unmanned aircraft, used for professional or recreational purposes, are subject to the national laws of the Member States, which considerably hinders the development of the sector and hinders its competitiveness at the European Union level.  That is why I voted in favour of the initiative report for the safe use of unmanned aircraft systems in the field of civil aviation, which aims to lay the foundations for harmonising European legislation for the drone industry in order to promote the expansion of this market, to ensure optimal control of uses, and in particular cross-border, while ensuring the protection of the privacy and security of individuals. However, I am in favour of risk-based regulation of drones, which takes care to distinguish between professional and recreational uses and to promote European leadership.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. The future European regulation will aim to address justified safety concerns but will also try to give this emerging sector the means to develop in a framework respectful of citizens and airspace. This report aims to ensure the traceability of all the machines, but also of the operators and owners as sine qua none conditions for any use. This is a good thing because we could see during the flyover of the French nuclear power plants that we were unable to find the pilots. A registration system must be put in place that will make it easy to identify drones, and even remotely if possible. The terrorist risks raise fears of a real threat to the safety of the French nuclear fleet, which could lead to an electric blackout or even a major nuclear accident, as we had demonstrated in a letter to the French government... unanswered. There are also plans to ensure better airworthiness for drones with clear airspace sharing. Above all, it will be necessary to distinguish between recreational and professional uses, and to give different permissions to their users

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In recent years, the sector of remotely piloted aircraft systems for civilian use, what we commonly know as drones, has been booming significantly in recent years. The absence of a legislative framework on the use of such aircraft gives this report a key role, which aims to influence the imminent aviation legislative package to be presented in 2016. The report reflects the need for European and global legislation to ensure the cross-border development of these systems. It calls for future regulations to include provisions on airworthability, certification, training and licensing, liability and insurance, no-fly zones, etc. It is also important to regulate the sector by differentiating the professional use of recreational-private and address the problem of the need to ensure air safety and coexistence between drones and other aircraft. I therefore support this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. RPAS are now becoming a reality and will soon be available on the European market. The RPAS market, which represents an opportunity to foster the creation of new jobs, is a source of innovation and economic growth for years to come. But it also raises new challenges to the safety, security and respect of citizens' rights, which must be addressed before RPAS can be used on a reasonable scale in a civilian setting. The absence of harmonised regulations in Europe and validated technologies is now the main obstacle to the opening up of the RPAS market.  Regulation at European level covering all relevant issues, including security, security, privacy and data protection requirements, is therefore necessary. In addition, research and development efforts are also required to ensure the gradual integration of RPAS into civil aviation starting in 2016. On this point, it should be noted that the European Commission will use the Horizon 2020 programme to support promising research and development actions.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the safe use of remotely piloted aerial systems (RPAS) in the civil aviation sector as I believe that a legislative update at European level in the civil aviation sector is necessary.  The lack of common legislation means that each country regulations this area as it sees fit, without being able to follow specific guidelines. Hence the need to lay down common rules that give certainty to entrepreneurs who will be able to decide calmly to invest in this sector, which will be very productive and profitable in a few years' time.  At the same time, however, we must not forget the aspects closely linked to the use of these systems, such as the security of citizens and the guarantee of respect for privacy.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the text deals with important security and privacy issues related to the use of remotely piloted devices.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Foster report. With the multiplication of commercial services using drones and the growing popularity of their use for recreational purposes, it is necessary to ensure that these devices do not create security or personal privacy risks.  There is also a need for a clear legal framework, at European and global level, that can ensure the investment and development of the sector in Europe in order to promote its competitiveness in the external market.  To ensure that these remotely controlled devices do not penetrate exclusion zones on critical infrastructures or pose a danger to other aircraft and also to prevent illegal uses, the text proposes to drive the development of detection, geoperie, anti-interference and anti-kidnapping technologies. On the other hand, drone design standards must incorporate privacy and data protection safeguards.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the own-initiative report on remotely piloted aircraft systems, called drones, because it contains a number of important points. It calls, for example, for a distinction between operating drones for commercial or recreational purposes, which is not taken into account by current aviation regulations. Drones should be equipped with software that would not allow them to fly in risky areas such as airports or industrial areas. The report highlights the need to ensure the right to the protection of citizens' privacy and the protection of personal data. In this context, it also includes issues of identification of drones, which would allow their owners to be traceable if necessary.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The European Aviation Safety Agency is currently the authority providing authorization for the flight of remotely piloted aircraft (RPAS) only when the mass of aircraft exceeds 150 kg. In view of this situation, the European Commission has submitted a proposal for a European regulatory framework that takes into account the characteristics of RPAS (weight, scope of operations, speed) and the nature of their use (recreational or professional).  While I support the Commission's intention to eliminate this 150 kg threshold and replace it with an appropriate regulatory framework, as well as to create a regular information mechanism among Member States addressing RPAS incidents and sharing good practices, I voted against this report. The Commission does not provide guarantees for a clear division of civilian and military use or for the espionage of drones. In addition, it stresses that the "very dynamic" Israeli manufacturing sector, clearly for military use (used for espionage and extrajudicial and extraterritorial executions), facilitates the integration of a civilian and military air navigation service into Israeli airspace. That is why I have not supported this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the civilian use of remotely piloted aerial systems (RPAS), commonly known as drones. Since there are two categories of use of RPAS systems, professional and recreational uses respectively, I believe that the two categories should be regulated with different requirements within the same regulatory framework as the European Union.  In the last 15 years there has been a rapid growth in the use of drones and this technology, initially developed for military purposes, is now also applied to the supply of commercial goods and services. I believe that it is important not only to regulate RPAS systems according to their use and possible risks, but also to ensure the necessary legal certainty for the industry that is investing in this innovative sector.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as this will allow for the EASA to take control over civil aviation in the UK under the current 150 kg threshold. Paragraphs 21, 22 and 48 all allow for more powers to be transferred to the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we need EU rules to make sure RPASs are used safely and responsibly, especially when filming at music festivals and from civilian drones, increasingly more common across the EU. I welcome the Parliament’s call for laws that recognise the benefits that may come from the use of drones, and it is great to see that there is an acknowledgement of the potential abuse that may arise from their usage, from invasions of privacy and guaranteeing citizens’ data protection.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. Drone production and sales have increased dramatically over the past two years. This segment of the market has great potential for growth and therefore national and European legislation needs to address the rules on the use, security and privacy of people.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. \u2012 Over the last 15 years, the use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) known as drones has increased rapidly. Technology developed primarily for military purposes is now being applied for commercial purposes, thereby moving legislative boundaries.  RPAS used for professional purposes today provide significant advantages for a variety of civilian use, such as use for security inspection and infrastructure control, precision farming, media production or delivery of consignments to remote regions. The potential for economic growth of this sector is enormous, so the task of the European Union should be to develop, on the basis of risk analysis, as soon as possible, a clear legislative framework that will apply exclusively to the civilian use of RPAS, in order to guarantee investment and development of a competitive European RPAS sector.  I supported the implementation of this report as it creates a new market that offers significant opportunities for investment, innovation and job creation throughout the supply chain. It also fosters innovative technologies in the field of RPAS that have enormous job creation potential, in particular green ones, as they cover a wide range of occupations, as well as fostering the development of a high potential for the inclusion of SMEs in parts and materials manufacturing services.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because there have been people operating small radio-controlled aircraft for years, as the use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS) known as drones has grown rapidly over the past 15 years. Also, small RPAS that are designed for hobby and recreation are becoming increasingly popular.  Technology developed primarily for military purposes is now being applied for commercial purposes, thereby moving legislative boundaries, as today RPAS used for professional purposes also provide significant advantages for a variety of civilian use, and their added value increases with the distance between the aircraft and the distant pilot. I also believe that the potential for economic growth of this sector is enormous, from producer to end-user, there is also huge potential for both large companies and the supply chain, which make up thousands of SMEs, and the same applies to innovative start-ups.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Enthusiasts have been operating small models of radio-operated aircraft for decades and in the past 15 years the use of remotely operated aircraft systems (RPAS), better known as drones (English: drones), has grown rapidly. RPAS regulations exist or are under construction in Austria, Croatia, the Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Ireland, Poland, Spain and the United Kingdom, and approved flight schools exist in Denmark, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.  Parliament therefore supports, both the development of innovative technologies in the field of RPAS and the inclusion of a specific section on data protection and privacy in the training of professional users and owners of RPAS. Concerns are also raised about potential illegal and unsafe use of RPAS (e.g. RPAS converted from civilian tools to weapons used for military or other purposes or RPAS used to disrupt navigation or communication systems).  I support this report because I believe that the regulation of new technologies is essential for their safe use and to prevent the invasion of the privacy and security of EU citizens.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal as I believe it represents a good compromise between the regulation of potential risks associated with the use of drones and the opportunities for development of this sector.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. Drones (drones) are in the hands of those responsible for replacing people with dangerous tasks, for example. I was recently told how they were used to restore the roof on the church bell tower in Styria.  But in the hands of the irresponsible or unskilled, they are a threat to things, animals, people's safety and our privacy. This area must therefore be well and quickly regulated. Security and privacy are of paramount importance. The recent VW car scandal, however, has shown the importance of overseeing the implementation of the law.  The call on the Commission and the Member States to provide sufficient resources for enforcement is therefore in place. At the same time, we all know how limited the budget is and how much people and businesses in the EU are taxed. This requires a well-thought-out control system that is effective but not too expensive.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the safe use of remotely controlled aircraft systems (RPAS), commonly known as drones. This EP report concerns drones used in civil aviation. This technology was first developed for military purposes, but is now beginning to benefit for various civilian uses, the added value of which increases with the increasing distance between the machine and the pilot controlling the remote machine. Furthermore, this report rightly emphasises the need to put in place appropriate privacy policies and to address security issues related to drone operations. There is also a need for a clear European legal framework to ensure investment and the development of a competitive European RPAS sector. Relevant innovative technologies need to be developed to fully integrate RPAS into European airspace.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The widespread use of new technologies, such as remote-controlled aircraft systems (RPAS), must be accompanied by laws and regulations and similar technologies aimed primarily at preserving and strengthening fundamental human rights but also ensuring, to the maximum extent, the prohibition of their application against public security and in favour of terrorism.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Unmanned vehicles are becoming a reality in our daily lives, and exploiting their potential is an opportunity to create jobs and bring economic and innovation development. At the same time, it brings new challenges in the area of security and the protection of human rights. This is why it is necessary to establish rules on unmanned civilian vehicles at EU level. A Community set of rules will help to maintain competitiveness, increase jobs, including support for SMEs and make the greatest possible use of technology, which could have a positive impact on technology in other industries. The report contains recommendations that could serve as an inspiration to the European Commission in the light of its own legislative proposal, which it intends to publish at the end of 2015. The report is in line with both the Programme of the European People's Party and the Hungary, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The use of unmanned aerial systems is undoubtedly an important step towards the aeronautical market of the future.  This technology has developed greatly in recent years for military purposes, but it has tremendous potential in civilian use, in other words, in everyday life.  Sectors such as transport and agriculture can benefit from these versatile aircraft, limiting the risk of human operation and increasing efficiency through access to areas where it is difficult to reach. Human rescue actions are yet another positive example on the list of these benefits.  This emerging market brings with it the need for regulation to ensure the security, security and respect for privacy and data protection of citizens of the European Union. It is clear that we need a European-wide strategy for remote unmanned air systems that is in line with THE ICAO standards.  While I am convinced that the hardware and software performance of the machines will evolve in the near future, we need to agree to some minimum standards in terms of pilot certification and aircraft identification and operation conditions.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted this afternoon in favour of European legislation on the use of drones. With 2,500 operators, Europe dominates the global market for civilian use. This technology, originally used for primarily military purposes, is now open to all, pushing the existing legislative boundaries. To ensure the safety of citizens, respect for privacy and coherence between Member States, while encouraging innovative technologies, European legislation is essential!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which sets the first step towards a European framework for the safe use of drones. Drones are a new and popular technology which is developing extremely fast. Whether it is for leisure or for professional purposes, drones bring enormous opportunities that should not be hampered, therefore the regulators, the industry and commercial operators must work together.  The many benefits we can derive from the use of drones dwell in the fact that they operate in the airspace; this is also the reason why their use must be carefully examined so that an unexperienced pilot cannot threaten the activities of the other users of the airspace such as flights or emergency air services. That is why I support a clear European framework which should be elaborated on a risk-based approach and needs to take into account the characteristics of the drones e.g. weight, scope of operation or speed, but also the purpose of their use.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the Report on the Safe Use of RemoteLy PilotEd Aircraft Systems (RPAS), commonly known as unmanned aerial aircraft, in the field of civil aviation, as I believe it is a politico that will enable European industry to grow in order to compete globally, while at the same time this emerging market is a great opportunity to invest, innovate and create jobs in the supply chain.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Foster report. With the multiplication of commercial services using drones and the growing popularity of their use for recreational purposes, it is necessary to ensure that these devices do not create security or personal privacy risks.  There is also a need for a clear legal framework, at European and global level, that can ensure the investment and development of the sector in Europe in order to promote its competitiveness in the external market. To ensure that these remotely controlled devices do not penetrate exclusion zones on critical infrastructures or pose a danger to other aircraft and also to prevent illegal uses, the text proposes to drive the development of detection, geoperie, anti-interference and anti-kidnapping technologies. On the other hand, drone design standards must incorporate privacy and data protection safeguards.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 A new era in air transport has been opened for remotely controlled aircraft systems. This sector urgently needs European and global regulation to enable the cross-border development of such systems. A clear European legal framework is needed to ensure investment in a competitive European sector of systems and to develop the sector. In the absence of swift action, there is a risk that the economic potential and positive effects of spacecraft systems will not be fully exploited. That is one of the reasons why I supported the adoption of the Foster report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Foster report. With the multiplication of commercial services using drones and the growing popularity of their use for recreational purposes, it is necessary to ensure that these devices do not create security or personal privacy risks.  There is also a need for a clear legal framework, at European and global level, that can ensure the investment and development of the sector in Europe in order to promote its competitiveness in the external market. To ensure that these remotely controlled devices do not penetrate exclusion zones on critical infrastructures or pose a danger to other aircraft and also to prevent illegal uses, the text proposes to drive the development of detection, geoperie, anti-interference and anti-kidnapping technologies. On the other hand, drone design standards must incorporate privacy and data protection safeguards.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which includes some good elements on environmental standards, data protection and privacy. Furthermore, it explicitly mentions the exclusion of nuclear and chemical no-fly zones.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on safe use of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS), commonly known as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). These systems are used primarily for military purposes but are now being applied commercially, pushing legislative boundaries, whereas today RPAS used in a professional context also provide significant benefits for different civil uses, the added value of which increases with the distance between the aircraft and the remote pilot (BVLOS (beyond-visual-line-of-sight) operations.  It is necessary to address the topics at international level because there are no harmonised rules at EU level. The development of a European drone market might be impeded, given that national authorisations are generally not mutually recognised among the Member States, and therefore the resolution puts forward suggestions for the future, such as the encouragement of innovative technologies in the area of RPAS that have an enormous potential for job creation, in particular green jobs, and the encouragement of the development and exploration of the great potential of involving SMEs in the field of services concerned with the production of specialised parts and materials.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about a sector in full development and with great marketing potential in the EU market. The report highlights the need for the EU to harmonize the legal framework for aircraft and also to promote actions to make European industry a global leader in the automatic aircraft technology market. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The European Aviation Safety Agency is currently the authority providing authorization for the flight of remotely piloted aircraft (RPAS) only when the mass of aircraft exceeds 150 kg. In view of this situation, the European Commission has submitted a proposal for a European regulatory framework that takes into account the characteristics of RPAS (weight, scope of operations, speed) and the nature of their use (recreational or professional).  While I support the Commission's intention to eliminate this 150 kg threshold and replace it with an appropriate regulatory framework, as well as to create a regular information mechanism among Member States addressing RPAS incidents and sharing good practices, I voted against this report. The Commission does not provide guarantees for a clear division of civilian and military use or for the espionage of drones. In addition, it stresses that the "very dynamic" Israeli manufacturing sector, clearly for military use (used for espionage and extrajudicial and extraterritorial executions), facilitates the integration of a civilian and military air navigation service into Israeli airspace. That is why I have not supported this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Developed initially for military purposes, drone technology is increasingly being applied for economic purposes. Drones used in a professional setting have a wide variety of uses that can still develop in the future, including safety inspections and infrastructure control (railways, dams and power plants, etc.), assessment of natural disasters, or for agriculture or delivery of parcels in remote areas. The resolution adopted by a very large majority by the European Parliament focuses above all on supporting the development of this new technology, which does have the potential for economic growth and therefore jobs. It stresses the importance of privacy and privacy, but the proposed recommendations seem insufficiently binding to ensure the safe use of drones. I therefore voted against this resolution which favours a market approach to the sector and does not offer sufficient protections.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The report focuses on the civilian use of drones, the economic and social relevance of which already justifies a regulatory framework. We have some concerns, in particular that there is no safeguard that public funding for the development of these technologies will not subsequently be internalised militarily. On the other hand, the issue of data protection and information of people is not addressed and defended with the necessary deepening. Please note that this is equipment that can easily be a means of surveillance and access to personal data by governments, companies and individuals.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. As the number of remote-controlled flight systems in civil aviation increases, it only makes sense if their use is to be regulated accordingly. Not only can these unmanned aerial devices be used in civil aviation for purely private purposes, they can also be very effective .B disaster missions or infrastructural inspections. Appropriately sensible subsidies and regulations in this area should be welcomed.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that guidelines need to be established for the Commission with a view to the presentation of the aviation package. With this document, which focuses on the use of drones, we ask for guarantees on the identity of drones and the owner/operator, insurance, insurance liability, data and privacy protection and no-fly zones.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – This resolution deals with the cross-border approval of remotely piloted aeronautical systems, such as model aircraft and drones. However, these are not small, radio-controlled model aircraft of hobbyists, but a part of the European aviation industry. Drones can be used for military and professional applications or recreational purposes. However, these applications differ and should therefore be subject to different requirements within the same EU legal framework. That is understandable and I therefore agree with this resolution.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the unmanned aerial vehicle sector (civil drones) is a job-giving area in which the European Union excels. It was therefore necessary to go the extra mile by approving positive legislation in this area that would allow the EU to retain its world leader in place while laying the foundations for global legislation that reflects our convictions. It's done. This text strikes the perfect balance between encouraging entrepreneurship in this field and protecting citizens (the obligation to identify all drones).

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the regulation of unmanned aerial vehicles. It is recognised that the European Parliament respects the rapid progress of technology and feels responsible for the need to create a clear legislative base for a sector whose unconscious use of the devices offered may pose a security threat to society. In addition to setting safety standards, personal privacy rights are equally important, as both commercial and hobbie-level unmanned aerial vehicles are often equipped with photo and film equipment. Finally, taking into account also the success of the Latvian drone "Airdog" novice company on a global scale, I believe that clear rules and understandable regulation of this fast-developing sector will also contribute to attracting investment. Although the US presu competes in the military sector, European Union companies can successfully compete in the commercial segment on the basis of such rules.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This historically first European Parliament report dealing with drones, or so-called drones, is evidence, along with many other topics, that european Union legislators are engaged in technological progress that is logically taking place in many areas and which, in the interests of a consistent approach, should be adapted at Pan-European level. Interest in these drones has grown rapidly in recent years. In Slovakia only, unofficial numbers say up to ten thousand pieces. Drones are widely used not only for professional purposes, namely activities such as controlling railway tracks, dams, power plants or professional photography of major events, but many use drones for sports or other recreational purposes. On the other hand, uncontrolled use of drones can lead to serious interference in private life. In my opinion, this report balances both areas. It promotes the growth of industry and trade in this area, does not place a disproportionate burden on producers, small and medium-sized enterprises, but also protects the public interest, security and the right to privacy. It also regulates some technical aspects of the use of drones, such as removing double-track in the area of authorities responsible for authorising the use of drones, which operated according to the weight of the drones. I therefore supported the report.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Remotely piloted aerial systems, or popular drones, are a permanent part of our environment. From military applications to commercial use to recreation, the number of such unmanned machines continues to grow. There are also new problems that are not properly defined. One of the most important issues is the safe use of these machines. The cases where pilotless aircraft interfere with air traffic are the most spectacular, but there are also other areas that need to be regulated, e.g. the issue of privacy violations by drone users. Despite the legislative action taken by the Member States, it is necessary for the European Commission to create a certain legal framework that will set a European standard for the production and use of remotely guided unmanned aerial systems. It is important to establish rules for the mutual recognition by Member States of the power to pilot such aircraft for commercial purposes.  We need to create a system for registering such machines, which, in the event of a life-threatening and health-threatening situation, will make it possible to easily identify their owner, including in another Member State. It is necessary to create a catalogue of technical parameters identifying drones intended for different purposes, so that for both manufacturers and users this division is clear and clear. Mrs Foster's report defines all these challenges comprehensively and precisely and makes clear conclusions for the EC. I voted in favour of it.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The report focuses on the civilian use of drones, which are already relevant and have greater economic, safety and recreational potential, lacking regulatory framework. From our point of view, the report does not safeguard that public funding for the development of these technologies will not be militarily internalised, nor does it safeguard the protection of data and information for persons, which is addressed and defended, but without much further development, in particular in the case of equipment that can easily be transformed into means of surveillance and access to personal data by governments , companies and individuals. We abstained.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission launched an initiative in 2010 called "Europe, a tourist destination no. 1 in the world" to give new impetus to tourism with the forecast of 21 shares. However, since May 2013, the Commission has stopped drawing up implementation plans and it is therefore difficult to assess the progress made now.  The report requires an implementation report to verify the actions taken, including the use of financial resources. One of the main problems with European tourism legislation is that the resources allocated to it are indeed derisory and that most of the actions undertaken require funds in different funding programmes, which are not integrated into each other. We have the opportunity to count on a vast territory, where nothing is really missing: beautiful coasts, mountain ranges, lakes, rivers and an immense historical and artistic heritage. The report is comprehensive and addresses all the problems and shortcomings identified in European tourism policy by making sound and easy-to-implement proposals. For these and other reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, even considering that it is useful for Europe to work to define joint strategies in support of tourism, the rapporteur uses it as a platform to promote further liberalisation of the conditions of the sector (including support for new digital service platforms) expressly excluding any harmonisation (social, fiscal...) that curbs the effects of devastating competition. In addition, the text contains references to migration or the political situation in some of the EU's neighbouring countries which only reinforce the more regressive guidelines of the current CFSP.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it proposes actions in the fields of digitisation, sustainable and responsible tourism and the promotion of Europe as the number one destination in the world. Emphasis is also placed on the need to promote, protect and preserve European cultural heritage, the importance of coastal and maritime tourism and budgetary issues, calling on the Commission to adopt a separate financial line for tourism in the next multiannual financial framework.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report is a first step towards European regulation of the tourism sector. With this in mind, it calls on the Commission to start by increasing its staff in charge of tourism policy, to report on the first steps it took in 2010 in this area, to take into account the challenges ahead (climate protection (sic!) and the environment, digitisation of the sector, accessibility, etc.) or to promote transnational and pan-European tourism and to develop marketing tools in this direction.  We believe that tourism does not need to be supervised from Brussels, whose sole purpose is to make European nations disappear. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Once again, we are voting on a matter which should be dealt with by each individual Member States. Is the UK tourist industry not fundamentally different from that of Greece, for example?

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to develop new tools to promote Europe as a tourist territory.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe. While the growth forecasts for the number of tourists visiting the EU in the coming years are positive, Europe increasingly needs to compete with other destinations in the world, especially those emerging, to which travel is cheaper. Tourism, like the economy as a whole, is affected by demographic change and youth unemployment. In addition, the tourism sector is experiencing changes in consumer behaviour, increased demand for high-quality services for customers and, finally, businesses need to adapt to the era of digitisation, as over 95% of travellers connect to the Internet to plan their journey. The Commission should continue to support the overall promotion of Europe in third country markets at its full potential, complementing existing public tourism promotion efforts at European and cross-border value. In 2013, 15% of Europeans did not use trains because platforms were difficult to access and lack information. It is therefore necessary to improve accessibility and pay particular attention to persons with reduced mobility. I support the calls on the Commission, the Member States, the regions and the tourism authorities and SMEs to make the most of the new funding opportunities from the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Europe is the world's number one tourist destination. The number of foreign tourists visiting the EU is expected to increase by 140 million each year until 2025. That said, the tourism industry in Europe also faces a number of major challenges. The digitization of distribution channels, increasing competition from less expensive destinations, emerging economies and seasonality are just a few examples. One in ten companies in the non-financial market economy belongs to the tourism industry and the sector employs no less than 12 million workers in the EU. Considering the significant potential of tourism in terms of growth, GDP, employment and foreign trade, I have obviously supported the initiative of the Committee on Transport and Tourism.  It encourages the European Commission not only to assess its ongoing tourism action plan but also to establish a new strategy. Among the various avenues envisaged, the emphasis is in particular on a budget line devoted exclusively to tourism, the development of new European transnational products, sports tourism, the sharing economy and the digitisation of the sector.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote is positive given that it is a question of promoting Europe in the world as a tourist destination, not only countries individually, but proposing transnational itineraries, enhancing the appreciation of coastal and maritime tourism and also cultural heritage.  The idea is to offer quality tourism options (through the proposal of a European quality brand and especially the national "made in". Sustainable, social and responsible tourism is another very important tool to be promoted above all by encouraging digitalisation and the use of new technologies.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. I support this report in that it advocates the promotion of the European tourism industry. In view of the various economic crises that have occurred and/or are present in the countries of the Union, tourism is and must remain more than ever a source of income for states and professionals in the sector.  Today, the tourism industry is facing increased global competition, particularly as a result of the less expensive emerging countries that attract international tourists. In the face of this competition, Europe must build on its comparative advantages, in particular its diversity of landscapes and its extraordinary cultural, artistic, gastronomic and historical richness.  I regret, however, that the European Parliament is taking advantage of this report to give free rein to its obsession with comitology, which is costly and too often inoperative. Why consider a European tourism agency, funds allocated to "a European Year of Tourism" or a "Destination Europe" label? Decidedly, the European institutions find it very difficult not to give in to the sirens of interventionism at all costs and the gabegie that ensues.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This De Monte report looks at new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe and aims to encourage the European Commission to develop a European-wide tourism offer. As such, I had tabled several amendments in committee, notably for accessible tourism.  The rapporteur deplores the Commission's lack of willingness to strengthen the EU's tourism policy. We always want "more Europe", as if more Europe would bring more tourists (it's probably the opposite...). No, on the contrary, it is up to each Member State to decide sovereignly its tourism policy. Moreover, tourist sites are being hit by the growing insecurity to which free movement is a cause. In fact, this report aims to smooth national diversity to promote Europe when I believe that Europe is rich in its nations, its cultures and its his stories. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a common strategy for improving tourism provision and management in Europe, in order to safeguard and promote Europe's vast cultural heritage. From this point of view, I believe it is important to support local and regional tourism growth, through the protection of the 'Made in' brand and to SMEs investing in digital to improve their services for consumers.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against this report. The report aims to establish a common European tourism agency to promote the European tourism industry. The report is partly for federalist and harmonisation and, on the other hand, the report proposes that new money be allocated to this area. I believe that spending more money on the tourism industry at a time when the welfare sectors are being cut back is a mispriority.  These are the main reasons why I voted against.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it advocates new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism. Tourism is a key potential area of growth for the European economy, accounting for more than 10% of the EU's GDP, including tourism-related sectors. Tourism also encourages the creation of many jobs, with 13 million people directly employed in the sector. at least 12% of jobs in the EU. While the growth forecasts for the number of tourists visiting the EU in the coming years are positive, we need to be vigilant about foreign visitors, as Europe increasingly has to compete with other destinations in the world, especially those emerging, which can be made cheaper. In addition, some additional challenges require the tourism sector in Europe to adapt rapidly in order to maintain its level of competitiveness. The tourism sector is affected by changes in consumer behaviour, higher demand for high-quality services for customers and, ultimately, companies need to adapt to the era of digitisation, as over 95% of travellers join the Internet to plan their journey, and the number of suppliers in the collaborative economy is growing. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission, the Member States, the regions and the tourism authorities, as well as businesses, especially SMEs, to make the most of the new funding opportunities from the European Fund for Strategic Investments, in particular through national and regional investment banks, so that EU action in the area of tourism support rises to a new qualitative level.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on 'new challenges and strategies to promote tourism in Europe', which I support, is part of a context in which it seems more essential than ever to enhance the quantitative as well as qualitative scope of tourism on our continent. Given that the tourism sector now contributes more than 10% of the EU's GDP and that it is also a strong driver of growth and employment throughout the Union, it is necessary to increase investment in this sector from a more strategic perspective. Europe is the world's leading tourist destination, but in order to maintain this primacy, especially in view of the growing competition from third countries, it may be useful to enhance a "Europe brand" that, starting from the richness and heterogeneity of the landscape and cultural heritage, is able to distinguish itself from other destinations for the quality and offer of services, also exploiting digitalization as a new source of growth , especially for small and medium-sized enterprises with a tourist vocation. Greater coordination between the different European tourist routes, as highlighted in the report, can help to cope with the limits of seasonality.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The rapporteur acknowledges that, in line with the needs and specific requirements of the Member States, common objectives must be clearly defined and the potential and added value of the 'Destination Europe' brand analysed. Some MePs believe that this could undermine the already recognised brands of individual Member States.  Citizens often complain to me that during the season there is often a lot of pressure on utilities. Croatia is successfully coping with this and there are a large number of municipalities and cities building infrastructure adapted to higher demands precisely through EU funds. However, the procedure is lengthy and complicated. That is why I have proposed to simplify access to such financing, especially in the Croatian case for waste and wastewater. I believe this will benefit domestic and foreign consumers.  As many as 95 per cent of consumers use the internet to book holidays. We must ensure that information is available to them in their own language and that their personal and financial data are protected. We must not forget that data is the currency of the new age and that its protection must be ensured.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The tourist attraction of Europe does not lie in the fact that most of the countries that make up it belong to the European Union. The European Commission is not in the best position to make an objective statement of the tourism situation in Europe, nor to propose an energizing policy. We would prefer that this subject be dealt with by independent experts. There is no doubt that such a study would show that the main obstacle to the development of tourism in Europe lies in the increase in insecurity in the various places of tourist attraction. The issue of heritage preservation must also be studied. The national wealth of the Old Continent deserves to be better highlighted, and therefore I am voting against this text.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Tourism is an important source of development for the EU, which has unfortunately so far been neglected by the Commission and the Council. In the third millennium tourism is an industry: a particular type of digital industry. More than 95% of tourist travel in 2014 saw the use of the Internet in the choice of destination, in the practical organization of travel and in travel-related purchases (tickets, flights, objects). At present, the tourism policy of European countries sees a high degree of divergence from country to country and is still all too often linked to a logic of competition between European countries: this causes a loss of competitiveness towards low-cost destinations outside Europe, which are the real threats to the turnover of the European tourism sector and which over the last ten years have learned to move deftly in the global tourism market , diverting significant EU tourist flows to their advantage.  We therefore need a European governance of tourism policy that guides and harmonises national strategies, with a view to not internal competition but cooperation. The multiplicity of landscapes, the historical and artistic offer and European cultural variability are the main reason for travel in the Union: only with a single European strategy can we make the most of it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 While in 2008 tourism provided 5.8% of existing jobs at European Union level and contributed more than 5% to European GDP, the same sector now provides 12% of jobs in the EU and contributes more than 10% to the Union's GDP. These percentages show us progress, as well as the important role that tourism plays in the European economy. European tourism currently faces a number of challenges, but also opportunities that require a more focused approach at European level, while respecting the characteristic differences of each Member State at all levels, thus taking into account the EU motto, 'Unity in Diversity'. I am in favour of the report on the new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe, because I am aware that this sector can play a key role in addressing the current economic crisis and in terms of employment at EU level.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The aim of the proposed text is to encourage the promotion by Member States of new tourist routes through the redevelopment of disused areas, roads, railways, abandoned paths and old routes; It also calls for action to protect Endangered European monuments and sites, with a view to safeguarding and promoting cultural heritage and thus encouraging cultural tourism. The report stresses that the variety of European languages – official, co-official, minority and lesser known – is the foundation on which Europe's cultural heritage is based and is the key to sustainable and responsible tourism.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Europe is a very popular tourist destination in the rest of the world. Both European culture, landscapes and gastronomy attract foreign tourists to Europe. The European tourism sector is highly developed and a vehicle for extremely important economic resources for the Member States. It is therefore necessary to put in place a strategy adapted to the particularities of this flourishing sector. Ancillary regulations that have an impact on the sector, such as competition, transport and internal market policies, must take into account the specifics of the tourism sector. Indeed, the other eu-employment policies must not undermine the growth of European tourism, but rather support its growth. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on new challenges and strategies to promote tourism in Europe.  The European economy needs to constantly exploit high-potential assets, such as tourism. However, although Europe is the world's leading destination, it is only vaguely aware of the potential that tourism can generate, which has traditionally been relegated to a spontaneous if not a secondary resource.  This lack of awareness is evident if we highlight the delay in building a European consciousness and consider that while tourism responds to many of Europe's priorities (sustainable growth, employment, the digital and fair single market), it does not have a dedicated line in the EU budget, but an inconsistent distribution of funds, pilot projects and preparatory actions. The report aims precisely to satisfy this strategic need, with both material (preservation and conservation of historical and monumental beauties) and immaterial purposes (strengthening of European identity, multicultural understanding and sustainability). I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because tourism plays an important role in the European Union and we need to constantly adapt in order to attract more visitors. Tourism is often a crucial part of economies of many European regions. Therefore, there is a need to improve access to a modern digital infrastructure by providing digital initiatives that seek to promote management of resources.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the promotion of tourism in Europe as a factor for economic growth and sustainable and responsible development. It focuses, on the one hand, on the development of a clear European label linked to quality indicators that can be exported and exported to the world; on the other hand, it focuses on sustainable, responsible and social tourism, including through the completion of the 'European Charter for Sustainable and Responsible Tourism'. The promotion and objective of the development of a quality label are underlying the whole report, on which I voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The variety of landscapes and cultural wealth make Europe the most sought-after destination for travellers, not only in Europe. Despite this, it is surprising to note that tourism has not been considered by cohesion policy as a thematic development objective that can be included in the 2014-2020 programming; In addition, there is still a lack of coherent and coordinated action at European level for the growth of the sector.  The Union must begin to confront the new frontiers represented by the online tourism offer and the growing development of the sharing economy, which require action with a regulatory framework appropriate to the digital market, especially for the protection of personal data and the protection of consumers who must receive correct and non-misleading information from the sites. I hope that in future legislative proposals a fair balance can be struck to regulate the activities carried out by tourism companies proper and those that support the sector but which do not generate a real profit. I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because it identifies new areas of action for tourism development that meet the needs of a more informed traveller who is more inclined to use technology to organise their journeys.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Although the European Commission makes announcements on tourism, tourism remains the EU's poor relative, as there is little support and support from EU funds. I agree with the Commission's recent position: 'Europe, the world's first tourist destination - a new tourism policy framework in Europe'. However, in order to make tourism an important and main driver of development, actions to support the tourism product are needed. My country, Cyprus, is an eminently touristic country that makes a significant contribution to GDP, which has so far benefited little from European policies. I believe it is time for the EU to take tourism policy seriously in the EU and to draw up plans to support, renew, upgrade the tourism product, particularly in countries with a comparative advantage such as Cyprus and the other Mediterranean countries. The EU and its economy will gain through the further development of tourism in Europe.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Isabella De Monte's report on the future of tourism in Europe because I agree with the approach she has taken to this text. Among other things, I have had the opportunity to share some impressions in the intergroup tourism, of which I am a member, and to follow this important policy document closely. There is also one aspect that I do not agree with: it is true that this action plan continues the work begun during the last term of office by the then Commissioner Tajani, that the attraction of tourist flows becomes a great continental challenge (considering that Asia also gains market share here), that in 2011 it was decided to launch the "Europe" brand, but the real challenge we win , in my opinion, focusing each on keeping their garden well cared for, that is, starting from the small territories and their ability to make system and attract tourists interested in living a unique experience more than seeing places.  In this respect, this issue ceases to be a problem for individual companies and becomes a political problem to be resolved before Europe ceases to be competitive in this area too.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters..

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Tourism is one of the sectors with the most growth potential in the European economy, generating more than 10 % of European GDP, which directly employs 13 million workers. It therefore urgently needs, in the face of the new realities faced by the sector, the revolution in the digital area and new technologies, competition from other destinations or the phenomena of a shared economy, reflecting on the challenges and the way european tourism is promoted as a foundation of economic growth and as a lever and instrument against the crisis.  It is vital that, on the one hand, the digital revolution is followed by ensuring that all companies, especially SMEs, can enjoy its benefits, and to congratulate the Digital Tourism Platform launched by the European Commission; on the other hand, the promotion of a sustainable, competitive tourism that promotes growth and jobs and always has the well-being of the tourist consumer at the heart of the world! Consumer confidence in companies providing tourist services is not only about accurate and understandable information, but also about providing means of protecting their rights and dispute resolution mechanisms.  Particular attention should be paid to the potential of the new tourist modalities, as well as to the different types of consumers, especially the most vulnerable.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe has a vast cultural and gastronomic heritage: however, in order to compete globally, it is obliged to face many challenges that threaten the tourist market, such as: firstly, increasing competition from emerging and less expensive destinations in third countries, the repercussions of demographic changes, the increase in youth unemployment, changes in consumer behaviour, an increase in quality supply standards and the development of the digitalisation process. An important first step to take is the implementation of a common European strategy in the tourism sector, which would involve creating an integrated offer of cultural products between Member States, responsible and sustainable management of available resources, investing in digitalisation, responding best to consumer needs and harmonising taxation systems and regulations to protect travellers. I therefore agree with what mrs De Monte's report says, stressing the fundamental role played by tourism in Europe, as one of the european Union's main socio-economic activities, with a far-reaching impact on economic as well as employment growth.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report addresses the promotion of tourism in Europe as a factor for economic growth and sustainable and responsible development. The ratification and implementation of the Treaty of Lisbon gives the European Union a greater role in the tourism sector and provides for the EU to support, integrate and coordinate member states' actions.  The central themes addressed in the report are: promotion of Europe as a tourist destination and creation of a European brand to be exported to the world; promotion of pan-European and transnational tourism products, creation of transnational thematic itineraries, redevelopment of abandoned and disused areas, enhancement of cultural heritage; creation of a European quality brand; enhancement of coastal and maritime tourism; completion of the European Charter for Sustainable and Responsible Tourism. I am voting in favour because I consider the proposal to be interesting, in particular the aspects relating to sustainable tourism, the sharing economy and digitalisation, and following the adoption of our amendment providing for the promotion of 'made in' brands in order to avoid the risk that a single European brand could penalise the many Italian excellences, being the first less attractive.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, even considering that it is useful for Europe to work to define joint strategies in support of tourism, the rapporteur uses it as a platform to promote further liberalisation of the conditions of the sector (including support for new digital service platforms) expressly excluding any harmonisation (social, fiscal...) that curbs the effects of devastating competition. In addition, the text contains references to migration or the political situation in some of the EU's neighbouring countries which only reinforce the more regressive guidelines of the current CFSP.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe's tourism industry faces a number of new challenges, including the digitalisation of distribution channels, increasing competition from emerging and less expensive destinations in third countries, changing consumer behaviour, moving to an experience economy, demanding quality services for customers, the need to attract and retain qualified staff , demographic changes and seasonality.  The European Parliament resolution, on which I voted in favour, starts from these challenges and promotes the tourism industry through a series of actions, including: 1) the creation of a 'Destination Europe' label for the enhancement of Member States' promotional activities, 2) the promotion of pan-European and transnational tourism products, 3) the sustainability of tourism, 4) the exploitation of coastal and maritime tourism , 4) better use of digitalisation, especially for SMEs.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. Tourism plays an extremely important role in the life of the European Union, an area of the European economy with key growth potential, which accounts for 10% of the EU GPD. Around 13 million jobs across Europe are directly or indirectly linked to tourism.  The aim of the report is to highlight areas where greater attention should be paid and to outline how to contribute to maintaining competitiveness, preserving jobs and spreading europe's most popular sites, contributing to the joint marketing of European tourist destinations and the dissemination of responsible and sustainable tourism. According to the report, Europe is facing increasing competition in this area, as emerging, cheaper third countries attract crowds of tourists. Europe must show its diversity and incredible cultural heritage in this competition in the first place. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report provides input to the Commission’s reflections to be presented at the Annual European Forum on Tourism. It proposes action in the fields of the sharing economy, digitisation, sustainable and responsible tourism as well as the promotion of Europe as the world's number one tourist destination. It also calls for better cooperation between the Member States and the Commission. Having a strong EU tourism sector means a stronger Maltese tourism sector. Acknowledging the centrality of this pillar in Malta’s economy and the need to further develop the industry to current trends I supported this report.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon has established the importance of tourism for the countries of the Union but, like the economy as a whole, this sector is now suffering the serious repercussions of the crisis and is facing changes in consumer behaviour, with a growing demand for high-quality services.  The report on the new challenges of tourism, for which I strongly voted in favour, ambitiously pursues the objective of making Europe a unified destination in the eyes of tourists. The creation of a 'Destination Europe' label, for example, would make it possible to avoid competition between the different European destinations and to better face up to the ever-increasing competition at global level, leveraging on the diversity of European landscapes, our extraordinary cultural wealth, our food and wine heritage, not forgetting religious tourism and wellness tourism.  Quality, sustainability and greater accessibility of tourist services and destinations must therefore be at the heart of our tourism promotion policies.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to promote tourism in Europe by ensuring better coordination with sectors directly or indirectly affected, such as transport, regional and rural development, the internal market, or consumer law. This report proposes a series of recommendations aimed at implementing a European brand strategy and promoting tourist destinations in Europe in a coordinated manner. It also advocates the development of sustainable and responsible tourism, as well as the sharing economy and digitisation. The aim of the European Union is to develop an attractive pan-European and transnational tourism offer in the face of international competition. In this context, cultural itineraries, heritage, gastronomy, commercial tourism, activity and adventure tourism, health and wellness tourism, education and religious tourism are among the pan-European themes that the Union wishes to promote internationally. Considering that the tourism sector, which already accounts for 10% of the European economy, is growing and that its expansion needs to be sustained, I voted in favour of this report which aims to further promote our European assets.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. – Tourism is an important source of income for the European economy and creates jobs. Europe is still the best destination to go on holiday globally. Nevertheless, we must show continued competitiveness and go along with digitisation. Promotion and tourism must remain of high quality without bureaucracy or too much regulation.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted for the De Monte Report on new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe. As tourism is a key sector of the European economy, it is, in my view, essential to improve coordination between Member States, regional, local and financial institutions. Similarly, through this report, we encourage synergies between the public and private tourism sector. This resolution will also enable Member States to cooperate in creating transnational thematic routes with the aim of highlighting the tourism assets of certain destinations. Finally, through this vote, we encourage the tourist experience that all citizens are now looking for.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. Tourism plays an extremely important role in the life of the European Union, so the European Parliament is also responsible for protecting the industry. This sector is also of great importance from a Hungarian point of view.  Around 13 million jobs across Europe are directly or indirectly linked to tourism. The report voted on today contributes to maintaining competitiveness, preserving jobs and spreading europe's most popular sites, helping to promote european tourist destinations together and promoting responsible and sustainable tourism.  Europe is also facing increasing competition in this area, as emerging, cheaper third countries attract crowds of tourists. Europe must show its diversity and incredible cultural heritage in this competition in the first place. With my vote, as a member of the Fidesz delegation, that is why I supported the report.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Tourism plays an extremely important role in the life of the European Union, so the European Parliament is also responsible for protecting the industry. This sector is also of great importance from a Hungarian point of view. Around 13 million jobs across Europe are directly or indirectly linked to tourism. The report voted on today contributes to maintaining competitiveness, preserving jobs and spreading europe's most popular sites, helping to promote european tourist destinations together and promoting responsible and sustainable tourism. Europe is also facing increasing competition in this area, as emerging, cheaper third countries attract crowds of tourists. Europe must show its diversity and incredible cultural heritage in this competition in the first place. That is why, with my vote, I supported the report as a member of the Fidesz delegation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report dealt with the promotion and new challenges of tourism in Europe. Unfortunately, tourism is not approached from an important sector of the Union's economy. While the text is dithyrambique on fashion effects such as "responsible tourism" or even ecological or even "sustainable", it addresses only anecdotally the problem of insecurity in major tourist places. By also proposing to increase the European Commission's staff in charge of tourism, this report attempts to make it appear that more Europe, again and again, is the solution to all ills. Attached to the specificity of the countries of European civilization in contrast to the promotion of border-strapped tourism, I voted against this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report builds on the Juncker Commission's three priorities: sustainable growth and jobs, the connected digital single market and a deeper and fairer internal market, but they have stagnated. What is proposed is simply half-measures that do not lead to any results. In addition, the report stresses the importance of avoiding cultural discrimination between religious and ethnic minorities and finally supports mobility and cooperation projects with various programmes by making funds available which will unfortunately be used for the benefit of specific enterprises for the sole purpose of profit and not for the benefit of professionals active in the tourism sector. For all the above reasons I voted against this report

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. Tourism plays an extremely important role in the life of the European Union, so the European Parliament is also responsible for protecting the industry. This sector is also of great importance from a Hungarian point of view.  Around 13 million jobs across Europe are directly or indirectly linked to tourism. The report voted on today contributes to maintaining competitiveness, preserving jobs and spreading europe's most popular sites, helping to promote european tourist destinations together and promoting responsible and sustainable tourism. Europe is also facing increasing competition in this area, as emerging, cheaper third countries attract crowds of tourists. Europe must show its diversity and incredible cultural heritage in this competition in the first place. That is why, with my vote, I supported the report as a member of the Fidesz delegation.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
