text: in writing. Tourism is a key activity for Europe and, especially for some countries and regions, so sufficient funds and a strengthening of tourism policy are needed to boost this activity under the umbrella of the new EU tourism competences recognised in the Lisbon Treaty. The launch of an Action Plan by the European Commission to develop the EU strategy for coastal and maritime tourism is a key tool in strengthening its growth and job creation opportunities, as well as recognised in this report on the new challenges and strategies for promoting tourism in Europe. The importance of addressing connectivity and accessibility is critical, in particular in the island and outermost regions, which rely heavily on maritime and air transport. It is also necessary to create intelligent and innovative strategies to combat seasonality that adapt to both high-season and low-season periods and take into account different audiences, as well as continue to bet on cruise tourism and ensure that there is sustainable development of the sector.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – We have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it promotes Europe as a tourist destination and aims to create a European brand to export to the world; it also promotes pan-European and transnational tourism products, through the creation of transnational thematic itineraries, the redevelopment of abandoned and disused areas, and the enhancement of cultural heritage; The resolution also accepted the amendment of the M5S for the protection of national "made in" brands, in order to avoid the risk that a single European brand could penalise the many Italian excellences. The resolution also values sustainable, responsible and social tourism to complement the 'European Charter for Sustainable and Responsible Tourism'; in addition, it promotes the coastal and maritime one. In 2010, the Commission launched an initiative called 'Europe, the World's No 1 tourist destination' to give tourism a new impetus with the forecast of 21 actions. The report therefore calls for an implementation report to verify the actions taken, including the use of financial resources. Finally, the resolution calls for the development of networks of green itineraries that include rural areas, forests and smaller natural sites by integrating existing transport infrastructure networks with new eco-sustainable solutions.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Tourism is one of the areas with the most growth potential in the European economy, generating more than 10% of EU GDP, if account is taken of tourism-related sectors which directly employs 13 million workers and therefore accounts for at least 12% of eu jobs. Europe is the world's leading tourist destination, with a market share of 52 %, and the number of international tourists arriving in the EU is expected to increase by 140 million a year by 2025. This sector employs 3.2 million people, mostly young people between the age of 16 and 35. I believe that the European Commission should continue and improve the joint promotion of Europe as the world's first tourist destination and implement the 'Destination Europe 2020' strategy, which includes a set of marketing, brand strategy and promotion of Europe as a tourist destination.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it marginalizes Europe's cultural and historical heritage.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is based on a logic of promoting a tourism scale that is "continental", noting that a very significant percentage of world tourism (52%) is in Europe. While it is true that the report contains some relevant recommendations with some interest, there are several aspects that we do not fully follow, at least in the formulations adopted here, such as the insistence on a mytified 'European identity' and an alleged 'common cultural heritage', alongside the subsidiary theses of the creation of a 'European brand' and 'pan-European products'. We advocate strengthening cooperation with third countries through tourism activities – which in itself does not raise any objection, quite the contrary. But it is cross-cutting to the report the concern about the so-called unstable situation of neighboring countries, moving forward with considerations that are not immune to a xenophobic and neocolonial logic (from facilitating the entry to companies operating in the area of tourism in developing countries to the refusal to accept refugees for reasons of "hygiene" of tourist spots) – which here , however, it is not made explicit in these terms. One of the positive aspects to be highlighted is the reference, in several points, to decent working conditions as a factor of quality and tourism appreciation.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I think there are positive aspects.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Tourism in the European Union has had to cope in recent years mainly with rapidly increasing competition outside European, often much less expensive countries. This is also one of the reasons why the promotion and development of tourism in Europe, despite the absence of a common policy, requires, at least to some extent, coordinated action, which the European Commission should seek to significantly reduce the number of its staff involved in this area, but signals that tourism may not be a priority in the near future. This cannot be considered good news, especially as tourism is irreplaceable in terms of promoting sustainable economic growth and increasing employment. The European Commission's actions in this area are incomprehensible, because estimates of an increase in the number of tourists within individual Member States in the coming period are positive, but it should not be forgotten that tourism is a sector that is very sensitive to various fluctuations and crises and it is therefore essential that it maintains the necessary competitiveness. This requires, in particular, emphasis on quality, the development of digitisation of services provided, but also improving the accessibility of different modes of transport, including facilitating access for disabled passengers.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: in writing. – The UK Conservative delegation voted against this report for a number of reasons. Firstly, we refuse to lend our voice to calls in this report for a single European Agency for Tourism, or for an increased EU budget for tourism in the next Multiannual financial Framework – which we fear would undermine efforts to restrain spending at EU level. Secondly, we cannot support the driving philosophy of this report: giving the Commission more powers to market Europe as a single entity under a Commission-led brand ‘Destination Europe’ – which would risk undermining existing successful campaigns at national level. Finally, whilst we support high quality standards in holiday accommodation across the EU, we believe it is up to the relevant Member State authorities, which already possess the required powers, to ensure that these standards remain high and that hotel and hostel owners are in full compliance with health and safety legislation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe for the following reasons: It builds on the Juncker Commission's three priorities, sustainable growth and jobs, the connected digital single market and the deeper and fairer internal market, but which have stagnated. What is proposed is simply half-measures that do not lead to any results. In addition, the report stresses the importance of avoiding cultural discrimination between religious and ethnic minorities and finally supports mobility and cooperation projects with various programmes, with funds which will unfortunately be used for the benefit of specific enterprises for the sole purpose of profit and not for the benefit of professionals active in the tourism sector.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ In view of the annual European Forum on Tourism, I believe it is absolutely necessary to promote Europe as the world’s number one tourist destination. To take steps in that direction, we have to act in the fields of the sharing economy, digitisation and sustainable and responsible tourism. We must promote and preserve Europe’s cultural heritage. This must be our priority, considering that many cultural sites lack funds, are not properly protected by national or local authorities and risk collapse. We must support professional training and education, especially in those countries most affected by the crisis and where young graduates in the arts and culture, experts and researchers face serious problems of long-term unemployment. Lastly, I support the request included in the report for specific tourism products to counteract seasonality and I welcome existing initiatives, such as Calypso, to promote social tourism.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because its objectives are to strongly encourage the Commission, in cooperation with the European Tourism Commission (ETC), which brings together national tourism organisations, to continue and enhance the promotion of Europe as the world's leading tourist destination under the auspices of a common European approach. I welcome the implementation of the 'Destination: Europe 2020' long-term strategy, which includes a range of marketing, branding and promotion actions to promote Europe as a tourist destination. I also consider it important to point out that the creation of a 'European destination(s)' brand aimed at complementing and enhancing the promotion activities of national, regional, cross-border and local tourism organisations and the European tourism sector in order to increase the visibility and competitiveness of European tourist destinations is of the utmost importance, especially in remote markets.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of being aware of the great importance of the tourism sector for EU employment and economic growth. Although the forecasts for the increase in the number of tourists visiting the EU in the coming years are positive, we must be vigilant about the share of international visitors, in the face of increasing international competition, so the European tourism sector must adapt in order to maintain its level of competitiveness.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Tourism is a key and essential sector for the European economy. Europe is famous all over the world for its excellence in all fields, from culture to the food and wine sector, from sport to all other recreational sectors. We have an invaluable heritage that is too often underestimated or undervalued.  The world of tourism is constantly changing and large investments and long-term strategies are needed, to support consumers and all economic actors involved in this sector, with priority attention to the essential digitalization.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. It is essential that Europe, which contains a very important number of destinations of tourism excellence in its territories, should have an overall strategy to enhance its heritage and to coordinate such a crucial sector for economic development. I would like to stress the importance of extending access to tourist services for those categories of citizens with disabilities and mobility difficulties too: the removal of existing barriers – physical and digital – is a fundamental legal battle and an important means of social inclusion.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP own-initiative report on the new challenges and strategies for promoting tourism in Europe, as tourism is indeed an economic activity of fundamental importance for the European Union and for the development of the regions that have most felt the effect of the continuing crisis.  I firmly believe that, especially for certain regions of southern Europe, tourism can become the main economic activity and ensure unta level playing field for growth and development.  The crisis season experienced by the tourism sector has had an important impact on the quality of life of operators and SMEs in the sector. I therefore believe that we must continue to push to ensure that the European Union does not lose its dominant position in the world tourism scene.  In this regard, I support the call for the Commission to report to Parliament on the implementation of the interventions implemented in the 2010 communication and the use of the Structural Funds and EU programmes in the tourism sector.  Finally, I hope that the role of macro-regions in the implementation of tourism strategies, and in particular the Adriatic-Ionian strategy, which offers a tourist, cultural and historical port that is certainly natural in the implementation of European tourism strategies, will be taken into account.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on 'New challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe', as it sets important priorities. I am particularly pleased that a large majority of the House is following my request and agreeing to the objective of making Europe the 'most family-, child- and generation-friendly holiday region in the world'.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. It is important that the European tourism industry remains competitive despite comparatively high prices. This is only possible if the industry can adapt quickly to changing circumstances. It is precisely here that we can benefit from common European solutions. That is what I have been voting for today, by voting in favour of the report.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which highlights the need for a European tourism sector that is sustainable, responsible and accessible. I am pleased to see an emphasis on the role of SMEs and the need for investment in training and education in order to provide quality jobs. Crucially, this report recognises Labour’s call for European legislation on tourism accommodation safety. Labour will continue to work with consumer groups, safety organisations and industry representatives to prevent rare but devastating cases where inadequate health and safety rules have led to tragedies, including deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. Europe is the world's first tourist destination, with a market share of 52%. The result is that tourism generates more than 10% of EU GDP (if tourism-related sectors are take into account) and directly employs thirteen million workers. We are therefore talking about a fundamental sector. That is why, in this report, we call on the Commission to pay comprehensive attention to this economic sector and to present a new strategy to meet the challenges facing the sector.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. In 2010, the Commission promoted the Communication entitled 'Europe, the world's first tourist destination: a new policy framework for European tourism'. In order for Parliament to judge the efficiency of the measures taken, the rapporteur calls on the Commission to submit a comprehensive implementation report, including the use of financial resources. The report also proposes a series of actions aimed at developing a common strategy for promoting Europe as a preferred tourist destination, taking into account economic, quality, sustainability, responsibility and technological innovation criteria, among others. However, while the report is interesting, it sneaks up a proposal for which we tabled a deletion amendment which was discarded in the vote. This proposal refers to the promotion of health tourism, which is not health tourism, i.e. in the face of the saturation of public health systems, promoting travel to use private assistance in other, cheaper countries. We believe that we cannot support a report which includes a measure that undermines one of our basic political principles: the defence of a quality public health system. We therefore voted against the report.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. Tourism plays an extremely important role in the life of the European Union, so the European Parliament is also responsible for protecting the industry. This sector is also of great importance from a Hungarian point of view. Around 13 million jobs across Europe are directly or indirectly linked to tourism. The report voted on today contributes to maintaining competitiveness, preserving jobs and spreading sustainable tourism. Europe is facing increasing competition in this area, as emerging, cheaper third-world countries attract crowds of tourists. Europe must show its diversity and incredible cultural heritage in this competition in the first place. I voted in favour of this report as a member of the Fidesz delegation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report to assist in ensuring the better integration of tourism into various EU policies and also ensure that the proper application of the legislation in force realises the sector’s full competitive potential. Efforts to coordinate the various policies concerned need to be increased with the aim of ensuring that interests and needs of the tourism industry are fully taken into account when formulating and implementing its policies.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur asks the Commission for an opinion on the use of funds to date from support programmes such as the European Structural Funds and identifies a wide range of ways in which she believes That European tourism could be promoted at EU level. Apart from a few economically sensible points, such as the openness to the "sharing economy", the potential of which is recognized in the tourism sector in particular, the proposals are largely critical. For example, the Commission is being urged to explore the possibilities of creating a new budget line in the multiannual financial framework, which will be exclusively reserved for tourism promotion. This is also the subject of a call for an increase in the staffing level in the relevant departments of the EU Commission. The report also calls for an analysis of the potential of a new EU tourism agency to be created. The proclamation of a "tourism for all" principle, which is intended to ensure access to and affordability of such offers for a broad population, is also particularly critical. Due to the many centralist tendencies mentioned, the rejection of the whole report remained the only conceivable option. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on new challenges and concepts to boost tourism in Europe, given the importance of tourism to European economic development, where the European Union is the world's leading tourist destination and tourism generates more than 10% of EU GDP with almost 10 million employees in 1.8 million companies. Tourism as an economic activity in the Mediterranean part of the EU, where unemployment rates are very high, especially among young people, is particularly important.  The Commission should pay more attention to tourism, the possibility of using EU funds for a more improved tourism economy should be addressed in a better way. European tourism has great potential that is not sufficiently exploited and ranks highly as an industry that is at the very top of the world in its competitiveness. I believe that the next step in integrating the offer, stronger promotion and quality coordination of activities at European level should be the establishment of a European tourist board modelled on similar national tourism bodies.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text paves the way for European regulation of the tourism sector.  The Commission is theor for the First Step to Increase its Tourism Policy Workforce, to report on the first steps it took in 2010 in this area, to take into account future challenges (climate and environmental protection, digitisation of the sector, accessibility, etc.) or to promote transnational and pan-European tourism. , to develop marketing tools in this direction.  Our party's position is that tourism does not need to be supervised from Brussels, whose sole purpose is to make European nations disappear.  I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow MEP’s and I have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Isabella De Monte's report on the new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe. Tourism intersects with many of the issues in different European policies. It is therefore a question of ensuring that the cross-cutting challenges associated with tourism policy are best taken into account. This report aims to build on a brand strategy for European tourism against global competition, as well as support for digital offerings and the preservation of biodiversity. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report should be rejected. It aims to create a fictitious brand 'Destination Europe'. It completely overlooks the fact that the European continent is made up of the most diverse regions of individual European Member States and other non-members of the Union. The cultural and ethnic diversity of peoples, as well as the enormous diversity of their natural environments, contradicts the attempt to homogenise all this. Moreover, the European Union has no significant competence in the tourism sector that would justify the creation of a tourism agency. This report must therefore be rejected.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the report, which includes Labour amendments calling for urgent action to address carbon monoxide safety across Europe in tourism settings, as it calls on the European Commission to come forward with proposals for minimum standards for tourism safety in the European Union, particularly on fire safety and carbon monoxide safety in holiday accommodation.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur calls on the Commission to comment on the use of funds to date from support programmes such as the European Structural Funds and describes extensive ways in which she believes That European tourism could be promoted at EU level. Apart from a few economically sensible points such as the openness to the "sharing economy", the potential of which is recognized especially for the tourism sector, the proposals are largely critical. For example, the Commission is encouraged to explore the possibilities of creating a new budget line in the multiannual financial framework, which will be exclusively reserved for tourism promotion. This is also the subject of a call for an increase in the staffing level in the relevant departments of the EU Commission. The report also calls for an analysis of the potential of a new EU tourism agency to be created. The proclamation of a "tourism for all" principle, which is intended to ensure access to and affordability of such offers for a broad population, is also particularly critical. In this context, airlines are being asked to provide more seats in Economy Class, at the expense of higher-priced quotas. This call is a clear intervention in free pricing and the European economic order. Due to the many centralist tendencies mentioned, the rejection of the whole report remains the only conceivable option.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs De Monte's motion for a resolution. Tourism is, for us Europeans and Italians, a strategic economic sector. In recent years, the tourism industry has been facing increasing global competition with less expensive emerging countries attracting international tourists.  In order to combat increasing international competition and the negative effects of the crisis, European tourism needs greater interregional and cross-border cooperation, and this own-initiative report addresses a number of issues and strategies aimed at this objective. Furthermore, I would like to highlight a number of paragraphs in the report which aim to strengthen European common branding and marketing policies for sustainable and responsible tourism, with a view to an increasingly shared and digitised economy.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe, as this report calls for more interference by the European Commission in the tourism sector, as well as an increase in the EU budget in this area. In particular, paragraph 19 calls on the Commission to study the creation of a European tourism agency. In addition, the text calls for a relaxation of the tourist visa policy, as if the problems were not yet acute enough.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it aims to increase the Brussels Commission's interference in the tourism sector. However, I believe that France, the tourist country par excellence, has everything to lose. The French know better than the Eurocrats what is good for the tourist attraction of their country!

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, even considering that it is useful for Europe to work to define joint strategies in support of tourism, the rapporteur uses it as a platform to promote further liberalisation of the conditions of the sector (including support for new digital service platforms) expressly excluding any harmonisation (social, fiscal...) that curbs the effects of devastating competition. In addition, the text contains references to migration or the political situation in some of the EU's neighbouring countries which only reinforce the more regressive guidelines of the current CFSP.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. As we already know, tourism plays a very important role in promoting Europe's rich cultural diversity. In addition, it strengthens European identity and, therefore, it is necessary to establish new challenges and strategies to promote it. It should be noted that, in recent years, global competition has increased considerably with the existence of emerging and cheaper countries attracting international tourists. To fill this situation, we need to exploit our comparative advantages, in particular landscape diversity and extraordinary cultural richness.   In order to promote tourism in Europe, it is essential to carry out initiatives that promote responsible management of resources, taking into account a number of limitations affecting the tourism sector, such as climate change.  Collaboration between the Commission and the Member States with tourism companies in relation to the digitisation of travel and tourism companies is essential. This report aims to allow travellers to plan, book and pay for their multimodal 'door-to-door' trips. In my opinion, these measures are more than welcome to exploit our comparative advantages and strengthen European tourism.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur asks the Commission for an opinion on the use of funds to date from support programmes such as the European Structural Funds and identifies a wide range of ways in which she believes That European tourism could be promoted at EU level. Apart from a few economically sensible points, such as the openness to the "sharing economy", the potential of which is recognized in the tourism sector in particular, the proposals are largely critical. For example, the Commission is being urged to explore the possibilities of creating a new budget line in the multiannual financial framework, which will be exclusively reserved for tourism promotion. This is also the subject of a call for an increase in the staffing level in the relevant departments of the EU Commission. The report also calls for an analysis of the potential of a new EU tourism agency to be created. The proclamation of a "tourism for all" principle, which is intended to ensure access to and affordability of such offers for a broad population, is also particularly critical. In this context, airlines are being asked to provide more seats in Economy Class, at the expense of higher-priced quotas. This call is a clear intervention in free pricing and the European economic order. In view of the centralist tendencies mentioned, the rejection of the report as a whole has remained the only conceivable option.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Tourism generates more than 10% of the GDP of the European Union, taking into account tourism-related sectors. Tourism directly employs 13 million people. Europe is the most popular tourist destination in the world, so tourism has a far-reaching effect on economic growth, employment and social development. Member States are invited to make the most of the new funding opportunities under the European Fund for Strategic Investments and for the Commission to encourage the development of tourism-related pilot scenarios, appoint independent experts to assess the impact of other Union policies on tourism, foster cooperation between public and private actors, analyse the economic and social impact of the sharing economy and its impact on tourism, consumers, technology companies and public authorities. I supported mp Isabella De Monte's report on the important role of tourism and for the purpose of finding solutions to new challenges such as the digitisation of distribution channels, the development of a new sector of the sharing economy, increasing competition from new and cheaper destinations of third countries and changes in consumer behaviour, and better positioning of Europe as a tourist destination in the world.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Tourism is one of the most important economic sectors in the Member States of the European Union. While overall in the EU it covers around 10% of GDP, the percentage is even higher in different countries, with the summer or winter months becoming particularly important depending on the location of the region. This means that the proper development of tourism, investment, innovation, exchange of specialist experience, renovation of cultural heritage sites, as well as, of course, environmental protection – all these aspects are very important and cannot be ignored under any circumstances. Especially in view of the fact that the European Union is the most visited place in the world when it comes to tourism, and would not be very reluctant to pass on this outstanding achievement to someone else. Kaur, too, fully agrees with the idea of developing and further implementing a more centralised approach to the development of the tourism sector in all EU Member States, however difficult it may be – especially in terms of human resources – that it is absolutely necessary to always take into account local specific characteristics and characteristics. Any region is familiar with something particularly relevant to it, which has a major impact on the tourism development strategy on a case-by-case basis. Consequently, the development of common standards and the promotion of transnational tourism products must necessarily take account of this general diversity, so as not to harm this uniqueness in any way because of the use of a structural common demed. For my part, I am very much in favour of the idea of promoting Europe as an ever-active destination for tourism, both outside and within our Community.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. ‒ Europe is the world’s number one tourist destination, with international tourists set to increase by 140 million each year until 2025. This rate of increase brings with it a new wave of challenges that the EU must meet. Therefore it is important to maintain and update the strategy for EU tourism to accommodate the strongly increasing rate for the EU tourism industry. I have voted in favour of this report. However, it would be equally important to allocate a significant share of the benefits to protect culture heritage in Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the new challenges and ideas for promoting tourism in Europe, because it is not complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 29/10/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The ENF group had proposed an alternative resolution which, unsurprisingly, was rejected. This report as a whole is inconclusive: despite what the rapporteur says, the point of promoting Europe 'as a whole' is not well understood, with no serious study justifying its effectiveness. Another negative point is that the report mentions only very, very briefly, the problems related to insecurity in tourist cities, or the negative impact of the presence of migrants. We are not convinced.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Due to the diversity of our continent, there are completely different motivations for tourists from country to country, why they are holidaying in the respective European country. A brand "Europe" is therefore meaningless. Moreover, the European Union has no significant competence in the tourism sector to justify the creation of such an agency for tourism. I therefore reject this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report is a first step towards European regulation of the tourism sector. With this in mind, it calls on the Commission to start by increasing its staff in charge of tourism policy, to report on the first steps it took in 2010 in this area, to take into account the challenges ahead (climate protection (sic!) and the environment, digitisation of the sector, accessibility, etc.) or to promote transnational and pan-European tourism. , to develop marketing tools in this direction.  Tourism does not need to be supervised from Brussels, whose sole purpose is to make European nations disappear. The Member therefore voted against this text.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the recommendations in this report for updating rules for a sustainable, accessible and responsible tourism sector, which is vital for the EU economy and for the well—being of European citizens. In particular, I welcome the calls for increasing minimum safety standards such as those on carbon monoxide detection. The emphasis on SMEs and on training investment for high-quality jobs is also welcome.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new challenges and ideas for promoting tourism in Europe. It is a vital sector for the European economy, which needs a clear framework of action defined by the Commission for the promotion of Member States as a tourist destination. The way tourism should be developed is based on assumptions of environmental responsibility, sustainability and social responsibility. The tourism sector is, par excellence, a sector with great dynamism, vitality and an enormous capacity to show itself as an engine of economic growth for several Member States.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which explores the challenges to increase European tourism’s competitiveness. The report highlights the need to focus on Europe’s historical and cultural heritage as a means of attracting greater numbers of tourists to the Union. It also recommends that the digitalisation of the tourism industry be further developed to increase the quantity and quality of interactions between tourists and tourism companies.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – The tourism sector in Europe remains a growth engine and has become one of the main employers with 13 million employees. Europe is still the top tourist destination in the world, but we must remain vigilant. After all, competition from other tourist attractions is very high. Innovation in the tourism sector will also have to be innovated in order to cope with competition. In a globalised world where national borders are falling away, promoting Europe as a top tourist destination is an important tool to highlight the rich variety of holiday opportunities in Europe. To this end, we need to continue to work towards a quality digitisation of the travel offer and to better connect top tourist destinations, for example through better train connections. In addition, we must ensure quality services by making training for workers in the tourism sector cross-border, and work towards a wider range of alternative recreation and tourism opportunities outside the high season.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of the advancing process of globalisation, the tourism sector is also facing increasing global competition from new, less costly countries attracting foreign tourists. I therefore welcome the report on new challenges and strategies to promote tourism in Europe. In the face of this competition, the old continent must benefit from its comparative advantages, in particular the diversity of countries and the extraordinary cultural wealth, which also applies to Slovakia. Moreover, the eu's renewed tourism policy expects an increase in spa and health tourism, but also in sightseeing tourism based on cultural and natural heritage, where our country also has a lot to offer. At the same time, however, I would like to draw attention to the importance of an effective and coherent procedure to achieve this objective. In fact, while the Commission is proposing to build a 'Destination Europe' label, several Member States' tourism organisations are expressing their concerns as to whether diversity and a common brand can be combined. I therefore consider it important to also take these views into account, although I agree that the Commission should continue to ensure the best possible support for the joint promotion of Europe on third-country markets by providing European and transnational added value to current national tourism promotion efforts.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report ‘New challenges and concepts for the promotion of Tourism in Europe’, providing input into the Commission’s reflections to be presented at the Annual European Forum on Tourism. I fully agree with the recommendations in this report proposing actions in the fields of the sharing economy, digitisation, sustainable and responsible tourism as well as the promotion of Europe as the world’s number one tourist destination.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report draws attention to the fact that tourism is an area of key growth potential in the European economy, which accounts for 10% of the EU GPD, taking into account tourism-related sectors, and that tourism directly employs 13 million people, which corresponds to at least 12% of EU jobs. It points out that Europe, with its 52% share, is the world's number one tourist destination; statistics show that the majority of EU citizens' journeys abroad remain within the EU and it is projected that the number of foreign tourists arriving in the EU will increase by 140 million a year by 2025. Tourism is therefore a major socio-economic activity in the EU, with a broad impact on economic growth, employment and social development and can therefore play a crucial role in addressing the current economic and employment crisis. As a result, it calls for concerted action to develop tourism and exploit its potential. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This De Monte report looks at new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe and aims to encourage the European Commission to develop a European-wide tourism offer.  The rapporteur deplores the Commission's lack of willingness to strengthen the EU's tourism policy. We are also entitled to the eternal "more Europe", as if more Europe would bring more tourists (it's probably the opposite...). It is up to each Member State to decide sovereignly on its tourism policy. Moreover, tourist sites are being hit by the growing insecurity to which absolute free movement in the EU is no stranger. In short, this report aims to smooth national diversity to promote Europe. So I voted against it.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The European tourism policy needs to be strengthened: tourism is a source of non-relocable employment and growth for the whole continent. We do need to clarify the supply of labels and face the challenges posed by the new players in this sector.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 After the world opened up and countries from other continents made great progress, European tourism was given great rivals. Today, it is very easy to get cheaply to distant places where one can learn about other cultures. If Europe wants to remain competitive in the field of tourism, it must take advantage of the old continent, which lies in its diversity, the fact that in a short period of time it is possible to visit many states, to learn about many cultures and to explore the countryside. In order to make use of this, it is necessary to strengthen the continent's common tourism policy, which can be achieved by bringing member states together and examining the areas that have a positive impact in this area. The first appropriate step in this direction is the adoption of this initiative.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will instate pan-European and transnational tourism products and sustainable and responsible tourism, taking into consideration that Europe’s international visitors find themselves under increasing pressure from other international destinations, in particular from newly—emerging, less expensive destinations.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Europe is one of the most desirable tourist destinations in the world and millions of tourists come here every year. The tourism sector generates 2.9% of EU GDP and employs 3.3% of the Union's workforce. It is no secret that what attracts them most is our rich cultural heritage. That is why we have an obligation to protect and promote it. I share the view that Europe's cultural heritage has huge strategic potential, which we need to develop and make optimal use of. In order to create the conditions for sustainable growth in Europe, we need to promote cultural tourism as a motor for sustainable economic and social development at local and regional level. In addition, I believe that in addition to the most popular tourist places, priority should also be given to smaller and unusual destinations, among which falls my home country, Bulgaria.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because tourism is one of the economic areas of major importance for the economies of the Member States. In the case of Romania, tourism is a sector with currently unused development potential and could be helped by any future strategies for this area at EU level.  By its very nature, tourism helps the development of regions by its horizontal and vertical economic multiplication; therefore, for Romania, together with the Cohesion and Regional Development Funds, an EU-wide tourism promotion strategy could bring more than expected benefits.  I also believe that all Member States, although many have a very well-developed tourism industry, could benefit from a Union-wide strategy, as it could better address regions and states with much untapped potential.  As the rapporteur points out in this document, tourism is indirectly financed by several EU funds, but the invitation to the Commission to develop a strategy for this area could help to better focus resources and bring better results.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Tourism is a pillar of many Austrian federal states and must therefore be promoted. However, this cannot be accompanied by an additional burden on farms, which is included, at least implicitly, in this report. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report proposes a harmonisation of Member States' national tourism policies by seeking synergy seeking to enhance European heritage. The aim is to entrust the committee with the development of a series of joint actions aimed at creating a 'Europe brand'. In particular, the report contains paragraphs calling on the Commission and Member States to take specific measures concerning the outermost regions and recognises the fragility and dependence of these regions on the tourism sector. I am in favour of pooling forces between Member States to promote European tourism. However, I regret that this approach, being entrusted to the Commission, is subject to a liberal and competitive logic, thus taking precedence over the market value of tourism. For these reasons, I abstain.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Tourism in the EU must be competitive and needs to develop a wide range of areas, such as advertising, sustainable tourism, access, etc.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. In view of the development of the tourism sector and its importance for European regions, a separate section should be laid down in the next multiannual programme for tourism.  Particular attention should be paid to the implementation of the long-term 'Journey to Europe 2020' strategy and to pan-European and international tourism products. The 'Travel to Europe' brand should be developed to increase the visibility and competitiveness of European tourist attractions. In particular, the potential and added value of this brand should be analysed and the overall objectives should be clearly defined. In addition, it is very important that a guide is drawn up for this brand.  Sustainable and responsible tourism must become a priority across the EU in order to preserve and improve cultural and natural heritage. We need to step up our efforts to improve the competitiveness of the EU tourism industry.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The interests of the tourism industry seek to upgrade the report on "promoting tourism in Europe" voted against by the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece. "Branding", "Europe as a tourist destination", "pan-European and transnational tourism products" are projects of business groups active in the tourism sector who do not hesitate to use even "health" as an attraction for tourism, in order to continue their profitability unabated. The report calls for the use of "tourist visas" and "visa waiver agreements" at the same time as the EU steps up its crackdown on refugees and migrants, highlighting how its so-called "smart borders" that "open" or "close" depending on the interests of monopolies work. The xenophobic call for "a report on the impact on the tourism sector of the uncontrolled influx of migrants" is also unacceptable. Moreover, there is no mention of the miserable working conditions of workers in the sector who, after being "drained" their labour force, are again driven to unemployment, but also by the inability of the popular families to have a short vacation, since the popular right of holidays as long as monopolies dominate has become a luxury commodity for the business groups of the sector to treasure.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on new challenges and concepts to boost tourism in Europe. Sustainable, affordable and responsible tourism that is in harmony with nature and landscape and tradition of destination, which relies on resource efficiency, sustainable mobility and climate protection, which helps to preserve the environment and its better understanding, and brings lasting results in terms of regional development and development of rural space, is the kind of tourism I want for Croatia.  I especially support the parts of the resolution that point to the importance of finding a favorable financial impulse for investments in tourism, especially in the part that is based on small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, which includes family farms.  The recognition of Europe's tourist offer is based on history, art, religion, culture and tradition, as well as quality food and drink. The village is the best place to protect the traditional, cultural, national and religious identity of European peoples. That is why the potential of rural tourism as an alternative to seasonal tourism must be adequately valued and supported.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This De Monte report looks at new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe and aims to encourage the European Commission to develop a European-wide tourism offer. The rapporteur deplores the Commission's lack of willingness to strengthen the EU's tourism policy. We are also entitled to the eternal "more Europe", as if more Europe would bring more tourists (it's probably the opposite...). It is up to each Member State to decide sovereignly on its tourism policy. Moreover, tourist sites are being hit by the growing insecurity to which absolute free movement in the EU is no stranger. In short, this report aims to smooth national diversity to promote Europe. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Coastal and maritime tourism represents the largest maritime activity in Europe and accounts for more than a third of the maritime economy, directly affecting many other sectors of the EU economy and employing 3.2 million people, most aged between 16 and 35. This sector is a lever for growth and job creation, especially in the Atlantic and Mediterranean regions. This is especially true of Croatia from which I come in which tourism generates almost a quarter of GDP. Taking into account the exceptional importance of tourism to the European economy, our core objective should be sustainable, affordable and responsible tourism that is aligned with nature and the environment and urban destinations and based on resource efficiency, sustainable mobility and climate protection, helps protect the local environment, in particular mountainous and coastal regions and islands, which will lead to lasting results in terms of regional growth , meets the increasing demands of passengers in terms of quality and helps companies compete, which this resolution also correctly underlines.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased by Parliament’s vote on the promotion of tourism in Europe. Europe is the number one tourist destination in the world, with millions upon millions of tourist coming to Europe each year. This provides a substantial portion of the EU’s GDP, in addition to providing millions of jobs within its regions. With these facts, I expect the Commission to continue supporting tourism throughout Europe and to call on them to make the European Structural and Investment Funds more transparent, since they are a large source of funding for tourism projects. I also support the enrichment of the Destination Europe brand in order to better promote European tourism as a whole. Europe has so much to offer in terms of culture and history and the European Union should do everything it can so that people around the world can experience it.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Tourism is a key sector of our economy as it generates more than 10% of the European Union's GDP and employs around 20 million people, particularly young people. Despite the economic crisis that erupted in 2008, Europe remains the World's No 1 tourist destination.  However, European tourism faces many challenges, starting with the need to constantly innovate and improve the quality of its services. The industry needs to adapt quickly to the digital revolution, bearing in mind that more than 30% of travelers plan their online itineraries. Tour operators must be able to cope with the growing competition from new emerging and less expensive destinations. The tourism sector needs all the support of the European Union and we must work to develop a model focused on quality, sustainability and the creation of highly specialised professional figures. I believe that the report: 'New challenges and strategies to promote tourism in Europe' can be a useful tool for promoting joint actions at continental level and ensuring that tourists have the highest quality standards in the world. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of its approval.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 Tourism promotion is, in my opinion, particularly important. Although tourists visiting Union countries are not expected to decline, Europe must respond to the pressure of popular destinations, especially the more financially advantageous ones. The Aim of the European Parliament should be to maintain or increase the competitiveness of tourist destinations in Europe. Several surveys have highlighted weaknesses in ensuring sufficient quality of service. 15% of Europeans do not use train services because of poorly accessible platforms or lack of information. Good accessibility is an important condition for promoting tourism in Europe. I believe that thanks to this report we will help to improve the quality of services and thus to increase the competitiveness of European tourist destinations.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report contributes to the Commission's deliberations, to be presented at the ordinary meeting of the European Tourism Forum. proposes actions in the field of sharing economy, digitisation, sustainable and responsible tourism, as well as promoting Europe as a major tourist destination. It also calls for better cooperation between the Member States and the Commission. As regards the actions taken since 2010, the report calls on the Commission to report to Parliament on the use of tourism funds under the Structural Funds and relevant EU programmes. The report stresses the need to promote, protect and preserve Europe's cultural heritage. Subject to a separate budget line for tourism in the next Multiannual Financial Framework and the initiative to create a European Tourism Agency, as another example of the growth of European bureaucracy, I decided to support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the new challenges and concepts for promoting tourism in Europe. It is important to promote the development of environmentally friendly tourism while encouraging the development of our tourism businesses.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution in question now reacts to the 2010 European Commission (EC) Communication "Europe, the world's first tourist destination - new political framework for European tourism" and outlines the European Parliament's position on the follow-up given by the EC services with regard to updating the implementation plan of the measures then adopted. In this respect, the rapporteur regrets that the Commission has stopped transmitting adequate and continuously updated information since May 2013 and that it is therefore difficult for Parliament to assess the efficiency of the measures adopted, exercising its full executive control power. The rapporteur also takes the opportunity to highlight the challenges that will enable the tourism sector in Europe to maintain its competitiveness and adapt to changing consumers, particularly in the field of digital technologies. Having said the above, and in the expectation that the Commission will take into account the warnings submitted to plenary by this resolution, I supported the motion for a resolution with my vote.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We have opposed this report as it is up to Member States to develop their own tourism sectors.  There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency or to promote Europe as a tourist brand, neither is there the necessity to create an EU-wide quality brand.  UKIP is in agreement with the UK Government on these matters.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. Tourism is one of the most dynamic sectors of activity in Europe due to the cultural diversity that exists in the different countries of the European Union, the result of multiple his or her and geographies. However, this sector needs to modernize in order to overcome the new challenges that lie ahead. First, emerging countries are increasingly competitive with the old continent, due in part to much lower costs. In addition, this sector must adapt to changes in consumer behaviour and profiles, with the development of the collaborative economy and an ageing population at the forefront. Finally, the tourism industry must take into account ever-increasing sustainability requirements. For example, I supported the initiative report on new challenges and concepts for the promotion of tourism in Europe, which aims in particular to take measures at EU level, such as the creation of the 'Destination Europe' label and the improvement of accessibility in transport. Finally, the strengthening of European passenger rights will be a decisive step in the development of passenger traffic in Europe, by strengthening confidence in the services offered.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the promotion of tourism in Europe. Let us remember that Europe is the number one tourist destination in the world, making tourism a key sector of the European economy. It has a major impact on economic growth, employment and social development and can therefore be a considerable lever in the context of the current economic crisis.  It is clear that the sector faces many challenges such as the digitization of distribution channels, the development of the sharing economy, the ageing of the population or the increasing competition from cheaper destinations in emerging countries.  This report, which I have supported, very usefully calls for the deployment of a new strategy for tourism in the Union. These include creating a budget line dedicated to tourism or a "Destination(s) Europe label in order to increase the visibility and competitiveness of European tourist destinations. The idea is also to promote sustainable, responsible and environmentally friendly tourism. Finally, we must take into account the growth of the sharing economy and the digitisation of the European tourism market.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This report contains all the proposed actions that the EU could develop in the field of tourism. It is a very broad spectrum report that includes initiatives and proposals of all kinds to promote the tourism sector in the EU, from recommendations on digitisation, responsible and sustainable tourism, ways to promote the EU as a global tourist destination, etc. It is worth noting from the report the call for greater clarity of the actions financed from the structural and cohesion funds in the area of tourism, and in particular the request for a budget line to better identify the different actions carried out by the EU. The report calls for the creation of a brand on Europe's destiny on the based on heterogeneity and a multitude of available tourist offers. It stresses the need to promote European cultural heritage and the importance of training to ensure quality and competitive service. It also touches on the shared economy sector, which requires the same degree of compliance with the regulations applicable to the traditional sector. That is why, among other issues, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This initiative report, which I supported, includes the implementation of a brand strategy, the common promotion of tourist destinations in Europe, sustainable and responsible tourism, the sharing economy and digitisation. The tourism industry in Europe is facing increased global competition, with emerging countries, less expensive, attracting international tourists. In the face of this competition, the adopted text calls for Europe to build on its comparative advantages, in particular the diversity of its landscapes and its extraordinary cultural richness. Pan-European and transnational tourism products are of the utmost importance for strengthening a common European profile. According to the European Tourism Commission (ETC), based on extensive market research, potential visitors to Europe are attracted to it by the range of experiences they can expect rather than by the number of countries they can visit.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon has brought greater recognition to the importance of tourism as one of the sectors with the most growth potential in the European economy, generating more than 10 % of European GDP. In view of the new challenges, Europe should adopt a differentiating strategy, highlighting its comparative advantages, in particular, in terms of the diversity of its landscapes and its extraordinary wealth and cultural heritage. Similarly, there should be a focus on promoting europe's destination in third markets and plans to create a common communication strategy, pan-European and transnational tourism products, as well as a single European portal presenting national tourist sites through a consensus policy with Member States. Finally, I would just like to stress that I support a European tourism strategy based on sustainability criteria, which is to say that, in this context, it is essential to promote initiatives that promote responsible resource management, with reliable indicators and initiatives that merit 'environmentally friendly' destinations. For the reasons listed above, I have given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the European Commission to present a comprehensive implementation report on the actions taken since 2013, which also includes the financial resources made available by these policies. The so-called 'Old Continent' has always been one of the most visited tourist destinations for tourists from all over the world, and we, as Europeans, have an obligation to bear this in mind, including from an economic point of view.  The report, therefore starting from this assumption, promotes the concept of Brand Europe: foreigners must leave to visit Europe, not just one of its countries. We must promote the European label in order to be stronger and more competitive. Hence the promotion of pan-European and transnational tourism products and a strong communication strategy that is equal to the times in which we live and therefore also points to the maximum digitisation of services, such as multimodal tickets, that is, a single ticket that includes different destinations. In this way the tourist will buy only one ticket for his European tour.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report calls on Member States to promote new tourist routes through the redevelopment of disused areas, roads, railways, abandoned paths and old routes, protecting endangered European monuments and sites in order to safeguard and promote cultural heritage and thus encourage tourism.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. In 2010, the Commission promoted the Communication entitled 'Europe, the world's first tourist destination: a new policy framework for European tourism'. In order for Parliament to judge the efficiency of the measures taken, the rapporteur calls on the Commission to submit a comprehensive implementation report, including the use of financial resources. The report also proposes a series of actions aimed at developing a common strategy for promoting Europe as a preferred tourist destination, taking into account economic, quality, sustainability, responsibility and technological innovation criteria, among others. However, while the report is interesting, it sneaks up a proposal for which we tabled a deletion amendment which was discarded in the vote. This proposal refers to the promotion of health tourism, which is not health tourism, i.e. in the face of the saturation of public health systems, promoting travel to use private assistance in other, cheaper countries. We believe that we cannot support a report which includes a measure that undermines one of our basic political principles: the defence of a quality public health system. We therefore voted against the report.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on tourism in Europe, which deals with a number of important aspects. Tourism is facing new challenges, particularly in the context of the development of new digital and communication technologies. I am therefore very glad that the report contains, inter alia, an important point on the removal of blocking of services on the basis of the geographical location of the user, the so-called geoblocking, which is widespread in the internal market. It thus makes it impossible to make full use of digital applications and services not only in the field of tourism. The text also emphasises the promotion of cultural tourism, including the promotion of European cultural trails. The report also sees the social dimension of tourism as being affordable and accessible to all population groups, including families with children, the elderly and people with disabilities.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, even considering that it is useful for Europe to work to define joint strategies in support of tourism, the rapporteur uses it as a platform to promote further liberalisation of the conditions of the sector (including support for new digital service platforms) expressly excluding any harmonisation (social, fiscal...) that curbs the effects of devastating competition. In addition, the text contains references to migration or the political situation in some of the EU's neighbouring countries which only reinforce the more regressive guidelines of the current CFSP.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the importance of tourism has been officially recognised. Tourism is one of the most important economic sectors for Italy, just think that, according to the most recent data of the World Tourism Organization, in 2013 it was the fifth most visited country in the world. The tourism industry as a whole would have contributed 9.4% of the country's GDP to EUR 147 billion, employing approximately 2.5 million people, or 10.9% of national employment.  In addition, two new forms of tourism are also developing in recent years: fish tourism and pescaturismo. According to the Centro studi di Lega Pesca, this type of "blue" tourism is set to increase by 3%. I therefore believe that the provision of tourist services must take into account the difficulties linked to climate change, the scarcity of water resources, the pressure on biodiversity and the risks that mass tourism entails for cultural heritage. In this respect, it is essential to encourage initiatives to promote sustainable tourism.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because it is for Member States to develop their own tourism sectors. There should not be the requirement to set up an EU tourist agency nor to promote Europe as a tourist brand.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Europe is currently the world's first tourist destination for tourists. However, global tourism trends are undergoing significant changes. It is expected that in 2030 Europe will be overtaken by globalisation by other continents. Tourism in the EU is under intense pressure from other international tourist destinations, especially from emerging and cheaper ones.  Tourism is the third branch of the economy in Europe (producing almost 10% of European GDP). Other sectors of the economy, such as agriculture, transport and culture, also benefit from tourism. Tourism plays a significant role in job creation. It is also crucial for the economic recovery of those countries that have been particularly affected by the economic crisis. Attention is also drawn to the fact that tourism is an area where SMEs are particularly active. They make up 99% of the industry. The challenges facing tourism in Europe are the effects of the following demographic changes, high youth unemployment rates, a change in consumer behaviour, an increase in demand for high-quality customer service, the need for digitisation.  The European institutions should take action to attract new investment, to initiate growth, to improve the business environment. European funds must support tourism in Europe. The issue of guaranteeing a well-functioning single market for services seems to be crucial. In addition, market trends must be keep up and the opportunities of the digital revolution must be exploited. Digitisation seems to be crucial for the development of tourism.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this report, highlighting the need for a tourism sector in Europe which is not only sustainable, but also accessible and responsible. I am so pleased to see an emphasis on the role of the SMEs and the need for investment in training and education in order to provide quality jobs. Crucially, this report recognises my party’s call for European legislation on tourism accommodation safety. Labour will continue to work with consumer groups, safety organisations and industry representatives to prevent rare, but devastating, cases where inadequate health and safety rules have led to tragedies including deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ Tourism is one of the key areas of potential growth of the European and Croatian economies, generating more than 10% of EU GDP if tourism-related sectors are also taken into account.  It is also a driver of large-scale employment, employing 13 million workers directly, representing at least 12% of jobs in the EU.  The contribution of tourism policy priorities is linked to the Juncker Commission's 3 priorities, i.e. sustainable growth and jobs, a connected digital single market and a better connected and fairer internal market. Sustainable, affordable and responsible tourism that is compatible with nature and the environment and urban destinations and based on resource efficiency, sustainable mobility and climate protection, helps protect the local environment, in particular mountainous and coastal regions and islands, leads to more lasting regional growth results and meets increasing passenger quality requirements, and helps businesses compete.  I think it is important to guarantee the development of sustainable, responsible and affordable tourism where natural resources would be used appropriately with new technologies for sustainable development, sustainable jobs and a stable economy. Lastly, I would like to emphasize the unfair neglect of cycling tourism, which brings considerable profit throughout the year.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it important that the European Parliament has formulated and agreed a report on new challenges and strategies in the field of tourism in Europe, thus supporting the maintenance of Europe's current position as the world's leading tourist destination. Comprehensive support for the tourism sector, which generates 10% of EU GDP and employs 13 million workers, not only contributes to sustainable economic growth and employment, but also highlights Europe's rich cultural diversity and strengthens Europe's identity. I appreciate the call on Member States, regions and businesses to make systematic and transparent use of new funding opportunities through eu structural funds and programmes. Improving coordination between Member States, together with increased involvement of digital infrastructure, is necessary to further develop this key sector of the European economy. I therefore also welcome the initiative to establish a European Year of Tourism and to consider the establishment of a European Tourism Agency to raise the profile of Europe as a whole, with an emphasis on protecting the diversity and uniqueness of europe's unique regions.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Tourism is a very important industry in Europe, providing huge jobs and potentially able to have a positive impact on economic growth. Tourism in Europe has a lot of potential, as we can offer health tourism, eco-tourism, green tourism and more.  I believe that tourism needs to be developed and invested in its further development and improvements. However, I would also like to stress here that we must also not forget consumers and their rights, as these must not be infringed and tourist services must provide the expected or promised level.  Although the development of tourism is very important, it is necessary to stimulate the economy in this area. As a Member of the Group of the Greens, I would like to emphasise another important aspect in promoting tourism in Europe. This is an appropriate protection of natural and cultural sites and awareness of the potential negative impacts that tourism can have on the environment.  I am thinking here, in particular, of national parks, mountains and other environmentally protected areas, which must not be exploited to an excessive extent by mass tourism, but must be treated with caution and common sense. I think the report is a good thing because it covers all the important aspects, which is why I voted in favour of it and supported it.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur asks the Commission for an opinion on the use of funds to date from support programmes such as the European Structural Funds and identifies a wide range of ways in which she believes That European tourism could be promoted at EU level. Apart from a few economically sensible points, such as the openness to the "sharing economy", the potential of which is recognized in the tourism sector in particular, the proposals are largely critical. For example, the Commission is being urged to explore the possibilities of creating a new budget line in the multiannual financial framework, which will be exclusively reserved for tourism promotion. This is also the subject of a call for an increase in the staffing level in the relevant departments of the EU Commission. The report also calls for an analysis of the potential of a new EU tourism agency to be created. The proclamation of a "tourism for all" principle, which is intended to ensure access to and affordability of such offers for a broad population, is also particularly critical. In this context, airlines are being asked to provide more seats in Economy Class, at the expense of higher-priced quotas. This call is a clear intervention in free pricing and the European economic order. Due to the many centralist tendencies mentioned, the rejection of the whole report remains the only conceivable option.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Tourism is a key sector of the European economy, generating up to 10% of EU GDP. Thanks to him, up to 13 million citizens have jobs. It is important to promote tourism because it creates jobs, produces profits and represents an important activity ensuring the social and economic development of both EU regions and countries. However, small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as family businesses, should receive all the more attention, as they are also very much involved in this development.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report because I believe that tourism is one of the key socio-economic activities that has a far-reaching impact on economic growth, social development and employment, and I think it could contribute more to solving the current economic crisis. Tourism is one of the key points of economic growth is evidenced by the fact that the sector generates more than 10% of EU GDP if tourism-related sectors are also taken into account.  Tourism is also a driver of employment, as it directly employs 13 million workers and, accordingly, accounts for around 12% of jobs in the EU. Also, coastal and maritime tourism represent the largest maritime activity in Europe and account for more than a third of the maritime economy. Furthermore, I believe that tourism plays a significant role in climate protection and the protection of the local environment, which also leads to long-term sustainable results that lead to positive trends in the economy.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The language used in the paragraph regarding the ‘uncontrolled influx of immigrants’ is unhelpful in the context of this report and the wider refugee crisis debate.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Tourism is one of the key areas of potential growth in the European economy, generating more than 10% of EU GDP if tourism-related sectors are also taken into account and is a driver of large-scale employment, as it directly employs 13 million workers and represents at least 12% of eu jobs accordingly. In Croatia alone, in 2014, employment in tourism increased by 12.6%.  It is also important to note that other European policies such as transport policy and the internal market have a major impact on tourism policy. The Commission therefore intends to ensure better integration of tourism into its many policies and to ensure that the sector makes full use of its competitiveness potential by adequately applying the legislation in force. I fully support this report because it foresees further development of the tourism sector, and as a citizen of a country where tourism is the main branch of the economy, I am aware of its importance, both for Croatia and for the entire European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new challenges and strategy for promoting tourism in Europe. With regard to the new challenges and the strategy for promoting tourism in Europe, I would like to highlight three things.  Firstly, tourism must not adversely affect the daily lives of the population. In tourism there is no place for the arrogance of the tourism industry towards the inhabitants in terms, be glad that we are here and give you work. Nor is it for the arrogance and irresponsibility of tourists in the sense, be glad to even come to you.
