Secondly, action plans and tourism strategies must have objectives and a roadmap, especially when they are financed from public funds. This is not the case, for example, in the Commission's action plan for the development of coastal and marine tourism. Without objectives and a roadmap, it is very difficult to assess the effectiveness and effectiveness of programmes and the use of public funds.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's report on new challenges and a strategy to promote tourism in Europe. I believe that it is absolutely right that the Treaties do not allow the uniform EU legislation to be adopted in the tourism sector, but I recognise that a certain degree of cooperation, exchange of experience or also the coordinated application of lessons learned from these experiences is appropriate, as to some extent the European Union as a whole is exposed to the competitive environment of other destinations in the world and this competitive environment needs to be responded to. Experience and improvements in the field of digital tourism services, for example, can then be harnessed at regional level, which is still primary, and its success is a prerequisite for a competitive European tourism policy.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this report as it makes general proposals on the promotion of common European strategies and products with a view to enhancing the development of quality, sustainable and social tourism. At the same time, it stresses the strengthening of coastal and maritime tourism and the need to combat seasonality, promote training and education and combat undeclared work.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 What is mentioned in the report is half-measures and does not lead to a substantial result in the tourism sector. In addition, the report stresses the importance of avoiding cultural discrimination between religious and ethnic minorities and finally supports mobility and cooperation projects with various programmes by making available funds which will unfortunately be used for the benefit of specific enterprises for the sole purpose of profit and not for the benefit of professionals and SMEs active in the tourism sector.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The tourism sector makes an estimated contribution of 10% to the EU’s GDP. It employs approximately 5.2% of the total workforce, corresponding to roughly 10 million jobs, involving 1.8 million businesses. Whereas other sectors in our economy still face difficulties, the tourism industry is one of the few sectors which continue to grow and create thousands of jobs in spite of the economic crisis. While acknowledging the opportunities provided by the tourism industry, we must also pay attention to the difficulties it is facing. Connectivity, sustainability, seasonality and shortage of skilled labour are few challenges which, if dealt with correctly, can help support the competiveness of our industry. These issues are addressed in the current report, which I voted in favour of. Along with those previously mentioned, the report also addresses the issues of sharing economy, digitisation, responsible tourism, and the promotion of Europe. Adopting this report sends a strong message of support from our Parliament to the tourism industry. Our investment will not go in vain, for it will help back the tourism sector, its competiveness and, ultimately, Europe’s position as the world’s number one tourist destination.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the provisions proposed by my eminent colleague, Mrs De Monte. Indeed, tourism is a key sector of the European economy, which has growth potential and generates more than 10% of the EU's GDP if tourism-related sectors are taken into account. Tourism is also an important driver of employment, directly employing 13 million workers, which accounts for at least 12% of employment in the EU.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which looks at possibilities for Europe to better promote itself as a tourist destination. Currently, Europe is the world’s number one tourist destination and the majority of trips abroad by EU residents remain within the EU. Tourism is extremely beneficial for the European economy and I think we could gain more of it if we, for instance, facilitate access to finance for companies working in this sector or encourage the digitalisation of our infrastructure. EU public money should be used for projects with clear European added value and so strengthen the development of cross—border tourism projects. In this respect, we should support the implementation of integrated and multimodal forms of transports which are strong incentives to cross-border tourism and a prerequisite for travelling.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs De Monte's report, which well describes the central role of tourism in the European economy because of its great growth potential, because it generates more than 10% of the EU's GDP and contributes decisively to reducing unemployment. The tourism industry in Europe is faced with new challenges, the development of digital sales and distribution channels, the sharing economy, the demand for quality services and the need to attract visitors, not only for the artistic heritage, but also for the competence and qualifications of operators. In order to respond to the new needs of a market facing very active and determined third-country actors, it is necessary for the Commission to continue to allocate resources to create an environment conducive to the development of businesses operating in the tourism sector, which can make full use of innovation and digital information technologies. We must insist that the Commission and the Council commit themselves to a genuine Integrated European Action Plan and dedicated investments in all programmes – Erasmus+, Social Fund, Creative Europe, but also Horizon 2020. The cuts in the 2016 budget for this sector are significant, I hope for a decisive change of course in the coming months.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on new challenges and strategies to promote tourism in Europe, as I believe that the tourism industry is facing increasing global competition as foreign tourists are attracted to cheaper countries.  With new strategies and challenges, Europe will remain competitive, it must reap its comparative advantages, in particular rural diversity and exceptional cultural wealth, and businesses will have to adapt to the age of digitisation.  The promotion of tourism will also bring new jobs, especially for young people.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. In 2010, the Commission promoted the Communication entitled 'Europe, the world's first tourist destination: a new policy framework for European tourism'. In order for Parliament to judge the efficiency of the measures taken, the rapporteur calls on the Commission to submit a comprehensive implementation report, including the use of financial resources. We believe that we cannot support a report which includes a measure that undermines one of our basic political principles: the defence of a quality public health system. We therefore voted against the report.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. In this report, the rapporteur asks the Commission for an opinion on the use of funds to date from support programmes such as the European Structural Funds and identifies a wide range of ways in which she believes That European tourism could be promoted at EU level. Apart from a few economically sensible points, such as the openness to the "sharing economy", the potential of which is recognized in the tourism sector in particular, the proposals are largely critical. For example, the Commission is being urged to explore the possibilities of creating a new budget line in the multiannual financial framework, which will be exclusively reserved for tourism promotion. This call is a clear intervention in free pricing and the European economic order. Due to the many centralist tendencies mentioned, the rejection of the whole report remains the only conceivable option.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Tourism is almost the only sector that performs well throughout Europe during and after the crisis, thus contributing to the national economic performance of the countries concerned. Two thirds of EU citizens are on holiday in one of the EU Member States, and around 50% of the revenues from world tourism are generated on the EU market. Tourism plays a major role in the economies of the European Union and the world: according to some measurements, this sector produces nine percent of the world's GDP and five percent of the European community's GDP. According to surveys, tourism provides nearly 20 million Jobs in Europe, four percent of the employment rate in European Member States. Therefore, the tourism sector needs more attention. The De Monte report is a great material, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. In 2010, the Commission promoted the Communication entitled 'Europe, the world's first tourist destination: a new policy framework for European tourism'. In order for Parliament to judge the efficiency of the measures taken, the rapporteur calls on the Commission to submit a comprehensive implementation report, including the use of financial resources. The report also proposes a series of actions aimed at developing a common strategy for promoting Europe as a preferred tourist destination, taking into account economic, quality, sustainability, responsibility and technological innovation criteria, among others.
