This proposal refers to the promotion of health tourism, which is not health tourism, i.e. in the face of the saturation of public health systems, promoting travel to use private assistance in other, cheaper countries. We believe that we cannot support a report which includes a measure that undermines one of our basic political principles: the defence of a quality public health system. We therefore voted against the report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report, since, although it incorporates a number of proposals to improve the tourism sector, it contains certain elements of criticism of measures taken by local authorities to ensure the control and quality of its tourist establishments.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on new challenges and concepts for the promotion of tourism in Europe. The tourism industry is facing increasing global competition, with emerging, less expensive countries attracting international tourists. Faced with this competition, Europe must play on its comparative advantages, in particular the diversity of its countryside and extraordinary cultural wealth. There are plans to create a genuine common communication strategy to identify Europe as a unique destination and to create a unique European portal introducing individual national websites, and I agree that an important step has been taken in this field. The resolution addresses several topics such as the branding/joint promotion of Europe as a quality tourist destination, pan-European and transnational tourism products, unlocking the potential of coastal and marine tourism, sustainable, responsible and social tourism, accessibility, sharing economy and the power of digitalisation, etc.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a report that focuses on issues such as sustainable and responsible tourism and digitization. The tourism industry is suffering from increasing global competition, with developing countries attracting international tourists. In the face of this, the report stresses the importance of the EU boosting its products and extraordinary cultural wealth, as well as pan-European and transnational tourism products in order to strengthen a common European profile. We are therefore talking about a report which seeks to strengthen tourism in Europe, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, even considering that it is useful for Europe to work to define joint strategies in support of tourism, the rapporteur uses it as a platform to promote further liberalisation of the conditions of the sector (including support for new digital service platforms) expressly excluding any harmonisation (social, fiscal...) that curbs the effects of devastating competition. In addition, the text contains references to migration or the political situation in some of the EU's neighbouring countries which only reinforce the more regressive guidelines of the current CFSP.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Written. The N-VA voted against this resolution today because of the over-the-counter measures. The tourism sector is in danger of being saddled with many new rules. Moreover, the principle of subsidiarity is not respected. Tourism policy is largely down to the Member States and regions. This is hardly highlighted in the resolution. The tourism sector is one of the most important economic sectors in the European Union. Small family businesses or SMEs are often active in the sector. We must give these companies every opportunity and not bury them under administrative obligations. Unfortunately, the resolution fails to strike the right balance between support for an important sector and all sorts of unnecessary issues. The sector does not need a new tourism agency, the sector does not need a new European budget line, the sector does not need another new label. The N-VA wants to give the tourism industry all the support, but we do not believe that this can be done by additional European rules. It is a missed opportunity for this resolution to fall into the time-honoured habit of centralised European bureaucracy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is based on a logic of promoting a European tourism scale, marketing for "Europe", and even a specific budget line, the creation of a European Tourism Agency defining a common European trade mark, etc. We note in the report a concern about the unstable situation of neighbouring countries and their impact on European tourism. It should be noted that all these issues, understanding their context, can easily slip into a more xenophobic and neocolonial logic, such as facilitating the entry to companies operating in the area of tourism in developing countries or refusing to take in refugees for reasons of "hygiene" of spots. We note as a positive the highlight given, in several points, to decent working conditions as a factor of quality and tourism appreciation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Due to the diversity of our continent, there are completely different motivations for tourists from country to country, why they are holidaying in the respective European country. A brand "Europe" is therefore meaningless. Moreover, the European Union has no significant competence in the tourism sector to justify the creation of such an agency for tourism. I therefore reject this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Tourism is one of Europe's main economic activities and is one of the areas with the greatest potential for growth. I voted in favour of this report because I consider tourism to be a resource that must be exploited to its full potential. Increasing resources and investment in infrastructure, simplifying standards and supporting sustainable tourism are key elements in structuring a long-term strategy that benefits the tourism sector and the european economy as a whole.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted against the report. While the promotion of tourism is certainly an important issue, it is not the competence of the European Union. The decision on measures to promote tourism should be dealt with directly by the regions and not by the European Union. That is why I rejected this report.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report, which the European Parliament is drawing up on its own initiative, stresses that Europe is the main destination for tourists from all over the world, with an estimated 140 million visitors each year by 2025. This necessitate action by the European Union to promote the economy of sharing, digitisation, sustainable and responsible tourism and to promote Europe as its main destination. To this end, it is necessary to strengthen cooperation between the Member States and the Commission and to report to the European Parliament on the use of tourism funds under the Structural Funds and relevant Union programmes. It is clear to me that the tourism sector in Europe is growing very rapidly and that action is needed to promote, protect and preserve Europe's cultural heritage – and I therefore supported the project.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: In writing. Tourism in Europe, which may seem secondary, is nevertheless an area that we need to take serious attention to. As the world's largest destination, Europe derives a great benefit from tourism by employing millions of citizens. As a promising sector for the future of Europe, tourism must be sustained and continue to develop qualitatively (taking into account the sustainable and responsible aspects), thanks in particular to new technologies that are taking an increasingly important part in the sector. For Europe to remain the world's leading tourist destination, this sector must be taken seriously by the European Union. That is why I voted in favour of the report

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. Tourism is a strategic sector for the EU: it accounts for 10% of GDP in the EU and is the world's first tourist destination. The European Union, despite the good numbers of tourists it has, knows perfectly well that the trend is changing. We face several challenges right now: First: to remain a competitive offer; emerging countries are increasing their market share progressively and are estimated to reach 57% market share in tourist reception by 2030. Secondly, a change in the behaviors of tourists. Demographic changes globally indicate that the number of people over the age of 65 by 2020 will be 1/5 of the world's population. This group is a potential goal, they have free time and in many cases economic capacity. Finally: potential tourists in emerging countries. Other issues facing the European Union are opening borders to potential tourists with high purchasing power. The granting of visas and exemption agreements should be made more flexible for those who demonstrate sufficient economic conditions.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The interests of the tourism industry seek to upgrade the report on "promoting tourism in Europe" voted against by the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece. "Branding", "Europe as a tourist destination", "pan-European and transnational tourism products" are projects of business groups active in the tourism sector who do not hesitate to use even "health" as an attraction for tourism, in order to continue their profitability unabated. The report calls for the use of "tourist visas" and "visa waiver agreements" at the same time as the EU steps up its crackdown on refugees and migrants, highlighting how its so-called "smart borders" that "open" or "close" depending on the interests of monopolies work. The xenophobic call for "a report on the impact on the tourism sector of the uncontrolled influx of migrants" is also unacceptable. Moreover, there is no mention of the miserable working conditions of workers in the sector who, after being "drained" their labour force, are again driven to unemployment, but also by the inability of the popular families to have a short vacation, since the popular right of holidays as long as monopolies dominate has become a luxury commodity for the business groups of the sector to treasure.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not give my vote to the De Monte report. Of course, the idea of promoting tourism in Europe is important, but it is equally important to preserve the cultural diversity of the individual countries of the European Union. I believe that tourism in the European Union can also be promoted without the need to create the so-called 'Destination Europe' label, which in itself evokes the idea of one destination, without emphasising that individual countries have much to offer in this area. This principle is further enhanced by proposals for the creation of special thematic routes, tours or products.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The importance of tourism for the European economy is best demonstrated by the figures. It generates around 10% of THE EU's GDP, and 13 million workers are directly employed in this sector, not counting the huge number of seasonal workers. However, our position as a leader in the global travel market is under threat, as globalisation processes and falling travel costs are rewarding other continents. So we have to face this challenge now and find a way to maintain and strengthen the current advantage. An interesting tool that can help in this is a new tourist brand promoting Europe as the direction of visits by foreign tourists. It should not compete with existing European national brands, but complement them in promoting tourism in regions whose visibility is still very low.  We must also make better use of the unique cultural heritage of our continent, including Christian heritage. Also, spa tourism, also thanks to the resorts in the Kuyavia-Pomeranian Voivodeship, has the potential to attract crowds of tourists from other continents. The Internet and new technologies offer a great opportunity to reach new customers with a European tourist offer, and the sharing economy offers new tools to take advantage of this offer. It is important that the digital single market that is currently being designed takes into account these needs and the potential of the tourism industry. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's vote because tourism is a key sector for the growth of the European Union economy: it already generates more than 10% of European GDP and employs 13 million workers, or 12% of the Union's jobs. For this reason, I would like to stress the call for the Commission to take action to improve coordination between Member States, regional and local authorities and financial institutions, as well as to create a deeper synergy between the public and private tourism sectors. The Union is the world's first tourist destination, with a market share of 52%, and precisely because of the importance that tourism has in our economy, I think it is only right that a section entirely devoted to the tourist economy should be included in the next financial programming: in this way, tourism would rightly be regarded as an individual economic activity also in terms of budget. I would also like to stress the need to promote and protect the diversity of European tourism: certainly to support and enhance maritime tourism, which is the most important, but also to support mountain and cultural tourism, which occupy important market shares.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is based on a logic of promoting a tourism scale that is "continental", noting that a very significant percentage of world tourism (52%) is in Europe. It emphasises a common European Union approach, a common European position, the establishment of a marketing for "Europe", a specific budget line, the establishment of a European Tourism Agency, the definition of a common European brand, pan-European products, the promotion of a European identity and a common cultural heritage, a system for classifying tourism infrastructure , a European System of Indicators and the definition of European quality standards for tour guides. In part, the report asks the European Commission to assess the impact that the uncontrolled flow of immigrants into the EU has on the sector. All these issues can easily slip into a more xenophobic and neocolonial logic, such as the refusal to take in refugees for reasons of "hygiene" of the spots. One of the positive issues to be highlighted is the reference, in several points, to decent working conditions as a factor of quality and tourism appreciation. Given that there are both positive and negative aspects, we abstained.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which addresses the issue of promoting tourism in Europe as a factor for economic growth and sustainable and responsible development.  The Treaty of Lisbon gave the European Union a greater role in the tourism sector and provided for the EU to support, integrate and coordinate member states' actions. However, since 2013, the Commission has stopped drawing up implementation plans and it is difficult to assess their progress. For this reason, the text requires a report to verify the actions taken, in order to clarify the use made of financial resources. I am convinced that the resources allocated in the field of tourism have been derisory and have not enabled the EU to effectively achieve the objective of developing and relaunching the sector.  In committee, we at the M5S obtained the promotion and protection of "Made in" brands, in order to avoid penalising the many Italian excellences that have always attracted tourists. Among the topics addressed that I welcome are the enhancement of coastal and maritime tourism, the promotion of sustainable, responsible and social tourism, the sharing economy and digitalization.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. From 2 to 27 November, the International Communications Union holds a World Conference on Radiocommunications (WRC-15) in Geneva. It will address the proposal – under study and evaluated favorably by the International Civil Aviation Organization – to assign a specific frequency band in the radio spectrum for global flight monitoring.  Currently only 30% of the world's air navigation consists of a satellite tracking system, which prevents the location or rescue of an aircraft in the event of an accident. Tragedies such as Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 or Air France AF447 show the need for commercial flight tracking systems to be unaffected by a normal on-board power outage and cannot be deactivated from the flight. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution, which urges the European Commission to take the necessary measures for the allocation of the radio spectrum band necessary to support the future development of a global satellite flight monitoring system that meets these characteristics.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The purpose of the oral question at the origin of this motion for a resolution was to seek the Commission's opinion on a new satellite-based air traffic control surveillance system (the "Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast"). This system is more efficient in many ways than today's ground systems that use radar technology.  However, problems remain and trials are under way in several Eu-Eu Member States, including France. Despite this, the European Parliament is asking the Commission to take charge of this issue and to put in place regulations that are specific to this system. This haste is unjustified, especially since there is an International Civil Aviation Organization responsible for ensuring the proper coordination of states in aviation safety.  I therefore voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ It is not for the European Union to instruct aviation companies of member states on how they should conduct their own business.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on the development of satellite technology with a view to the operation of global flight tracking systems. The tragic events involving Air France flight AF447 (1 June 2009) and Malaysia airlines flight MH370 (8 March 2014) have highlighted the need for new systems to be introduced to determine the situation of public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote areas. The use of global air traffic management surveillance systems will facilitate the detection of the aircraft's location in the event of abnormal operation, emergency or accident. I welcome the Commission's action to rapidly develop a results-based global flight tracking system that will allow air navigation service providers to determine the situation of public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote areas. The operation of such a system should not be disrupted even in the event of a normal power supply interruption on board the aircraft and should not provide for any possibility of disabling it during flight.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The tragedies of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and Air France Flight 447 have shown the limitations of current air navigation systems that have failed to identify and locate distressed aircraft on time. As a result, search, rescue and recovery operations have been seriously hampered. Flight tracking systems currently cover only 30% of the airspace. Public confidence in air travel must be preserved through the use of advanced technologies. The satellite tracking system is one of them. It would enable governments, air navigation service providers and airlines in Europe and the rest of the world to strengthen air traffic management and increase efficiency, and significantly improve aviation safety.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution to sustain the future development of satellite technology that allows global flight tracking systems. I support the Commission's measures to develop a global flight monitoring system based on the results enabling air navigation service providers to determine the position of commercial flights at all times.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to develop technology using satellites to track aircraft in flight worldwide in remote areas where ground systems are insufficient. The ADS-B is an instrument that would replace the current radar system and allows the identification of aircraft as well as the knowledge of its precise position. However, technical problems remain as aircraft that have this system will not be able to see aircraft that do not have it. Moreover, doubts remain about its computer security. Nevertheless, it is essential that the Member States give a definitive opinion on this system since it has been the subject of experimentation in France in particular.  So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is of fundamental importance for the safety of air transport that continuous and efficient monitoring of flights anywhere in the world is guaranteed, so as to know at all times the position of public transport aircraft. I therefore voted in favour of the call for the Commission to take all necessary measures for the development of a global satellite flight monitoring system.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this document on the development of satellite technology for the use of global flight monitoring systems. The tragedies involving Air France Flight AF447 and Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 have highlighted the urgent need for an upgrade of systems for the identification and monitoring of public transport aircraft. A comprehensive monitoring system is therefore necessary to ensure a prompt response in the event of emergencies, search or rescue.  Action must also be taken to identify safer routes that are less harmful to the environment. At the moment only 30% of global airspace is subject to monitoring, but it should be noted that satellite communications-supported technologies are already available (or under advanced study) and that the European satellite industry is able to play a central role in the development of these technological systems.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution recommends that the Commission take steps towards developing a satellite-based global flight-tracking system to replace the current radar locations system which has a much more limited scope. This would enable the location of aircraft at all times, even in remote locations such as long-haul flights over oceans or desert areas. This technology would also be of assistance in avoiding situations such as the Air France AF447 and Malaysia Airlines MH370 tragedies, and would improve the effectiveness of search and rescue operations and investigations. The resolution also calls for a discussion at the World Radiocommunication Conference in November about allocating a specific radio spectrum to support this technology. I therefore voted for the resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the development of a satellite technology that underpins global flight tracking systems because the latest tragedies, namely Malaysia Airlines and Air France 447 flights, in which hundreds of people have lost their lives, prove to us that new instruments are needed to make the air system more robust and capable of avoiding future dangers to passengers. It is necessary for the competent institutions to find the best solutions to provide passengers and aviation personnel with the safest travel conditions. Without a conjugated action we cannot prevent, but only ascertain the effects and this can only be done by using advanced technologies!

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution supporting the Commission's action to rapidly develop an efficient global flight monitoring system that will allow air navigation service providers to determine the position of a public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote locations. The Commission is invited to take the necessary measures with regard to the allocation of the radio spectrum band necessary to support the future development of a global satellite flight monitoring system.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on the allocation by the World Radio Conference, to be held in Geneva from 2 to 27 November 2015 (WRC-15), of the radio spectrum band necessary to support the future development of satellite technology for the use of global flight monitoring systems. Indeed, following recent tragedies in the field of civil aviation, it has become clear that new systems need to be put in place to establish the position of a public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote places. In addition to facilitating the location of aeroplanes, some global air traffic management surveillance systems (ATMs) do not have the possibility of being affected by a loss of energy on board the aircraft, nor are they disabled during flight. The report highlighted the importance of these mechanisms, which are capable of making search and rescue operations, as well as subsequent investigations, more efficient. I therefore voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution for the development of satellite-based technology to enable global flight tracking systems.  The resolution asks the Commission to take steps towards developing a satellite-based global flight-tracking system to replace the current radar locations system (which has a much more limited scope). This would enable the location of aircraft at all times, even in remote locations (in this context, the resolution makes reference to the Air France AF447 and Malaysia Airlines MH370 tragedies). The resolution also calls for a discussion at the World Radiocommunication Conference in November about allocating a specific radio spectrum to support this technology. (As an aside, the tech suggested – ADS-B – is already compulsory in Australia, and widely used in North America, China, the UAE and parts of Europe).

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because recent tragedies, such as those of flights AF447 and MH370, involving passenger airplanes, showed us the great need for better aviation safety regulations and prevention systems. We must provide grounds for the creation of better tracking systems which will allow us to have better control and knowledge of what is happening on board an aircraft. The resolution also takes into consideration the safety and concerns of all airspace users.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Global flight tracking systems currently cover only 30% of global air traffic, and in order to implement this system, the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) must provide a corresponding bandwidth allocation for the required radio spectrum.  This resolution calls on the Commission to take action to make commitments to this effect and to support the development of this technology by arriving at regulation. I voted in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe we do need a tracking system in all aircrafts. After the tragedy of Malaysian Airlines 370 and all the events before and since, there is no excuse for such a system not to be present. While radar is able to cover most flights, once a flight is out of range or over a sea, it is flying blind. I hope we will agree an international GPS tracking protocol soon for all our safety.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution supports the Commission's action aimed at the rapid development of a performance-based global flight tracking system that will allow air navigation service providers to identify the location of a public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote areas.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because the tragedies involving Air France Flight AF447 and Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 have highlighted the need to put in place new systems to determine the position of public transport aircraft at all times, including in remote locations. Furthermore, I think it is very important that through this overall air traffic management surveillance systems are facilitated in determining the position of an aircraft in the event of abnormal behaviour, an emergency situation or an accident and, more importantly, these systems could also be an important tool for increasing aviation safety and reducing infrastructure costs. Finally, I fully support the Commission's action to rapidly develop the global performance-based flight tracking system, which will allow air navigation service providers to determine the position of public transport aircraft at all times, even in distant locations.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of developing satellite technology for the use of global flight monitoring systems because, in view of the tragedies involving Air France Flight AF447 on 1 June 2009 and Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 on 8 March 2014, I consider it strictly necessary to introduce new systems to establish the position of a public transport aircraft at any time , even in remote places. Furthermore, I believe that such surveillance systems can increase the level of safety, as they will facilitate the location of an aircraft in the event of abnormal behaviour, emergency or accident. It is also necessary to establish close cooperation between all stakeholders in order to ensure the creation of effective and high-quality systems.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution is being tabled on behalf of the TRAN Committee and is linked to an oral question to the Commission on the implementation of satellite technologies to ensure overall flight traceability.  Traceability systems currently cover only 30% of global air traffic. One of the best technologies currently available is called "Satellite ADS-B" (Automatic Dependent Surveillace - Broadcast) and has been identified as such by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). However, in order to implement this system, the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) must provide a corresponding bandwidth allocation for the required radio spectrum. This will be discussed at the next World Radio Conference in 2015 (WRC15).  The resolution calls on the Commission to take action to make commitments to this effect and to support the development of this technology by arriving at regulation. I can only vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. From 2 to 27 November, the International Communications Union holds a World Conference on Radiocommunications (WRC-15) in Geneva. It will address the proposal – under study and evaluated favorably by the International Civil Aviation Organization – to assign a specific frequency band in the radio spectrum for global flight monitoring.  Currently only 30% of the world's air navigation consists of a satellite tracking system, which prevents the location or rescue of an aircraft in the event of an accident. Tragedies such as Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 or Air France AF447 show the need for commercial flight tracking systems to be unaffected by a normal on-board power outage and cannot be deactivated from the flight. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution, which urges the European Commission to take the necessary measures for the allocation of the radio spectrum band necessary to support the future development of a global satellite flight monitoring system that meets these characteristics.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with flight tracking systems. As of today these systems cover only around 30% of the global airspace, corresponding to the national territory. There is no coverage overseas or in the desert.  The International Civil Aviation Organization has identified satellite ADS-B as one of the technologies that can assist flight tracking outside of the most densely populated areas where other forms of terrestrial aircraft tracking systems are limited. Through this resolution Parliament asks for the opinion of the Commission on the necessity to make the radio spectrum band allocation. I support this initiative because of a number of aspects including the security dimension, hence I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution calls on Member States to step up the use of satellite technology to track aircraft and assist in the location of aircraft in distress. The tragedies of Malaysia Airlines flights 370 and Air France 447 have highlighted the weaknesses of current air navigation systems. Currently, only 30% of the world's airspace is covered by satellites, which significantly complicates search and rescue efforts during abnormal aircraft behaviour or accidents.  The European Parliament proposes to allocate a specific radio frequency for these monitoring satellites and calls on the European Commission to promote this system ahead of the World Conference on Radiocommunications (WRC-15) in Geneva in November. Considering that the safety of air transport is a priority in terms of the development of air traffic, the safety of citizens and the threat of terrorism, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Aircraft crashes in previous years have shown that flight control systems need to be improved. This development can be made with satellite technology that can track aircraft anywhere on Earth, and the authorities will be informed of any problem immediately. Thanks to the global system, civil aviation safety and the amount of data that can be extracted during investigations can be increased to shed light on the circumstances of the accident, thus preventing further accidents. Therefore, as a member of the Fidesz delegation in the People's Party, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Aircraft crashes in previous years have shown the need to improve flight control systems. This development can be made with satellite technology that can track aircraft anywhere on Earth, and the authorities will be informed of any problem immediately. Thanks to the global system, civil aviation safety and the amount of data that can be extracted during investigations can be increased to shed light on the circumstances of the accident, thus preventing further accidents. Therefore, as a member of the Fidesz delegation in the People's Party, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution concerned the development of technology using satellites to track aircraft in flight worldwide. While the oral question only asked for an opinion from the Commission on this, the motion for a resolution gives it the power to set up this system. In addition to a very high cost, this system, which does not seem to be a priority, has many drawbacks. Thus, by digitizing aircraft flight data, this system opens the door to numerous bugs, hacks, and manipulations of information of all kinds, both by terrorists and by unscrupulous interests. While conventional transponders and radar systems have been working quite well for more than half a century, this measure does not seem appropriate. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of technology to deal with situations of abnormal behaviour of public transport aircraft can contribute to the timely rescue of human lives in the event of an accident but also prevent criminal acts.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Aircraft crashes in previous years have shown that flight control systems need to be improved. This development can be made with satellite technology that can track aircraft anywhere on Earth, and the authorities will be informed of any problem immediately. Thanks to the global system, civil aviation safety and the amount of data that can be extracted during investigations can be increased to shed light on the circumstances of the accident, thus preventing further accidents. Therefore, as a member of the Fidesz delegation in the People's Party, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The tragedies of Air France AF447 and Malaysia Airlines MH370 have highlighted the need to adopt new systems to determine the position of passenger transport aircraft at any time, even in remote locations. These Global Air Traffic Management (ATM) surveillance systems will make it easier to determine the location of aircraft in the event of abnormal, emergency or crash behaviour, should not be affected by the loss of normal electricity on board and should not be able to be disabled during flight. I agree with the development of a system based on the performance of global flight tracking that allows air navigation service providers to determine at any time the position of passenger transport aircraft, even in remote locations, and should be developed through strong cooperation between all stakeholders.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better security of aviation safety.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution aims to implement/improve a satellite system that allows the position of passenger transport aircraft to be determined at any time, even in remote locations, considering recent tragic episodes. To this end, the resolution calls on the European Commission to take the necessary measures with a view to the next World Radio Conference (WRC-15), to be held in Geneva in November 2015, with regard to the allocation of the radio spectrum needed to support the future development of this system. If there are already some such systems, a finer assessment of their possibilities and limitations should be carried out, and it is true that the purposes set out in the resolution appear relevant and appropriate, in line with fair concerns relating to the safety of passengers and crew of air transport. In this chapter, there would be many factors that would be of interest to deepen (although it is understandably not appropriate to do so in this resolution), which could interfere with the security of this mode of transport, particularly in terms of the effects of liberalisation and privatisation of the sector, the monopolistic concentration associated with it and the attack on rights, wages and jobs that underlies it. It is also certain that the use of this type of technology carries risks related to the possibility of its dual use, which should not be ignored.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe we need to develop global flight tracking systems.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the tragedies associated with Air France flight AF447 and Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 stressed the need to introduce new systems for the continuous positioning of public transport aircraft, including in remote locations. The systems in question will improve the effectiveness of search and rescue operations and investigations, as the current flight tracking systems cover only around 30% of global airspace. It is therefore necessary to support the European Commission's actions aimed at rapidly establishing a global performance-based flight tracking system that allows air navigation service providers to continuously determine the location of passenger transport aircraft.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the rapid development of a performance-based global flight tracking system that will allow air navigation service providers to locate the location of a public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote areas. However, as the use of technology to deal with situations of abnormal behaviour of public transport aircraft can contribute to the timely saving of human lives in the event of an accident but also prevent criminal situations, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering recent airplane accidents, it is clear that there are vulnerabilities in the current air navigation systems that hamper timely identification and localisation of aircraft in distress. This issue must be addressed as soon as possible in order to avoid tragedies in the future. I therefore support technologies, like the Satellite ADS-B (Automatic Dependent Surveillance – Broadcast), that can help governments, air navigation service providers, as well as airlines in Europe and around the world to increase air traffic management efficiency and capacity, and significantly enhance aviation safety, all while lowering infrastructure costs. I therefore support the call to eliminate regulatory barriers to satellite-based flight—tracking systems, a technology that can provide life-saving services for EU citizens, and the allocation of the necessary radio spectrum band to support the future development of satellite-based technology to enable global flight—tracking systems.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the tragedy of Air France flight AF447 and Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 has highlighted the need to put in place new systems to ensure that the position of aircraft involved in air transport can be determined at all times, even in remote locations, and that these global air traffic control systems make it easier to determine the position of aircraft in the event of abnormal behaviour, emergency or accident. I support the Commission's action to rapidly develop a performance-based global system for the monitoring of flights, enabling air navigation service providers to determine the current situation of aircraft involved in public transport, even in remote locations. I would like to stress that this system must remain operational even in the event of a normal on-board power failure and should not offer the possibility of shuting down the system in flight. I believe that the development of such a system should be carried out through close cooperation between all stakeholders (e.g. industry, airlines, air navigation service providers, air safety and rescue services, aviation safety investigation authorities and international organisations).

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the finding, following the tragedies of Malaysia Airlines' AF447 and MH370 flights, of the need to establish new systems for determining the position of commercial flights at all times. I therefore support EU measures to rapidly develop a global flight tracking system.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Past tragedies such as Air France flight 447 and Malaysia-Airline flight have shown that we need to make travel safer for our citizens. That is why I have today advocated a new system for locating aircraft worldwide.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Flight—tracking systems today cover only around 30% of global airspace, corresponding to national territory. There is no coverage over seas or deserts. The tragic events involving Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 clearly show the need for a system that allows flights to be tracked at all times, including in remote areas.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ The Air France AF447 and Malaysia Airlines MH370 tragedies have proven that the current radar location system has not enabled location of flights in distress, thus seriously hindering rescue operations. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution that calls for the development of satellite-based technology that would enable flight tracking at global level.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Technology that not only tracks aircraft in flight in areas not covered by radar or is poorly covered and enhances aviation safety looks promising. We also think, alas, of the facilities to find planes damaged at sea or lost. What is less so, however, is to ask the Commission at this stage to intervene. Because this technology is in the experimental stage, especially in France, and it has many shortcomings. This includes security deficiencies, as hackers claim to be able to obtain flight data, including passenger data, and consider it largely feasible to generate ghost tracks or on the contrary to hide illegal flights, scramble signals, etc. Not to mention, as with all "communicative" technologies, the other side of the coin: potential malicious or intrusive use. It is first and foremost up to the national authorities and the International Civil Aviation Organization to decide on the feasibility, viability and safety of this new surveillance system before Brussels intervenes.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this motion for a resolution tabled by the Chairman of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Current air navigation systems do not, in many cases, allow difficult aircraft to be detected and located in time. Flight tracking systems now cover only 30% of the world's airspace, significantly impairing the effectiveness of search, rescue and recovery operations. To address this limitation we have technology such as satellites with automatic dependent surveillance - broadcasting ("Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast" or ADS-B), the use of which would help governments, air navigation service providers and European and global airlines to increase air traffic efficiency and management capacity, and significantly improve aviation safety , while reducing infrastructure costs. The rapporteur proposes removing regulatory barriers to satellite flight tracking systems in order to provide EU citizens with life-saving services.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Aircraft crashes in recent years have demonstrated the need to improve flight control systems. This development can be made with satellite technology that can track aircraft anywhere on Earth and immediately notify the authorities of any problems. Thanks to the global system, civil aviation safety can be enhanced and the amount of data that can be extracted during investigations is increased, which explains the circumstances of the accident, thus preventing further accidents. As a member of the Fidesz delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion in favour of rapidly developing a performance-based global flight tracking system that will enable air navigation service providers to determine the position of public transport aircraft at all times, even in remote locations. I agree with the aim to increase safety by facilitating the recovery of information for the purposes of civil aviation safety investigations and improving flight recorder performance and handling.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a resolution on the development of satellite technology with a view to establishing a global flight tracking system, as I believe that after many plane accidents in the last ten years, public air transport monitoring and allocation systems really need to be improved at all times. Likewise, in any emergency situation or accident in the air, it will be possible to react and provide assistance as soon as possible, even when all options on the plane are disabled and there would be a lack of electricity. Satellite ADS-B technology based on communication between planes and satellites is a promising option for developing a successful global surveillance system.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. At the origin of this motion for a resolution is an oral question whose purpose was to seek the Commission's opinion on a new air traffic control surveillance system using satellites (the "Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast").  This system is more efficient in many ways than today's ground systems that use radar technology. However, problems persist and trials are under way in several Member States, starting with France. Nevertheless, the European Parliament has asked the Commission to take charge of this issue and to put in place a regulation specific to this system. This haste is unjustified, especially since there is an International Civil Aviation Organization responsible for ensuring the proper coordination of states in aviation safety.  So I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution of my colleague Michel Cramer, which supports the Commission's work to set up a global flight tracking system. The implementation of the necessary satellite technology should not be restricted by the lack of frequency allocation, as underlined in this motion for a resolution. The motion for a resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this resolution as we are today called upon to identify weaknesses in current air traffic control systems and, if technically possible, to close them as soon as possible. It is a question of locating distressed aircraft in good time in order to initiate effective search and rescue operations. Today, existing systems cover only about 30% of global airspace. In order to improve aviation safety, therefore, the use of state-of-the-art technologies is needed, while at the same time removing existing regulatory barriers to satellite-based flight tracking systems in order to ensure the safety of citizens.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the development of satellite technology to track aircraft in flight worldwide. While the oral question merely sought the opinion of the European Commission on a new system for monitoring air traffic control using satellites, the motion for a resolution gives the Commission the power to set up this system. Even though tests are under way in several Member States, including France, and there is an International Civil Aviation Organisation to ensure good coordination between states in terms of safety, it is not desirable for the Commission to take charge of this issue.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. From 2 to 27 November, the International Communications Union holds a World Conference on Radiocommunications (WRC-15) in Geneva. It will address the proposal – under study and evaluated favorably by the International Civil Aviation Organization – to assign a specific frequency band in the radio spectrum for global flight monitoring.  Currently only 30% of the world's air navigation consists of a satellite tracking system, which prevents the location or rescue of an aircraft in the event of an accident. Tragedies such as Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 or Air France AF447 show the need for commercial flight tracking systems to be unaffected by a normal on-board power outage and cannot be deactivated from the flight. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution, which urges the European Commission to take the necessary measures for the allocation of the radio spectrum band necessary to support the future development of a global satellite flight monitoring system that meets these characteristics.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The air accidents of Air France and Malaysia Airlines have highlighted the need to create a new system that would determine the position of the aircraft at all times. Such global air traffic control would allow for timely identification and locating of aircraft at risk. It supports the actions of the Commission, which is rapidly developing a global flight monitoring system. Such a system should remain active even after the loss of electricity and eliminates the possibility of deactivation during flight. Satellite technology of an automatic dependent aircraft surveillance system is important for the development of global surveillance of ATM systems. It calls on the Commission to take the necessary steps to meet the World Radiocommunication Conference to be held in Geneva in 2015.  I supported the European Parliament's resolution, as it is necessary to find a way to take more efficient search and rescue actions, as existing flight tracking systems cover only 30% of airspace.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Promoting the security of citizens is one of the most important tasks of any national or other human-oriented entity. In particular, in this case, the call to the International Telecommunication Union, at its closest conference in Geneva, to examine the possibility of a special frequency to be used for the development of satellite technology for the implementation of global flight surveillance systems, is very important and welcome. There are already a variety of Internet-based services in the world, thanks to which any online user is free enough to know the information about any aircraft registered in the database. Nowadays, for a few decades now, there has been an opportunity to fully embrace the world through surveillance systems of different formats – which is, of course, already being done, especially in the military. Therefore, it certainly should have been a long time ago to create something like this, rather than "wait" for the same Flights of Air France AF447 or Malaysia Airlines MH370. On the way out of what has been said above and in the draft resolution itself, it is clear that this vote, with all due respect to the others, was one of the most important.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Proposal on distribution by the World Radioconsuation Conference, to be held in Geneva from 2 to 27 November 2015 (WRC-15), the necessary spectrum of radio frequencies to support the future development of satellite technology with a view to achieving global flight tracking systems, because it is complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 29/10/2015.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The development of a performance-based global flight path tracking system, which enables air navigation services to determine the position of commercial aircraft at any time, is, in my view, welcome, as it is an important approach to air traffic control.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The purpose of the oral question at the origin of this motion for a resolution was to seek the Commission's opinion on a new satellite-based air traffic control surveillance system (the "Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast"). This system is more efficient in many ways than today's ground systems that use radar technology.  However, problems persist and trials are under way in several Eu-Eu Member States, including France. Despite this, the European Parliament is asking the Commission to take charge of this issue and to put in place specific regulations for this system. This haste is unjustified, especially since there is an International Civil Aviation Organization responsible for ensuring the proper coordination of states in aviation safety. I therefore voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Commission's initiative to develop satellite technology capable of using global flight tracking systems, determining its position at any time. The tragedies of the Air France flight on 1 June 2009 and the Malaysia Airlines flight on 8 March 2014 have brought the need to develop and adopt new systems to locate flights even in more remote areas. I therefore presented my vote in agreement with the European Parliament's motion for a resolution.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as the World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva appears to be an apt opportunity to explore the idea of a new system to track aircraft, as recent tragedies have exposed the shortcomings of the current systems in place.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of a resolution on the development of a technology to enable the creation of a global flight tracking system. The purpose of this satellite technology is to locate aircraft at any time and anywhere in the world. In light of the recent tragedies of aircraft that have disappeared in flight, the development of such technology is essential to facilitate search and rescue operations. It should also provide rapid responses to the families of those on missing or crashed aircraft.  The European Parliament is therefore in favour of the development of such technology and asks the Commission to set the frequencies reserved for it, in order to avoid interference. I am pleased that the development of this technology can eventually enable the location of public transport aircraft even when they fly over remote or even desert areas. In the current light, making aviation safety a priority is more important than ever. I therefore welcome and support the Union's action to ensure ever greater safety for travellers.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Flight-tracking systems today cover only around 30% of global airspace, corresponding to national territory. There is no coverage over seas or deserts. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has identified satellite ADS-B as one of the technologies that can assist flight tracking outside of the most densely—populated areas where other forms of terrestrial aircraft tracking systems are limited. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's draft resolution tabled by the Committee on Transport and Tourism proposes that Parliament support the Commission's action to rapidly develop a performance-based global system for the monitoring of flights, enabling air navigation service providers to determine the current situation of aircraft involved in public transport.  It points out that this system should remain operational even in the event of a normal on-board power failure and should not allow the system to be disabled in flight. Finally, it recommends that the Commission take the necessary steps to support the future development of a satellite system for the global monitoring of flights in view of the forthcoming World Conference on Radio Communications in Geneva in November 2015. I supported the proposal.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to develop technology using satellites to track aircraft in flight worldwide in remote areas where ground systems are insufficient. The ADS-B is an instrument that would replace the current radar system and allows the identification of aircraft and the knowledge of their precise position. However, technical problems remain as aircraft that have this system will not be able to see aircraft that do not have it. Moreover, doubts remain about its computer security.  Nevertheless, it is essential that the Member States give a definitive opinion on this system since it has been the subject of experimentation in France in particular.  So I decided to vote for it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion for a resolution on the allocation by the World Radiocommunication Conference, to be held in Geneva from 2 to 27 November 2015 (WRC-15), of the necessary radio spectrum band to support the future development of satellite-based technology to enable global flight-tracking systems.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – This resolution recommends that the Commission take steps towards developing a satellite-based global flight-tracking system, to replace the current radar locations system, which has a much more limited scope. This would enable the location of aircraft at all times, even in remote locations such as long-haul flights over oceans or desert areas. This technology would also be of assistance in avoiding situations such as the Air France AF447 and Malaysia Airlines MH370 tragedies, and would improve the effectiveness of search and rescue operations and investigations. The resolution also calls for a discussion at the World Radiocommunication Conference in November about allocating a specific radio spectrum to support this technology. I therefore voted for the resolution

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The oral question on the development of satellite-based technology for systems for the worldwide positioning of aircraft aims to control the unexplained disappearance of passenger aircraft, as has been the case time and again in the past, through a new technology for the worldwide positioning of aircraft. I would have supported this new regulation, because the need for such a system is obvious.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is essential that the position of an aeroplane can be determined at any time during its flight in order to respond as soon as possible in the event of an emergency.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – As aircraft volumes grow, it is also necessary to improve and introduce new systems to determine the situation of public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote areas.  It is essential to ensure that systems do not interrupt the normal power supply on board the aircraft. In addition, there should be no possibility of disabling them during flight.  It should be noted that ADS-B technology based on communication between aircraft and satellites is one of the promising opportunities for developing a global air traffic management surveillance system. However, the change of any system that directly affects air transport poses a serious security risk, regardless of the type of aircraft. It is therefore essential to ensure the interoperability of alternative technologies when implementing the new system.  It should be noted that the safety and accuracy of radio communications are of great importance both during the period of system integration and in the fully operational system. Therefore, in order to avoid any interference, an appropriate radio frequency band must be allocated to the new technology.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒in 2012 Existing flight tracking systems cover only a third of the airspace and therefore it is necessary to increase this percentage of coverage. Several plane crashes, which we have witnessed recently, make it clear that it is necessary to develop a system that will allow us to track aircraft at any time and place.  The exact location of the aircraft is a necessary precondition for the protection of human lives in emergency situations or in the event of an accident. The satellite tracking system must be independent from other technologies and function in all circumstances. That is why I call on the International Communication Union to award the necessary radio spectrum belt at the World Radiocommunication Conference in November this year.  The allocation of radio spectrum is the first step in the development of an independent flight tracking system in the entire airspace. Air transport of passengers and goods is constantly increasing. As a result, further efforts are needed to keep this form of transport one of the safest and continue to enjoy high passenger confidence.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to develop technology using satellites to track aircraft in flight worldwide in remote areas where ground systems are insufficient. The ADS-B is an instrument that would replace the current radar system and allows the identification of aircraft and the knowledge of their precise position. However, technical problems remain as aircraft that have this system will not be able to see aircraft that do not have it. Moreover, doubts remain about its computer security. Nevertheless, it is essential that the Member States give a definitive opinion on this system since it has been the subject of experimentation in France in particular. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Following the tragedies of Air France flight AF447 (1 June 2009) and Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 (8 March 2014), it became clear that new systems needed to be introduced to determine the position of passenger aircraft at all times, even when in remote locations. The way this is done correctly underlines a report by my colleague Cramer to whom I have expressed my support. Measures should be taken to ensure that the issue of timely allocation of an appropriate radio spectrum is not a factor holding back the development of ADS-B technology.  Also, urgent development of an efficiency-based global flight tracking system is needed that will allow air navigation service providers to determine the position of passenger aircraft at all times, even when they are in remote locations. Such a system should function even in the event of an aircraft's power outage and there should be no possibility of disabling it during flight. In doing so, the development of such a system requires strong cooperation between all stakeholders (e.g. industry, airlines, air navigation service providers, security and rescue services, security investigation authorities and international organisations).

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In light of the tragedies of Air France Flight AF447 in 2009, and Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in 2014, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.  I believe that the use of new global flight monitoring systems (ADS-B technology) can significantly facilitate the location of an aircraft in the event of abnormal behaviour, emergency or accident. In addition, the use of such technologies would greatly improve the effectiveness of search and rescue operations even in the most remote places.  I therefore hope that the European Commission will be able to follow up the development of these systems quickly, through close cooperation between all the parties involved, in particular the world of industry and that of specialised research centres.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The resolution speaks of the need to take action and improve current air navigation systems that do not allow for timely identification and location of aircraft in a state of emergency. This necessity was highlighted by the tragic flights of Malaysia Airlines 370 and Air France 447.  Ads-B satellite technology (automatic dependent surveillance - broadcast) is identified as one of the technologies that can be helpful in tracking flights outside the most densely populated areas, where other types of ground-based aircraft tracking systems operate in a limited way. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has asked the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) to allocate the necessary radio spectrum band. Parliament supports the Commission's efforts to rapidly develop effective global flight tracking systems to determine at any time the location of public transport aircraft, even in remote areas. Parliament also notes that ADS-B satellite technology is one of the promising opportunities for the development of a global air traffic control system. The resolution calls on the Commission to take the necessary steps at the 2015 World Radiocommunicommunications Conference on the allocation of the radio spectrum band necessary for this future satellite global flight tracking system. I therefore supported the resolution.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The tragedies of Air France AF447 and Malasyia Airlines MH370 have highlighted the need to rapidly develop new worldwide flight tracking systems, taking into account the lessons learned by these tragedies. In the future, it is necessary that the systems to be developed are not affected by the loss of electricity on board, cannot be deactivated during flight, and that they finally cover areas where radar coverage is limited (including oceans and uninhabited land areas). In order to avoid interference in flight records, it will be necessary to allocate an appropriate spectrum of radio frequencies to be determined at the World Radio Conference. The rapporteur assessed a number of documents relating to the location and tracking of aircraft, giving its assent to the measures already put in place by the Commission. I voted in favour.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. In transport, safety must be the priority, and I note that gaps are now pre-existing in the field of the traceability of civilian aircraft in the world sky. Just look at the case of flight MH370, which disappeared in March 2014, is still unaccounted for, despite the technologies and the many experts deployed. This situation is not tolerable as difficulties in locating crashed aircraft greatly reduce the chances of finding the victims alive. Today, only 30% of airspace is covered by a flight tracking system.   I therefore voted in favour of a motion for a resolution, following an oral question from the Chairman of the European Parliament's Transport and Tourism Committee on the future development of satellite technology for the implementation of flight tracking systems on a global scale. The ADS-B system in question would increase the safety of global aviation, but would also improve traffic regulation and thus reduce infrastructure costs.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. •u2012 Recent aerial tragedies such as Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 (8 March 2014) or Air France flight AF447 (1 June 2009) have marked the need to seek new air traffic management surveillance systems; these new systems are an important tool to increase the efficiency and capacity of such management through significant improvement of aeronautical safety and reduced infrastructure costs. In this sense, ADS-B technology based on communications between aircraft and satellites seems very promising; this technology helps monitor air traffic management outside the most densely populated areas, where radar coverage is limited, impossible or very expensive (uninhabited oceans and land areas). In order to ensure the development of this technology, timely allocation of an adequate radio spectrum band is of vital importance.  This Resolution calls on the Commission, at the next World Radiocommunication Conference to be held in Geneva in November 2015, to take the necessary measures in relation to the allocation of this radio spectrum band. That is why I supported that resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The tragedies of Air France flight AF447 in June 2009 and Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014 highlighted the need for new systems to locate aircraft at any time. Such surveillance systems for global air traffic management would facilitate the location of an aircraft in the event of abnormal behaviour, emergency or accident. The European Commission, in cooperation with the European Aviation Safety Agency (EEAS) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), has begun to examine the various technical options based on their performance, and has proposed rules on aircraft tracking.  The text of the resolution I voted on today supports the Commission's efforts to rapidly develop a results-based global flight tracking system that allows air navigation service providers to locate aircraft and calls on the Commission to take the necessary action - ahead of the World Radiocommunications Conference , to be held in Geneva in November 2015 - to support the future development of a global satellite flight tracking system.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal because I do not wish to see the Commission getting involved in this area.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I supported the report because numerous studies in the field of aviation indicate system failures and the need for accurate aircraft locating. The tragic stories of Malaysia Airlines and Air France Flight 447 and many other tragedies are widely known. Only 30% of the world's air traffic is covered by current monitoring systems, which makes monitoring and rescue difficult. The satellite technique can enable the air system to better control and better manage air traffic, but also lower costs for infrastructure.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC-15) of the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) will be held in Geneva from 2 to 27 November 2015 to discuss in-flight aircraft monitoring. Following the tragedies of Air France flight AF447 (1 June 2009) and Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 (8 March 2014), it became clear that new systems needed to be introduced to determine the position of passenger jets at all times, even when in remote locations. Therefore, Parliament supports the Commission's commitment to the urgent development of such systems and considers that the development of such a system requires strong cooperation between all stakeholders (e.g. industry, airlines, air navigation service providers, security and rescue services, security investigation authorities and international organisations). I fully support this proposal because it will make air travel even safer.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: writing \u2012 I support the efforts presented to streamline flight recording systems, which can increase the safety and efficiency of air transport.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution which supports the Commission's action aimed at quickly establishing a more powerful system for worldwide flight tracking, which will enable air navigation service providers to locate public transport aircraft at any time. I believe that by developing this system we will promote better cooperation and coordination between all the actors concerned, such as the aviation industry, air carriers, air navigation service providers, security and rescue services or international organisations. Furthermore, it is necessary to ensure interoperability between alternative technologies in order to avoid disruptions to airspace security and to allocate an adequate radio spectrum band in order to avoid any interference, in order to support the future development of a global satellite flight tracking system.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of technology to deal with situations of abnormal behaviour of public transport aircraft can contribute to the timely rescue of human lives in the event of an accident but also prevent criminal acts.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The tragedies of Air France flight AF447 (June 1, 2009) and Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 (March 8, 2014) have highlighted the need for new systems to locate public transport aircraft at any time, even in remote locations. Such surveillance systems in the field of global air traffic management would facilitate the location of an aircraft in the event of abnormal behaviour, emergency or accident.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is more than timely that the EU works on the development of satellite-based flight tracking technology. The disappearance of Air France flight AF447 and Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 proved that the full coverage of airspace by tracking technologies is a matter of safety. Today, only satellite technologies enable such a coverage, even above oceans, but to be fully operable they require a specific spectrum band. The allocation of spectrum bands will be discussed next month during the World Radiocommunication Conference.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - Motions for resolutions - The development of satellite technology to enable global aircraft tracking systems to operate, I supported it, as I believe that in order to avoid the disappearance of aircraft, it is necessary to establish new systems for positioning aircraft for public transport at any time.

It will address the proposal – under study and evaluated favorably by the International Civil Aviation Organization – to assign a specific frequency band in the radio spectrum for global flight monitoring.  Currently only 30% of the world's air navigation consists of a satellite tracking system, which prevents the location or rescue of an aircraft in the event of an accident. Tragedies such as Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 or Air France AF447 show the need for commercial flight tracking systems to be unaffected by a normal on-board power outage and cannot be deactivated from the flight. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution, which urges the European Commission to take the necessary measures for the allocation of the radio spectrum band necessary to support the future development of a global satellite flight monitoring system that meets these characteristics.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The tragedies with Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and Air France Flight 447 highlighted the vulnerabilities of current air navigation systems that prevented the identification and identification of planes in difficulty in time. Currently, flight tracking systems cover only about 30% of the world's airspace.  The ADS-B (automatic dependent-broadcast surveillance) satellite system, according to the International Civil Aviation Organization (CICI), is a technology that could contribute to better air traffic monitoring. This system will help governments, air navigation service providers and airlines in Europe and the rest of the world to increase air traffic efficiency and management capacity. We consider that all steps that can contribute to strengthening passenger safety are positive. We would remind you, however, that this step should always ensure public control of these systems.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The development of a performance-based global flight path tracking system, which enables air navigation services to determine the position of commercial aircraft at any time, is, in my view, welcome, as it is an important approach to air traffic control.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The development of global aviation markets is progressing. This positive development requires technical support. The aviation area is typically a policy area in which joint actions coordinated by the Member States are justified. This includes the development of a performance-based global flight path tracking system that enables air navigation services to determine the location of commercial aircraft at any time, including in remote areas. Satellite-based ADS-B technology, which facilitates the exchange of data between aircraft and satellite, can be a promising option for the development of a global air traffic management monitoring system, in the light of the information available today. I admit that I do not master every technical detail in detail. But I trust the rapporteur of my ECR Group, Jacqueline Foster: before becoming an MEP, she worked as a flight crew member for more than 20 years at British Airways, and she probably knows best of all our MEPs the procedures and safety requirements during a flight. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 After the malaysia airlines plane crash, it was very difficult and tedious to even identify its location. That is why this resolution, which calls for the introduction of global monitoring of aircraft runways over the sea and ocean, is very important and I supported it. It has become clear that our current technologies are inadequate and work is needed to develop them.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the explanations of vote.
